Verse: The Haraam post is the post of an oppressive ruler and the posts of those who are busy in the assignments entrusted by the tyrants. Hence it is Haraam to fulfill the duty of this post. One who takes up this post will become involved in Divine punishment. Whether the job is significant or paltry, any attempt to help the oppressor is a Greater Sin. Because accepting a post from an oppressor will result in the trampling of rights, the manifestation of injustice, the spread of corruption and disturbance, the destruction of heavenly books, the murder of Prophets, the demolishing of mosques and the interpolation of religious laws. Therefore it is Haraam to work with them. Except when there is a condition of utter helplessness, like when it becomes permissible to drink blood and eat the flesh of dead.

Verse: Abdullah ibn-i-Abbas said: "Allah's Prophet rode on a mule that either Qaisar or Kasra had donated to him. He grabbed its hair and helped me ride behind him and said: "Young fellow, remember Allah, so that He protects you. Remember Allah so that you will always see Him. Remember Allah whenever you are about to err so that He helps you during times of hardship. Whenever you want to ask a question, ask it from Allah. Whenever you need help, ask Allah for help. Destiny has already specified what must take place. If people try to help you get what Allah has not destined for you, they will not succeed in doing so. If you can be patient and have certitude, then do so. If not, just be patient, as there is much benefit in being patient regarding what is very difficult for you. Know that victory is associated with patience, and relief is associated with suffering hardships. There always comes relief after suffering hardships."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 5 On Perseverance,Page 68, Hadees 59

Verse: Surely fulfillment of pledge is the twin of truth. I do not know a better shield (against the assaults of sin) than it. One who realises the reality of return (to the next world) never betrays. We are in a period when most of the people regard betrayal as wisdom. In these days the ignorant call it excellence of cunning. What is the matter with them? Allah may destroy them. One who has been through thick and thin of life finds the excuses preventing him from orders and prohibitions of Allah, but he ignores them despite capability (to succumb to them and follows the command of Allah), while one who has no restraints of religion seizes the opportunity (and accepts the excuses for not following the commands of Allah).

Verse: Some of the companions of Imam Sadiq (a.s) have narrated him as saying the following to his children: "O' Children! Please honor what you are entrusted with so that your worldly and heavenly life remains healthy. Be trustworthy and you will need nothing
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 14 On Being Trustworthy, Hadees 252

Verse: In Rauzat al-Vaezeen it is narrated that Imam Zayn al-Abedin (a.s) told his followers: "You ought to return what you are entrusted with to its owner. I swear by Allah who rightly appointed Muhammad to the prophethood that even if the murderer of my father Imam Hussein (a.s) entrusts me with his sword with which he killed my father, I shall return it to him."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 14 On Being Trustworthy, Hadees 253

Verse: "The dearest person near Allah is the one who is honest in his speech; the one who guards (i.e. he performs) his prayers, and does what is incumbent upon him; and the one who returns what he is entrusted with." He then added: "Whoever is entrusted with something and returns what he is entrusted with has indeed opened up one thousand knots of the Fire of Hell from around his own neck. Therefore compete with each other in being trustworthy, and know that Satan will appoint one hundred of his followers to tempt whoever is known to be trustworthy. They will tempt him to violate the trust, and get ruined. Only those protected by Allah the Almighty shall be saved."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 14 On Being Trustworthy, Hadees 254

Verse: "Do not only consider how much a person prays and fasts, how many times he goes on pilgrimage, how many good deeds he has performed and how much he engages in supplications at night. But consider his honesty and trustworthiness."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 14 On Being Trustworthy, Hadees 255

Verse: "There are three acts which we must do no matter what happens: honor whatever we are entrusted with whether it belongs to a good person or a bad one; honor our promises whether they be to a good person or a bad one; and treat our parents with kindness whether they are good or bad."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 14 On Being Trustworthy, Hadees 256

Verse: In Al-Mahasin it is narrated that Hassan al-Baz'zaz narrated that Imam Sadiq (a.s) said "Do you want me to inform you about the hardest duties Allah has made incumbent upon His servants?" He then discussed three duties, the third of which was to always remember Allah, whether we are rushing to obey Him, or we are committing sins."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 15 On Remembrance, Hadees 257

Verse: "Remembering Allah often is one of the most important acts that Allah has made incumbent upon His servants." He then added: "Beware that by this I do not mean just reciting the praises of Allah the Almighty. Rather I mean remembering what Allah has allowed, what He has forbidden, obeying Allah and abandoning sins."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 15 On Remembrance, Hadees 258

Verse: : "There are three groups of people: those who are quiet; those who remember Allah; and those who say things to cause discord among the people."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 15 On Remembrance, Hadees 259

Verse: Unus ibn Abdulrahman narrated that Luqman said to his son "O' my dear son! Be careful when you enter a gathering to sit with those who are remembering Allah. This way your knowledge will increase if you are knowledgeable, and you will become knowledgeable if you are ignorant. There is hope that Allah will spread the shade of His Mercy upon them, and you may benefit from His Mercy, too. But if you see some people who do not remember Allah, do not sit with them since you will not gain any knowledge if you are knowledgeable, and you will be more misguided if you are ignorant, and Allah may encompass them with the shadow of His Chastisement in which case you will be chastised too."

Verse: "There are seven things in the body in charge of remembrance of Allah: the tongue, the soul, the spirit, the intellect, the wisdom, the head, and the heart- either of which needs to persevere. The tongue's perseverance is attained through honesty in uttering words. The soul's perseverance is attained through presence of one's mind. The spirit's perseverance is attained through sincerity in repentance. The heart's perseverance is attained through properly begging for pardon. The intellect's perseverance is attained through properly learning from one's mistakes. The wisdom's perseverance is attained through proper pride, and the head's perseverance is attained through awareness of the secrets of the world. Thus the remembrance of Allah is equal to uttering praises of Allah for the tongue; struggling and hard work for the spirit; fear and hope for the soul; honesty and sincerity for the heart; exaltation and shyness for the intellect; submission and contentment for the wisdom; and witnessing to and approaching Allah for the head."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 15 On Remembrance, Hadees 265

Verse: "All good characteristics are summarized in three acts: looking, silence and talking. Any looking that is without learning is a waste of time. Any silence that is without pondering is due to ignorance. And any talking that is not accompanied by remembrance of Allah is vain talk. Then blessed be those who learn when they look; think when they are silent; remember Allah when they talk; are sorry for their wrong-doings; and the people are safe from their mischief."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 15 On Remembrance, Hadees 266

And also when Abraham said he was ill and would not attend the party, "I am indeed sick (at heart)!" [The Holy Quran: Saffat 37:89], by Allah he was not ill." Translators' note: Yusuf had put the Kings drinking-cup in his brother's saddlebag, as the only possible means of keeping his brother. See verses 55 through the end of chapter Yusuf of the Holy Quran for more details. Also in verses 83 through 96 of the chapter Saffat of the Holy Quran we read that Abraham said he feels sick, and they left him. Verse: In the book Al Kafi there is a tradition, which says that a wife of Imam Sajjad (a.s.) had some connection with the tribe of Bani Hanifa. A Shia of Imam (a.s.) informed him that this wife of his bore enmity to Amirul Momineen (a.s.). After investigating the matter Imam (a.s.) divorced her. She had already received the Meher amount (Dower), but she filed a claim for it against Imam (a.s.) in the court of the ruler of Madinah. She demanded four hundred Dirhams as Meher from him. The ruler of Madinah told Imam Sajjad (a.s.), "Either you swear that you have already paid her or you pay the amount of Meher (now)." Hazrat Syed-e-Sajjad (a.s.) did not swear, but ordered his son Hazrat Muhammad al-Baqir (a.s.) to pay four hundred Dirhams to the woman. Hazrat Baqir (a.s.) said, "May I be sacrificed for you! Verse: Imam Baqir (a.s) narrated upon the authority of Allah's Prophet (a.s): "Allah the Almighty said: I swear by my Honor, Majesty, Greatness, Grandeur, Light, and Highness of Position that none of the servants will choose his desires over Mine, without Me disrupting his affairs, and ruining his life, and getting him involved in it; and not giving anything to him but what I have destined for him. There is no creature that seeks help from Me- not my creatures, without My establishing the Heavens and the Earth as a means of providing for his sustenance. Then Allah's Prophet (a.s) said: "These are wise and knowledgeable people with such a high rank, near that of the Prophets." Verse: "Allah the Almighty sent a Prophet to a nation and asked him to fight with them. The Prophet complained to Allah about being weak. Allah the Almighty said: "Either choose to fight, or go to hell with them." That Prophet (a.s) said: "O' my Lord! I cannot withstand the Fire." Then Allah revealed to him that he would become victorious during that same year. Then that Prophet told his followers that Allah had ordered them to go to war, and he has said they are weak. But Allah has said either to fight or go to Hell. He told his followers to choose between fighting and going to Hell. They said that they could not withstand the Fire. Then he told them that Allah had revealed to him that they would be victorious during that same year. They said they would do whatever he ordered them to do." Then Imam Sadiq (a.s) said: "Allah appointed another Prophet and ordered him to go fight a nation. He complained of his weakness, and Allah the Almighty revealed to him that they would be victorious after fifteen years. When he told his followers about this, they said: "There is no strength nor power but in, or by means of, Allah the High, the Great." He then told them that Allah has revealed to him that they will be victorious after fifteen years. They said: "Whatever Allah decides. There is no strength nor power but in, or by means of, Allah the High, the Great." Since they entrusted their affairs to Allah, Allah made them victorious that same year."

Verse: Imam Reza (a.s) quoted upon the authority of his noble father: "My father, Imam Sadiq (a.s), ordered me to go to Mafzal ibn-i-Amr, and express condolences upon the death of Ismail. He said: "Send my greetings to Mafzal and tell him that we were patient with Ismail, so you should be patient as we were. Indeed whenever we will something and Allah wills otherwise, we submit to Allah's will.Then he added: "Make sure that you are patient in all affairs, since when Allah appointed Muhammad to Prophethood, He ordered him to be patient, and said: "And have patience with what they say, and leave them with noble (dignity). And leave Me (alone to deal with) those in possession of the good things of life who (yet) deny the Truth." [The Holy Quran: Muzzammil 73:10-11] And Allah the Almighty the High said: "Repel (Evil) with what is better: then will he, between whom and thee was hatred become as it were thy friend and intimate! And no one will be granted such goodness except those who exercise patience and self-restraint, none but persons of the greatest good fortune." [The Holy Quran: Ha-Mim 41:34-35]

Verse: In Al-Mahasin it is narrated that Muala ibn Khunays narrated that Imam Sadiq (a.s) told him "O' Muala! Conceal our secrets, and do not divulge them since Allah will honor those who conceal our secrets in this world, and will provide him with a guiding light directing him to Heaven in the Hereafter. O' Muala! Allah will abase whoever divulges our secrets in this world, and will darken his path in the Hereafter leading him to Hell. O' Muala! Concealing faith is a part of my religion, and the religion of my forefathers. Whoever does not practice it, is not religious. Allah likes to be worshipped in secret the same way that He likes to be worshipped publicly. O' Muala! Whoever divulges our secrets is like one who denies them."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 172

Verse: "Whoever divulges our secrets is like one who has deliberately killed us, not by mistake."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 173

Verse: Bashir narrated that Imam Sadiq (a.s) reported on the authority of his father (a.s):  "I swear by Allah that there is nothing on the Earth dearer to me than concealing faith, my darling. Allah will raise the status of whomever practices concealing faith, and Allah will abase whoever does not. O' my darling son! The people are in peace. If the decree to the holy Jihad is issued by the Imam (a.s), then the followers do not have to conceal their faith anymore."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 174

Verse: Regarding Allah's statement: "Twice will they be given their reward, for that they have persevered, that they avert evil with good" [The Holy Quran: Qasas 28:54], Imam Sadiq (a.s) commented: "This means by their perseverance in concealing faith they will receive a double reward. And here good means concealing faith and evil means divulging our secrets."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 175

Verse: Abi Basir said that he once asked Imam Sadiq (a.s) "Why do you not inform us about secrets in the same way that (Imam) Ali (a.s) informed his companions?" Imam Sadiq (a.s) replied: "By Allah you are right. But can you tell me of even one case when I told you a tradition about something and you kept it as a secret?" Then Abi Basir said: "By Allah I cannot even remember one tradition which I kept a secret."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 176

Verse: "Concealing faith is for times when it is necessary to do so, and the person who conceals his faith knows best when to do it."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 177

Verse: "Concealing faith is for protecting lives and preventing bloodshed. There is no reason to conceal faith if there is bloodshed."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 178

Verse: Abi Basir said that once he asked Imam Sadiq (a.s) about traditions. Then Imam Sadiq (a.s) asked him if he had kept any of the ones he had been told a secret so that he could be told new ones. When Imam Sadiq (a.s) noticed that Abi Basir was upset he said: : "Do not worry about the ones that you told your friends. Divulging traditions means telling them to people other than your companions."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 179

Verse: Ibn Miskan said that Imam Sadiq (a.s) told him "I think if someone insults Imam Ali (a.s) in front of you, you will chop off his nose if you can." Ibn Miskan replied: "May I be your devoted servant! Yes, my family and I are all this way." Imam Sadiq (a.s) said: "Do not do this. I swear by Allah that there were many occasions when I heard someone insult Imam Ali (a.s) while there was only a small pillar between the man who insulted Imam Ali (a.s) and me. I hid behind that pillar and when I finished my prayer I walked by, greeted him and shook hands with him."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 181

Verse: Imam Sadiq (a.s) said the following regarding Allah's statement "And slew the Prophets in defiance of right" [The Holy Quran: Al-i-Imran 3:112], "I swear by Allah that they did not kill them with their swords, but caused them to be killed by divulging their secrets."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 182

Verse: In Sifat ul-Shi'ia it is narrated that Imam Sadiq (a.s) said "Whoever does not believe in the practice of concealing faith is not a follower (or Shiite) of Imam Ali (a.s)."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 183

Verse: In Taqieh Lil-Ayashi it is narrated that Imam Sadiq (a.s) said "Whoever does not believe in the practice of concealing faith is not religious. And indeed the practice of concealing faith is more extensive than whatever exists between the Heavens and the Earth."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 184

Verse: "Whoever believes in Allah and the Resurrection Day and lives under an unjust government will only talk in order to conceal his faith."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 185

Verse: Allah admonished a tribe for not concealing faith and said: "When there comes to them some matter touching (public) safety or fear, they divulge it." [The Holy Quran: Nisaa 4:83]
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 186

Verse: There is no good in one who does not believe in the practice of concealing faith. And one who does not practice concealing faith does not have faith
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 187

Verse: One who is not pious is not religious, and one who does not practice concealing faith does not have faith. The dearest one from among you near Allah is the one who practices concealing of faith the most." Then the people asked the Prophet's descendent (a.s): "Until when should we continue to practice concealing of faith?" He replied: "Until a predetermined day, the day on which our Riser will rise. Whoever abandons concealing of faith before that day does not belong to our nation.
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 188

Verse: In Al-Mahasin it is narrated that Imam Sadiq (a.s) said that his father used to always tell him "Nothing is more pleasing for your father than concealing faith. Indeed concealing faith is a believer's armor."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 11 on Concealing Faith, Hadees 189

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 141; Safinatul Bihar

Verse: "When Hazrat Yaqoob (a.s.) went to Egypt to meet his son Hazrat Yusuf (a.s.), he (Yusuf a.s.) did not alight from his horse to pay respect to his father. Hazrat Jibraeel (a.s.) descended, and told Hazrat Yusuf (a.s.) to open his fist. As he did so, a light shot out from his palm and rose towards the sky. Hazrat Yusuf (a.s.) enquired, "What was this light which came out of my hand and shot to the sky?." Jibraeel (a.s.) replied, "The light of Prophethood has departed from your loins. You did not pay due respect to your father hence none of your descendants will get Prophethood." It is true that Hazrat Yusuf (a.s.) did not descend from his horse to pay respect to his father. However, this was not due to any feelings of pride and vanity. The Prophets are sinless and could never harbour such emotions. His intentions were merely to maintain his dignity as a King among his subjects."
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 141

Verse: Those who wish an easy death should do good to the relatives and be kind to parents. When one does this, Allah will make easy the agony of death. In this world he will not face difficulties and poverty

VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1472; Page No. 209&210

Verse: O people! Fear God and be moderate in seeking your sustenance, for no one dies before receiving his sustenance in full, though late. So, fear God and be moderate in seeking your sustenance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1473; Page No. 210

Verse: O people! Fear the Exalted God, for by Him I swear that He will avenge, in the Day of judgment, any believer who oppresses another believer.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1474; Page No. 210

Verse: O people! Verily, I am a human being who will meet the messenger of my Lord in near future and follow his call (i.e. die).I leave with you two grand things: the Book of God and my Household. The former abounds in light and guidance. Whoever grasps at it and discerns it, will be guided aright and whoever falls short in that, will go astray. So, grasp at the Exalted God's Book and (try to) discern it. As to the latter, I remind you of God! I remind you of God!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1475; Page No. 210

Verse: O people! What is narrated to you on my authority is mine if it accords with the Quran, and what is narrated to you on my authority is not mine if it is in discord with it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1476; Page No. 210

Verse: O people! Your Lord is one and your father is one. You are all sons of Adam, and Adam was created from soil. The most pious among you is verily the most worthy of honor to God. No Arab is superior to a Persian, save for virtue.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1477; Page No. 211

Verse: O servants of God! I advise you to prayers, for praying efficaciously affects what has already happened and what has not.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1478; Page No. 211

Verse: O son of Adam! Be obedient to your Lord to be considered wise, and refrain from disobedience to Him, not to be regarded unwise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1479; Page No. 211

Verse: O son of Adam! When you have health of body and peace of mind and your sustenance you easily find, what use of the (material) world to mind!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1480; Page No. 211

Verse: O son of Adam! You have at your disposal what suffices your needs, (but) continuously you seek what to rebellion in you leads! O son of Adam! You're not convinced with less, nor are you satiated with more!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1481; Page No. 211

Verse: O sons of Ishmael! Practice shooting, for your father was an archer.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1482; Page No. 211

Verse: Obedience to a creature is not allowed, if it's disobedience to the Creator.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1483; Page No. 211

Verse: Obedience to fathers is obedience to God, and disobedience to them is disobedience to Him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1484; Page No. 212

Verse: Observe equality in gifting your children. Were I to give priority (on this respect), I would prefer women (i.e. daughters).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1485; Page No. 212

Verse: Observe God's (orders and prohibitions) to see Him ahead of you (as a guide).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1486; Page No. 212

Verse: Observe the rights of your slaves and share them in your own food and clothing. Should they commit sins you do not wish to forgive, sell them to (other) servants of God and stop torturing them thereof.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1487; Page No. 212

Verse: Observing the bonds of kinship leads to abundant wealth, affection among families and the postponement of death.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1488; Page No. 212

Verse: Observing the bonds of kinship prolongs one's life and expels bad deaths.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1489; Page No. 212

Verse: Observing the bonds of kinship, good-temperedness, and good neighborliness make lands flourish and prolong people's lives.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1491; Page No. 212

Verse: Of all people, the poorest (indeed), are holders of greed.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1492; Page No. 213

Verse: If you are praying a mustahab prayer and your father calls you, do not break your prayer but if your mother calls, break the prayer.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 143

Verse: Paradise is at the feet of your mother."
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 143

Verse: And if they contend with you that you should associate with Me what you have no knowledge of, do not obey them, and keep company with them in this world kindly
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 143; Surah Luqman 31:15

Verse: "I shall intercede for four types of people even if they carry the sins of all humanity."
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 178

Verse: On the day of Qiyamat a caller will announce, 'O people, keep silent, because Muhammad (s.a.w.s.) is to say something to you.' Then the Messenger will arise and say, 'O people! If anyone of you has any right or favour upon me, or if there is any obligation upon my neck then he should stand up. I will see that he is compensated.' The people will reply, 'May our parents be sacrificed upon you. What right? What favour? And what obligation? Rather the rights and favours are of Allah and His Prophet upon all the creatures.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 178

Verse: No, they do have a right. Whoever has provided shelter and help to anyone from my Ahlul-Bayt (a.s.) or did good to them or gave them clothes in their need or fed them when they were in need, should stand up so that I can recompense him
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 178

Verse: Verily, God afflicts His faithful servant with a disease to let him find (of all his sins) release.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2448.

Verse: Verily, God bestows the world (on His servants) on account of their want of the next world, but bestows not the next world on account of their want of this world.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2449.

Verse: Verily, God decrees low and high prices.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2450.

Verse: Verily, God detests a woman who falsely attributes a child to a people, and will not let her to Paradise.(In like manner), God keeps distance with a man who denies his relationship with his own child while being worried about him, and will put him to disgrace among the first and the last in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2451.

Verse: Verily, God detests cheeky beggars.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2452.

Verse: Verily, God detests the adulterous old, the cruel rich and the arrogant poor.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2453.

Verse: Verily, God detests those who are expert in worldly affairs but ignorant about otherworldly matters.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2454.

Verse: Mualla Bin-Khanees asked Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq (a.s.): "What are the rights of the believing brother?"
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 179; Al Kafi

Verse: Those who cannot come for our Ziarat must visit our virtuous followers. They shall get the reward of performing our Ziarat. And those who wish to do Sileh Rahmi towards us but are unable to do so must do Sileh Rahmi towards our pious devotees. They shall be given the reward of our Sileh Rahmi.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 180

Verse: As for) those who swallow the property of the orphans unjustly, surely they only swallow fire into their bellies and they shall enter burning fire."
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 181; Surah Nisa 4:10

Verse: And give to the orphans their property, and do not substitute worthless (things) for (their) good (ones) and do not devour their property (as an addition) to your own property; this is surely a great sin.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 181; Surah Nisa 4:2

Verse: And let them fear who, should they leave behind them weakly offsprings, would fear on their account, so let them be careful of (their duty to) Allah, and let them speak right words.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 182; Surah Nisa 4:9

Verse: And whatever affliction befalls you, it is on account of what your hands have wrought, and (yet) He pardons most (of your faults)
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 182; Surah Shuara 42:30

Verse: Verily, friends are holders of the Exalted God's trusts and thus, they are not allowed to reveal each other's secrets.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2445.

Verse: Verily, friendship and enmity are both inheritable.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2446.

Verse: Verily, God addresses the least chastised dweller of Hell, asking: Had you possessed all things on the earth, would you have bargained them with your release? "Yes" she (he) replies. God says, "When you were in the loins of Adam, I asked you to do something easier, i.e. taking nobody as a partner for Me, but you did not act upon it."
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2447.

Verse: Verily, God gives dominance over the son of Adam to the one whom he fears. If he feared no one except God, He would save him from such dominance.(In like manner), God leaves the son of Adam on the one whom he is hopeful about.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2459.

Verse: Verily, God has (special) angels on the earth, who speak as men speak and who report men's good and evil.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2460.

Verse: Verily, God has an (special) angel who calls out at the time of all prayers: "rise up, O sons of Adam! and put out by prayer the fire you have set your souls at.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2461.

Verse: Verily, God has blessed the demand for which a man prays a lot, being it granted or not.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2462.

Verse: Verily, God has created some of His servant for the settlements of people's needs.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2463.

Verse: Verily, God has forbidden repentance for all heretics.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2464.

Verse: Verily, God has forbidden three groups of people to be allowed to Paradise: drunkards, those with whom their parents are dissatisfied, and those who connive at their wives' unfaithfulness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2465.

Verse: Verily, God has forbidden you to engage in idle talks.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2466.

Verse: Verily, God has forgiven for my sake the faults, and oblivion of my people as well as their deeds done out of helplessness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2467.

Verse: Verily, God has not given rise to any disease unless He has first offered its cure, save old age.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2468.

Verse: Verily, God has not given rise to any disease unless He has first offered its cure, (whether or not people know about it) save death.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2469.

Verse: Verily, God has purified this religion (Islam) for Himself. It gets along with nothing but generosity and good-temperedness and thus, you should adorn your religion with these two.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2470.

Verse: Verily, God has sent me revelation on being humble to such an extent that no one (can) pride over another and no one (can) oppress another.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2471.

Verse: Three things enlighten one's eyes: watching green (plants), looking at current water, and catching sight of beautiful faces.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2310.

Verse: Three things follow a dead person, two of which to return and one to stay- family and property return and deeds stay with him/her.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2311.

Verse: Three things I know will definitely come true: the Exalted God will add to the dignity of the one who connives at the oppressions having been brought on him, will expand the poverty of the one who stretches his hand of need towards others out of excessive wishes, and will increase the wealth of the one who gives charity for the sake of God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2312.

Verse: Three things lead to prosperity: controlling one's tongue, shedding tears for one's sins, and being good-tempered at home.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2313.

Verse: Three things make a servant (of God) realize his worldly and otherworldly requests: keeping patient in calamities, being pleased with one's destiny and praying at times of prosperity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2314.

Verse: Three things make of man a perfect being: fearing not the blame of blamers in matters divine, refraining from dissimulation in his actions, and preferring eternal affairs to worldly ones when they co-occur.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2315.

Verse: Three things originate from true faith: generosity in poverty, observance of justice (even if it brings you loss), and sacrifice in teaching for (the sake of) learners.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2316.

Verse: Three things purify your friend's love (for you): honoring him in visits with greetings, finding him a seat in meetings and calling him by his best names.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2317.

Verse: Three things ruin and three things save you. They are respectively as follows: the misery acted upon, the passion being depended on and self-conceit, and fear of God in public and privacy, moderateness in wealth and poverty and justice in anger and pleasure.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2318.

Verse: Three things show one's hypocrisy though one might set prayer, keep fast, and make minor or major pilgrimages to Mecca: telling lie, breaking promises and being treacherous to trusts.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2319.

Verse: Three things will finally come back to their holders (doers): oppression, deceit and breach of promises.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2320.

Verse: Throw dust at the flatterers' face.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2321.

Verse: Thunder is one of the divine angels with mastery over clouds and with fiery scourges to push them wherever God wishes.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2322.

Verse: Times of discomfort here sweeps away times of discomfort in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2323.

Verse: To be a (true) believer, wish for others what you wish for yourself, and to be a (true) Muslim, be kind to your neighbors.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2324.

Verse: To be loved by God, spread the love of Him among people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2325.

Verse: To God, the most favorite food is the one which satiates many (in the neighborhood).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2326.

Verse: To God, the most High, the best hobbies are horsemanship, and archery.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2327.

Verse: To me, the most prosperous person is a believer who has less dependence, availing himself more of prayer, who enjoys sufficient sustenance with which he keeps satisfied till he joins God, who worships his Lord in the best manner and away from people's sight, and who leaves less behind when he dies and less people offer him their cries.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2328.

Verse: To most people, two conditions are the best: health and rest.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2329.

Verse: To rich people pay less frequent visits, for appreciating God's blessings brings you more benefits.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2330.

Verse: Toleration entails abundance and blessing, and those lacking it are devoid of any good. Toleration is the basis of wisdom (indeed).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2332.

Verse: Whoever enjoys moderation enjoys goodness, and whoever is deprived of moderation is bereft of goodness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2954.

Verse: Toleration is auspiciousness, and violation, inauspiciousness, and when God wishes good for the members of a family, He opens on them the gate of toleration, for it leads to adoration in everything it occurs, while violation is the cause of humiliation wherever it befalls.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2333.

Verse: Toleration is the basis of wisdom.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2334.

Verse: Touch the earth, for it is kind to you.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2335.

Verse: Traders await sustenance, and hoarders of foodstuff await (people's) curse.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2336.

Verse: Allah has ordered three things along with three others, in the glorious Quran:

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 162; Behaarul Anwaar

Verse: People resemble their own time the most.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1549; Page No. 221

Verse: I will (command) all the people of my Ummat, whether present or not, and those generations which are to come till the Qiyamat, who are still in the loins of their father and wombs of their mothers, that they should be kind to their relatives (and visit them) even if they live at a distance of a year's journey. Because kindness to relatives is one of the commands which is made an integral part of the faith (Imaan).
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 163

Verse: Whoever extends mercy, even about killing a sparrow, will receive God's Mercy in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2955.

Verse: Imam Muhammad al-Baqir (a.s.) relates from Hazrat Abu Zar Ghaffari (r.a.) who quotes the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) to have remarked:
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 163; Al Kafi

Verse: Hazrat Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq (a.s.) related three traditions from the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) in the court of Mansur Dawaniqi (l.a.).
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 164; Behaarul Anwaar

Verse: Hazrat Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq (a.s.) related three traditions from the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) in the court of Mansur Dawaniqi (l.a.).2) "Fulfilling the rights of kith and kin increases the life-span even if the relative is a sinner."
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 164; Behaarul Anwaar

Verse: Hazrat Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq (a.s.) related three traditions from the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) in the court of Mansur Dawaniqi (l.a.)3) Sileh Rahmi (kindness to relatives) is a cause for the easy accounting of one's deeds on the day of Qiyamat and it (Sileh Rahmi) protects one from sudden death."
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 164

Verse: Sileh Rahmi perfects the morals and encourages charity. When one performs Sileh Rahmi he has to be benevolent towards his relatives. The continuous practice of Sileh Rahmi brings refinement in his morals. In the same way repeated acts of kindness inculcate a benign and compassionate feeling in the person, and the soul is purified (from the sin of jealousy and enmity).
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 165; Safinatun Behaar

Verse: There are two actions, towards which, a step taken is liked by Allah more than anything else. One is the step taken to join a row formed in the name of Allah (for Jehad or Namaz); the second is the one taken to extend a hand of friendship towards kith and kin who want to break relations.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 165; Behaarul Anwaar

Verse: Take refuge in God from disaster, wretchedness, bad destinies and blames of enemies.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1814; Page No. 256

Verse: Certainly there is a section in Paradise which can not be attained except by three kinds of people. First the just Imam, second, the one who does Sileh Rahmi, and third the one who has family (and children) but remains patient (in poverty and diffi culties
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 166; Behaarul Anwaar

Verse: When a person goes towards his relatives so that he can fulfill his rights with his life and his wealth, Allah bestows upon him the reward of a martyr at every step he takes. He (Allah) writes down forty thousand Hasana (the unit of Divine rewards) and He erases forty thousand of his sins and He elevates him by forty thousand grades. The person achieves the position of one who has worshipped Allah for a hundred years
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 166; Behaarul Anwaar

Verse: If the father is virtuous the Almighty Allah protects the children
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 184

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 184; Surah Kahf 18:82

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 184; Behaarul Anwaar

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 184,185; Behaarul Anwaar

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 185

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 185; Wasaelush Shia

VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2087; Page No. 292&293

Verse: The most beloved creatures to God are the unknown pious.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2088; Page No. 293

Verse: The most capital sins on a liar's tongue begin.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2090; Page No. 293

Verse: The most dangerous enemy of yours is your wife who shares your bed, or your maid servant whom you possess.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2091; Page No. 293

Verse: Patience belongs to Heaven, and haste to Satan.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1528; Page No. 218

Verse: Patience belongs to the Heaven, and haste to Satan.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1529; Page No. 218

Verse: Patience is half of faith, and certainty is faith in its entirety.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1530; Page No. 218

Verse: Patience is the cause of contentment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1531; Page No. 218&219

Verse: Patience to faith is like unto brain to body.

What do you think?!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1538; Page No. 219&220

Verse: Peace of mind is gain and missing it is loss.

Verse: People are Adam's sons (anyway), and Adam was made of clay.

Verse: People are all dependents of God, and the most favorite of them to God is the most beneficial to His dependents.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1541; Page No. 220

Verse: People are like unto camels- a hundred of them you see, but not even one among them for a load to carry.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1542; Page No. 220

Verse: People are like unto the teeth of a comb.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1543; Page No. 220

Verse: People are mines, mines of gold and silver.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1544; Page No. 220

Verse: People are mines, with their race (origins) affecting them, and bad training is like unto bad race.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1545; Page No. 220

Verse: People are two groups: teachers and learners, and there is no good in other than these two.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1546; Page No. 220

Verse: People do good deeds, but their reward in the Day of Judgment will be to the extent of their wisdom.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1547; Page No. 220&221

Verse: People perish through the offshoots of their tongues.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1548; Page No. 221

Verse: People who entrust the administration of their affairs to a woman will never be saved(prosperous).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1550; Page No. 221

Verse: People will be resurrected with respect to their intentions in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1551; Page No. 221

Verse: People will face a time when a believer will be meaner than his sheep.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1552; Page No. 221

Verse: It is the right of a neighbor to pay him a visit in sickness, to attend his funeral procession, to lend him money in times of need, to congratulate him in happiness, to console him in sadness and to avoid constructing your building higher than his, lest you should block up the wind blowing to his house.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1094; Page No. 155

Verse: It is undesirable for a ruler to accept gifts, and blasphemous for a judge to do so.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1095; Page No. 155

Verse: It is unlawful for the men of my people, but not for women, to dress themselves in silk and gold.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1096, Page No. 155

Verse: It may happen that a man beseeches the Exalted God to settle his need, but He does not grant his request on account of a reason and thus, he charges people of being unjust to him, saying, "who has taken away my share"?
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1097; Page No. 155

Verse: It may happen that a man is raised in Paradise, and on asking how this happened, he will be told, "Your son has asked forgiveness for you".
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1098; Page No. 155

Verse: It may happen that a man or a woman worships (obeys) God, the Exalted, for sixty years, but at the time of death, (s) he does not act properly concerning his (her) testament and thus, Hell will be indispensable for him (her).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1099; Page No. 155&156

Verse: It may happen that a man performs deeds, which seem heavenly to others, but he is, in fact, a dweller of Hell, and it may happen that a man performs deeds, which seem hellish to others, but he is, in fact, a dweller of Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1100; Page No. 156

Verse: It may happen that a man performs heavenly deeds for a long time but his deeds end up with those of the dwellers of Hell, and it may happen that a man does hellish deeds for a long time but his deeds end up with those of the dwellers of Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1101; Page No. 156

Verse: It may happen that a servant (of God) gives a loaf of bread in charity but it turns out to be great as Mount Uhud to God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1102; Page No. 156

Verse: It may happen that one of you is used to performing heavenly deeds so that there remains only a cubit between him and Paradise, but (suddenly) his fate outruns his deeds and he commits a hellish deed which earns him Hell, and it may happen that one of you is used to performing hellish deeds so that there remains only a cubit between him and Hell, but (suddenly) his fate outruns his deeds and he commits a heavenly deed which earns him Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1103; Page No. 156&157

Verse: It was quite probable that poverty end in blasphemy.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1104; Page No. 157

Verse: It was quite probable that the patient be appointed to prophethood.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1105; Page No. 157

Verse: It will be sufficient for a man if the Exalted God know his dissatisfaction as to what he sees indecent but is unable to change.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1106; Page No. 157

Verse: It would be much better for one to give a penny in health (in the way of God) than to emancipate a salve at the point of death.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1107; Page No. 157

Verse: Jealousy eats away good deeds just as fire eats away firewood, and charity puts out (the flames of) sins just as water puts out fire.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1108; Page No. 158

Verse: Jealousy ruins (one's) faith just as aloe decays honey.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1109; Page No. 158

Verse: Jens will not make idiot those who have horses of noble birth at home.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1110; Page No. 158

Verse: Jesus, son of Mary beheld a man stealing (something)."Did you steal anything"?, he asked him." No, by the God save Him no god exists". The man retorted." I believe in God and my eyes have erred". Jesus asserted.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1111; Page No. 158

Verse: Join the one who has renounced you, do good to the one who has deprived you and forgive the one who has oppressed you.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1112; Page No. 158

Verse: Join the one who has renounced you, do good to the one who has wronged you and tell the truth, though it might be against you.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1113; Page No. 159

Verse: Joining a servant's meal shows one's humility.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1114; Page No. 159

Verse: Joking is not allowed in the following three: divorce, marriage, and emancipation of slaves.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1115, Page No. 159

Verse: Justice is good but it's better with rulers, generosity is good but it's better with the rich, abstinence is good but it's better with the learned, patience is good but it's better with the poor, penitence is good but it's better with the youth, and chastity is good but it's better with women.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1116; Page No. 159

Verse: Keen is the one who rules over his (evil) soul and makes provisions for the Hereafter, and weak is the one who obeys his carnal desires and asks God for (unrealizable) longings.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1117; Page No. 160

Verse: Keep away from the unlawful to be the most (obedient) servant of God, and be convinced with your destined share to be needless of all people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1118, Page No. 160

Verse: Keep away from a leprous as you do from a wild animal. Should (s)he settle somewhere, you do settle somewhere else.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1119, Page No. 160

Verse: Keep away from oppression, for it will bring (you) darkness in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1120, Page No. 160

Verse: Whoever pays a visit to a patient plunges himself into the Mercy of God, and if he sits beside him\her, Mercy will surround him. A perfect visit to a patient is achieved when one of you puts his hand on his\her face or hand and asks him\her how he feels. The perfect way of greeting for you is to shake hands with each other.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3066.

Verse: Whoever performs the following three, a wrongdoer will turn out to be: hoisting the banner of falsehood, subjecting oneself to his (her) parents' curse, and accompanying a tyrant with the intention to assist him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3068.

Verse: Whoever plants a good deed will profit by it, and whoever plants an evil deed will reap it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3069.

Verse: Whoever plants a good deed will profit by it, and whoever plants an evil deed will reap remorse.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3070.

Verse: Whoever plants something on which a bird feeds itself, earns an act of charity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3071.

Verse: Whoever plays a trick on us does not belong to us.Verily, cheating and deceiving lead man to Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3072.

Verse: Whoever plays backgammon is like unto the one who has dipped his hands into a pig's meat and blood.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3073.

Verse: Whoever possesses four things, will enjoy the good of both worlds: a tongue by which to remember God, a heart by which to express gratitude to Him, a body to be tolerant enough against sufferings, and a wife not to be disloyal to one's wealth and chastity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3075.

Verse: Whoever practices the following three, will taste the sweetness of faith: loving God and His prophet more than any other one, loving people just for the sake of God, and detesting blasphemy, after having been saved from it by God, just as one detests falling into fire.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3076.

Verse: Whoever prays much at night, will in the day have a face bright (nice).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3077.

Verse: Whoever prays well in the presence of people but does the reverse in privacy, is actually offending his Lord.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3078.

Verse: Whoever prepares provision in this world, will make use of it in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3079.

Verse: Whoever pronounces judgment without knowledge, is responsible for its subsequent sins, and whoever advises his brother (in faith) to do an action which he knows should not be done, is a traitor to him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3080.

Verse: Whoever purifies (his intent) forty mornings for God's sake, will come up with fountains of wisdom flowing from his heart to his tongue.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3081.

Verse: Whoever refrains from bearing witness when required is like unto the one who gives false testimony.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3082.

Verse: Whoever regards tomorrow a day of his/her life, is not well aware of death.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3083.

Verse: Whoever rejoices at the good or evil deeds of a people is like unto the doers of those deeds.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3084.

Verse: Whoever remains in the sulks with his brother (in faith) more than three days before death, will be put to Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3085.

Verse: Whoever remains in unfriendly terms with his brother (in religion) for one whole year, is like unto the one who may happen to kill him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3086.

Verse: Whoever rules over ten people will be brought to the Day of Judgment in chains to be either freed for justice or demolished for tyranny.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3089.

Verse: Whoever seeks a sort of knowledge and finds it, will be rewarded in double, and whoever seeks a sort of knowledge but fails to find it, will be rewarded in single.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3090.

Verse: Whoever seeks knowledge to vie with the wise, to dispute with the unwise, or to attract laymen's attention, will be put to Hell by God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3091.

Verse: Whoever seeks people's admiration through disobeying God, will end up with his admirers' reproaches.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3092.

Verse: Urwah Ibne-Yazeed asked Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq (a.s.) the meaning of this Ayat (Surah Raad 13:21), the Imam (a.s.) replied;
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 167; Al Kafi

Verse: The kindness towards relative and goodness towards the believing brother makes easy your reckoning on the Day of Judgement and protects you from sins. So you should be kind to your relatives and be good to your believing brothers even if it is as little as a sincere 'salaam' (salutation) or a hearty reply to a salaam
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 167; Al Kafi

Verse: Do Sileh Rahmi towards your relatives and the near ones even if it is just by offering a glass of water to them
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 167; Wasaelush Shia

Verse: Do not break ties with your relatives even if they break them with you.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 170

Verse: Abdullah Ibne Sinan says that I pleaded to Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq (a.s.), "I have a cousin, I do Sileh Rahmi (kindness) towards him and do not wish to break ties with him. But he wants to break ties with me. (Master!) I want to maintain relations but he wishes to sever them. Due to this behaviour of his I am also inclined to cut off ties with him. Can you permit me to do so?"
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 170; Al Kafi

Verse: If any one betrays trust with you, do not betray trust with him or you will also become like him. Similarly, do not break ties with your relatives even if they do so.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 171; Behaarul Anwaar

Verse: The three such qualities are, firstly, to do Sileh Rahmi with one who does Qat-e-Rahmi with you. Secondly, fulfill the needs of one who has deprived you. Thirdly, forgive those who have oppressed you.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 171;

Verse: Punish your servants to the extent of their intellect.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1606; Page No. 228

Verse: Whoever gives his condolences to an afflicted person, will receive the same reward as him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2976.

Verse: Ibne-e-Hamid enquired from Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq (a.s.): "My relatives are not of my religion. Are any of their rights upon me?" Imam (a.s.) gave the following reply:
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 171; Al Kafi

Verse: Dawood Raqqi says: "I was sitting in the company of Imam (a.s.) when Imam (a.s.) himself started speaking and said:
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 172; Behaarul Anwaar

Verse: You will not be helped but for the prayers and patience of your poor ones.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3209.

Verse: Conversation of Imam as-Sadiq (a.s.) With Abdullah Hasani
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 172; Al Kafi

Verse: You shall not find people who believe in Allah and the latter day befriending those who act in opposition to Allah and His apostle, even though they were their (own) fathers, or their sons or their brothers or their kinsfolk
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 174; Surah Mujadila 58:22

Verse: Allah does not forbid you from respecting those who have not made war against you on account of (your) religion, and have not driven you forth from your homes, that you show them kindness and deal with them justly, surely Allah loves the doers of justice. Allah only forbids you from respecting those who made war upon you on account of (your) religion, and drove you forth from your homes and backed up others in your expulsion, that you make friendship with them and whoever makes friends with them, these are the unjust.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 174; Surah Mumtehana 60:8-9

Verse: The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) told Ali (a.s.):
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 175; Behaarul Anwaar

Verse: Amirul Momineen (a.s.) writes a letter to one of his officers,
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 176

Verse: When a group of people falls into evil, they (extravagantly) decorate their mosques.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2780.

Verse: Certainly Allah conferred a benefit upon the believers when he raised among them an apostle from among themselves, reciting to them His communications and purifying them, and teaching them the book and the wisdom, although before that they were surely in manifest error.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 177; Surah Aale Imran 3:164

Verse: Yunus Ibne Abdul Rehman told Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq (a.s.):
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 177

Verse: Certainly the Believers Are Brothers of Each Other.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 177; Surah Hujarat 49:10

Verse: ...Say: I do not ask of you any reward for it but love for my near relatives...."
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 178; Surah Shuara 42:23

Verse: Whoever happens to witness a sin which (s)he detests, will be regarded as absent, and whoever is pleased with a sin committed in his/her absence, will be regarded as a witness to it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2981.

Verse: Whoever has a blessing is subject to jealousy, save humble people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2982.

Verse: Whoever has a debt and intends to repay it, will always be supported by an angel on God's side.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2983.

Verse: Whoever has an excessive greed for people's property, will touch fire, being it a bit or a lot he takes.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2984.

Verse: May God damn the slaves of Dirhams and Dinars.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1283; Page No. 183

Verse: May God shower His mercy on those who oppress their brethren in so far as their respect or wealth are concerned, but happen to meet them with the request of forgiveness err they are called to account, for then if they will possess no Dirham and Dinar (with which to expiate their oppression), their good deeds (if any) will be taken away from them, and the oppressed' evil deeds will be loaded on them if they are devoid of any good deeds.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1296; Page No. 185

Verse: May God shower His mercy on those who utter good words and thereby receive good, or stop uttering bad words and thus ensure their (own) safety.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1297; Page No. 185

Verse: May God shower his Mercy on those who withhold the excess of their words, but spend the excess of their wealth (in the way of God).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1298; Page No. 185

Verse: May God shower His mercy on well-speaking people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1299; Page No. 185

Verse: May the sunrise of a day be not blessed for me when I fail to acquire the knowledge which might draw me nearer to God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1300; Page No. 185

Verse: Measure (your) friend by his friend.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1301; Page No. 185&186

Verse: Mediation between two persons in marital affairs is among the best forms of mediations.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1302; Page No. 186

Verse: Medicines are the Exalted God's destined creatures, and only with His permission they exert their effects.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1303; Page No. 186

Verse: Meditate on anything, save God's nature.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1304; Page No. 186

Verse: Meditate on creatures, but not on the Creator, for you will face failure in understanding His nature.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1305; Page No. 186

Verse: Meditate on God's blessings, but not on His nature.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1306; Page No. 186

Verse: Meditate on God's creatures but not on His nature, for you will perish.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1307; Page No. 186

Verse: Meditate on what you do. Should it end in good, let it continue; but let it cease, if a source of worry it will be to you.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1308; Page No. 186

Verse: Men's hearts naturally like those who do good to them and dislike those who do evil to them.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1309; Page No. 186

Verse: I assure (you) on behalf of God that each time a wise man makes a mistake, he is upgraded by God so that he finally joins Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 957; Page No. 135&136

Verse: I do not like Mount Uhud to turn to gold for me and even one Dinaar of it be left with me more than three days, save for lending.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 958; Page No. 136

Verse: I eat food like slaves and sit on the ground as they do.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 959; Page No. 136

Verse: I give you glad tidings, and you give glad tidings to others, that whoever honestly bears witness to "There is no god but Allah", will undoubtedly be allowed to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 961, Page No. 136

Verse: I looked at Paradise and saw the poor dwelled therein the most, and at Hell wherein women were the majority (to roast).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 964, Page No. 136

Verse: I never buy something before getting aware of its price.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 965; Page No. 137

Verse: I saw a man in Paradise walking around a tree he had cut off in the world, for it blocked people's path and annoyed them.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 966; Page No. 137

Verse: I suffered in the way of God when no one suffered and I was frightened in the way of God when no one feared at all. Many a day and many a night I spent when Baal and me had nothing to eat.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 967, Page No. 137

Verse: I swear by God that leading one to the right path is much better than having red-haired camels.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 968, Page No. 137

Verse: I swear by God that this world to the Hereafter is just as one of you puts his finger into a sea, and see what happens! (Nothing he gains).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 969; Page No. 137

Verse: I swear by God that you will not find anyone juster to you than me after my death.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 970; Page No. 137

Verse: I was appointed to treat people moderately.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 971; Page No. 137

Verse: I was appointed with a pure, easy religion and, therefore, whoever opposes my manners is not my follower.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 972; Page No. 137

Verse: I was given the option to either choose intercession or to take half of my nation to Paradise (without final judgment), and I chose the former for it is more extended and sufficient in range. Do you think that intercession is specifically applied for pious believers? No, it is for the sinful wrong doers.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 973; Page No. 138

Verse: I was offered short, but comprehensive words.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 974; Page No. 138

Verse: I was so much advised to brush my teeth that I got scared lest it might become obligatory for me.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 975; Page No. 138

Verse: I was so much advised to brush my teeth that I got scared of putting them to harm.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 976; Page No. 138

Verse: I will inform you of what authority is, if you ask me to do so. It begins with blame, leads to remorse and ends up with the torment of the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 977, Page No. 138

Verse: I will undertake to reserve Paradise for whoever undertakes to put no demand to people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 978; Page No. 138

Verse: I wonder at a Muslim who keeps patient when calamity befalls him and thanks and praises God when he attains some good.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 979; Page No. 138

Verse: If a believer manages to hide himself in a hole, someone will be sent by God to hurt him(put him to trial).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 980; Page No. 138&139

Verse: If a drop of hellish Zaghoom drips to the world, it will ruin the life of the people.So, what would happen to the ones whose otherworldly food is Zaghoom.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 981; Page No. 139

Verse: If a relative is in need, giving alms(to others) will not be fair.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 982; Page No. 139

Verse: If a woman perfumes herself and passes by people to please them, she will be adulterous.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 983, Page No. 139

Verse: If animals were aware of what men know about death, they would avoid weight-growing meat.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 984; Page No. 139

Verse: When two Muslims draw sword against one another, and one manages to kill the other, both will be put to Hell. The people asked, "O Messenger of God! the case is clear as to the killer, but why is the killed treated as such?" The Holy Prophet replied: "He too sought to kill the other party."
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2850.

Verse: When two persons insult each other, the one who has begun (the game) is sinful, provided that the oppressed does not exceed his limits.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2851.

Verse: When two persons invite you simultaneously, accept the invitation of the one whose house is closer to yours, thus being your closer neighbor than the other, but if one of these two neighbors invites you sooner, accept his invitation (first).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2852.

Verse: When two persons whisper to each other, do not approach them
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2853.

Verse: When usury and adultery spread out in a place, the residents of that place are (actually) bartering their doings for God's punishment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2854.

Verse: When you are deep in religion, the most good-natured of you are the best in Islam.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2855.

Verse: When you are told a mountain has left its place, believe in it; but when you hear someone has left his manners, believe it not; for man will finally return to his own nature.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2856.

Verse: When you brush your teeth, move the brush horizontally.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2857.

Verse: When you come across something you can not change, be patient and leave it to God for so doing.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2858.

Verse: When you conquered your enemy, forgive him out of thanksgiving for your power.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2859.

Verse: When you decide to do something, ask for God's grace seven times, and then see what you are inclined to, for your good lies surely in that.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2860.

Verse: When you decide to do something, meditate on its results. If it entails good results, perform it; otherwise, forget about it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2861.

Verse: When you face those overtaken by calamities, ask God (to grant you) health.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2862.

Verse: When you love one of your brethren, show your love to him, for this will strengthen your friendship and make it last longer.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2863.

Verse: When you make a request to your brother (in faith), do not start with extolling him, for it puts a pressure on his back.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2864.

Verse: When you make friend with someone, try not dispute with him, nor to seek superiority over him, nor to inquire about him, for it may come to pass that you come across one of his foes who might cause discord between you by speaking ill of him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2865.

Verse: When you see breach of promise and weakness of trusteeship prevalent among people, (the Holy Prophet said with enveloped fingers), run a solitary life at home, control your tongue' practice what you know, leave aside what you know not, manage your personal affairs and keep away from people's business.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2866.

Verse: When you see God has subjected one of His servants to poverty and disease, know that He intends to purify him (of his sins).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2867.

Verse: When you see someone who is superior to you in beauty and wealth, think of someone who is inferior to you in these respects.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2868.

Verse: When you want to know about one's status to God, heed to what is said of him in his absence.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2869.

Verse: When your rulers are the benevolent, your rich men are the most generous and your affairs consulted among you, the back of the earth would better suit you than its depth, and when your rulers are the most wicked, your rich men are the most miserly and your affairs controlled by women, the depth of the earth would better suit you than its back.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2870.

Verse: When your servant serves you a meal which he has prepared with lots of troubles, share the meal with him, or (at least) ask him to have a morsel or two.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2871.

Verse: Whenever a human being or one of God's creatures eats the fruits of a tree, a good reward is recorded for the one who has planted the tree.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2872.

Verse: Whenever Gabriel came to me urged me to brush my teeth, to the extent that I got worried of wearing away my gum.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2873.

Verse: Whenever the Sun rises, two angels call out from its two sides, "O Lord! Reward the generous and ruin the stingy as soon as possible."

Verse: While weakness befalls an old man's body, his heart grows younger (eager) towards the love of long life and abundant wealth.

Verse: Who commits adultery will be afflicted with adultery.

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, Part 1, Tradition 7, page 14; Odatool-Daee page 236

Verse: Hazrat Musa (a.s.) passed by a person from his followers who was in prostration. After completing his chore Musa (a.s.) returned to find him still in prostration. He said, "If I had the power to grant your wish I would surely have granted it." Allah revealed to Musa (a.s.) that, "Even if this man prostrates for Me till his head gets detached from his neck, I will not accept his deeds, till he abstains from that which I dislike and does that which pleases Me. Otherwise sin hinders the supplications from acceptance."
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, Part 1, Tradition 10, page 15; Odatool-Daee page 125

Verse: "Abstaining from sins is the basis of religion. Hence, refrain from sins in order to become the most pious worshipper. Adorn yourself with piety. Do not perform a single good deed without piety. Surely that deed is most acceptable by Allah which is accompanied by piety, even though it may be trifle. As Allah says, "Allah accepts the good deeds only from the pious people."
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, Part 1, Tradition 11, page 15; Odatool-Daee

(Surah Furqan 25:23) He said, "By Allah, even if their deeds are as white as Egyptian cotton, but if they find sin and lewdness they do not abstain from it."

Verse: Whoever feels self-conceit and walks arrogantly will meet the Exalted God's anger.

Verse: "Allah revealed to Hazrat Musa (a.s.), "Verily, My slave cannot achieve nearness to Me without the three things which I like." Musa (a.s.) asked with reverance, "My Lord what are those three things?" Allah replied, "O! Musa those three things are: To practice piety in this world, to abstain from sins and to weep due to fear." Musa (a.s.) asked, "Does one who fulfills the three things gets compensation and reward?" Allah replied, "One who practices piety in this world will get Paradise. One who weeps due to My fear will be accorded such a high position that no else would be able to reach it. The deeds of all the creatures shall be accounted. But one who abstains from that which I have forbidden, then accounting of his deeds will not be carried out; he would be admitted to Heaven directly.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, Part 1, page 16,17

Verse: If one avoids the Greater Sins, the Lesser sins shall be overlooked. Allah, the Almighty, by His grace, excuses the Lesser sins. As it is mentioned in the following verse of the Holy Qur'an

Verse: Imam Muhammad Taqi (a.s.) has related from his forefathers that Amirul Momineen Ali (a.s.) was queried by someone about death. He replied, "You have come to the knowledgeable (personality)." "Death occurs to a person in one of the three ways: He is given the good news of everlasting bounties, or informed of the never-ending retribution or he remains in a perpetual state of terror and fear. His affair remains undecided and unpredictable, and it is not known about the kind of future that awaits him. Then (you must know) that our devotee who is obedient of our command and does not sin, is given the good news of everlasting bounties. But our opponent shall forever be involved in Divine punishment. And the person who has been unjust to his soul and who has abused it will be found in an unsure condition. Unaware of what the future will hold. Such a person is a sinner whose death will be accompanied with terror and fear. But Allah will not consider him on the same level as our enemy. Rather he would be removed from Hell because of our intercession. Then, act (rightly) and obey the commandments of Allah. Do not consider the Divine punishment to be trifle, and certainly there are such people who would not be able to receive our intercession till after 3,00,000 years."
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, Part 2, page 20; Behaarul Anwaar vol.3 quoted from Ma'aniul Akhbaar

Verse: "There is no man who does not have a white spot in his heart. When he commits a sin a black spot emerges from this spot. When the white spot is totally covered by the blackness, the owner of this heart will never revert towards goodness. This tradition is in consonance with the utterance of Allah:

Verse: "One day when the Prophet (a.s) went to the mosque with his companions, he prostrated for so long that they suspected his health was endangered. When he finally sat up they told him that he had prostrated for such a long time that they suspected he had died. He said: "Gabriel descended to me from near Allah the Almighty and said: O' Muhammad! Your Lord sends His greetings and says: "I have never hurt your feelings concerning anyone of your nation who loves you. I have not done anything for a believer to please him or hurt him unless it was good for him."" The Prophet (a.s) added: "At that time I had no property to give away in charity, and no slave to free, so I fell prostrate in worship and thanked Allah and praised Him for this."

He said: "I remembered a blessing that Allah gave me, and I felt I would like to give thanks to my Lord."

Verse: Mu'amir ibn Khal'lad narrate "Fear Allah, and be humble; grateful and give thanks to Him. There was a man among the Israelite tribe who had a dream one night. In his dream a man told him that he would only live half of his life in comfort, and asked him which half he preferred. He told the man that he had a partner. When he woke up the next morning, he told his wife about his dream. She told him to choose the first half, and he accepted. Then they got wealthy receiving constant blessings. His wife kept informing him about needy neighbors and relatives, and he would help them. They continued donating whatever they received, and giving thanks to Allah. One night the man had another dream and saw the same man. He told him that half of his life was now over, and asked his opinion. Again he told the man that he had a partner. When he woke up the next morning he told everything he saw in his dream to his wife. She said: "Allah gave us blessings, and we gave thanks, and Allah is most faithful." Then that man appeared in his dream again and said: "Now you will live in comfort all your life."
