Verse: This is recorded in the Holy Quran and the tradition of Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq (a.s.) as related by Amash and the tradition of Imam Reza (a.s.) as reported by Fazl Ibne Shazaan. Imam (a.s.) says: "Decreasing (fraudulently) in measure and weight." (is also a Greater Sin). It is haraam for a seller to give less than the specified quantity or for the debtor to repay less than what is specified.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twenty-Fourth Greater Sin ,page 145

Verse: Woe to the defrauders. Who, when they take the measure (of their dues) from men, take it fully, but when they measure out to others or weigh out for them, they are deficient. Do not think that they shall be raised again, for a mighty day, The day on which men shall stand before the Lord of the worlds?
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twenty-Fourth Greater Sin ,page 145; Surah Mutaffefeen 83:1-6

Verse: "Nay! Most surely the record of the wicked is in the sijjin. And what will make you know what the sijjin is? It is a written book." Sijjin is either the name of that register which contains the account of deeds of disbelievers and transgressors. Or it is a special corner of Hell where the disbelievers and sinners will be consigned. Hence the translation of the ayats will be as follows:
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twenty-Fourth Greater Sin ,page 145; Surah Mutaffefeen 83:7-9

Verse: Hazrat Shoeb (a.s.) was preaching to his people:
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twenty-Fourth Greater Sin ,page 146; Surah Hud 11: 84-85

Verse: The following tradition has been recorded from the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) in the book Tafseer Minhajus Saadeqeen According to this tradition there are five types of sins which bring about five types of calamities.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twenty-Fourth Greater Sin ,page 147; Tafseer Minhajus Saadeqeen

Verse: O people! Fear Allah! Weigh and measure with justice. Do not cheat people (by giving less) and do not spread corruption in the earth
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twenty-Fourth Greater Sin ,page 147

Verse: One day Ali (a.s.) saw a saffron seller short-weighing. He had applied oil to his hand and very cunningly he applied it to the pan of the balance which held the saffron. Ali (a.s.) picked up the saffron from the balance and said,
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twenty-Fourth Greater Sin ,page 147

Verse: One who does Khayanat in weighing and measuring is thrown into the lowest section of Hell. There he shall be placed between two mountains of fire. He will be told to weigh those mountains. He will be busy in this forever
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twenty-Fourth Greater Sin ,page 147

Verse: Shaykh Sadooq has recorded the prophetic tradition:
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twenty-Fourth Greater Sin ,page 149; Iqaabul Aamaal

Verse: "One day the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) was passing through the bazaar of Madinah. He (s.a.w.s.) told a wheat seller, 'Your wheat is of a good quality.' Then he put his hands inside the pile and found inferior quality of wheat below He said, 'I see that you have gathered the provisions of Khayanat and adulteration.'"
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twenty-Fourth Greater Sin ,page 150; Iqaabul Aamaal

Verse: Allamah Hilli says that a man asked Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq (a.s.), "If a person has two types of goods one is of a superior and expensive quality and the other is of inferior and cheap quality, can he mix these two and sell at a special rate?"
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twenty-Fourth Greater Sin ,page 150; Iqaabul Aamaal

Verse: Dawood Ibne Sujaan asked Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq (a.s.): "I had two varieties of musk. One was wet, the other dry. I sold the wet and fresh musk but no one was prepared to buy the dry one at the same rate. Is it permitted for me to make it wet so that it is sold out?" Imam (a.s.) told him,
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twenty-Fourth Greater Sin ,page 150

Verse: The dead suffers in the grave from the groans and shouts of others on his death.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1958; Page No. 273

Verse: The deeds of three groups will not be recorded: the insane who lack control on their intellect till they recover, sleepers as long as they are asleep, and children till they reach maturity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1959; Page No. 273

Verse: The disgrace of this world is more tolerable than that of the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1960; Page No. 274

Verse: The divine Mercy is of one hundred parts, one of which He has showered on people, and the rest He has saved for the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1961; Page No. 274

Verse: The doer of good is better than good, and the doer of evil worse than evil.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1962; Page No. 274

Verse: The doers of the following five will suffer immediate heavenly punishment: oppression, breach of promise, mistreatment of parents, disconnection of bonds of kinship and ungratefulness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1963; Page No. 274

Verse: The doors of heavens open at the time of prayers as well as the time of preparation fight in way of God, and at these two times the supplications of those who pray are less likely to be rejected.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1964; Page No. 274

Verse: The doors of heavens open on four occasions, and prayers are granted: when warriors in the way of God join hands, when it rains, at times of prayer, and on visiting Kasbah.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1965; Page No. 274

Verse: The doors of heavens open on Mondays and Thursdays and all servants of God are forgiven, save those who are hostile to their brethren.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1966; Page No. 275

Verse: The double-faced and the double-tongued are both damned.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1967; Page No. 275

Verse: The double-faced in the world will suffer double-flamed fire in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1968; Page No. 275

Verse: The double-faced will not enjoy respect.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1969; Page No. 275

Verse: The earth is God's and the people are His servants. So, settle in the land where good you find.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1970; Page No. 275

Verse: The earth is God's earth, and the people are God's servants. Whoever enlivens (cultivates) a dead (barren) piece of the earth will be its owner.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1971; Page No. 275

Verse: The earth will be filled with inequity. Then, a man will rise from my household to fill it with equity just as it was filled with injustice and enormity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1972; Page No. 275

Verse: The earth will be filled with inequity. Then, God will appoint a man to fill it with equity just as it was filled with injustice and enormity- a man whose name and whose father's are respectively mine and my father's.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1973; Page No. 275&276

Verse: The easiest pressures of death are like unto a hundred strokes of sword.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1974; Page No. 276

Verse: The Exalted God has appointed no prophet with a language other than that of his people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1975; Page No. 276

Verse: The Exalted God has created three classes of jinn. Snakes, scorpions and insects comprise the first class. The second class is like unto wind in the air, and the third are those who will suffer reckoning and retribution. He has also created three classes of human being. The first class are like unto beasts of burden. The second class has human bodies but devilish spirits, and the third will enjoy the shade (patronage) of God the day when no shade but His exists.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1976; Page No. 276

Verse: The Exalted God has prescribed His creatures' fate fifty thousand years prior to the creation of heavens and the earth, when His Throne was on water.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1977; Page No. 276

Verse: Praying for oneself is the best (kind of) praying.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1591; Page No. 225

Verse: The Exalted God postpones to the Day of Judgment the punishment of the sins He wishes, saves the sin of displeasing one's parents, which He hastens to recompense in this very world before the sinner's death.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1978; Page No. 276

Verse: The Exalted God says: By my Glory and Honor I swear that I do not grant a servant two states of security together with two states of fear, i.e. if he feels secure from Me in this world, I will frighten him in the Resurrection and if he is afraid of Me in this world, I will secure him in the Resurrection.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1979; Page No. 277

Verse: The Exalted God says: Grandeur is My prerogative and I will demolish anybody who tries to claim it as his own.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1980; Page No. 277

Verse: The Exalted God says: I am a company to My servant's thinking about Me- being it good, I will benefit him and being it bad, I will bring him loss.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1981; Page No. 277

Verse: The Exalted God says: I am the most needless of all partners when people take partners with Me, and so when someone takes a partner with Me in an act of worship, I leave him on his own with his polytheism.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1982; Page No. 277

Verse: The Exalted God says: I will be cross at anybody who does not pray to Me.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1983; Page No. 277

Verse: The Exalted God says: I will forgive the one who believes in My power of forgiving sins, and nothing matters so long as (s)he takes nothing as a partner with Me.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1984; Page No. 277

Verse: Refrain from liars, for they are mirage in resemblance, drawing near you what's far in distance and brining what is remote to your presence.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1634; Page No. 232

Verse: Refrain from lust, for it makes man blind and deaf.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1635; Page No. 232

Verse: Refrain from minor sins, for God will call you to account for them.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1636; Page No. 232

Verse: Refrain from minor sins, for they are like unto a group of people landing in valley, each gathering little pieces of wood which might finally make a huge heap for baking bread. Minor sins, too, will (finally) be so great to cause one's ruin when s(he) is called to account.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1637; Page No. 232

Verse: Refrain from misery, for it led to the ruin of predecessors and caused them to shed the blood of one another and to consider the unlawful as lawful.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1638; Page No. 232

Verse: Refrain from obstinacy, for it begins with ignorance and ends in repentance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1639; Page No. 232

Verse: Refrain from polytheism and telling lie.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1640; Page No. 233

Verse: Refrain from red color, for it is the most favorite ornament to Satan.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1641; Page No. 233

Verse: Refrain from slackness, for you live for today, not for tomorrow. Should there be a tomorrow, pass it as you do today, and should there be no tomorrow, you will not regret today's slackness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1642; Page No. 233

Verse: Refrain from vanity, for it induced Satan to avoid prostrating to Adam. Refrain from greed, for it made Adam eat the fruit of the (forbidden) tree. Refrain from jealousy, for it caused Cain to kill Abel. Verily, these are the origins of all vices.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1651; Page No. 234

Verse: Refrain from whatever makes you drunk.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1652; Page No. 234

Verse: Refrain from whatever sounds bad for (your) ears.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1653; Page No. 234

Verse: Refrain from whatever you have to pardon for
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1654; Page No. 235

Verse: Refrain from wine, for its sin gives birth to (other) sins, just as its tree gives birth to new vines.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1655; Page No. 235

Verse: Release Muslims, from their trouble and let Your good deeds increase.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1656; Page No. 235

Verse: Reliance on man in worldly and otherworldly affairs suffices to show his prosperity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1657; Page No. 235

Verse: Religion (faith) starts with abstinence.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1658; Page No. 235

Verse: Religion is not strengthened, save with manliness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1659; Page No. 235

Verse: Religious zeal originates from faith, and debauchery from hypocrisy.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1660; Page No. 235

Verse: What a strange status has a believer! I strongly swear by God that He does not decree for a believer a non-beneficial destiny.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2769.

Verse: What do I have to do with the world? To it, am I like unto a traveler who rests a while under the shade of a tree but leaves it (finally).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2770.

Verse: Verily, this (worldly) fire of yours is one of the seventy flames of the Fire of Hell which could not have been beneficial to you, had it not been extinguished twice with water. Verily, the worldly fire calls unto God to return it not to Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2717.

Verse: Verily, this religion is firmly-based, wherein you should proceed without haste in order not to make the worship of God an object of hate, for an impatient wayfarer (can) neither hike a lot (in fact), nor can he keep his horse intact.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2718.

Verse: Verily, those who engage in idle (false) talks the most will have the heaviest sins in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2719.

Verse: Verily, those who love for God's sake will rest under the shade of the (Divine) Throne.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2720.

Verse: Verily, three times God rejected my request, concerning (the forgiveness of) the killer of a believer.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2721.

Verse: Verily, through good-temperedness, servants (of God) can attain the status of fast persons who stand to prayer at nights.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2722.

Verse: The remembrance of Allah is a healing for the hearts.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 1751; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 777

Verse: Search for knowledge even (if it is to be acquired) in China, for seeking knowledge is a precept for all Muslims, and angels spread their wings for the seekers of knowledge (to sit on) and derive pleasure from what they search for.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1704; Page No. 240&241

Verse: Search for lore from the birth shore to the grave door.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1705; Page No. 241

Verse: Secure your properties by giving alms, cure your patients through charity, and resort to praying to guard yourself against calamity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1706; Page No. 241

Verse: Security and health are two divine blessings most people lose.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1707; Page No. 241

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God has not appointed me to be fault-finding and trouble making but to be an easy-going teacher.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2612.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God has prescribed efforts for you. Make efforts, therefore.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2613.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God has prescribed for sons of Adam a share in adultery, which they commit willy nilly. The eye's adultery is an unlawful look and the tongue's, an illogical utterance. The (evil) soul requests (something) and invokes (man to answer it), and his private parts either put it into effect or not.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2614.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God has prescribed for women bearing rival wives, and for men struggling in the way of Him. So, any woman who, due to her faith in God, keeps patient in awaiting His reward for this suffering, will be rewarded as a martyr.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2615.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God has prescribed goodness, evil and whatever is there between them (for people).Thus, He will record a perfect reward for whoever intends to do good but falls short in doing that, and He will record for him ten to seven hundred (or more) rewards, if he puts it into effect. Also God will record a perfect reward for whoever intends to do evil but stops doing that, and He will record only one sin for him, if he puts it into effect. As such, whoever brings himself ruin, deserves it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2616.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God has special groups of people on whom He bestows His blessings to offer to His servants. He keeps His blessings with them as long as they practice generosity, but as soon as they turn out to be stingy, He withholds His blessings from them and shower them on others.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2617.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God hates men and women who marry a lot.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2618.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God hates scurrilous, foul-mouthed people as well as those who raise their voices in bazaars.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2619.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God hates the cruel rich, the arrogant poor and the ignorant aged.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2620.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God heeds not your wealth and appearance, but your hearts and deeds, He attends.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2621.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God informed the strugglers in (the Battle) of Badr, saying: "Do whatever you wish, for I surely forgive you".
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2622.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God is chaste, loves glossing faults and loves secrecy. So, cover yourselves when you perform ceremonial washing.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2625.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God is conscious of the tongues of all who talk. Thus, (God's) servants should be virtuous and careful about what they say.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2626.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God is Forgiver and loves forgiveness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2627.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God is Fragrant and loves fragrance, is Clean and loves cleanliness, is Generous and loves generosity, and is Magnanimous and loves magnanimity. So, clean outside of your houses and be not like unto Jews.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2628.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God is Magnanimous and loves magnanimity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2629.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God is Moderate, loves moderateness, and through it He bestows (on people) things which he does not do through violence.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2630.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God is pleased with ease, not hardship, for this Islamic nation.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2631.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God is the most beautiful and loves beauty, is the most generous and loves generosity, and is the cleanest and loves cleanliness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2632.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God is the most generous and loves the generous. He loves high moral values and hates low morality.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2633.

Verse: Know for sure that Satan is the third party to the illegitimate privacy of a man and a woman.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1148, Page No. 163&164

Verse: Know for sure that sons of Adam have been created into different classes: some are born believers, living and dying as believers; some are born disbelievers, living and dying as disbelievers; and some are born disbelievers, living as disbelievers but dying as believers.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1149; Page No. 164

Verse: Know people by knowing their friends, for men love the like of themselves.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1150; Page No. 164

Verse: Know that in man's body there is a lump of flesh which corrupts or rectifies the whole body, being it corrupt or rectified respectively. That is man's heart.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1151; Page No. 164

Verse: Know that the best businessman is the one who is good both in paying debts and demanding credits, and the worst is the one who is bad in both. If a man is good in the former but bad in the latter or vice versa, that is something in its own right.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1152; Page No. 164

Verse: Know that the best of men is the one who becomes enraged hardly and gets pleased easily, and the worst of them is the one who gets pleased hardly and become enraged easily. If a man hardly becomes enraged and hardly gets pleased or easily becomes enraged and easily gets pleased, that is something in its own right.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1153; Page No. 164&165

Verse: Knowing your faults should stop you recounting people's faults. Control your tongue, save for well- wishing, for this can make you defeat Satan.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1154, Page No. 165

Verse: Knowledge and the learned dwell in Paradise and thus, if the learned do not act upon their knowledge, action and knowledge will in Paradise dwell, and the learned in Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1155; Page No. 165

Verse: Knowledge and wealth keep all faults covert, but ignorance and poverty make them overt.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1156; Page No. 165

Verse: Knowledge id better than deed, and the best of all deeds is a moderate one.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1157; Page No. 165

Verse: Knowledge is a believer's friend, fortitude being his minister, intellect being his guide, action being his leader, moderateness being his father, kindness being his brother, and patience being the commander of his army.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1158; Page No. 165

Verse: Knowledge is a believer's lost one. Whenever (s)he learns a bit of it, (s)he demands another.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1159; Page No. 165

Verse: Knowledge is acquired through learning and forbearance is achieved through practicing it. Whoever seeks good will be offered good and whoever fears evil will be saved from it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1160; Page No. 166

Verse: Knowledge is of three kinds: a manifest book, a practiced tradition and "I don't know".
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1161; Page No. 166

Verse: Knowledge is of two kinds: the one lying in man's heart, i.e. beneficial knowledge, and the one being on (the tip of) one's tongue and, thus, being God's proof for Adam's sons.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1162; Page No. 166

Verse: Knowledge is superior to deed, religion is founded on abstinence, and a (true) scholar is he who practices what he knows.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1163; Page No. 166

Verse: Knowledge is superior to worship, and abstinence is the basis of religion.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1164; Page No. 166

Verse: Knowledge is the heritage of me and my predecessors(in prophethood).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1165; Page No. 166

Verse: Knowledge is the spirit of Islam and the pillar of faith, and God will give perfect reward to s(he) who acquires some sort of knowledge, and if s(he) happens to practice it, He will let him\her know what s(he)knows not.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1166; Page No. 166

Verse: Knowledge is treasures, and the key to them is asking. So, question to gain God's Mercy, for God rewards four groups in so far as knowledge is concerned: seekers of knowledge, teachers, listeners, and those who love the first three groups.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1167; Page No. 167

Verse: Knowledge should not be stopped (being learned or taught).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1168; Page No. 167

Verse: Knowledge without use is like unto a treasure untouched.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1169; Page No. 167

Verse: Knowledge without use is like unto untouched treasure. For everything there is a poor-rate, and for the body, fasting.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1170; Page No. 167

Verse: Lambs are blessings (of God).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1171; Page No. 168

Verse: No trustworthiness, and no companionship.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1400; Page No. 198

Verse: Laughing is of two kinds-that which God likes, i.e. a man's smiling at his brother's face out of pleasure to see him, and that which the Exalted God dislikes, i.e. a man's saying something false or unjust to laugh or make people laugh and thus, falling to Hell for seventy autumns.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1172; Page No. 168

Verse: Learn shooting and horsemanship, but I love you shoot more than ride on horseback. Whatever makes you busy is idle, save shooting an arrow, training your horse or playing with your wives. All these are among your rights, and whoever abandons shooting after having learned it, is guilty of ingratitude to his teacher.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1173; Page No. 168

Verse: Learn whatever you like, for God will not let you avail yourself of your knowledge unless you put it to practice.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1174; Page No. 168&169

Verse: My eyes fall asleep, but my heart doesn't.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1337; Page No. 190

Verse: My God damn (curse) the one who curses his/her parents.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1338; Page No. 190

Verse: My intercession belongs to the noblemen of my people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1339; Page No. 190

Verse: My nation will experience a time with the largest number of the poor and the least number of the learned (in religious jurisprudence), when knowledge decreases and sedition increases. Then they will see a time when some men of my nation recite the Quran, but it will not rise beyond their very throats (i.e. it will not affect their minds). They will still see a time when polytheists argue with the believers, using the same words (and reasoning) as they do.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1340; Page No. 190

Verse: My people are like unto rain whose beginning and ending benefits nobody can explain (foresee).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1341; Page No. 191

Verse: My people will not be called to account for mistake, oblivion and helplessness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1342; Page No. 191

Verse: Narrating whatever you have heard suffices to show your mendacity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1343; Page No. 192

Verse: Needlessness does not in abundance lie; on needless souls does it rely.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1344; Page No. 192

Verse: Needlessness lies in being hopeless of what people possess, and whoever walks in the way of greed, should slow his/her speed.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1345; Page No. 192

Verse: Neighborhood extends to forty houses.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1346; Page No. 192

Verse: Neighbors have priority (to others) in buying their neighbors' houses.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1347; Page No. 192

Verse: Never leave your job for tomorrow, for each day has it's own share.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1348; Page No. 192

Verse: Never long for death.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1349; Page No. 192

Verse: Never will God put to Fire the flesh of a servant to whom He has given good countenance and character.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1350; Page No. 192&193

Verse: New dresses wear, and good fame (try to) bear.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1351; Page No. 193

Verse: No expiation can make up for the following five sins, and faithless is the one who lacks any single one of them: surrendering to the will of God, being pleased with His decrees, leaving one's affairs to Him, relying on Him, and keeping patient when one first faces a disaster.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1362; Page No. 194

Verse: No good can you find in the company of the one who does not count himself equal to you.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1363; Page No. 194

Verse: Allah the Almighty granted some blessings to a nation. That nation did not thank Allah for these blessings. The blessings turned into trouble for them. Allah brought some calamities upon another nation. They were patient, therefore those calamities were converted into blessings for them.
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 5 On Perseverance,Page 82, Hadees 87

Verse: "There is a rank in heaven which a believer cannot reach unless he suffers some physical calamities."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 5 On Perseverance,Page 83, Hadees 88

Verse: Abu Basir said that he told Imam Sadiq (a.s): "I have been told that Allah will not take away anyone's eyesight unless He grants him a reward in Heaven." Imam Sadiq (a.s) said: "There is some thing there (in Heaven) that is even better." Abu Basir asked: "What is it?" The Imam (a.s) replied: "It is seeing Allah's face."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 5 On Perseverance,Page 83, Hadees 90

Verse: In Al-Mahasin it is narrated that Imam Sadiq (a.s) said: "Nothing has descended from Heaven as rare and as dear as the following: submission to Allah, piety and certitude."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 6 On Thanksgiving, Hadees 91

Verse: Al-Nufli narrated that Allah's Prophet (a.s) said: "The one who eats and gives thanks has the same reward as the one who fasts (who will be rewarded in the Hereafter). The reward of one who is healthy and gives thanks is the same as the one who is suffering and is patient. The reward of one who gives charity and is thankful is the same as the one who is deprived but content."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 6 On Thanksgiving, Hadees 92

Verse: Refrain from tale bearing, causing disunity and spreading rumors among people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1643; Page No. 233

Verse: The good of hear and the Hereafter in knowledge lies, and in ignorance the evil exists likewise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2029; Page No. 285

Verse: Al-A'ala ibn Kamil narrated that once he told Imam Musa ibn Ja'far (a.s) that "Allah had granted him so many blessings that he could not even count, and he did not know the reason for that. The Imam (a.s) asked if he really did not know the reason and told him that it was due to his thanksgiving. And in another tradition we read that the Imam (a.s) told him not to underestimate thanksgiving."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 6 On Thanksgiving, Hadees 93

Verse: Imam Sadiq (a.s) quoted the Prophet of Allah (a.s) on the authority of his forefathers (a.s) on the authority of Allah's Prophet (a.s): "Allah will not open the doors to thanksgiving for anyone without opening up a door to increased blessings."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 6 On Thanksgiving, Hadees 94

Verse: "Give thanks to Allah whenever you do a good deed, and seek Allah's forgiveness whenever you do something bad."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 6 On Thanksgiving, Hadees 95

Verse: Sanan ibn Zarif said "I told Imam Sadiq (a.s) that I am afraid to be reprimanded. He asked me why. I said I asked Allah for a thousand Durhams, and He granted it to me. I asked him for a servant, and He gave me one. Then Imam Sadiq (a.s) asked me what I have to say now. I said praise be to Allah. He said: "What you have said is better than what you have been given."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 6 On Thanksgiving, Hadees 96

Verse: Sae'dan ibn Yazeed said: "I told Imam Sadiq (a.s) that I saw some one having hard times in life while I had a good life. Whatever I reach out for, I find in it what I like. Sometimes I see other people who are superior to me but they do not have these blessings. I am afraid this might be a sort of divine test for me". The Imam (a.s) said: "Have no fear as long as you give thanks for these blessings."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 6 On Thanksgiving, Hadees 97

Verse: "A man from among my nation goes to the bazaar, and buys a shirt-like dress for a half or a third of a Dinar, and praises Allah whenever he wears it. His sins are forgiven before this dress reaches down to his knees."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 6 On Thanksgiving, Hadees 98

Verse: "Whenever a believer gets full, stops eating and drinking and praises Allah, Allah grants him the reward of one who fasts. Allah is Grateful and loves to be praised."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 6 On Thanksgiving, Hadees 99

Verse: "One of the men among you will drink some water, and Allah will reward him with Heaven for this act." He added: "He brings the cup of water next to his lips, and calls Allah's name. Then he drinks some water and takes the cup away while he is still thirsty. Then he praises Allah and takes another sip, and he repeats this again. Allah will reward him with Heaven for this act."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 6 On Thanksgiving, Hadees 100

Verse: Imam Sadiq (a.s) quoted on the authority of the Prophet Jesus (a.s) "People are divided into two groups. Some people are healthy, and others are in trouble. Praise Allah for being healthy, and ask Allah for His Mercy upon those in trouble."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 6 On Thanksgiving, Hadees 101

Verse: Should a club of hellish iron be laid on the earth and all the people gather to lift it up, they will not be able to do so, and should it strike a mountain just as it does with the dwellers of Hell, the former will be chopped into dust.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1747; Page No. 247

Verse: Should a mountain oppress another mountain, God will punish the aggressive one.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1748; Page No. 247

Verse: Should a spark of Hellish flames be in the east, the one who is in the west will feel its heat.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1749; Page No. 247

Verse: Should hardship be in a hole, relief would enter and force it out.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1750; Page No. 247

Verse: The best of you are the best to their family.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1915; Page No. 268

Verse: Should man escape from his sustenance as he escapes from death, his sustenance will come upon him just as death does.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1751; Page No. 247&248

Verse: Should man have two gold territories, he will seek a third one, for nothing will fill his belly but soil, and God will accept the repentance of whoever repents.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1752; Page No. 248

Verse: Should one among you do something whatsoever inside a hard rock having no door and opening to it, it will spread out among people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1753; Page No. 248

Verse: Should one look at those who are superior to him in matters divine and follow them, and look at those who are inferior to him in matters secular and thank God for His grace, God will consider him patient and grateful. Conversely, God will neither consider patient nor grateful the one who follows those who are inferior than him in matters divine and looks at those who are superior to him in matters secular and pity himself for his less abundance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1754; Page No. 248

Verse: Should one of the Paradise women make her appearance on the earth, her aroma of musk will fill up the earth and take away the light of the Sun and the Moon.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1755; Page No. 248

Verse: Should someone give me a sheep's arm for gift or invite me, I will accept both.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1756; Page No. 249

Verse: Should someone rub his/her face against the earth from birth to death for the pleasure of the Exalted God, s(he) will surely find his/her action insignificant in the Resurrection.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1757; Page No. 249

Verse: Should the dwellers of heavens and the earth take part in slandering a believer, the Greatest and the most Powerful God would turn them upside down in the Fire.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1758; Page No. 249

Verse: Should you make so many mistakes piling up high into the sky, and then repent, even then will God accept your repentance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1759; Page No. 249

Verse: Should your reliance on God be, as it deserves, He will expand your sustenance as He does for birds, being hungry in morning and satiated at night.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1760; Page No. 249

Verse: Silence is beauty for the wise and covering for the fool.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1761; Page No. 249

Verse: Silence is safety.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1762; Page No. 249

Verse: Silence is sagacity, but few people can keep silent.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1763; Page No. 249

Verse: Silence is the first stage of servitude.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1764; Page No. 249

Verse: Silence is the most lofty (form of) worship.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1765; Page No. 250

Verse: Silence stands at the peak of morality, and joking reduces its value.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1766; Page No. 250

Verse: Since his creation, the son of Adam has not experienced anything harder than death, but the world after death is even harder.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1767; Page No. 250

Verse: Sins cause evil to the sinless too, for if he blames the sinners, he will happen to commit sins himself, if he backbites them, he will be a sinner himself and if he agrees with them, he will get a share in their sins.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1768; Page No. 250

Verse: Verily, (men's) hearts are containers, and the best hearts are the most capacious (to contain the knowledge of God).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2391.

Verse: Verily, (men's) hearts are within God's two fingers, changing them (as He wishes).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2392.

Verse: Verily, (men's) hearts rust as iron." What chisels them?" they asked." Remembrance of death and recitation of the Quran", replied the Prophet (P.B.U.H).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2393.

Verse: Verily, (one single) man makes a large circle in the company of his brothers and cousins.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2394.

Verse: Verily, a banner will be raised for the treacherous in the Day of Judgment, and someone will call out, "this is the treachery of so-and-so, son of so-and-so".
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2395.

Verse: Verily, a believer can through good-temperedness reach the status of those who keep fast during days and stand up to prayer at nights.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2396.

Verse: Verily, a believer emaciates the Satan appointed for him (her) just as you make your camel skinny in journeys.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2397.

Verse: Verily, a believer struggles in the way of God by his sword as well as his tongue.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2398.

Verse: Verily, a group of my people seek the knowledge of religion, recite the Quran and say, "We join rulers to avail ourselves of their worldly possessions and we keep our faith intact in their company", but this is impossible, for as quitted fruits nothing but thorn, nearness to rulers avails them nothing but vice.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2399.

Verse: Verily, a man of dignity does not practice misery.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2400.

Verse: Verily, a present man beholds things, which an absent one will not.(Hearsay is no witness.)
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2401.

Verse: Verily, a scholar whom God stops enjoying his own knowledge, will suffer the most in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2402.

Verse: Verily, adulterers will appear (in the Day of Judgment) with faces flamed with fire.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2403.

Verse: Verily, all the good is perceptible through wisdom, and he who lacks wisdom is bereft of faith.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2404.

Verse: Verily, alms given to a relative entail a double reward.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2405.

Verse: Verily, among (good) habits is to accompany guests to the house gate.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2406.

Verse: Verily, among God's servants are the ones whose swears will prove to be true should they swear by God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2407.

Verse: Do not keep company with the foolish.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 491; Page No. 71

Verse: Verily, among the claims of a child on his father is to teach him how to write, to choose him a good name and to take a wife for him when he reaches maturity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2408.

Verse: Verily, among the good deeds and actions of a believer, which will rejoin him after death are: the knowledge spread, a righteous child, a Quran left as inheritance, a mosque built, a house made for the wayfarers, a stream flown by one's assistance and a share of one's wealth set aside for the poor when one is healthy and still alive.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2409.

Verse: Verily, among the indications of a woman's felicity are the ease in her engagement and the scantiness of her dowry.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2410.

Verse: Verily, among the means of (God's) forgiveness is greeting and well-speaking.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2411.

Verse: Verily, among the means of (God's) forgiveness is to please one's faithful brethren.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2412.

Verse: Verily, among the mines of piety is the acquisition of what you know not and adding it to what you know, for the reduction in knowledge enhancement will make it defective, and (s) he who avails himself (herself) less of his (her) knowledge, will fall short in learning what (s) he knows not.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2413.

Verse: Verily, among the most capital sins is to usurp someone's properties, and paying a visit to patients is among good deeds.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2414.

Verse: Verily, among the prerequisites of faith are to please nobody through causing God's anger, to thank nobody for what God has given you, and to berate nobody for what He has withheld from you, for (the destined) sustenance will not increase through the avarice of the avaricious, nor does it decrease through the displeasure of the displeased.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2415.

Verse: Verily, among the signs of one's perfection of faith is to observe some degrees of exception (probability) in whatever one says.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2416.

Verse: Verily, among the signs of the Hour (the Resurrection) are the fall of knowledge and the rise of ignorance, the prevalence of adultery, drinking wine and the increase in the number of women over men to the extent that one man might remain as the guardian of fifty women.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2417.

Verse: The best of my people is the one who calls people towards God, the Almighty, and makes them lovers of Him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1904; Page No. 267

Verse: The best of people is a poor believer who expends (in the way of God) to the possible extent.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1905; Page No. 267

Verse: The best of people is the one who benefits them the most.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1906; Page No. 267

Verse: The best of people is the one who lives a long life of good deeds, and the worst is the one who lives a long life of evil deeds.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1907; Page No. 267

Verse: The best of people is the one whom others profit by.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1908; Page No. 268

Verse: The best of women is the one with a more beautiful visage and the less gift of marriage.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1909; Page No. 268

Verse: The best of you are the most good-tempered who associate with people, and with whom people (tend to) associate.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1917; Page No. 268

Verse: The best of you are the most reluctant to here and the most inclined towards the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1918; Page No. 269

Verse: The best of you are those who defend their clan without committing sins.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1919; Page No. 269

Verse: The best of you are those who learn and teach the Quran.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1920; Page No. 269

Verse: The best of you are those who neither abandon here for the Hereafter, nor do the reverse, nor stand a burden on others.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1921; Page No. 269

Verse: The best of you are those whose good we can be hopeful about and from whose evil we can find a way out, and the worst of you are those whose good we cannot be hopeful about and from whose evil we cannot find a way out.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1922; Page No. 269

Verse: The best of you are, in refunding their debts, the quickest.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1923; Page No. 269

Verse: The best of you in faith has the best manners (in rate).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1924; Page No. 269

Verse: The best of you is not the one who abandons this world for the next or the next for this in order to avail herself/himself of both, for this world is a bridge to the next. Try not to be a burden to others.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1925; Page No. 269

Verse: The best of you is the one whom God has given a hand, and who has on his own `self' full command.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1926; Page No. 269&270

Verse: The best of you is the one whose meeting reminds you of God, whose words increase your knowledge, and whose deeds incline you towards the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1927; Page No. 270

Verse: The best of your homes is the one wherein an orphan is kept in respect.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1928; Page No. 270

Verse: The best of your leaders are those whom you love and pray for, who love and pray for you, and the worst ones are those whom you hate and curse, and who hate and curse you.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1929; Page No. 270

Verse: The best of your women are the affectionate, childbearing ones who are assistant and obedient to their husbands and pious at the same time, and the worst of them are the arrogant ones who use makeup (for other than their husbands). The latter are hypocrites (in reality) who will not be allowed to Paradise, save to the number of crows with red feet and beaks.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1930; Page No. 270

Verse: Revealing all you know suffices to show your ignorance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1688; Page No. 238

Verse: Revealing God's blessings is one way of thanksgiving to Him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1689; Page No. 238

Verse: Ruin is the end of men who obey women.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1690; Page No. 238

Verse: S(he) who recites the Qoran, will not suffer poverty, and that's the peak of riches for him/her.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1691; Page No. 239

Verse: Safeguard the earth, for it is your mother who will report (to God) the good or evil any one does on it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1692; Page No. 239

Verse: Satan tries to deceive one or two persons (when sitting together) but leaves them as soon as they turn out to be three.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1693; Page No. 239

Verse: Save the Almighty God, a believer does not have anything better than an abstinent wife who obeys his orders, makes him cheerful when he casts a look at her, observes his oath whenever he swears, and keeps his wealth and her own modesty intact in his absence.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1694; Page No. 239

Verse: Save your face by your wealth.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1695; Page No. 239

Verse: Save yourself from Fire, even through half a date; or by good words, if lacking the former.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1696; Page No. 240

Verse: Say a good word to derive benefit, and avoid speaking evil words to be safe.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1697; Page No. 240

Verse: Say: O God! I beg You to bestow upon me a confident heart, believing in Your visit in the Last Day, pleased with Your predestination and content with Your blessings.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1698; Page No. 240

Verse: Say: O God! make my inner self better than my outer self, and rectify the latter's God! I beg You to give me the good you have bestowed upon people, of wealth, family and children that are neither deviated nor deviating.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1699; Page No. 240

Verse: Sedition will arise before the Hour, as gloomy as parts of dark nights.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1708; Page No. 241

Verse: Seditions will soon arise. When believers in the morning will turn out to be disbelievers at night, save those whom God has enlivened their hearts with knowledge.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1709; Page No. 241

Verse: See where you place your child(cultivate your sperm),for nature leaves its effect.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1710; Page No. 241

Verse: Seek (something), even if it is an iron ring.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1711; Page No. 241

Verse: Seek (your) sustenance through marriage.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1712; Page No. 241

Verse: Seek good deeds with holders of good faces.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1713; Page No. 241

Verse: Seek knowledge, for it is a believer's friend, his minister being forbearance, his guidance being intellect, his guardian being (good) deeds, his father being moderateness, his brother being gentleness, and the commander of his army being patience.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1714; Page No. 242

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God has banned Hell for anybody who utters, `there is no god but Allah', and intends nothing but God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2607.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God has banned Paradise for the double-faced (hypocrites).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2608.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God has created (colored) Paradise white, and (thus) the most favorite color to Him is white.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2609.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God has forgiven my people as to what occurs in their hearts, if not given expression to or acted upon.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2610.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God has likened the (material) world to the excrements of the son of Adam.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2611.

Verse: Verily, the most satiated of all people in this world, will starve the most in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2691.

Verse: Verily, the most thankful of all people is the one who is grateful to people the most.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2692.

Verse: Verily, the most truthful of all people believes in what others say the most, and the most untruthful of them denies what others say the most.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2693.

Verse: Verily, the most wicked people to God in the Resurrection Day are those who have lost their own eternal shares for others' worldly affairs.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2694.

Verse: Verily, the most wretched of all wretched people is the one who enjoys poverty here coupled with punishment in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2695.

Verse: Verily, the oppressed are the prosperous in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2696.

Verse: Verily, the punishment of this (Muslim) people is given in this very world.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2697.

Verse: Verily, the remedy to ignorance is asking questions.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2698.

Verse: Verily, the worst ones to God in the Day of Judgment are those with whom people keep distance due to their scurrility.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2709.

Verse: Verily, the worst people to God in the Day of Judgment are those whom others fear the most (in this world).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2710.

Verse: Verily, there is a claim on one's wealth besides poor rate.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2711.

Verse: Verily, there is a door to Hell, which nobody passes through save those who quench their anger by committing sins against God's will.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2712.

Verse: Verily, there is a door to repentance, vast to the extent of East from West, which gets closed only if the Sun happens to rise from the West.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2713.

Verse: Verily, there is a house in Paradise called 'house of the generous.'
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2714.

Verse: If the world were as valuable to Allah as a wing of a mosquito, He would never give a sip of water to an infidel.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1012; Page No. 143

Verse: If there were no hope, no mother would milk her child, and nobody would plant a tree.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1014; Page No. 143

Verse: If there were no women, (all) men would be allowed to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1015, Page No. 143

Verse: If there were no women, God would be duly worshipped.

Verse: If you knew what you have with God, you would like to fall into more poverty and need.

Verse: If you seek the love of God and that of the Prophet, return the things given to you in trust, be honest in speaking and treat your neighbors well.

Verse: If you wish to be a favorite to God, dislike the (material) world, and if you wish to be a favorite to people, offer them your excess.

Verse: Struggle against polytheists through your wealth and souls and words.

Verse: Struggle against your passions to gain control over your souls.

Verse: Struggling in the way of God is the nearest of all deeds to Him, and nothing is equal to it.

Verse: Stupidity is inauspicious and moderateness is auspicious (in nature).

Verse: Suffice it for death to decline your love for the world and to incline you towards eternity.

Verse: Suffice it for time to advise and for death to separate.

Verse: Surprised am I of the negligent who is not to be neglected, and of the seeker of the (material) world who is sought by death, and of the one who laughs boisterously but knows not weather God is pleased or displeased with him\her.

Verse: Suspend the punishment of merciful people, unless they are condemned to divinely-ordered penalties.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1806; Page No. 255

Verse: Suspicion is far-sightedness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1807; Page No. 255

Verse: Sustenance reaches a generous family faster than a knife hits a camel's hump.

Verse: Sustenance seeks God's servants more than their death.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1809; Page No. 255

Verse: Taking up man's soul by the Angle of Death is harder than a thousand strokes of sword.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1821; Page No. 257

Verse: Talk less and be not enticed by Satan.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1822; Page No. 257

VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1853; Page No. 261
