Verse: Whoever spares his help from people, will not be spared from the fire of Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3110.

Verse: Whoever spreads out an evil deed is like the doer of that deed, and whoever blames a believer for doing something, will not die unless (s)he does the same.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3111.

Verse: Whoever starts his day with obedience to God in his parents' affairs, will face two opened doors of Paradise; and one door, if (s)he has only father or mother.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3112.

Verse: Whoever starts his day with other than God in his mind, will not receive any attention from Him, and whoever starts his day with no attention to Muslims' affairs is not a Muslim.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3113.

Verse: Whoever starts his day with piety in mind, but happens to commit a sin, will be forgiven by God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3114.

Verse: Whoever supports his own or others' orphans as long as they are made needless of him by God, will be entitled to enter Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3115.

Verse: Whoever supports oppression through hostility (to people), will always be detested by God unless he stops doing so.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3116.

Verse: Whoever swears an oath to do something but faces a better one to perform, should atone for his oath and do the latter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3117.

Verse: Whoever swears by anything save God, is a dualist.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3118.

Verse: Whoever takes an affair of Muslims upon himself but does not carry it out as carefully as the does his own, will not be allowed to enjoy the fragrance of Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3119.

Verse: Verily, the most penitent of all people in the Day of Judgment will be the one who has bartered his eternal life for another's worldly life.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2688.

Verse: Verily, the most perfect prosperity is spending the entire life in worship of (and obedience to) God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2689.

Verse: Verily, the seven skies and earths as well as mountains curse an old adulterer, and the fetid smell of an adulterer's privy parts will annoy the dwellers of Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2700.

Verse: Verily, the similitude of he who commits evil deeds followed by good deeds is the similitude of the one who has a tight armor on, exerting pressure on his breathing, who does something good causing one single chain to loose and then goes on doing so until the whole armor drops down.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2701.

Verse: Verily, the similitude of the one who requests back his gifts is the similitude of a dog which eats food to satiety, vomits it and then eats again what it has vomited.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2702.

Verse: Verily, the son of Adam is highly desirous for what is banned on him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2703.

Verse: Verily, the stingiest among people is he who hesitates to greet others, and the weakest is the one who falls short in praying.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2704.

Verse: Verily, the strongest handhold in Islam is to like and dislike for God's sake.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2705.

Verse: Verily, the value of deeds lies in (the doer's) intentions, and in their results.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2706.

Verse: Verily, the world is green and sweet, and God has made you (His) caliphs in it. He watches you to see how you act. Thus, as to the world, keep yourself intact and from women refrain, for the Sons of Israel's troubles began with matters concerning women.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2707.

Verse: Verily, the world is sweet and green, and God has placed you in it to see how you act.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2708.

Verse: Do not leave wisdom to the unwise, and do not withhold it from the wise, for both these will be injustice to it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 493; Page No. 71

Verse: Do not look at your wives' or bond women's vulvas when having sexual intercourse with them, for it is a cause of blindness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 494; Page No. 71

Verse: Do not make your hearts die of drinking and eating excessively, for they're like unto farms dying of over-irrigation.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 495; Page No. 71&72

Verse: Do not make yourself afraid of religion.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 496, Page No. 72

Verse: Do not marry barren or old women, for I take pride in your greater population (as compared with others').
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 497; Page No. 72

Verse: Verily, when God bestows His blessing on a servant (of Him), He likes to see it apparent in him (her).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2731.

Verse: Verily, there is a lump of flesh in the body, which will guide the whole body if guided aright, but will ruin the whole body if misled---it is man's heart.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2715.

Verse: Verily, thighs are one's privy parts.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2716.

Verse: No one should go to troubles that they cannot afford for a guest.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 25876; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 414

Verse: Whoever intends to return his debt but dies before doing so, will have his debt paid by God in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3008.

Verse: Whoever intercedes to prevent divine punishment being carried out, will be subject to God's wrath until he stops doing so.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3009.

Verse: Whoever introduces something heretical to this(Islamic) nation, will not die before being afflicted with it in this very world.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3010.

Verse: Whoever is able to assist a believer being humiliated in his sight, but avoids doing so, will be humiliated by God in the sight of all people in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3011.

Verse: Look! You are not superior to the black or red in anything but piety.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1202; Page No. 172

Verse: Looking (dispassionately) at beautiful women and at green grass strengthens eyesight.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1203; Page No. 172

Verse: Looking at the bright side of everything comes from proper worshipping.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1204; Page No. 172

Verse: Looking at the letter of one's brother without his permission is looking at Hell indeed.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1205; Page No. 173

Verse: Lose your modesty and do whatever you want to.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1206; Page No. 173

Verse: Loser is the one in whose heart the Exalted God has not placed sympathy towards other human beings.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1207; Page No. 173

Verse: Loving a servant, God deprives him (her) of the world, just as you deprive your patients of drinking water.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1208; Page No. 173

Verse: Loving a servant, God puts him (her) to test to see him (her) supplicating.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1209; Page No. 173

Verse: Loving a servant, God puts him (her) to test, and loving him (her) more, He chooses the servant for Himself. "How?", the people demanded. The Holy Prophet replied: "By leaving him (her) without property and heir."
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1210; Page No. 173

Verse: Loving a servant, God throws His love for him in the angels' hearts, and detesting him, He sets His hatred in their hearts as well as in men's hearts.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1211; Page No. 173

Verse: Lustful music makes hypocrisy in one's heart show, just as water makes sown seeds grow.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1212; Page No. 173

Verse: Lying darkens one's face, and tale bearing entails chastisement in the grave.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1213; Page No. 173

Verse: Make a pilgrimage to Mecca, needlessness to gain; and travel, healthy to remain.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1214; Page No. 174

Verse: Make the most of your chances to do good deeds before a time when sedition comes to pass as gloomy as parts of dark nights, when man happens to be a believer in the morning but a disbeliever in the evening and vice versa, and when he exchanges his faith for the insignificant worldly fame.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1221; Page No. 175

Verse: Whoever belies intercession, will not enjoy it in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2913.

Verse: Make the most of your chances to do good deeds prior to the occurrence of the following six: the rule of the ignorant, the trade of ranks and positions, belittlement of bloodshed, breaking bonds of kinship, the recitation of the Quran by the newcomers (in religion) who appoint a singer to imamate (leadership), though he is the least in understanding the religion.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1222; Page No. 175

Verse: Make your food cold to bring you bliss (health).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1223; Page No. 175

Verse: Make your minds accustomed to the remembrance of God, and meditate a lot.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1224; Page No. 175

Verse: Make your world thrive, and for the other world in such a way try as if tomorrow you would die.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1225; Page No. 175

Verse: Making friends with your father's friend is a form of kindness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1226; Page No. 176

Verse: Man does not fill up anything worse than his stomach.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1227; Page No. 176

Verse: Man does not satiate anything worse than his belly(stomach).For sons of Adam, that which keeps them strong (and healthy) would suffice.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1228; Page No. 176

Verse: Whoever abandons shooting while knowing it well, loses one of (God's) blessings.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2877.

Verse: Whoever abandons something merely for the sake of God, will in return receive things from God serving him better here and in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2878.

Verse: Whoever abandons the (material) world, will be made knowledgeable and insightful by God without taking lessons.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2879.

Verse: Whoever abides by the following three (before death), will be pardoned by the Exalted God for all his (her) sins: taking no partner with God, refraining from sorcery and following sorcerers, and harboring no grudges against brothers (in faith).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2880.

Verse: Whoever abides by the following three, among the good ones will be: being satisfied with one's destiny, abstaining from heavenly-unlawful deeds, and becoming angry for the sake of the Great and Powerful God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2881.

Verse: Whoever abides by the following three, perfected in faith and competent for heavenly reward will turn out to be: good manner by which to get along with people piety by which to keep away from heavenly-forbidden deeds, and forbearance by which to ward off the ignorance of the ignorant.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2882.

Verse: Whoever abides by the following three, will be kept under the shade of Divine Throne the day when no shade but God's will prevail: making ablutions in trouble, walking towards mosque in darkness, and feeding the hungry.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2883.

Verse: Whoever abides by the following three, will be perfected in attributes of faith: refraining from wrong when pleased, deviating not from right when crossed, and avoid seizing others' property when in power.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2884.

Verse: Do not laugh excessively, for it makes (your) heart wither.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 492; Page No. 71

Verse: Whoever abides by the following three, will face the exalted God's easy reckoning and will be allowed to Paradise with God's Mercy: bestowing upon the one who has deprived him (of something), forgiving the one who has wronged him, and joining the one who has broken the bonds of kinship.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2885.

Verse: Whoever abides by the following three, will receive vast heavenly support and merry, and will be allowed to Paradise: thanking God when bestowed with blessings, forgiving (people) when in power, and slowness in action when crossed.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2886.

Verse: Whoever accompanies a tyrant, has committed a crime.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2887.

Verse: Whoever accuses a believer of blasphemy, has actually killed him/her.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2888.

Verse: Whoever acts as a mediator before a man of power to solve a Muslim brother's problems or to do him some good, will be helped by God to pass over the Bridge the day when everybody slips.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2889.

Verse: Whoever acts without knowledge, will cause more corruption than correction.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2890.

Verse: Whoever among women asks her husband for divorce without reason, will not be allowed to enjoy the fragrance of Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2891.

Verse: Whoever among women dies while her husband is pleased with her, will be given entrance to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2892.

Verse: Whoever among women leaves home without her husband's consent will be subject to the Exalted God's anger until she returns or satisfies her husband.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2893.

Verse: Whoever among women perfumes herself and leaves home to pass by a group of people to enjoy her pleasant smell, will be adulterous, and all eyes are adulterous.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2894.

Verse: Whoever among women uncovers herself outside her husband's house, is actually tearing out the veil between herself and the Great, Powerful God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2895.

Verse: Whoever among you is able to benefit his Muslim brothers, should do so.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2896.

Verse: Whoever among you is able to have a hidden reserve of good deeds must do so.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2897.

Verse: Whoever among you is able to provide a Muslim brother with a piece of dress should do so.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2898.

Verse: Whoever among you is able to save one's face and faith with his wealth, should do so.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2899.

Verse: Whoever appoints someone a ruler to ten people, knowing that among them there is one superior to the former, has actually (tried) to deceive God, His Messenger as well as Muslims.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2900.

Verse: Whoever argues about, without knowledge, in a dispute, will face God's anger till he abandons his arguments.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2901.

Verse: Whoever asks forgiveness (from God), does not (in fact) insist in sins even if (s)he commits seventy sins a day.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2902.

Verse: Whoever asks goodness from God will not suffer despair, whoever counsels in his affairs will not regret, and whoever considers lawful the prohibitions in the Quran, does not believe in it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2903.

Verse: "Enjoining the right and forbidding the wrong are two of Allah's creatures. Whoever assists them will be honored by Allah, and whoever abandons them will be abandoned by Allah."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 224

Verse: "Whoever has the following characteristics will enjoin the right and forbid the wrong: is knowledgeable about the right and abandons the wrong; is moderate and just concerning what he enjoins as right, and what he forbids as wrong; and behaves according to what he enjoins and/or forbids."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 225

Verse: "I saw a man from my nation in a dream. He was surrounded by the Fire of Hell. At once his acts of enjoining the right and forbidding the wrong came to his help and saved him from the Fire and handed him over to the angels."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 226

Verse: "Woe to the people who do not pay back their debts to Allah by enjoining the right and forbidding the wrong."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 227

Verse: "A man from the Khasa'em tribe went to see the Prophet of Allah (a.s) and said: "O' Prophet of Allah! Please tell me what is the noblest form of submission to Allah?" He replied: "Faith in Allah." Then he asked: "What is next?" The Prophet replied: "Visiting the relations of kin." Then he asked: "What is next?" The Prophet replied: "Enjoining the right and forbidding the wrong." The man asked: "What is the most despised act near Allah?" He said: "Being an infidel." He asked: "What is the next worst thing?" He said: "Cutting off relations of kin." He asked: "What is next?" He replied: "Enjoining the wrong and forbidding the right."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 228

Verse: "What would you do if all your women were corrupt and your youth were deviated, and no one enjoined the right and forbade the wrong?" He was asked: "O' Prophet of Allah! Will this happen?" He replied: "Yes. It will get even worse. What will you do when the people enjoin the wrong and forbid the right?" He was asked: "O' Prophet of Allah! Will things ever get this way?" He replied: "Yes, it will get even worse than this. What will you do when the people consider the right as the wrong and the wrong as the right?"
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 229

Verse: Verily, remembrance of God weighs over dispensing one's wealth.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2554.

Verse: Verily, s (he) who asks nothing from God, will experience His wrath.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2555.

Verse: Verily, s(he) who eats and thanks will be rewarded the same as a fast, patient man.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2556.

Verse: "When the following verse was revealed: "O' ye who believe! Save yourselves and your families from a Fire!" [The Holy Quran: Tahrim 66:6], a Muslim man sat down and started to cry. He said: "I am not even able to protect myself from the Fire, now I am ordered to protect my family from the Fire, too." The Prophet of Allah (a.s) said: "It suffices for you to enjoin the right and forbid the wrong for them in the same way that you do it for yourself."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 230

Verse: Imam Reza (a.s) narrated that the Prophet of Allah (a.s) said: : "My nation should prepare itself for divine calamities whenever they abandon enjoining the right and forbidding the wrong."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 231

Verse: : "Whenever a zealous Muslim observes that a forbidden act takes place, it suffices for him to know that Allah is aware of his disapproval and displeasure."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 232

Verse: Ghiyas ibn Ibrahim said: "Whenever Imam Sadiq (a.s) reached a group of people who were quarrelling, he would loudly say: "fear Allah" three times and pass by them."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 233

Verse: "Whoever seeks the pleasure of the people in what raises Allah's anger will be admonished by the people who used to admire him before. Allah will protect whoever prefers to obey Allah, despite the people's displeasure, from any enemies. Allah the Almighty will remove from him the jealousy of any jealous ones, and the oppression of any oppressors, and will be his helper and protector."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 234

Verse: Mufaz'zil ibn Zayd said that Imam Sadiq (a.s) told him: "O' Mufaz'zil! If one objects to an oppressive ruler and gets hurt by that ruler, he will not get any reward and will not be granted patience."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 235

Verse: Enjoining the right and forbidding the wrong will only affect a believer or an ignorant person who learns from these acts, but it will not affect a person who is armed to the teeth."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 236

Verse: Allah the Almighty has left a believer's affairs up to himself, but has not abandoned him to be humiliated. Have you not heard Allah's words: "But honor belongs to Allah and His Apostle, and to the Believers." [The Holy Quran: Munafiqun 63:8]; Therefore believers are honored, not abased." He then added: "Believers are even nobler than the mountains since we can knock down the mountains and destroy them, but nothing can diminish a believer's faith.
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 237

Verse: You must enjoin the right and forbid the wrong, else the bad people will rule over you, and the prayers of your good people will not be answered."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 238

Verse: It is not good for a believer to do something to get humiliated. He was asked: "What will humiliate him?" Imam Sadiq (a.s) replied: "When he does something for which he has to apologize later.
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 239

Verse: Masaedat ibn Sadaqih narrated that Imam Sadiq (a.s) was asked if it was incumbent upon the entire nation to enjoin the right and forbid the wrong. He replied in the negative. They asked him the reason. He said "It is incumbent upon those who are in power whom the people obey and can distinguish between the right and the wrong. It is not incumbent upon the weak people who do not know how to approach this issue, and might say wrong things about what is right. That is why Allah says: "Let there arise out of you a band of people inviting to all that is good, enjoining the right, and forbidding what is wrong. [The Holy Quran: Al-i-Imran 3:104]. But this is especial, and not general. As Allah the Almighty said: "Of the people of Moses there is a chapter who guide and do justice in the light of truth." [The Holy Quran: Araf 7:159]. He has not said it is for all the people of Moses or all his tribe to enjoin the right and forbid the wrong, even though there were many groups there. And by people it is meant more than one, as Allah the Almighty said: "Abraham was indeed a model, devoutly obedient to Allah." [The Holy Quran: Nahl 16:120]. In this verse it is said that he was obedient to Allah. Therefore it is not incumbent upon anyone who does not have any power, helpers or followers at peace time."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 240

Verse: Masaedat ibn Sadaqih said that Imam Sadiq (a.s) was questioned about the Prophet's statement: "The best form of Jihad -holy war- is expressing what is just in the presence of an oppressive ruler." Imam Sadiq (a.s) said "This act will only be accepted of him if his enjoining the right is based on knowledge, otherwise it is not accepted."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 241

Verse: "Allah the Almighty revealed the following to the Prophet Shu'aib (a.s): "I shall punish one hundred thousand people from your nation. Forty thousand of them are from the wicked ones, and sixty thousand of them are from the good people." Shu'aib (a.s) asked: "You punish the bad people. Why are the good people punished?" Allah the Almighty revealed to him: "They are the people who got along with the sinners, and were not worried about My Anger."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 242

Verse: : "The people will live in prosperity as long as they cooperate with each other in enjoining the right and forbidding the wrong. However, once they stop doing so, their blessings will be taken away from them, and some will rule over others, and they will have no helpers in the heavens or on the Earth."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 243

Verse: "Whoever stops physical, verbal and spiritual enjoining of the right and forbidding of the wrong is like a living corpse that seems to be alive."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 13 On Enjoining the Right and Forbidding the Wrong, Hadees 244

Verse: In Al-Mahasin it is narrated that Imam Sadiq (a.s) said "Return whatever you are entrusted with to its owner, even if the owner is the murderer of Imam Hussein (a.s)."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 14 On Being Trustworthy, Hadees 245

Verse: : "Be pious and return the property that you have been entrusted with, since I shall even return any property of Imam Ali's (a.s) murderer to him, if he entrusted me with his property."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 14 On Being Trustworthy, Hadees 246

Verse: Abdullah ibn San'an said that once he went to see Imam Sadiq (a.s) in the mosque. Imam Sadiq (a.s) had finished saying his afternoon prayers and was sitting facing the Qibla He told Imam Sadiq (a.s): "O' grandson of the Prophet! There are several rulers who have entrusted their treasury with me, but do not pay you your due one-fifth levy. Should I return their property to them?" Imam Sadiq (a.s) replied "I swear three times by the Lord of this Qibla that even if Ibn Muljam who has killed my grandfather (Imam Ali (a.s)) (and I wish to take revenge on him) entrusts his property with me, I shall return it to him."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 14 On Being Trustworthy, Hadees 247

Verse: "The residents of the planet Earth will receive divine blessings as long as they love each other, act righteously, and honor what they are entrusted with."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues,Chapter 14 On Being Trustworthy, Hadees 248

Verse: Imam Sadiq (a.s) was questioned about Allah's statement: "We did indeed offer the Trust to the Heavens and the Earth and the Mountains, but being afraid, they all refused to undertake it. However man undertook it- he was indeed unjust and foolish." [The Holy Quran: Ahzab 33:72]. He was asked: "What was offered to them? What did man undertake? What is it?" Imam Sadiq (a.s) replied "Trust between the people was offered, and this was done during the creation of the creatures."

Verse: Muhammad Ibne Qasim Ibne Fuzail narrates a tradition from Imam Musa al-Kazim (a.s.). He says, "I asked Imam (a.s.), 'One of your devotees has taken a loan from an enemy of yours. The creditor wants to oppress him and have him imprisoned. Allah knows that he has no money to repay the debt, neither is he capable to do so at present. He does not even have Bayyanah (two just witnesses) to prove his bankruptcy. Then is it allowed for him to take an oath so that he can prove his bankruptcy and obtain respite till the return of favourable conditions? And if from your Shias there are some witnesses who can testify against him, (that he has taken the loan) can they testify?'"
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Twewntieth Greater Sin ,page 81; Al Kafi

Verse: O God! I take refuge in You from poverty, indigence and abjectness, and from being oppressed or being an oppressor.

Verse: O God! I take refuge in You from the knowledge with no use, the action not accepted and the prayer not granted.

Verse: O God! I take refuge in You from vitiligo, insanity, leprosy and (all) bad diseases.

Verse: O God! I take refuge in You from weakness, laziness, fear, misery, old age, hard-heartedness, negligence and indigence, I take refuge in You from poverty, infidelity, debauchery, hypocrisy, conflict and dissimulation, and I take refuge in You from deafness, dumbness, madness, leprosy, vitiligo and (all) bad diseases.

Verse: O God! I take refuge in You from weakness, laziness, fear, misery and old age, I take refuge in You from chastisement in the grave and punishment in Hell, and I take refuge in You from trials in life and in death.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1455; Page No. 206

Verse: O God! improve my faith for it saves my affairs, improve my worldly life for in it my sustenance lies and improve my eternal life for towards it is my return's God! conjoin my life with increase of the good, and my death with relief from all evils.

Verse: O God! Leave me not on my own for a twinkling of an eye, and deprive me not of the best of Your gifts.

VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1461; Page No. 207

Verse: O God! make me thankful, patient, insignificant in my own sight and great in people's.

Verse: O God! Verse: Treating people moderately is charity.

Telling lie (on the contrary) is a hellish act. When a man tells lie, he is led to wrongdoing, which will (in turn) lead him to disbelief, and this will direct him to Hell.

Verse: Truthfulness is peace; lying is anxiety.

Verse: Try to be kind, for a kind person wants people to be at good and in abundance.

VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2820.

Verse: When God wishes good for someone, He makes the grateful avail his good deeds, and when He wishes evil for someone, He makes the ungrateful avail his good deeds.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2821.

Verse: Verily, Satan loves red color, and thus (you should) avoid it and avoid any dress, which makes you pretentious.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2561.

Verse: Verily, the best merit (for a man) is good-temperedness.

VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2577.

Verse: Verily, the dead can recognize those who carry him (her), those who perform his (her) ceremonial wash and those who bury him (her).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2579.

VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2798.

Verse: When an inexpert person is made responsible of doing something, bad results are to be awaited.

Verse: When anyone of you consults with his brother (in faith), the latter should offer him benevolent consultation.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2800.

Verse: When anyone of you hires somebody, he should tell him how much his wage is.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2802.

Verse: When aroused by jealousy, keep away from tyranny, when fallen into suspicion, put it not into action, and when something you weigh, on it an extra amount lay.

Verse: When comes the end of Time, death culls out the good among my people just as you handpick the best of date.

Verse: When God wishes good for a person, He grants him/her deep thought in religion.

Verse: When God wishes good for somebody, He makes him suffer a calamity.

Verse: When God wishes good for someone, He grants him a deep understanding of religion, makes him heedless of the world, and discloses his defects for him.

Verse: When God wishes good for someone, He sets up needlessness in his soul, piety in his heart, and when the reverse He wishes, He makes poverty maneuver in his sight.

Verse: How nice for those of my people who brush their teeth before or after eating and when making ablution.

Verse: How nice weapons are patience and prayer for a believer!

Verse: I am mostly worried about my nation of carnal desires and unfulfilled wishes.

Verse: I am mostly worried about my nation, of glib-tongued hypocrites.

VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 946; Page No. 134

Verse: I am not worried about my people as to villains who may kill them or foes who may cause them to annihilate, but as to misleading leaders who will kill them in case of disobedience and impose on them seditions in case of obedience.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 947; Page No. 134

Verse: I am not worried about my people concerning any trials, save wine and women.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 948; Page No. 134

Verse: I am not worried about your poverty but only about taking pride in your excessive wealth, nor am I worried about your wrongdoings but only about intentional ones.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 949; Page No. 134

Verse: I am the most eloquent Arab.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 950; Page No. 134

Verse: I am very amazed at those who believe in eternal abode but try hard for the abode of vanity!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 951; Page No. 134

Verse: I am worried about my (Islamic) nation more of gluttony, over-sleeping, laziness and weakness of faith than anything else.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 952; Page No. 134&135

Verse: I am worried about you more for blessings than for sins. Beware that blessings not thanked for will entail your definite ruin.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 953; Page No. 135

Verse: I am worried about you more for trials in poverty than for trials in affluence. Verily, you were afflicted with poverty but kept patient; verily the world is sweet and charming!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 954; Page No. 135

Verse: I asked Gabriel, "Do you see your Lord? He said: "There are seventy screens of light between me and Him, the closest of which will set me afire should I happen to look at it".
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 955, Page No. 135

Verse: I asked God to let me call my people to account (in the Hereafter), lest they might feel disgrace in the sight of others, but He-the Great and powerful -sent me a revelation, saying "O Muhammad! I Myself will call them to account and hide their sins (if any) from you, so that they will not feel disgrace even in your sight".
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 956; Page No. 135

Verse: Whoever teaches his/her knowledge (to others), will receive the reward of the one who acts upon it, with the doer's reward not reduced.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3120.

Verse: Whoever treats his subjects deceitfully, will assuredly dwell in Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3121.

Verse: Whoever treats my people moderately, will be treated in like manner by God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3122.

Verse: Whoever undertakes the leadership of my people after me, will in the Resurrection Day be made to stop on the Bridge, and the angels will read out his book of deeds. He will then be saved by God, if he has practiced justice, but if he has been unjust (to people), the Bridge will shake under him in such a way that his bodily organs will disintegrate, with a two-hundred year distance between any two organs, and he will finally fall down the Bridge (into Hell).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3123.

Verse: Whoever unduly kills a sparrow, will be called to account by God in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3124.

Verse: Whoever unjustly kills an animal, a bird and so on will be called to account by God in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3125.

Verse: Whoever veils his brother('s faults), will be veiled by God here and in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3126.

Verse: Whoever walks in a way in search of knowledge, will be led by God to a path to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3127.

Verse: Whoever wishes to be the most needless of all people, should rely on what is with God more than what himself possesses.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3135.

Verse: Whoever wishes to be the most powerful of all, should rely on God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3136.

Verse: Whoever wishes to be the strongest among people, should rely on God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3137.

Verse: Whoever wishes to do something and counsels with a Muslim about it, will be granted success by God in (carrying out) the most logical affairs.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3138.

Verse: Whoever wishes to have abundant sustenance and long life, should go on keeping the bonds of kinship.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3139.

Verse: Whoever wishes to know what (s)he has with God, should see what of God is with him/her.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3140.

Verse: Whoever wishes to reside at the heart of Heaven, should get along with people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3141.

Verse: Whoever wishes to taste the sugar of faith, should love people just for the Exalted God's sake.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3142.

Verse: Whoever wishes to taste the sweetness of faith, should wish to love someone whom s(he) loves only for God's sake.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3143.

Verse: Whomsoever you benefit, will benefit you, and whoever loses patience in worldly events will turn helpless, whoever slanders people will be slandered, and whoever leaves people on their own, will not be left unrequited.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3144.

Verse: Why do you kill your brothers (in faith)? When someone sees something pleasing in his/her brother, he/she should ask God's blessing for him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3145.

Verse: Willing someone to die in a certain place, God sets there a need for him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3146.

Verse: Islam is superior (to all things) and nothing will take precedence over it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1067; Page No. 151

Verse: It happens that a servant (of God) commits a sin, but he is given entrance to Paradise for he minds it time and again and remains penitent thereof.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1068; Page No. 151

Verse: It is a capital treachery to tell your brother (in faith) something that he takes as truth, while it's not.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1069; Page No. 151

Verse: It is a right for a child that his father should choose him a good name, provide him with good opportunities and teach him the best acts of civility.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1070; Page No. 151

Verse: It is a right for a man that his wife should avoid keeping away from his bed, should act upon his promises, should obey his orders, should avoid leaving his house without his permission, and should avoid inviting to his house those whom he dislikes.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1071, Page No. 151

Verse: etentious poor will (finally) fall into poverty.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2147; Page No. 300

Verse: Verily, God has some servants who are able to know the inner character of people through cleverness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2472.

Verse: It is better for a woman to pray in a room of her house than in the veranda, to pray in the veranda than in the yard, and to pray in the yard than in the mosque.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1081, Page No. 153

Verse: It is better for any one of you to take in a piece of earth than to take in unlawful things.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1082, Page No. 153

Verse: It is better to nail on your head than to touch a woman not legitimate for you.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1083; Page No. 153

Verse: It is blasphemy to dispute about the Quran.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1084, Page No. 153

Verse: It is clear what is lawful and what is unlawful. Thus, keep distance with what you doubt about, and stick to what you don't.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1085, Page No. 153&154

Verse: It is hard for God to put to Hell a Muslim servant who has lost two daughters.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1086; Page No. 154

Verse: Blessed is the one who has a long life, good deeds and a happy ending, for God is pleased with him, and woe to the one who has a long life, evil deeds and an unhappy ending, for God is displeased with him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 342, Page No. 53

Verse: Blessed is the one who is a Muslim with sufficient sustenance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 343; Page No. 53

Verse: Blessed is the one who is guided to Islam, who has sufficient sustenance, and who is contented with it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 344; Page No. 53

Verse: Blessed is the one who suppresses his soul, who is good-mannered, who dispenses the excess of his wealth, who follows (the Prophet's) tradition and who does not leave it for (heretical) innovation.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 345; Page No. 53

Verse: On the Day Judgment, the Exalted God will call (His) believer servant to His presence and while keeping him covered and saved from people and making him acknowledge his sins, asks him questions like this: "Do you know such and such a sin?" The servant answers in the positive and continues doing so until it occurs to his mind that due to his (boundless) sins, he will surely perish. Then, God says: "I covered your sins in the world and I forgive you today", and He places the book of his good deeds in his right hand. As to the disbelievers and hypocrites, He openly states: "these are the ones who belied their Lord. God's damnation be on oppressors.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1499; Page No. 213&214

Verse: On the Day of Judgment when there is no shelter, three groups of people will reside beneath God's shadow: those who are kind to their kin and are thus gifted with increased sustenance and long life, women whose husbands die, leaving them with little orphans, who avoid getting married to bring their children up to maturity or let them die, and those who prepare food to serve their guests in perfect hospitality, calling the poor and orphans to their table the Hereafter to feed them for the sake of the Great and Powerful God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1500; Page No. 214

Verse: One difficulty will not prevail over two reliefs, for "Verily, with every difficulty there are two reliefs", and "Verily, with every difficulty there are two reliefs".
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1501; Page No. 214

Verse: One Dirham will be more valuable than one hundred thousand Dirhams when we compare two men, one of whom having only two Dirhams but giving one in charity, and the other having great wealth but giving one hundred thousand Dirhams of it in charity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1502; Page No. 214&215

Verse: One hour of (doing) justice is superior to one year of worshiping (God).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1503; Page No. 215

Verse: One hour of a learned man, who rests in his bed, meditating about his knowledge is worthier than seventy years of praying by the pious.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1504; Page No. 215

Verse: One night of being on the look-out in the way of God, the Great and Powerful, is better than one thousand nights of praying and one thousand days of keeping fast.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1505; Page No. 215

Verse: One who fights his own self in obedience to God is a (true) struggler in the way of Him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1506; Page No. 215

Verse: One who insists on adultery is like unto an idolater.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1507; Page No. 215

Verse: One who testifies to falsehood will not step in the road before God makes Hell his/her unavoidable abode.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1509; Page No. 215

Verse: One's faith will not get perfected save by three characteristics: giving alms in poverty; doing justice even if it's against one's own self, and greeting (people) a lot.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1510; Page No. 215&216

Verse: One's older brother is like unto his (her) father.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1511; Page No. 216

Verse: Paradise buildings are made of gold and silver bricks, its clay is musk, its sand, pearl and ruby and its soil, saffron. Whoever arrives at it will enjoy its blessings forever, will be free from calamities, will live to eternity, never experiencing death, and will have unending youth and constantly-new dresses.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1518; Page No. 217

Verse: Paradise has a hundred levels, and each level is vast enough for the population of the whole universe.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1519; Page No. 217

Verse: Paradise has a hundred levels, and it takes five hundred years to cover the distance between each two levels.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1520; Page No. 217

Verse: Paradise has a hundred levels, and the distance between each two levels is that of heavens from the earth.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1521; Page No. 218

Verse: Paradise is in pledge of swords.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1522; Page No. 218

Verse: Paradise is the city of the holders of generosity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1523; Page No. 218

Verse: Paradise will be the reward of the one with three daughters, who trains them in good manners, gives them in marriage and is kind to them.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1524; Page No. 218

Verse: Passionate love of the world is the source of all evils.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1525; Page No. 218

Verse: Many a fast person whose fasting avails them naught but hunger, and many a worshiper at night whose prayers avail them naught but vigilance!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1256; Page No. 179

Verse: Many a holder of knowledge who are not deeply knowledgeable! He whose knowledge is of no avail to him, will suffer from his ignorance. Recite the Quran as long as it stops you doing wrong. Should it not befall, it will be as if you have not recited the Quran at all.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1257; Page No. 180

Verse: Many a man are satiated and pleased here but will be hungry and naked (poor) in the Hereafter, and many a man are hungry and naked here, but will be satiated and pleased in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1258; Page No. 180

Verse: Many a man are there who experience humiliation through glorifying themselves, and many a man are there who experience honor by showing humility.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1259; Page No. 180

Verse: Many a man are there whose vigilance at night avails them naught but wakefulness, and many a man are there whose fasting during the day avails them naught but thirst and hunger.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1260; Page No. 180

Verse: Many a man is there who arrive at a day which ends without them or await a tomorrow which never begins.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1261; Page No. 180

Verse: Many a non-fasting, but grateful person who will be rewarded more than fast, patient people!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1262; Page No. 180

Verse: Many a pious person who are ignorant, and many a learned person who are corrupt. Beware of them both!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1263; Page No. 180&181

Verse: Many a time an hour of indulging in lust has resulted in prolong sorrow!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1264; Page No. 181

Verse: Many a wise person who is held in contempt and ugly in face, but will be saved, and many an eminent, beautiful and sweet-tongued person who will be ruined in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1265; Page No. 181

Verse: Many a worshiper at night whose prayers avail them naught but vigilance, and many a fast person whose fasting avails them naught but hunger and thirst!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1266; Page No. 181

Verse: Markets are the worst places of cities.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1267; Page No. 181

Verse: Marry but don't divorce (your wife), for verily the Divine Throne shudders (with anger) when divorce occurs.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1268; Page No. 181

Verse: Marry kind, fertile women, for I pride myself over other prophets for the largeness of your population.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1269; Page No. 181

Verse: Marry women of equal status, and give in marriage (your daughters) to men of equal status with you, thus choosing the appropriate place for your sperms.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1270; Page No. 181

Verse: May God bless a father who gives his child a hand in being kind to him (i.e. his father).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1271; Page No. 181

Verse: May God bless the eyes, which shed tears out of fear of God, and bless the eyes, which keep awake for God's sake.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1272; Page No. 182

Verse: May God damn (curse) the one who makes separation between a mother and her child or between two brothers!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1275; Page No. 182

Verse: May God damn a woman who calls her husband to bed but by denying him immediate sex causes him to fall asleep.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1276; Page No. 182

Verse: May God damn a woman who dresses up like men and a man who dresses up like women.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1277; Page No. 182

Verse: May God damn both sides of a usury affair as well as the one who writes the contract for it, and damn the one who blocks the way to charity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1278; Page No. 182

Verse: May God damn mohallels([1]) and those for whom someone plays the role of a mohallel.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1279; Page No. 182&183

Verse: May God damn the giver and receiver of bribe, as well as the mediator between them!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1280; Page No. 183

Verse: May God damn the giver of bribe as well as its receiver.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1281; Page No. 183

Verse: May God damn the one who makes his face!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1282; Page No. 183

Verse: How nice is lawfully-earned wealth for a pious man!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 933; Page No. 131

Verse: Are you (women) not pleased that when one of you becomes pregnant of her husband and he is satisfied with her, she will be rewarded the reward of the one who keeps fast while struggling in the way of God, and when she gives birth to a child, she will be offered a reward for each drop of milk she produces and for each time her breast is sucked, and if she keeps awake one night to look after her child, she will be given the reward of releasing seventy slaves for God's sake?
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 228, Page No. 38

Verse: As long as a man truly guides those who consult him he continues to enjoy correctness of opinion, but as soon as he starts deceiving them, the Exalted God will deprive him of this blessing.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 229; Page No. 38

Verse: Ascended to me Gabriel and said: "Muhammad! Live as long as you wish, for you will finally perish, love whatever you mind, for you will leave it behind and do whatever you want to do, for its reward will come back to you. Know that night vigilance (for worship) is man's dignity and needlessness from people shows his magnanimity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 230, Page No. 38

Verse: Ask for generosity from the merciful among my people, not from the hardhearted, and live under the protection of the former.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 231; Page No. 38&39

Verse: Ask God (to give you) of His bounties, for he likes asking Him. The best act of worship is looking forward to deliverance (in hard times).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 232; Page No. 39

Verse: Ask God (to give you) useful knowledge, and take refuge with Him from useless knowledge.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 233; Page No. 39

Verse: Ask God for everything, even a shoelace; for should He not wish success, to nothing will you have access.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 234; Page No. 39

Verse: Ask God for good health and cure of all illness here and in the Hereafter, for should you be bestowed with these in this world and in the next, you will be prosperous.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 235; Page No. 39

Verse: Ask God for good health and forgiveness, for apart from certainty, no one has been bestowed with anything better prosperity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 236; Page No. 39

Verse: Ask guidance from the wise to find the straight path, and do not disobey them; otherwise, you will become remorseful.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 237; Page No. 39

Verse: Ask your heart for what's false or true, and let others say whatever they want to.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 238; Page No. 39

Verse: Asking forgiveness (from God) rubs off sins.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 239; Page No. 39

Verse: Asking properly is one half of knowledge.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 240; Page No. 40

Verse: Assign people their due status(value) of good and evil.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 241, Page No. 40

Verse: Assist your brother (in faith), being him an oppressor or oppressed; if the former, keep him away from oppression and if the latter, lend him a hand.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 242; Page No. 40

Verse: Assist your children in doing good, for everybody can save his (her) children from being cursed if (s)he so wishes.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 243; Page No. 40

Verse: Assure me of six things, and I will ensure you of entering Paradise: avoidance of telling lie, avoidance of breaking your promise, keeping away from treachery to trusts, closing your eyes on the unlawful, controlling your hands and restraining your privy parts.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 244; Page No. 40

Verse: Attending the Friday ritual prayer is obligatory for all mature people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 245; Page No. 40

Verse: Attending the weak is paying attention to me, for your sustenance and its support (by God) is for the sake of them.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 246; Page No. 40

Verse: Avail yourself of five things before five other things: youth before oldness, health before illness, wealth before need, convenience before inconvenience and life before death.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 247; Page No. 40&41

Verse: Avail yourself of what God has made available for you.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 248; Page No. 41

Verse: Avoid doing evil to people, for it is charity you give for yourself.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 249; Page No. 41

Verse: Avoid drinking wine, for it is verily the key to all evils.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 250; Page No. 41

Verse: Avoid using (even one piece of) unlawfully-earned stone in (your) building, for the very stone causes its collapse.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 251; Page No. 41

Verse: Avoidance of bidding to good results in disgrace here and Fire in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 252; Page No. 41

Verse: Awaiting betterment (in life), is servitude to God if coupled with patience.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 253; Page No. 41

Verse: Verily, Satan enjoys nearness to man and angels do too. The former suggests (to him) calling to evil and belying the truth, while the latter suggest calling to good and accepting the truth. Thus, whoever feels the second state of affairs should know that it is divine, and whoever finds in himself the first, should take refuge in God from the Satan.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2559.

Verse: Verily, Satan flows like blood in man's body.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2560.

Verse: Verily, Satan sets his throne on water and dispatches his groups (of satans) to every place, and those of whom who give rise to greater seditions are closer to him in residence. Then, one of his servants approaches him with a report of his great achievements, but Satan tells him that he has no great accomplishment. Then, another approaches him and reports of a man whom he has separated from his folk, and so Satan calls him to his close presence and tells him that he has achieved a lot.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2565.

Verse: Verily, satans arrive at bazaars early in the morning with their banners, entering there with those who come earlier and leaving there with those who get out later than others.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2566.

Verse: Verily, sedition prevails to vanquish people, and only the learned can find a way out of it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2567.

Verse: Verily, some people are the key to good and some others, the key to evil. Thus, how good for those on whom God has bestowed the key to good and how bad for those to whom He has given the key to evil.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2568.

Verse: Verily, some sins cannot be wiped out through setting prayer; fasting and making minor or major pilgrimage to Mecca. They can only be wiped out through struggling to earn one's sustenance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2569.

Verse: Verily, some statements are enchanting, some poems contain wisdom, some sayings are defective and some ways of seeking knowledge lead to ignorance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2570.

Verse: Verily, struggling in the way of God is the best of a believer's deeds.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2571.

Verse: Verily, sustenance looks for servants of God more than their death does.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2572.

Verse: Verily, swearing ends either in disregard or regret.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2573.

Verse: Verily, the best (form of) kindness is to make friend with one's dead father's friends.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2574.

Verse: Whoever wishes to be safe, should keep silent.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3133.

Verse: Whoever wishes to be the most beloved of all people to God, should fear Him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3134.

Verse: Do not do in privacy what you like people not to see in you(in public).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 479; Page No. 70

Verse: Do not drink wine, for it's the key to all evils.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 480; Page No. 70

Verse: Do not feed the poor on the things you don't eat yourselves.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 481; Page No. 70

Verse: Do not frighten a Muslim, for it's great injustice.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 482; Page No. 70

Verse: Allah is He who created seven Heavens, and of the earth the like of them; the decree continues to descend among them, that you may know that Allah has power over all things and that Allah indeed encompasses all things in (His) knowledge.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, Part 3, page 54; Surah Talaq 65:12

Verse: "And the stars are made subservient by His commands."
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, Part 3, page 54; Surah Nahl 16:12

Verse: Allah is the One who created milk from the dirty red blood and caused it to flow from the mammary glands of the animals and humans so that it may reach the gullets of infants.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, Part 3, page 55; Surah Nahl 16:66

Verse: When the young ones are not yet capable of digesting solid food it is only milk which nourishes them. And the provider of this milk is Allah. He is the bestower of every benefit.

Verse: Masma bin Abdul Malik relates that Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq (a.s.) was at Mina (in Makkah) when a beggar approached him. Imam (a.s.) ordered that a bunch of grapes be given to him. The beggar said, "I do not need these, if possible give me money." Imam (a.s.) did not give him anything but said, "May Allah make you self-sufficient." After this another beggar approached. Imam (a.s.) picked up three grapes from the bunch and offered them to him. The beggar picked them up and said, "All Praise is for Allah (only) who has given me sustenance." Imam (a.s.) said, "Wait", and he placed as many grapes as his hands could hold. Twice again he gave him the same quantity. The beggar thanked Allah again. Imam (a.s.) again stopped him and asked his slave how much money he had. The slave replied, "Twenty dirhams." Imam (a.s.) ordered him to give these to the beggar. The beggar took the money and said, "All praise is for Allah alone. O Allah You are the sustainer, You are One, there is no partner for You. Imam (a.s.) again stopped him. Then the Imam (a.s.) removed his shirt and gave it to the beggar and said, "Wear it." The beggar put the shirt on and thanked Allah who had bestowed him with the dress and made him happy. At this stage the beggar turned towards Imam (a.s.) and said, "O slave of Allah may Allah reward you for this." After this he went his way. The narrator says that if the beggar had not addressed the Imam (a.s.) as such, Imam (a.s.) would have continued to give him gifts for his thankfulness to Allah.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, Part 3, page 61; Al Kafi

Verse: During the rule of Prophet Sulaiman (a.s.) a male sparrow told its mate, "Why do you stop me from mating? I possess such might that if I want I could pick up the dome of (the palace) of Hazrat Sulaiman (a.s.) and drop it in the river." When Hazrat Sulaiman (a.s.) came to know of this, he summoned both the birds and asked the male bird if he could substantiate his claim by putting it into practice. The bird replied that he had only tried to impress his mate by the false claim. He said that he loved his companion hence could not afford to lose her. When Hazrat Sulaiman (a.s.) asked the female bird for her opinion she said that her suitor did not love her and his affections were for someone else. Upon hearing her grievance Hazrat Sulaiman (a.s.) became remorseful. He retired into his prayer niche and did not come out for forty days. He prayed, "O Allah purify the heart of this male bird from the love of everything except his own mate."
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, Part 3, page 64; Safinatul Behaar

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) relates that Long ago, there was a person who earned lawfully but later could not do so and began to earn unlawfully. However he failed to do that also. Then Shaitaan came to him and said, "You tried to earn lawfully and failed. Then you started earning unlawfully and failed here also. Should I tell you a way by which your wealth will increase along with the number of your lovers?" The person replied, "Why not? Tell me about it." Shaitaan said, "Bring out a new religion and call people towards it." The person did so and people started coming to him in large numbers. Now his worldly life improved a lot. Later he realized what he did was really wrong. First of all, he invented a new religion and invited people towards it. He thought that the only way to repent was to send back whoever comes to him for seeking orders. Next time people came to him, he told them that what he had told was false and the religion they were following was created by him. His followers were not ready to believe him and said, "No, your religion is a true one. It is only that you have started doubting it and want to leave it." That person nailed a chain to ground and tied it around his neck and said, "I will remain in this condition till Allah forgives me." The Almighty Allah sent one of His prophets to him and conveyed the message that He swears by His honor that He is not going to forgive that person even if he repents so much that the joints of his body are separated. If the person wants to be forgiven, he should bring back to life those people who died on his religion."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 324

Verse: "The Almighty Allah has created a house in Paradise as well as in Hell for each and every creature. When the people of Paradise and Hell go to their respective houses, a call will be given out: O people of Paradise! Look down. When the people look down they will see their houses in Hell. They will be told: You would have been given those had you disobeyed Allah. The people of Paradise will die out of happiness for being saved. Then the people of Hell will be told: O people of Hell! Look above your heads. They will lift their heads and look above. They will be able to see their houses filled with bounties in Paradise. They will be told: You would have been given these had you followed the commands of Allah. The people of Hell will die out of the grief. They will be given their respective houses which they deserved. This is the exegesis of the verse of Allah, in which He says: These are they who are the heirs. Who shall inherit the Paradise; they shall abide therein.[Surah Mominoon 23:10-11]"
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 325/326

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that Amirul Momineen (a.s.) said, "There is no relation of doubt and sin with us and the way of doubt and sin does not reach us in any way."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 326

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "If a woman goes out after applying perfume, she will be cursed till the time she returns."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 326

Verse: The narrator went to Imam Husain (a.s.) along with his cousin to greet him. After greeting him and inquiring about his health, the cousin said, "I can see dye applied on your hair. Are your hairs turning white?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "Yes it is the dye which I have applied. We, the Hashemites turn old soon." Then Imam glanced at the narrator and asked, "Have you come for my help?" The narrator replied, "I have become aged and turned old. I have huge loans on my head and I have a large family. I am also having the things of other people with me kept as trust. I don't know what will happen to me if I go with you? I don't want to deprive so many people of their trust." The cousin also gave similar excuses for not accompanying the Imam (a.s.). Upon this, Imam (a.s.) told them, "Go away from this place as if you have not heard me asking for help because one who hears an Imam asking for help and turns a deaf ear, will be thrown headlong into Hell."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 326/327

Verse: "One who takes up the leadership of ten persons and is not able to do justice to them, will come on the Day of Judgment with his hands, feet and head perforated."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 327

Verse: "Allah will destroy one who takes the command of Muslims and destroys it."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 327

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said that A caller will call out on the Day of Judgment, "Where are oppressors and their helpers? Those who bring ink for them, who prepare bags for them and those who hold the pen for them; all are included among their helpers."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 328

Verse: "One who becomes proximate to a king is away from Allah. His wealth might have increased but his accounting will be tough. The number of his followers must have increased but all of them are devils."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 328

Verse: Calamities are rewarded greatly; and should God love a people, He will put them to trial.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 362; Page No. 57

Verse: "Keep away from the doors of the king and his confidants because as a person goes near them, he goes far from Allah. A person who considers the king more important than Allah will continue to lose piety and remain confused and perplexed."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 328

Verse: "One who gets his name entered in the registers of the son of so and so, Allah will resurrect him as a pig on the Day of Judgment."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 328

Verse: "If a ruler does not fulfill the needs of his subjects, Allah will not fulfill his wishes on the Day of Judgment. If the ruler accepts gifts it is betrayal of trust and if he takes bribe, he is a polytheist."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 328/329

Verse: "If some people of a community commit sins and if they are not stopped from doing so, a time will come soon when Allah will send chastisement on all of them."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 329

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "One who is committing sins secretly, it is harmful for that individual himself. However if he is sinning openly and is not being restrained, it is harmful for everyone." Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) said, "It is an insult of Allah's religion. The sinners and their followers are like enemies of Allah."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 329

Verse: "Surely Allah will not send chastisement on all because of the sins of some people until they commit sins secretly and others are not aware of it. However if they sin openly and are not restrained from it, everybody will be deserving of divine chastisement. If an unjust king kills someone out of oppression and enmity or does any other injustice, you should not remain over there. If you are, helping the victim becomes obligatory for you. However there is no responsibility upon you until the innocence of the victim is proved. People of Bani Israel were careless about prohibited deeds. Once a person sinned in front of his brother who advised him not to do so but he turned a deaf ear to his words. This sin did not affect their friendship in any way. At last, Allah put the love of that sin in their hearts and these verses are revealed for those persons: Those who disbelieved from among the children of Israel were cursed by the tongue of Dawood and Isa, son of Maryam; this was because they disobeyed and used to exceed the limit. They used not to forbid each other the hateful things (which) they did; certainly evil was that which they did." [Surah Maidah 5:78-79]
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 329/330

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that There are six kinds of punishments for an adulterer. Three are related to this world and three to the hereafter. The punishments of this world are that the person will continue to lose the brilliance of his face; he will face poverty and die soon. The punishments of hereafter include displeasure of Allah on the Day of judgment, bad accounting of deeds and living in Hell forever.
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 330

Verse: Oppression is (the source of) darkness in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1512; Page No. 216

Verse: Oppression ruins (the value of) bravery; self-pride ruins familial dignity; conferring favors spoils (the worth of) generosity; selfishness ruins (the value of) beauty; telling lie breaks (the validity of) speech; forgetfulness ruins knowledge; ignorance ruins fortitude; extravagance ruins generosity, and carnal desires ruin (one's) faith.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1513; Page No. 216

Verse: Amirul Momineen (a.s.) relates that The Almighty Allah will spread a foul stench in the air on the Day of Judgment. This stench will irritate everyone assembled over there to an extent that people will start suffocating because of it. A caller will ask, "Do you know from where this stench is coming which is troubling you so much?" People will reply, "We don't know from where it is coming but we know that it is very suffocating indeed." They will be told, "This is the smell of the genitals of adulterers. Those who committed adultery and passed away from the world without repenting. May Allah's curse be upon them. You all should curse them." Each and everyone gathered over there will say, "May Allah's curse be upon them."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 330

Verse: The narrator was with Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) when Imam (a.s.) was asked, "Is an adulterer a believer at the time of committing that sin?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "When he is committing the sin, faith is taken away from him and returned to him after the act." Imam was asked, "What about one who wants to commit the sin once again?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "In most cases, even if people try to do so they are not able to."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 331

Verse: "A person who memorizes the Holy Quran and obeys its commandments is in the group of senior angels."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 142

Verse: "One who tries to memorize the Holy Quran with extreme difficulty due to a weak memory will get two rewards." He further said, "Why don't the people who trade in markets whole day not recite a Surah when they return to their homes at night before going to bed? If they do so they would get ten rewards for each verse and ten sins will be wiped off."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 143

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) says that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) was asked, "Who is the best of men?" The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) replied, "One who comes and goes." He was again asked, "What is meant by one who comes and goes?" He replied, "One who starts and ends. One who starts reciting the Holy Quran and ends it. There is no one nearer to Allah than him and his supplications are accepted."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 143

Verse: "The reciter of the Holy Quran is rich; there is no misery for him and one who does not recite the Holy Quran is not rich."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 143

Verse: "One who recites the Holy Quran by looking at it, his eyes will become stronger and the chastisement of his parents would be reduced even if they had been disbelievers."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 143/144

Verse: "There is nothing more severe for Satan except a person reciting the Holy Quran by looking at it."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 144

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that his father said, "I like keeping the Holy Quran at home. Allah keeps Satan away from the house because of it."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 144

Verse: Our Lord laughs (amazingly) at His creatures' hopelessness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1514; Page No. 216

Verse: Out of mercy is shedding tears and out of Satan, shouting.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1515; Page No. 216

Verse: Paradise belongs to the penitent, and (Divine) Mercy to men of endowment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1516; Page No. 217

Verse: Paradise beneath mothers' steps lies.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1517; Page No. 217

Verse: Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) says that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "One who recites ten verses of the Holy Quran at night won't be included among the ignorant ones. One who recites fifty verses would be included among those who remember Allah much. One who recites a hundred verses would be included among those who perform Qunoot. One who recites two hundred verses would be included among Khashi-in (most humble). One who recites three hundred verses would be included among successful people. One who recites five hundred verses would be included among Mujtahideen (Holy warriors). One who recites a thousand verses would get the reward of one Qintar and a single Qintar is worth fifteen thousand Mithqal gold and a single Mithqal comprises of twenty-four Qirat and the smallest Qirat is equal to Mount Ohad and the biggest Qirat is equal to the distance between the earth and the heaven."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 144/145

Verse: "There is a best season for everything and the best season of reciting the Holy Quran is the month of Ramadan."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 145

Verse: "One who says Yaa Allaah seven times after reciting a hundred verses of the Holy Quran from anywhere, even if he prays against Sakhr (a stone) it would be dislodged from its place."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 145

Verse: "The Greatest Name of Allah is in Ummul Kitab (source of the book) i.e. Surah Hamd."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 145

Verse: "One who recites Surah Baqarah and Surah Aale Imran, these Surahs will cover him like a cloud on the Day of Judgment."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 145

Verse: Imam Zainul Abideen (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "One who recites the first four verses of Surah Baqarah, Ayatal Kursi and two verses which follow it and the last three verses of this Surah he and his wealth would remain safe from all calamities. Satan would not come near him and he will never forget the Holy Quran."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 145/146

Verse: "One who recites Ayatal Kursi before going to bed would remain safe of Paralysis and one recites it after every Salaat no poison would harm him."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 146

Verse: "One who recites Surah Nisa every Friday would remain safe from the squeeze of the grave."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 146

Verse: "One who recites Surah Maidah every Thursday, his faith will never wear the clothes of injustice and he would never commit polytheism."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 146

Verse: One who recites Surah Anaam every night would remain safe on the Day of Judgment and would never see the fire of Hell
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 146

Verse: "Surah Anaam was revealed whole at once. Seventy thousand angels kept watch on it when it was revealed on Muhammad (s.a.w.s.). Hence it should be regarded as an honored Surah and must be respected. If people had known what is there in it they would have never ignored it."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 146/147

Verse: "One who recites Surah Araaf once every month would be included among those for whom there is no fear or sorrow on the Day of Judgment. One who recites it every Friday would be included among those for whom there is no accounting on the Day of Judgment. Know that one of the Muhkamat (clear verses) of the Holy Quran is present in this Surah and it will bear witness on the Day of Judgment for the reciter."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 147

Verse: "One who recites Surah Anfaal and Surah Taubah every month would never get involved in hypocrisy and would be among the Shias of Amirul Momineen (a.s.)."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 147

Verse: "One who recites Surah Yunus every two to three months would never have fear that he is ignorant and he would be included among the near ones on the Day of Judgment."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 147
