Didn't I reply you last time? Drinking wine forces a person to commit adultery, theft, murder and polytheism. The effects of wine are more than any other sin just like its tree is taller than other trees."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 308/309

Verse: The narrator told Imam Reza (a.s.), "Ibne Dadhuya says that you told him: 'A drunkard is a polytheist'?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "He is right and I had told him that
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 309

Verse: The narrator asked Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) regarding alcohol (Khunsa). Imam (a.s.) replied, "Khunsa is prohibited and one who drinks it, is like one who drinks wine."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 309

Verse: "A person who eats mud may suffer from white spots and piles. A number of diseases affect him and the strength of his legs continues to reduce. The good deeds performed before eating mud will be rejected and his accounting of good deeds will be from those which are performed after this act. He will receive a lot of punishment as a result."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 309

Verse: "Most of the evil thoughts are due to eating mud. Surely, eating mud causes many diseases. It makes a person ill soon and the strength present before no longer remains in the body. Good deeds performed by him earlier are deducted. Deeds performed by him during his weakness and strength will be accounted for and he will be involved in chastisement."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 309

Verse: Verily Allah loves the young man who spends his entire youth in the obedience of Allah.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 43060; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1030

Verse: A believer does his best in what his ability demands, but craves for what beyond his power stands.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1; Page No. 9

Verse: A believer does not resort to jealousy or flattery, save in seeking knowledge.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2; Page No. 9

Verse: A believer has all kinds of natures save treachery and telling lie.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3; Page No. 9

Verse: A believer has four enemies: a jealous believer, a detesting hypocrite, a deviating satan, and a hostile infidel.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 4; Page No. 9

Verse: A believer is a servant of God who doesn't oppress his enemies nor does he commit sins for the sake of his friends,who keeps trusts intact and refrains jealousy, sarcasm and cursing others, who tells the truth though not called to bear witness and calls not people with bad names, who observes humility in prayers, hastens in paying his due alms, keeps patient in calamities and thanks (God) in affluence, who is content with what he has and claims not what he doesn't, who doesn't stop doing good deeds due to misery, who keeps company with people to learn and talks to them something to earn, and who forebears oppression and tyranny, awaiting the merciful God to give him victory.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 5; Page No. 9 & 10

Verse: A believer is in a good state all the time; even when he is on the verge of death, he praises God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 6; Page No. 10

Verse: A believer is like unto a bar of gold, getting reddened when breathed upon and losing nothing when weighed.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 7; Page No. 10

Verse: A believer is like unto a date palm; whatever you take from it will be to your benefit.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 8; Page No. 10

Verse: A group of the people of Paradise will get worried about some of the people of Hell, and will (therefore) inquire: "Why are you in Hell? By God, we did not enter Paradise save through what we learned from you". The Hell-bound reply: "We did not practice what we preached."
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 70, Page No. 18

Verse: A group of you will always resort to begging till they(finally) meet God, with no flesh in their faces.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 71, Page No. 18

Verse: A guest carries his/her own sustenance, removes the host's sins and cause them to vanish.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 72; Page No. 18

Verse: A guest is a guest for three days; the more s(he) stays, will s(he) be under charity (to the poor); and thus, a guest should leave his host's home after three days.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 73; Page No. 18

Verse: A guide to goodness is like unto its doer, and God loves helping the poor.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 74; Page No. 18

Verse: A heart with no sign of wisdom is like unto a ruined house. So, learn and teach, meditate deeply, and try not to die in ignorance, for God will not pardon people for ignorance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 75; Page No. 18

Verse: A house wherein children (we) miss, is bereft of bliss.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 76; Page No. 19

Verse: A house wherein they recite the Quran is as (bright) to the dwellers of the heavens as are the stars to the dwellers of the earth.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 77, Page No. 19

Verse: A hypocrite is devoid of two traits: reputation and deep knowledge of religion.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 78; Page No. 19

Verse: A hypocrite is known by three characteristics: s(he) tells lie, breaks his (her) promise and commits treachery in trusts.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 79; Page No. 19

Verse: A hypocrite is like unto a goat, wandering between two flocks (of sheep).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 80; Page No. 19

Verse: A hypocrite is the one who humiliates the learned, just leaders and those who have grown old in their struggles for the cause of Islam.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 81; Page No. 19

Verse: A hypocrite rules over his own eyes, shedding tears as he wishes.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 82; Page No. 19

Verse: A journey for the sake of God is superior to making fifty pilgrimages to Mecca.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 83; Page No. 19

Verse: A just and humble leader is God's shade and blade on the earth, for whom the rewards of seventy sincere ones will be saved.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 84; Page No. 19&20

Verse: A just and most magnanimous man who must be observed in brotherhood and must not be backbited, is the one who treats people with justice, speaks to them in truth and does not break his promises.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 85; Page No. 20

Verse: A just leader is God's shade on the earth. Whoever keeps him in honor will be kept in honor by God, and whoever disrespects him will be disrespected by Him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 86; Page No. 20

Verse: A just leader is God's shade on the earth, to whom resort the weak, and whose assistance the oppressed seek.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 87; Page No. 20

Verse: A just leader is God's shade on the earth; and so, when one of you arrives at a place wherein there is no such leader, he should avoid staying there.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 88; Page No. 20

Verse: A learned man's sleep is better than the prayer of a devout.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 89; Page No. 20

Verse: A little bit of action accompanied by knowledge is useful, and a lot of deeds followed by ignorance is of no use.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 90; Page No. 20

Verse: A little chance (opportunity to do good deeds)is better than much intellect. Intellect is the cause of loss in worldly and that of pleasure in otherworldly affairs.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 91; Page No. 20&21

Verse: A little child's memory is like unto a picture carved on stone, and an adult's is like unto something written on water.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 92; Page No. 21

Verse: The head of a people is their servant and cupbearer, and should thus drink last.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2042; Page No. 286&287

Verse: The heart of sons of Adam is more flexible (changeable) than a boiling pot.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2043; Page No. 287

Verse: The hidden weighs over the manifest, but the manifest will be better if one does it as ka pattern (for others).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2044; Page No. 287

Verse: The highest degree of calamity is the least patient to be.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2045; Page No. 287

Verse: The highest degree of calamity is to have a large family in a state of poverty.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2046; Page No. 287

Verse: The highest status in Islam is struggling in the way of God, which is not achieved save by the best Muslims.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2047; Page No. 287

Verse: The honor of three groups of people is not to be observed: those who commit vice in public, tyrant leaders and heretics.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2048; Page No. 287

Verse: The Hour (Resurrection) is subsequent to the prevalence of three things: Constructions are ruined and ruins are settled in, good is considered as evil and evil as good, and trusts are played with just as trees are played with by camels.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2049; Page No. 287

Verse: The Hour has come indoor, and people's greed for the world has grown more and more, but the world moves away from them all the more.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2050; Page No. 287&288

Verse: The Hour will not come until children turn out to be the cause of (their parents') anger, the noble decrease and the ignoble increase in number, the youth become rude to the elderly, and the ignoble revolt against the noble.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2051; Page No. 288

Verse: The ignorant generous is more beloved to God, than the knowledgeable miser.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2058; Page No. 288

Verse: The ill-tempered will face torment, the sorrowful will suffer physical pain, and the contentious will encounter loss of greatness and generosity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2059; Page No. 289

Verse: The ill-tempered will not be allowed to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2060; Page No. 289

Verse: The impolite is unwise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2061; Page No. 289

Verse: The jealous enjoy (the world) less than others.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2062; Page No. 289

Verse: The justest of all people is he who likes for himself what he likes for others and dislikes for others what he dislikes for himself.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2063; Page No. 289

Verse: The knowledge not taught is a treasure not used.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2064; Page No. 289

Verse: Get married, but do not divorce your wives, for God surely detests men and women who marry a lot.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 665; Page No. 97

Verse: Get married, for I pride myself over other nations for the largeness of your population, and do not follow the path of Christian monks.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 666; Page No. 97

Verse: The lawful and the unlawful are crystal clear, but between them lie dubious things of which most people are unaware. Whoever refrains from the doubtful will keep his faith and face intact, and whoever falls into them, will indulge in the unlawful, just as a shepherd who pastures his cattle around a preserved field might find himself on it. Know that just as a king has restrictions, the Exalted God has restrictions, i.e. what He has made unlawful. Knowthat in man's body there is a lump of flesh which if rectified, the whole body will enjoy rectification, and if corrupted, the whole body will suffer corruption. That's man's heart'.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2065; Page No. 289&290

Verse: People will face a time when holding fast to one's faith will be as hard as holding burning fire in one's hands.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1553; Page No. 221

Verse: People will not perish till they are forgiven.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1554; Page No. 221

Verse: People will not perish unless they are given a final warning.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1555; Page No. 221

Verse: Perfect bravery is to get extremely furious, with reddened face and trembling hair, but still managing to quench one's fury.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1556; Page No. 221

Verse: Perfect kindness lies in doing in privacy what you do among the public.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1557; Page No. 221&222

Verse: Perform acts of worship to the extent of your ability, for weariness in you will annoy God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1558; Page No. 222

Verse: Piety stands at the peak of all deeds.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1559; Page No. 222

Verse: Piety suffices to show man's sagacity and self-conceit, to show his ignorance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1560; Page No. 222

Verse: Pilgrimage to Mecca is Jihad (struggling in the way of God) for the weak, and a woman's Jihad is to take care of her husband well.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1561; Page No. 222

Verse: Pleasing and displeasing God rest on pleasing and displeasing one's own father.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1562; Page No. 222

Verse: Pleasing and displeasing God rest on pleasing and displeasing one's own parents.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1563; Page No. 222

Verse: Poetry is a piece of discourse - it can be either a good or a bad one.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1564; Page No. 222

Verse: Polytheism among my people is more concealed than an ant's movement on Mount Safa at dark night, and the closest thing to it is to like a bit of injustice and dislike a bit of justice, for isn't religion but liking and disliking for God's sake? The Exalted God says: "Say, if you love God, obey me, and so He will love you".
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1565; Page No. 222

Verse: Poverty is a believer's gift in this world.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1566; Page No. 223

Verse: Poverty is a trust and an act of worship, if not revealed.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1567; Page No. 223

Verse: Poverty is humiliation to people, but beauty to God in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1568; Page No. 223

Verse: Practice by truth though you see in it your destruction, for in reality it brings you prosperity, and refrain from falsehood though you see in it your prosperity, for it surely results in your destruction.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1569; Page No. 223

Verse: Practice divine precepts, refrain from the unlawful and be content with your divine lot in order to be respectively the most worshipping, the most abstinent and the most needless servant of God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1570; Page No. 223

Verse: Practice shooting, for it's among your best endeavors.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1571; Page No. 223

Verse: Praise your (dead) children, for they are your pioneers.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1572; Page No. 223

Verse: Praising (people) other than one's own parents and just leaders is not allowed, and kindness to people other than religious and noble men is not permissible.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1573; Page No. 223&224

Verse: Pray to (your) Lord a lot, for it stops the occurrence of your destined lot.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1574; Page No. 224

Verse: Prayer blackens Satan's face, charity breaks his back and loving for God's sake demolishes him. If you act upon the last one, he will keep aloof from you as far as East from West.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1575; Page No. 224

Verse: Prayer in a sitting position is half a prayer in a standing position.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1576; Page No. 224

Verse: Prayer is a believer's light.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1577; Page No. 224

Verse: Prayer is a key to (God's) mercy, ablution is a key to prayer, and prayer is a key to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1578; Page No. 224

Verse: Prayer is like unto a scale, whoever sets it properly, will earn perfect reward.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1579; Page No. 224

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God loves His sensitive zealous servants.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2644.

Verse: Verily, the Exalted God loves moderateness in all affairs.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2645.

Verse: Gabriel came to me and said: "Give your people good tidings that whoever does not adopt a partner for God, will enter Paradise after death". I said: "What if s(he) has committed theft or adultery", and I repeated it thrice, but the answer was in the positive and Gabriel added, "even if (s)he has drunk wine."
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 660, Page No. 96

Verse: Generosity is a heavenly tree with branches hanging over the earth, leading to Paradise whoever clings to one of them, and miserliness is a hellish tree with branches hanging over the earth, directing to Fire whoever touches one/of them.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 661; Page No. 96

Verse: Generosity is God's outstanding attribute.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 662; Page No. 97

Verse: Get accustomed to grief, for it's the light of man's heart. Keep yourself hungry and thirsty.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 663; Page No. 97

Verse: Get married and increase in number, for I will pride myself in you over other nations in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 664; Page No. 97

Verse: Get married, for women bring you wealth.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 667; Page No. 97

Verse: Gifts are sustenance from God; and so, whoever is offered a gift should accept it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 668; Page No. 97

Verse: Gifts blind men of wisdom.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 669; Page No. 97

Verse: Gifts impair ears, eyes and hearts.

Verse: Girls' consent (in marriage) should be sought from their fathers, and silence is their consent.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 671; Page No. 97

Verse: Give alms, for a time may come to pass when man manages to give something on charity, but the one who is supposed to get it will say, "I would have accepted it if you had brought it yesterday. Today, I am no more in need of it." and thus he will find nobody to accept it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 672; Page No. 98

Verse: Give alms, for it surely releases you from the Fire.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 673; Page No. 98

Verse: Give alms, though a date it might be, for it drops one's hunger and puts out (the fire of) sin just as water makes fire extinguished.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 674; Page No. 98

Verse: Give good tidings to the poor believers that in the Day of Judgment, they will get rid (of the trial) five hundred years earlier than the rich-the former residing in Paradise, benefiting from God's blessings, and the latter being called to account.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 675; Page No. 98

Verse: Give good tidings to those who move towards mosques in the darkness of night that theirs will be full brightness in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 676; Page No. 98

Verse: Give something to a beggar, even if it is half a date (petty).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 677; Page No. 98

Verse: The narrator went to visit Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.). During the discussion, Imam (a.s.) said, "One who usurps the property of an orphan, the Almighty Allah will appoint an oppressor over him or his children. Surely the Almighty Allah has said: And let those fear who, should they leave behind them weakly offspring, would fear on their account, so let them be careful of (their duty to) Allah, and let them speak right words." [Surah Nisa 4:9]
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 296

Verse: The narrator asked Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) regarding the verse: they shall have that whereof they were niggardly made to cleave to their necks on the resurrection day [Surah Aale Imran 3:180]. Imam (a.s.) replied, "For one who does not pay Zakat from his wealth, the Almighty Allah will make a serpent of fire from that wealth and put it around the neck of that person on the Day of Judgment. This serpent will sting the person continuously till the time he is giving account of his deeds. According to that verse, acting miserly in spending wealth means non payment of Zakat."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 296

Verse: "Surely some people will have their hands tied behind their necks when they are brought out of the graves on the Day of Judgment. They will not have the strength to hold the lightest thing. Some angels will accompany them torturing them severely and saying: These are the people who did not do any good from the abundance. Allah had given a lot to these people but they did not pay Allah's share from their wealth."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 296/297

Verse: "One who owns gold and silver and does not pay Zakat; the Almighty Allah will do the accounting of his deeds in a barren desert on the Day of Judgment. He will appoint a serpent whose venom would have reached its hair from its head. The serpent will follow the person who will try to run away. However when he comes to know that it is difficult to save himself from the serpent, the person will try to defend himself using his hands. The serpent will pounce upon him within the twinkling of an eye and shackle him by his neck. This is in accordance with the saying of Allah: they shall have that whereof they were niggardly made to cleave to their necks on the resurrection day [Surah Aale Imran 3:180]. Similarly one who owns camels, cows, sheep and goats and does not pay Zakat, the Almighty Allah will capture him in a barren desert. Every poisonous creature present over there will sting him. Similarly one who owns dates, grapes and farms and does not pay Zakat, the Almighty Allah will shackle him in the ring made as large as the seven layers of the earth."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 297

Verse: Once a person sent the narrator to Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.). This person used to murmur in his sleep out of fear of a woman. His voice used to increase so much that it reached the neighbors. Imam (a.s.) told the narrator to go and ask that person whether he had avoided paying Zakat. The person replied, "By Allah! I pay Zakat regularly." Imam (a.s.) told the narrator to convey that he pays Zakat regularly but does not give it to those who are eligible.
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 297/298..

Verse: It is narrated that Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) said that One who does not pay Zakat, will desire to return to this world once again after his death. This verse of the Holy Quran points out the same fact: Until when death overtakes one of them, he says: Send me back, my Lord, send me back; Haply I may do good in that which I have left.[Surah Mominoon 23:99-100]"
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 298

Verse: The Hour will not come until virtue and piety turn out to be pretentious(in nature).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2055; Page No. 288

Verse: "There are two sins in Islam whose punishment will not be given in this world before the reappearance of Imam-e-Zamana. One of them is stoning a fornicator who is married and another is breaking the neck of the person who does not pay Zakat."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 298

Verse: "One who does not pay Zakat throughout his life, will desire to return to this world at the time of his death. One who avoids payment of a penny of Zakat and he dies, he has an option i.e. to die as a Jew or as a Christian."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 298

Verse: It is narrated from an infallible that One who avoids payment of a single penny of Zakat and he dies, he will not be considered a Muslim or a believer. Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) said, "One who pays Zakat, his wealth will never be wasted neither on land nor in the sea. When the Qaim of the progeny of Muhammad reappears, he will cut off the heads of those who do not pay Zakat."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 298

Verse: "One who is needy and does not accept Zakat, is like one on whom Zakat has become obligatory and he is not paying it."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 299

Verse: Whoever regularly recites "Surah Li Ilafe Quraishin", Allah would raise him on the Day of Judgment making him ride a vehicle of Paradise; so much so that on the Day of Judgment that man would sit on a brilliant and shining throne of Paradise.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 171

Verse: "Recite Surah Feel and Quraish together in a rakat of an obligatory prayer because they are considered a single Surah. Hence it is not permissible to recite only one of them in an obligatory prayer."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 171

Verse: Whoever recites Surah Maoon in his obligatory and optional prayers would be among those whose prayers and fasts are accepted by Allah, the Mighty and the Sublime, and that man would not be subjected to reckoning for whatever he has done in the world.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 172

Verse: Whoever recites Surah Kauthar in his obligatory and recommended prayers, Allah would give him to drink from Kauthar on the Day of Judgment and he would be of those who had been with the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w.s.) under the shade of the tree (of Paradise) Tooba.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 172

Verse: Whoever recites Surah Kafiroon and Surah Tauheed in one of his obligatory prayers, Allah grants forgiveness for him, for his parents and for his children, and if his name is written in the register of unfortunate and disobedient persons, then after erasing it He writes in it the register of virtuous and happy people and Allah would grant him the death of a martyr and raise him on the Day of Judgment with the martyrs.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 172

Verse: "One who recites Surah Nasr in his obligatory or recommended prayers Allah will give him conquest over all enemies and he will have a talking book with him on the Day of Judgment. He will have protection against the bridge, fire and fiery voices of Hell when Allah resurrects him from grave. Every person meeting him will congratulate and give him glad tidings till he enters Paradise. A number of doors of goodness will be opened for him in this world so much that he would never have imagined or desired."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 172/173

Verse: "Whenever you recite Surah Lahab, curse Abu Lahab without fail because he was such a liar that he had denied the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) and whatever was revealed upon him."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 173

Verse: "One who offers five times prayer daily but does not recite Surah Tauheed would be told, 'O servant of Allah! You are not a reciter of Salaat'?"
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 173

Verse: "One who dies on Friday without having recited Surah Tauheed has died having faith on the religion of Abu Lahab."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 173

Verse: "One who is involved in some sort of disease or problem and dies without reciting Surah Tauheed is condemned to Hell."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 173

Verse: "One who has faith on Allah and the Day of Judgment it is necessary for him to recite Surah Tauheed in his obligatory prayers. If a person does so Allah will grant him goodness in this world and the hereafter and will forgive him, his parents and his children."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 173

Verse: It is narrated from Amirul Momineen (a.s.) that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "One who recites Surah Tauheed a hundred times before going to bed, Allah will forgive sins committed by him in the past fifty years."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 174

Verse: A giving hand is better than a receiving hand, and start charity at home.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 66; Page No. 17

Verse: Whoever is merciless towards his subjects, will not receive God's permission to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3029.

Verse: It is narrated from Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) through his predecessors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) offered funeral prayer of Saad bin Maaz and said, "His funeral prayer was attended by ninety thousand angels accompanied by Jibraeel (a.s.). I asked Jibraeel (a.s.), 'Why did you people attend this funeral prayer?' Jibraeel (a.s.) replied, 'He used to recite Surah Tauheed while standing or sitting, riding or walking and while coming and going'."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 174

Verse: "One who recites Surah Tauheed eleven times before going to bed Allah will protect his house along with all the neighboring houses."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 174

Verse: "One who recites Surah Qul huwallaahu ah'ad eleven times after Morning Prayer won't commit any sin during that day even if the Satan tries hard. In this way, the Satan will be disgraced."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 174

Verse: "One who recites Surah Tauheed before meeting an unjust person, Allah will protect him from all sides and he will remain safe from the mischief of that unjust person. He will benefit from meeting that unjust person. Whenever you develop fear of something, recite a hundred verses of the Holy Quran and say, 'O Allah! Take this calamity away from me' thrice."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 174

Verse: It is narrated from Hafs bin Ghiyas that Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) asked someone" Do you like to remain alive in this world?" The person replied, "Yes" Imam (a.s.) asked, "Why?" He responded, "Because I recite Surah Tauheed." After some time Imam (a.s.) said, "O Hafs! One from our Shias who dies without having a good knowledge of recitation of the Holy Quran, is taught the Holy Quran in grave so that Allah grants him great ranks. Know that the levels of Paradise are equal to the number of verses in the Holy Quran. A reciter of the Holy Quran is told over there, 'Recite a verse of the Holy Quran and go to the next level'."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 174/175

Verse: One who recites in Watr Prayer Surah Falaq and Surah Naas with Surah Tauheed, it is said to him: O Servant of Allah! Congratulations! Allah has accepted your Midnight Prayer.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 175

Verse: The Hour will only come for (the judgment) of the wicked.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2056; Page No. 288

Verse: The narrator asked Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) the meaning of the verse 'If you shun the great sins which you are forbidden, We will do away with your small' [Surah Nisa 4:31]. Imam (a.s.) replied, "One who keeps away from such sins due to which Allah throws one in Hell, Allah will forgive his sins and make him enter a good place (Paradise). There are seven greater sins, which condemn a person to Hell   killing an innocent, disobeying parents, taking interest, apostasy, accusing a virtuous woman of adultery, usurping the property of orphans and running away from Jihad."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 175

Verse: Imam Reza (a.s.) says regarding the verse 'If you shun the great sins which you are forbidden, We will do away with your small, [Surah Nisa 4:31]. "One who abstains from those sins for which Allah has promised Hell, Allah will forgive his (lesser) sins."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 175/176

Verse: "Allah revealed onto Prophet Dawood, 'O Dawood! If a believer commits sins and repents for it and feels ashamed in front of Me while repenting I forgive him. I will make the angel forget this sin and convert this sin into a good deed. I do not care (it is not difficult for me) for I am the Most Merciful'."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 176

Verse: Imam Musa Kazim (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "One who takes a loanee to a ruler and he knows that he has taken a false oath; but due to the sake of the respect of Allah, the Mighty and Sublime, he condones the loanee, Allah would not be satisfied with nothing less than giving him the position of Ibrahim, the friend of the Beneficent."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 176

Verse: "Every animal walking on this earth, fishes of oceans and every small and big thing in the earth and the heaven repents for a good teacher."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 176

Verse: "A single scholar is better than one thousand worshippers and one thousand people who repent. If people benefit from the knowledge of a scholar he is better than seventy thousand worshippers."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 176/177

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "One who walks on the way to seek knowledge, Allah will make him walk on the way to Paradise. Angels spread their wings for the pleasure of a student and every thing in the earth and the heaven including the fishes of oceans repent for him. A scholar is better than a worshipper much in the same way as a full moon is compared to stars. The scholars are inheritors of the prophets and the value of inheritance of prophets is measured in terms of knowledge instead of wealth. Whoever got a little of their inheritance has achieved a lot." Whoever got a little of their inheritance has achieved a lot."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 177

Verse: "No day or night of a scholar ends until he enters the Mercy of Allah. The angels call out, 'Congratulations, O visitor of Allah! The way, which you are seeking, is the way to Paradise'."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 177

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, ""One who sits with religious people will be honored in the world and the hereafter."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 177

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 297; Mustadrakul Wasael

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 297; Mustanad al Taraqi

Verse: Singing creates hypocrisy and causes poverty.

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Sixteenth Greater Sin ,page 13

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Sixteenth Greater Sin ,page 13; Furu Al Kafi

VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Sixteenth Greater Sin ,page 13

Verse: One who avoids songs shall be provided by Allah, a tree, which will produce such a melodious sound as has never been heard by anyone. But the one who has not kept himself aloof from songs will not be able to hear this sound
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Sixteenth Greater Sin ,page 13; Al Kafi

Verse: The following tradition of Allah's Messenger (s.a.w.s.) is recorded in the book Tafseer Majmaul Bayan,

Verse: Hazrat Dawood (a.s.) will be the chief of the singers of Paradise.

Verse: Singing is the stepping stone to fornication."

Verse: And all those wasteful pastimes are haraam which make one forgetful of Allah; like songs and playing musical instruments

Verse: The gravest of the grave sins is love of the world.

Verse: Searching for what will improve you is not considered love of the world.

Verse: The world is not trouble-free for the believer, how can it be when it is his prison and his trial?

Verse: Mourning (for the dead) is an act of ignorance.

Verse: "I seek immunity from Allah regarding one who offers full prayers (4 rakats) while traveling
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 348

Verse: Your Lord addresses you, saying, 'O son of Adam! Devote yourself exclusively to My worship and I will fill your heart with wealth and your hands with ready sustenance. O son of Adam! Do not distance yourself from Me or I will fill your heart with poverty and your hands with work [to preoccupy you].
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 43614; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1012

Verse: Worship Allah as if you see Him, for although you may not see Him, indeed He sees you.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5250; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1013

Verse: The prosperous one is he who prospered from when he was in his mother's womb, and the wretched one is he who was wretched from when he was in his mother's womb.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 491; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1018

Verse: The most wretched of all wretched people is he who faces both poverty in this world as well as punishment in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16683; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1019

Verse: Beware of wrongdoing for verily it corrupts your hearts.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 7639; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1020

Verse: The wrath of Allah is indeed severe on one who wrongs somebody that has no one to help him apart from Allah.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 7605; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1023

Verse: Be on your guard against the plea [to Allah] of one who has been wronged, for verily he asks Allah his right, and verily Allah never denies a right to one whom it is due.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 7597; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1027

Verse: Be on your guard against the plea of one who has been wronged, even if he be a disbeliever, for verily there is no veil preventing his plea from being answered.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 7602; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1027

Verse: The best of your youth are those who act like the old from among you, and the worst of your old ones are those who act like your youth.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 43058; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1028

Verse: Verily Allah, most High, boasts about the worshipping young man to His angels, saying, 'Look at My servant! He has abandoned his desires for My sake.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 43057; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1029

Verse: Verily Allah, most High, loves the penitent young man.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 10185; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1030

Verse: The superiority of a young worshipper who worships Allah in his youth over an old man who worships after he has grown old, is as the superiority of the prophets over the rest of people.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 43059; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 1030

Verse: A believer is like unto a perfumer who will benefit you, should you keep company with him,or move along with him, or be a partner to him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 9; Page No. 10

Verse: A believer is like unto a sieve, receiving nothing but clean and passing nothing but pure.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 10; Page No. 10

Verse: A believer is like unto a stalk bending to all sides by winds but staying calm and static when winds vanish. Blights make a believer bend in same manner. The wicked (on the contrary) is like unto a spruce-fir standing firm and straight till the Exalted God destroys it should He wish.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 11; Page No. 10 & 11

Verse: A good companion is like unto a perfume-seller who might spare you any perfume, but the pleasant fragrance of his perfumes you (can surely) smell, and a bad companion is like unto a blacksmith whose flame of fire you might be able to escape but you surely suffer the bad smell of his working place.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 67; Page No. 17

Verse: A good deed is recorded for whoever removes a stone from people's path.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 68; Page No. 17&18

Verse: A group of my people will always stick to truth for God's decree to be issued.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 69; Page No. 18

Verse: Be steadfast, and how nice is your steadfastness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 301; Page No. 48

Verse: Be truthful, for truthfulness is surely a path to Paradise, and avoid lying for it's verily a way to Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 302; Page No. 48

Verse: Be truthful, for truthfulness will surely lead you to kindness which will (in turn) lead you to Paradise, and man constantly tells and seeks the truth till he is (finally) considered truthful before God, and avoid telling lie, for it will surely lead you to wickedness which will (in turn) lead you to Hell, and man constantly tells lie and seeks falsehood till he is (finally) considered a (great) liar in the sight of God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 303; Page No. 48

Verse: Beautiful hair and visage, (material) properties, and good language are among man's wealth.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 304; Page No. 48

Verse: Beautify your dresses and improve your tools to shine as a star among people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 305, Page No. 48

Verse: Beauty is to speak well based on truth, and perfection is to act well based on honesty.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 306, Page No. 48&49

Verse: Begin (your affairs) with what God has begun with.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 307; Page No. 49

Verse: Be on your guard against sins and restrain yourself from them, for verily the wretched one is he who gives himself free rein to them.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4499; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1018

Verse: Verily Allah, Mighty and Exalted, created prosperity and wretchedness before He even created His creation. So whoever Allah knows will be prosperous, He will never despise, and even when he commits an evil deed, He will despise the deed but not the person. And if He knows that someone will be wretched, He will never love him, and even when he performs a good deed, He will love the deed but despise the person because of what he is to become.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 357, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1018

Verse: Verily Allah, Blessed and most High, may transfer a servant from wretchedness to prosperity, but He never transfers anyone from prosperity to wretchedness.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 358, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1018

Verse: A Little knowledge is better than praying much. Worshipping God suffices to show one's knowledge and selfish judgment is enough to show his ignorance. People are two groups: the faithful and the ignorant. Do not annoy the former and do not be a company to the latter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 93; Page No. 21

Verse: A little sufficient thing is better than a lot making one negligent.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 94; Page No. 21

Verse: Whoever calls on diviners or soothsayers and confirm their sayings, has (actually) denied what has been descended on Muhammad.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2921.

Verse: Whoever calls people to corruption will carry the same (burden of) sins as his followers, without any reduction befalling to the latter's burdens, and whoever calls people to guidance will enjoy the same rewards as his followers', without any reduction befalling to the latter's rewards.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2922.

Verse: Whoever carries his own goods, is devoid of vanity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2923.

Verse: Whoever casts a kind look at his brother(in faith), with no animosity in the heart, will be purged from his sins before turning back.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2924.

Verse: Whoever casts an angry look at his father, is not (in fact) kind to him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2925.

Verse: Whoever causes a loss (to people) will be made by God to sustain a loss, and whoever is hard on people will be treated harshly by God
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2926.

Verse: Whoever causes discord between a mother and her child, will be made by God to suffer discord between him and his friend in the Day of the Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2927.

Verse: Whoever commits a folly or a sin, and then turns regretful, his regret is the atonement of his fault.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2928.

Verse: Whoever commits adultery with a slave girl whose adultery has not been established, will be whipped by God with a fiery lash in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2929.

Verse: Verily, charity reduces the charity givers' heat of grave, and believers will rest under the shade of their charity in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2428.

Verse: Verily, chastity and faith are interrelated, when one fades, the other lasts on more.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2429.

Verse: Verily, children are the cause of man's misery, fear, ignorance and sorrow.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2430.

Verse: Verily, committing sins deprives man of his sustenance; divine decree is not changed but through praying and long life is not gained save by kindness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2431.

Verse: Verily, creditors have dominance over debtors until their debts are paid.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2432.

Verse: Verily, each of you is the mirror of your brothers (in faith), i.e. discovering any defect in them, you should (try to) rub it off.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2433.

Verse: Verily, entrance to Paradise is in pledge of striking swords.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2434.

Verse: Verily, every religion has a characteristic feature, and mine is characterized by chastity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2435.

Verse: Verily, every tree has a (kind of) fruit, and the fruit of heart is a child.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2436.

Verse: Causing the world to decline is more tolerable to God than killing a Muslim.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 370; Page No. 58

Verse: Verily, everything has a reality, and servants of God will not find access to the reality of faith unless they come to know that what has occurred to them or has not, has been out of necessity and unpreventable.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2437.

Verse: Verily, evil eyes send man to his grave, and for the camel the path to table they pave.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2438.

Verse: Verily, faith grows old in you, as your dress turns worn on you. So, ask the Exalted God to enliven faith in your hearts.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2439.

Verse: Verily, for every people there is a trial, and wealth is my people's trial.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2440.

Verse: Verily, for every traveler there is a destination, and man's destination is death. Remember God, therefore, for it make easy your affairs and makes you fond of the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2441.

Verse: Verily, for everything there is a basis and the basis of this religion (Islam) is knowledge, and one single holder of knowledge is more harmful to Satan than one thousand simple men of worship.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2442.

Verse: Verily, for everything there is a mine, and the mine of piety is the mystics' hearts.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2443.

Verse: Verily, fortune-tellers will be expelled to Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2444.

Verse: The bane of humour is lack of shame; the bane of courage is aggression; the bane of generosity is mentioning one's favors to others; the bane of beauty is arrogance; the bane of worship is abeyance; the bane of speech is lying; the bane of knowledge is forgetfulness; the bane of wisdom is foolishness; the bane of good lineage is pride; and the bane of liberality is wastefulness.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 44091; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 129

Verse: For everything there is a bane: the bane of knowledge is forgetfulness; the bane of worship is showing-off; the bane of the conscience is self-admiration; the bane of lineage is pride; the bane of humor is lack of shame; the bane of liberality is wastefulness; the bane of bashfulness is weakness; the bane of clemency is submissiveness; and the bane of stamina is degeneracy.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 44226; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 130

Verse: Allah, most High, is beautiful and He loves beauty. And He likes to see the evidence of His bounty on His servant. He loathes misery and pretending to be miserable.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 17166; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 140

Verse: The best thing given to a believer is good character, and the worst thing given to a man is a corrupt heart in a beautiful figure.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5170; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 141

Verse: Weigh your food, for there is blessing in weighed food.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9434; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 145

Verse: Allah's curse is on the briber, the bribed, and the agent between them
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 1508; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 146

Verse: Seek to increase your brothers [i.e. believeing friends], for every believer will make an intercession on the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 24642; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 148

Verse: Allah, the Exalted, likes the maintenance of old brotherhood, so maintain it.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 24759; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 156

Verse: When you see three traits in your brother, place your hope in him: bashfulness, trustworthiness, and truthfulness. If you do not see them, do not place your hope in him.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 24755; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 159

Verse: Ablution is a main part of faith, and brushing one's teeth is a main part of ablution.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 26200; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 163

Verse: Freshen your mouths by brushing, for verily they are the means to the Qur'an.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, 2753; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 163

Verse: Stand up, Bil l, and relieve us with the [call for] prayer.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 20954; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 166

Verse: Satan flees when he hears the call for prayer.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 20951; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 166

Verse: The inhabitants of Heaven hear nothing from the inhabitants of the earth except for the call for prayer.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 20934; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 166

Verse: Islam is to be good-natured
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5225; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 168

Verse: Verily Allah loves high moral virtues and detests poor manners.'
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5180; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 170

Verse: Verily I was deputed to perfect noble moral traits.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5217; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 171

Verse: Everyone will only have recourse to the shade provided by charity they had given until their affairs are judged [by Allah].
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16068; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 175

Verse: Verily charity extinguishes the wrath of the Lord.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16114; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 175

Verse: Charity prevents seventy different types of adversities, the simplest of them being elephantiasis and leprosy.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 15982; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 176

Verse: Give charity, and cure your sick ones through the giving of charity, for verily charity repels accidents and illnesses, and is a source of increase in your life spans and your good deeds.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, 16113; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 176

Verse: The best form of charity is to give away when one is healthy and covetous, when one has high hopes of one's livelihood and fears poverty. Do not wait until you are breathing your last to bequeath to others, saying: 'this is for x and this is for y, and this belonged to z.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16251; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 178

Verse: The best of people is he who gives away his hard-earned money [in charity].
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16084; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 178

Verse: The best form of charity is that which is secretly given to the poor by one who himself has little to offer.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16250; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 179

Verse: The best form of charity is for the Muslim to gain knowledge and then teach it to his fellow Muslim brother.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16357; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 179

Verse: The best form of charity is to shade someone under one's tent for the sake of Allah.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16362; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 179

Verse: Whoever is able to defend his Muslim brother being backbited in his presence but avoids doing so, will be made abject by the Exalted God, here and in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3012.

Verse: Whoever is afflicted with a physical or material calamity but hides it and avoids stating his grievance to people, will be definitely blessed by God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3013.

Verse: Whoever is appointed as a judge, is like unto the one beheaded without a knife.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3014.

Verse: Whoever is bereft of any of the following three features is meaner than a dog: piety to stop indulging in heavenly-unlawful acts, forbearance to ward off people's ignorance, and good-temperedness by which to deal with people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3015.

Verse: Whoever is born into a respectful family and is pure in birth, has a desirable company.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3016.

Verse: Whoever is called to account, will (actually) touch his/her punishment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3017.

Verse: Whoever is degraded by his own deeds, will not be upgraded by his parental lineage.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3018.

Verse: Whoever is devoid of moderation is bereft of all good.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3019.

Verse: Whoever is devoid of the following three, imperfect his deeds will be: piety to keep him away from disobeying the Lord, good-mannered ness through which with people to accord, and forbearance by which to repel fools' ignorance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3020.

Verse: Whoever is double-faced in this world, will be harnessed with two tongues (flames) of fire in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3021.

Verse: Whoever is easy-going, gentle and kind, will not be put to hellfire by God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3022.

Verse: Whoever is endowed with a bit of moderateness, is actually endowed with the good of both worlds.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3023.

Verse: Whoever is granted a (heavenly) gift should thank God for it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3024.

Verse: Whoever is granted God's grace, should reveal the sign of it on his face.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3025.

Verse: Whoever is hard on his family despite God's facilities for him, does not belong to us.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3026.

Verse: Whoever is helped by God to keep away from the evils of his tongue and privy parts will be allowed to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3027.

Verse: Whoever is kind to others, will see nothing but praise for which he should thank (God); if not, he will be considered ungrateful.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3028.

Verse: Whoever is not pleased with divine decree and does not believe in his (predestined) destiny, should search for a god other than the (Unique) Deity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3030.

Verse: Whoever is not respectful to the elderly, is not merciful to the younger ones, does not bid to good and does not forbid evil, does not belong to us.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3031.

Verse: Whoever is pleased that God is his Lord, Islam is his religion and Muhammad is the messenger (of God), and gives expression to these three, will be allowed to Paradise. The fourth to the above three is struggling in the way of the Great, Powerful God, which is as important as the heavens and the earth.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3032.

Verse: Whoever is pleased with his good deeds and is worried about his evil deeds is a (true) believer.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3033.

Verse: Whoever is raised to the leadership (of people) and treats them moderately, will be treated in like manner by the Exalted God in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3034.

Verse: Whoever is seized by pain, uneasy will remain.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3035.

Verse: Whoever is slain in defending his faith, is a martyr.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3036.

Verse: Whoever is slain in defense of his possessions is a martyr.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3037.

Verse: Whoever is treated kindly, should make up for it or remember and mention it, if not able to do so, for in the latter case he has actually shown his gratitude.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3038.

Verse: Singing and music is a nest for the bird called hypocrisy
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 2, The Sixteenth Greater Sin ,page 12; Al Kafi

Verse: The Hour will not come until man passes by a grave and wishes to be therein.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2052; Page No. 288

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that Amirul Momineen (a.s.) relates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "Shaitaan fears man as long as he offers five times prayer in its prime time. When the person wastes these Salaat, Shaitaan gets bold and involves that person in greater sins."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 290

Verse: Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) narrates that Amirul Momineen (a.s.) said, "One who recites Surahs while attending Congregation Prayer behind an Imam, will not be considered a follower of Islam after his death."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 291

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "O people! Make your rows proper. Your shoulders should touch that of the people standing beside you. There should be no gap between two persons. Don't remain aloof from a row so that Allah does not create difference between you people. Know that I am seeing the people who create differences among you."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 291

Verse: Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "The difference between a Muslim and a disbeliever is eliminated when a Muslim leaves an obligatory Salaat purposely or considers it unimportant."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 291

Verse: Intercede for someone and you will be rewarded
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 6489; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 477

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors and Jabir that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "There is no difference between a believer and a disbeliever except for the avoidance of Salaat."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 291

Verse: "One who delays Asr Prayer so much that he is not able to offer it, the Almighty Allah will bring him without relatives and wealth on the Day of Judgment."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 292

Verse: The narrator went to Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) and asked, "Tell me about one who delays offering Asr Prayer purposely?" "He will be brought without relatives and wealth on the Day of Judgment." The narrator asked, "May I be sacrificed for you! Is it so even if he is worthy of Paradise?" Imam said, "Yes, even if he is worthy of Paradise, he will be brought without relatives and wealth on the Day of Judgment." The narrator asked, "What position will he get in Paradise?" Imam answered, "He will be deprived of relatives and wealth over there also. Such a person will have no house and he will have to stay as a guest in others' houses in Paradise."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 292

Verse: "Get deceived in anything but not in Asr Prayer. Offer it in the brightness of the sun for the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) has said: a person who wastes Asr Prayer will be without relatives and wealth." The narrator asked, "Who is one without relatives and wealth?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "He is one who has neither any relatives nor any wealth in Paradise." The narrator asked, "What is meant by wasting Salaat?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "It means not offering it during the time between noon and sunset."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 292

Verse: "The appointed angel calls out: May Allah not give sleep to the eyes of those who go to bed without offering Isha Prayer by midnight."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 293

Verse: Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) addressed his companions after Morning Prayer and asked whether so and so persons had come to pray. The companions replied saying that they hadn't. The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "Didn't they come? Remember it that offering of no other Salaat is difficult for a hypocrite except this and Isha Salaat."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 293

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his father that the Prophet (s.a.w.s.) has made Congregation Prayer compulsory for those living in the neighborhood of a mosque and used to say, "Those who do not pray in congregation will not succeed in their business. I will order the muezzin to give prayer-call and order a personality from my Ahle Bayt, that is Ali, to take a torch in his hand and burn the houses of those who do not pray in congregation."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 293

Verse: "One who does not attend Friday Salaat continuously for three weeks without any reason, the Almighty Allah puts a seal on his heart."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 293

Verse: "Congregation Prayer is compulsory and it is obligatory to offer Friday Salaat in congregation with the Imam. Hence one who does not attend Friday Prayer for three consecutive weeks without any valid reason has avoided three obligatory acts and a person who leaves three obligatory acts without any valid reason is a hypocrite. One who avoids offering Prayer in congregation without any reason, none of his prayers is acceptable."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 293/294

Verse: A man gains more value when the world is less worthy in his view.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 96; Page No. 21

Verse: The narrator asked Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) regarding greater sins. Imam said, "Greater sins are five and Allah makes Hell obligatory for those who commit them as per the words of Allah: Surely Allah does not forgive that anything should be associated with Him [Surah Nisa 4:48]. Allah has also said: (As for) those who swallow the property of the orphans unjustly, surely they only swallow fire into their bellies and they shall enter burning fire [Surah Nisa 4:10]. Allah has also said: O you who believe! when you meet those who disbelieve marching for war, then turn not your backs to them[Surah Anfaal 8:15] nor accuse a chaste woman of adultery nor should you kill a believer purposely."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 294

Verse: The narrator asked Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) regarding a greater sin. Imam (a.s.) replied, "Every such deed for which Allah has promised Hell is a greater sin."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 294

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) said that it is written in the book of Imam Amirul Momineen (a.s.) that One who usurps the wealth of an orphan forcefully, this wealth will be a cause of calamity for him soon on the Day of Judgment. And regarding the punishment of this world, Allah says, "And let those fear who, should they leave behind them weakly offspring, would fear on their account, so let them be careful of (their duty to) Allah, and let them speak right words.[Surah Nisa 4:9] Allah says regarding the punishment of the hereafter: (As for) those who swallow the property of the orphans unjustly, surely they only swallow fire into their bellies and they shall enter burning fire. [Surah Nisa 4:10]."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 295

Verse: "The Almighty Allah has promised two punishments for those who usurp the wealth of orphans forcefully. One of these is the punishment of hereafter and that is the fire of Hell. Another is the punishment of this world and Allah says regarding this: And let those fear who, should they leave behind them weakly offspring, would fear on their account, so let them be careful of (their duty to) Allah, and let them speak right words.[Surah Nisa 4:9] Because your children can be dealt in the similar way as you deal with other orphans."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 295..

Verse: The Hour will not come until men decrease and women increase in number.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2053; Page No. 288

Verse: The Hour will not come until the ignoble turn out to be the most fortunate of all people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2054; Page No. 288

Verse: The worthiest (form of) worship is the most hidden one.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2235.

Verse: The worthiest of all people is the one who avoids interfering with what concerns him not.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2236.

Verse: There are four groups of people; namely, the munificent who feed themselves and others, the generous who feed others but not themselves, the miserly who feed themselves but not others, and the mean who neither feed themselves nor others.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2237.

Verse: There are no better characteristics than the following two: having faith in God and being beneficial to God's creatures.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2238.

Verse: How nice a gift is a word of wisdom!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 928; Page No. 131

Verse: How nice a place of worship is a Muslim's house for him!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 929, Page No. 131

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "A person who laughs while committing a sin will enter Hell weeping."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 283

Verse: Imam Musa Kazim (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "Some people will be ordered to be thrown into Hell on the Day of Judgment. The Almighty Allah will ask the angel of fire not to burn their feet for they walked with them to the mosque. Also He will order not to burn their faces for they used to face Allah while supplicating. He will order not to burn their tongues for they used to recite Quran excessively. The attendant of Hell will ask those people about their sin. They will reply that they used to perform good deeds for others instead of Allah. Those people will be ordered to go and ask for reward from the persons for whom they performed good deeds."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 283

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "I like to give one thousand dirhams as loan twice instead of giving them once as Sadaqah. It is not permissible for an indebted person to delay repayment if he is capable of doing so. Similarly it is not permissible to be strict when a person is not capable of repaying it."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 184

Verse: "A worshipper prayed to Allah for eighty years. Then he fell in love with a woman and fulfilled his desires with her. When the angel of death approached him, he became mute. A beggar happened to pass by. That person pointed out the beggar to take the piece of bread lying in his pocket. The Almighty Allah had destroyed his worship of eighty years due to the adultery committed by him but He forgave him for offering that piece of bread."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 184/185

Verse: "My father used to say that the first deed to be rewarded on the Day of Judgment is offering water as Sadaqah."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 185

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "Sadaqah keeps one away from unpleasant death."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 186

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "The ground of Qiyamat is fire except the shade of a believer. Indeed his Sadaqah shades him."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 186

Verse: Imam Musa Kazim (a.s.) was asked,"Is it better for a rich person to give Sadaqah or to buy a slave and free him?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "I prefer Sadaqah."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 186

Verse: "Good deeds and Sadaqah keep poverty away, increases life. A person who does good deeds and gives Sadaqah is safe from seventy types of unpleasant deaths."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 186

Verse: Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) narrates that Amirul Momineen (a.s.) said that once he gave a dinar as Sadaqah. The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) told him,"O Ali! Don't you know, that before a believer gives Sadaqah seventy Satans are released and they plead him not to do so. This Sadaqah passes through the hands of Allah before reaching the hands of the beggar." Then he recited the verse: 'Don't you know that only Allah accepts the repentance of the servants and takes Sadaqah. Surely Allah is the Greatest Forgiver and Most Merciful."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 186/187

Verse: Caution does not block the way of fate.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 371; Page No. 58

Verse: Caution is not useful against fate; rather, praying is of use against the befallen and non-befallen(events).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 372; Page No. 58

Verse: "Instead of going for Hajj I would prefer freeing a slave." Then he went on increasing the number of slaves to be freed one by one comparing them with a single Hajj till he reached ten. Further he increased the number of slaves to be freed in multiples of ten comparing them with a single Hajj till he reached seventy. Then he said, "I like to feed a Muslim family, clothe them and safeguard their honor instead of going for a Hajj." Then he went on increasing the number of Hajj by one comparing them with care of a family till he reached ten. Further he increased the number of Hajj in multiples of ten comparing them with care of a family till he reached seventy.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 187

Verse: "If eighty people do a good deed together each person will get the reward equal to that of all the people without decrease in the reward of any one of them."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 187

Verse: "The Sadaqah given at the time of prosperity is the best Sadaqah."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 187

Verse: The narrator asked Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) or Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.),"Which Sadaqah is the best?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "Sadaqah given from a little wealth. Didn't you hear Allah's saying: 'and prefer (them) before themselves though poverty may afflict them'?[Surah Hashr 59:9]. Do you realize its excellence now?"
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 187/188

Verse: "Giving Sadaqah with hand keeps away unpleasant death. It keeps away seventy types of calamities and opens Satanic mouths all stopping the person from giving Sadaqah."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 188

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) was asked, "Which Sadaqah is better?" The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) replied, "Giving Sadaqah to an inimical relative."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 188

Verse: "The Almighty Allah keeps seventy calamities away from one who gives Sadaqah in the month of Ramadan."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 188

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) was asked, "Should we give Sadaqah to beggars or to our near relatives?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "Give it to your near relatives for it carries greater reward."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 188

Verse: It is narrated that a beggar came to Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) on Thursday night. Imam returned him empty-handed and told the people present there, "I had enough money to give him as Sadaqah but Sadaqah given on Friday carries multiple rewards."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 188/189

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that Imam Zainul Abideen (a.s.) said, "Giving Sadaqah secretly cools the anger of Allah."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 189

Verse: "A Sadaqah given openly keeps away seventy calamities and giving Sadaqah secretly cools Allah's anger."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 189

Verse: "Giving Sadaqah at night keeps away unpleasant death and seventy types of calamities."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 189

Verse: What a wretched servant the hoarder is, for if Allah, most High, lowers the prices he is saddened but if He raises them he rejoices.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9715; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 406

Verse: The hoarders and the murderers will be resurrected to occupy the same position in Hell.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9739; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 406

Verse: Invite one whom you love in the way of Allah to partake of your food as a guest.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 25881; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 413

Verse: Whoever sells a house and does not invest the money in something of similar value will not be blessed in it [his money].
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5440; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 417

Verse: Whoever from among you sells a house or some real estate, then let him bear in mind that the money acquired is not worthy of being blessed unless he invests it in something of similar value
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5441; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 417

Verse: Allah, Mighty and Exalted, says, 'When a servant' s predominant state is preoccupation with Me then I make the object of his desire My remembrance and place his pleasure therein. And when I make My remembrance the object of his desire and place his pleasure therein, he becomes infatuated with Me and I with him. And when he becomes infatuated with Me and I with him, I remove all veils between Me and him, and make this state predominate over him where he is never again negligent even when other people are
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 1872; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 433

Verse: I would not be pleased to die as a child and be made to enter Paradise without being able to grow up and get to know my Lord, Mighty and Exalted.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 36472; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 436

Verse: If you truly knew Allah as He is worthy of being known, you would be able to walk on the seas and the mountains would fall by your command.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5893; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 437

Verse: Ponder about the creation of Allah, but do not ponder about Allah Himself lest you be ruined.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5705; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 441

Verse: The innovators are the worst of all of [God's] creation.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, nos. 1095 and 1126; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 459

Verse: The innovators are the dogs of the inmates of Hell.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 1125; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 459

Verse: The innovators are those who contradict the command of Allah, His Book and His Messenger; they are those who follow their own opinion and desires, even if they are the majority.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 44216; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 459

Verse: When a man rejects an innovator, out of dislike for him, Allah will fill his heart with peace and belief.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5599; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 460

Verse: The blind is not someone who has lost his eyesight, but the one who has lost his insight
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 1220; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 461

Verse: The one who insults a believer is as one who is on the verge of ruin.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 8093; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 462

Verse: If any of you ever insults his fellow brother, he must not insult his family or his father or mother. He can only say - if he knows these flaws for certain - 'You are indeed a miser, or you are indeed a coward, or you are indeed a liar' only if he is certain of the existence of these traits.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 8134; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 464

Verse: Whoever intercedes for someone settling thereby a financial liability or procuring someone's due profit, Allah will give him a firm footing on the day that feet will stumble.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 6496; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 478

Verse: My intercession will avail those people from my community who love my household
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 39057; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 478

Verse: On the Day of Resurrection, I will surely intercede for anyone who harbours even a fly's wing's worth of faith in his heart.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 39043; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 478

Verse: Wherever you may be, invoke blessings on me for verily your blessing reaches me.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 2147; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 486

Verse: Whoever invokes blessings on me, writing it on paper, the angels continue to seek forgiveness on his behalf as long as my name remains written on the paper.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 2243; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 486

Verse: Verily the most miserly of people is he who hears my name mentioned and does not invoke blessings on me.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 2144; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 486

Verse: Every supplication remains veiled until blessings are invoked on the Prophet (SAWA).
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 2153; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 486

Verse: Chastity comprises one's whole faith.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 381; Page No. 59

Verse: when he was asked how to send blessings on him, replied, 'Say: O Allah, bless Muhammad and the family of Muhammad, just as you blessed Abraham and the family of Abraham, verily you are Praiseworthy and Glorious. And send Your benediction on Muhammad and on the family of Muhammad, just as you sent Your benediction on Abraham and on the family of Abraham, verily you are Praiseworthy and Glorious.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, 3993; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 487

Verse: Calamity is in pledge of (man's) words-should anybody berate someone for sucking a dog's breast, he will himself do the same.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 363; Page No. 57

Verse: Calamity is in pledge of (man's) words-when someone says, "By God I will not do such a thing", Satan abandons all his affairs and craves for making him commit sins.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 364; Page No. 57

Verse: Call unto your Lord and believe that He will hear you, and know that God will not grant the prayers of those with negligent hearts.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 365; Page No. 57

Verse: Calling to good weighs over silence, and silence weighs over calling to evil.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 366, Page No. 57

Verse: Carnal desires will be forgiven, if not put to words or action.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 367; Page No. 58

Verse: Carrying out heavenly-ordained punishments in this very world is better for men than forty days of raining.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 368; Page No. 58

Verse: Casting an unlawful look (at a woman) is a poisoned arrow from Satan.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 369; Page No. 58

Verse: Charity to the needy is only alms-giving, but to the kinds is alms-giving as well as strengthening kinship ties.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 375; Page No. 58

Verse: Charity wards off hard deaths.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 376; Page No. 58

Verse: Chastity and faith are interrelated. Should one of them vanish, the other will (definitely) perish.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 377; Page No. 58

Verse: Chastity and faith are interrelated; none lasts without the other.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 378; Page No. 59

Verse: Chastity and faith are two companions. They do not leave (their holder), but collectively.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 379; Page No. 59

Verse: Chastity and taciturnity are two components of (one's) faith, while scurrility and talkativeness are two elements of hypocrisy.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 380; Page No. 59

Verse: Chastity is (man's) beauty, piety brings magnanimity, patience is the best means to ends, and awaiting divine solution is an act of worship.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 383; Page No. 59

Verse: Chastity is a portion of faith.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 384; Page No. 59

Verse: Chastity is goodness in its entirety.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 385; Page No. 59

Verse: Chastity is women's beauty.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 386; Page No. 59

Verse: Chastity originates from faith, and faith leads (man) to Paradise. Scurrility roots from cruelty, and cruelty ends in Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 387; Page No. 59

Verse: Cheerfulness carries away one's hatred.
