Verse: Happy is the man who has a good house, a good neighbor and a tame horse.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 856; Page No. 121

Verse: Hard trials (hardships) befell you and you kept patient, but I am worried about you as to harder trials on the part of women when they decorate themselves with gold, and dress themselves in precious cloths, thereby causing troubles for the rich and asking the poor what they cannot afford.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 857, Page No. 122

Verse: Hope and fear will not simultaneously befall a believer's heart unless God, the Greatest and the most Powerful, grants him/her hope and keeps him safe from fear.

Verse: Horses abound in everlasting gains and achievements and stand as a source of assistance for their owners, and spending for horses is like unto being generous in giving charity.

Verse: Horses abound in everlasting gains, and spending for them is like unto spending generously for one's family.

Verse: Horses abound in everlasting gains, i.e. spoils and rewards.

Verse: Hours of sickness sweep away hours of sins.

Verse: Houses you make wherein you will not rest, things you amass which you never taste and wishes you have which are never fulfilled.

Verse: How bad are the people among whom believers have to live with dissimulation and denial.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 921; Page No. 130

Verse: How bad are those who do not invite guests (to their houses)!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 922; Page No. 130

Verse: How bad is a hoarder of things, who gets depressed when the Exalted God makes the prices fall, and rejoices when He causes them to rise!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 923; Page No. 130

Verse: How is God (expected) to consider a people as pious, who do not endeavor to take back the rights of the weak from the powerful?
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 924; Page No. 130

Verse: How is it that when one of our agents returns to us says, "I have collected this for you and I have been gifted that?" If so, why did he not stay in his father's and mother's house to see whether people gift him or not?
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 925; Page No. 130

Verse: How loathsome is the food of a marriage ceremony, when served to the rich but not to the poor!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 926; Page No. 130

Verse: How nice a bestowal it is to hear a word of truth and communicate it to your Muslim brother!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 927; Page No. 130&131

Verse: was once asked by Ibn Abi 'Umayr about the Prophet (SAWA)'s saying, 'The prosperous one is he who prospered from when he was in his mother's womb, and the wretched one is he who was wretched from when he was in his mother's womb', to which he replied, 'The wretched one is he who, from when he was in his mother's womb, Allah knew would commit acts characteristic of wretched people, and the prosperous one is he who, from when he was in his mother's womb, Allah knew would perform acts characteristic of prosperous people.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 356, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1019

Verse: O Allah, make me fear you as if I see you, let me prosper through being conscious of my duty to You, and keep me from becoming wretched as a consequence of Your disobedience.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 98, p. 218, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1019

Verse: The most wretched of people is he who is reputed amongst people for his knowledge but not known for his action thereof.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 52, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1019

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.), when asked who the most wretched of all people was, replied, 'He who sells his Hereafter for someone else's profit in this world.'.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 322, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1020

Verse: Among the symptoms of wretchedness are: a look of apathy in the eyes, hardness of the heart, intense greed in seeking out one's livelihood, and persistence in committing sins.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 243, no. 96; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1020

Verse: One of the symptoms of wretchedness is swindling one's own friend.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9297; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1020

Verse: Among the symptoms of wretchedness is maltreatment of good people.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9307; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1020

Verse: Verily the servant will come on the Day of Resurrection having performed many good deeds which please him, when a man will come, complaining [to Allah], 'O Lord, this man has wronged me', whereupon some of his good deeds will be taken and transferred to the good deeds of the plaintiff. The situation will continue thus until finally he will be left with no good deeds, and then the plaintiff's evil deeds will start being transferred to his own evil deeds, and he will continue to pay for them thus until he will enter the Fire.
VerseRef: Nihayat al-Bidaya wa al-Nihaya, v. 2, p. 55; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1021

Verse: Fear wrongdoing, for verily it is a source of darkness on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 332, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1021

Verse: Wrongdoing is the most painful of all vices.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 804; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1021

Verse: Wrongdoing causes feet to slip, snatches away bounties and destroys nations.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1734; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1021

Verse: By Allah, I would rather spend a sleepless night on the thorns of the Sa`adan tree [a type of prickly tree], or be driven as a prisoner in shackles, than meet Allah and His Messenger on the Day of Resurrection having wronged any servant or having usurped any kind of worldly wealth. How can I wrong anyone for the sake of this soul that is rapidly hastening towards destruction and is to remain under the earth for a long time?
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 224; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1021

Verse: By Allah, if I was given all the seven domains with all that exists under its celestial spheres in order that I may disobey Allah to the extent of snatching a single grain of barley from an ant, I would not do it.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 224; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1022

Verse: Beware of wrongdoing, for the living days of one who wrongs others become odious.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2638; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1022

Verse: Nothing induces the reversal of Allah's bounty or the hastening of His retribution than continuous injustice [to others]; for verily Allah hears the call of the oppressed and lies in wait for the oppressors.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 53; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1022

Verse: The life of one who wrongs others is shattered.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7940; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1022

Verse: The one who takes wrongdoing as a mount is thrown off by it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5391; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1022

Verse: The one who tyrannises others is ruined by his own tyranny.

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) forbade anyone from eating anything that an ant carries in its mouth or holds in its grip.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 305, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1022

Verse: Know that wrongdoing is of three types: the wrongdoing that is unforgivable, the wrongdoing that cannot be left unaccounted, and the wrongdoing that is forgivable and unquestioned. The wrong that is unforgivable is association of anything with Allah  the wrong that is forgivable is when the servant is unjust to himself and wrongs himself with regard to his faults, and the wrong that cannot be left unaccounted is the wrong that people do unto each other.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 176; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1023

Verse: Wronging the weak is the most atrocious type of injustice.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1023

Verse: was once asked, 'Which sin hastens punishment down on its perpetrator the fastest?' to which he replied, 'He who wrongs somebody that has no helper save Allah, he who repays bounties with negligence and laxity, and he who displays arrogant and intimidating behaviour towards the poor.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 320, no. 43; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1023

Verse: One of the most atrocious types of injustice is to wrong kind people.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9272; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1024

Verse: O my son, I am advising you of the same thing that my father advised me in his will when he was approaching death, and the same thing that he said his father advised him - O my son! Beware of wronging one who has no helper against you but Allah.

VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 322, no. 51; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1024

Verse: Expect good for whoever dies while doing good, and be worried about and fear for whoever dies while doing evil.

Verse: Goodness does not lie in finery and brilliant bearing, but in peace and solemnity.

Verse: Goodness has many forms to do, but good doers are few.

Verse: Grave is the first dwelling of the eternal ones.

Verse: Greatness lies in piety, dignity in humility, and needlessness in certainty.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 837; Page No. 119

Verse: Greed is like unto a slippery piece of stone on which the scholars' feet will not stand firm.

Verse: Ismail bin Ammar asked Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.), "May I be sacrificed for you! Is a believer mercy for another?" "Yes," said the Imam (a.s.). Ismail asked, "How?" Imam said, "If a believer goes to a person with a desire, it is surely a blessing of Almighty God sent for the latter. If he fulfils that wish, he has accepted the blessing and if the person does not fulfill the desire in spite of being capable of doing so, he has rejected the blessing of Allah. This blessing will be saved till the Day of Judgment. The person whose wish is not fulfilled has full right over this blessing. He can keep it with himself or give it to someone else. O Ismail! What do you think? Will this person keep the blessing with himself or give it to someone else on the Day of Judgment?" Ismail replied, "I don't think he will give it to someone else." Imam said, "Do not think and guess. He will certainly keep that blessing for himself. If a believer goes to his brother seeking help and the latter does not fulfill his wish in spite of being capable, the Almighty Allah will leave a snake in his grave which will continue to sting his toe till the Day of Judgment whether he is forgiven or involved in punishment."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 313/314

Verse: "One who goes to fulfill a desire of a believer but does not try his best to fulfill his wish, he is like a person who has been dishonest to Allah and His Messenger. Allah will become his enemy."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 314

Verse: "One who among our lovers tries to help a believer but does not make full effort in his cause, has surely distrusted Allah, His Messenger and the believers." The narrator asked Imam what he meant by a believer. Imam (a.s.) replied, "A person who has faith in all Imams from Amirul Momineen (a.s.) to the last Imam (a.s.)."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 314

Verse: "If a Shia goes to his brother and seeks help from him in any matter and if the latter has capacity to help him out but does not do so, the Almighty Allah will give him power to help our enemies. He will be punished on the Day of Judgment for doing so."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 314

Verse: "One who keeps away from helping a Muslim brother and helps a person whose help is prohibited, will get no reward for it."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 314

Verse: "One who has extra clothes and he comes to know that there is a needy person in his neighborhood and if he does not give his clothes to the needy, the Almighty Allah will throw him headlong into Hell."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 315

Verse: "One who sleeps after having his fill while there is a believer in his neighborhood who is hungry, Allah will say: O My angels! I hold you witness for this servant that I had ordered him but he did not follow it and obeyed other's order. He relied upon someone other than Me in his deeds. I swear by My honor that I will never forgive him."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 3215

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said that the Almighty Allah said, "One who sleeps after having his fill while there is a hungry believer near him, the former has no faith on Me."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 315

Verse: "Do not insult a poor believer because the Almighty Allah insults one who insults a poor believer. Allah will become his enemy till he does not stop doing so or repents for his deed. One who disgraces a believer because of his poverty the Almighty Allah will disgrace him on the Day of Judgment in front of His entire creation."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 315

Verse: "If a brother in faith of a person is being backbited and the person helps his brother the Almighty Allah will help him in the world and hereafter. If a brother in faith of a person is being backbited and the person does not help his brother the Almighty Allah will disgrace him in his world and the hereafter."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 316

Verse: "The Almighty Allah delegated the power to an angel of His to build all of the seven earths and heavens. When he created them and found that everyone has started obeying him, he called out: Is there anyone like me? The Almighty Allah sent a little fire in order to burn down everything so that he gets to know the consequence of boasting." The narrator asked about the amount of fire sent. Imam (a.s.) replied, "It was just a handful."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 316

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "When my Ummah avoids beggars and walks proudly, Allah will swear by His honor and say: I will punish these people because of some of them."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 316

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "My Ummah will remain safe till they do not betray trust and return the things to their owners and pay Zakat. When they cease to do so, they will face famine and drought."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 317

Verse: "It is not that the amount of rain is increasing year by year. The Almighty Allah sends rain wherever He feels. If the people of an area commit sins, Allah sends the rain destined to fall in that area elsewhere in a forest, ocean or a mountain. The Almighty Allah deprives the earth of rain because of the sins committed by the people. He diverts the rain to a place where sins are not committed." Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) said, "O those who see! Gain lesson from this. We have seen in the book of Amirul Momineen (a.s.) that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said: When extra-marital sex becomes common, the number of deaths increase suddenly. When cheating increases much, Allah involves people in drought and loss. When people stop paying Zakat, the Almighty Allah stops abundance of crops and yield from earth. When injustice spreads, people start helping each other in unjust causes and when promises are broken, Allah leaves them at the mercy of their enemies. When relations are broken, wealth is handed over to evil people. When people are not called towards good and are not stopped from doing evil and when the virtuous among our Ahle Bait (a.s.) are not obeyed, the Almighty Allah will give their control to evil people. At that time, virtuous people will pray but their prayers will not be accepted."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 317/318

Verse: Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "There are five things from which you should seek Allah's refuge. When people of a community start sinning openly, epidemic plagues, which were not destined for them earlier, become common. When people start cheating in weight, they have to face drought and oppression of an unjust ruler. When Zakat is not paid, rainfall is reduced and they would not have received rain had there been no animal among them. When the oaths of Allah and promises to His Messenger are broken, the Almighty Allah gives their control to their enemies. He takes away whatever is present with them. When people act without obeying Allah's commands, He sends His chastisement on them."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 318

Verse: Your need to a miser is colder than the cold wind.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 31, no. 99; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 612

Verse: Verily the most detested of all people in the sight of Allah are two: the man whom Allah has relegated to his own carnal self, so he has deviated from the straight path and is passionately fond of talking about innovations and misguiding others towards the wrong path. He tempts those who are charmed by him. He himself has strayed away from the guidance of his predecessors, and misleads those who follow him during his life as well as after his death. He carries the burden of others' sins and is entangled in his own misdeeds
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 896

Verse: I warn you against the hypocrites, for verily they are themselves misguided and they misguide other people. They have slipped and they cause others to slip too.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 194; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 897

Verse: When Allah wants good for a servant, He educates him in religion and inspires him to its complete path.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28690; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 495

Verse: There is a support for everything, and the support for this religion is education.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28768; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 495

Verse: There is nothing more difficult [lit. backbreaking] for Satan than a scholar emerging from a tribe.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28755; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 497

Verse: When committing a sin, the knowledgeable man is guilty of the one sin whereas the ignorant man is guilty of two [i.e. the sin itself and the sin of ignorance].
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28784; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 501

Verse: By the One Who holds Muhammad' s soul in His Grasp! Verily one knowledgeable man is more difficult for Satan to bear than seventy worshippers, for the worshipper serves himself whilst the knowledgeable man serves others.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28908; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 505

Verse: The death of a scholar is an affliction that cannot be compensated and a void that cannot be filled, for he is a star that has been obliterated. The death of a whole tribe is easier to bear than the death of a scholar.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28858; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 506

Verse: Seek knowledge even in China, for verily to seek knowledge is an obligation on every Muslim.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28697; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 507

Verse: There are two insatiable types of people who are never satisfied by their quest the seeker of knowledge and the seeker after this world.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28726; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 507

Verse: The seeker of knowledge among ignorant people is as the living one among the dead.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28726; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 508

Verse: He who goes out to seek knowledge is indeed on the path of Allah until he returns.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28702; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 508

Verse: He who goes out to seek knowledge, Allah guarantees his sustenance for him.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28701; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 508

Verse: The seeker of knowledge is the seeker of mercy; the seeker of knowledge is the pillar of Islam and is given his recompense with the prophets.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28729; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 508

Verse: Verily the angels spread their wings over the seeker of knowledge and seek forgiveness on his behalf.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28745; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 509

Verse: He who goes out to seek knowledge is himself sought after by Paradise.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28842; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 509

Verse: Whoever gains knowledge for the sake of anything other than Allah, most High, should take himself a seat in the Fire.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 29035; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 512

Verse: There are three types of people whose right none will deem lightly apart from the hypocrite who manifests his hypocrisy the old person in Islam, the just leader, and the teacher of good.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 43811; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 515

Verse: It is a scholar' s right upon you that you greet people in general as a whole but single him out with your greeting, that you sit in front of him, that you do not point to him with your hand, nor make hints against him with your eyes, nor say, 'but x said' in opposition to his statements, nor backbite anyone in his presence, nor whisper secrets to others in his gathering, nor pull on his robe, nor insist for him to continue if he is tired, nor show disinclination at the length of his speech, for verily it [i.e. his speech] is as a palm tree from which you [should] anxiously wait for something to fall from it for you.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 29363; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 515

Verse: It is not part of the moral virtues of a believer that he should flatter or be jealous except in the quest for knowledge.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 29364; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 515

Verse: He who goes forth to meet the scholars has indeed come forth to meet me, and he who visits the scholars has indeed visited me, and he who sits in the company of the scholars has indeed sat in my company, and whoever sits in my company is as if he has sat in the company of my Lord.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28883; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 516

Verse: O Moses, devote yourself exclusively to knowledge if you want it, for verily knowledge is for the one who devotes himself exclusively to it.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 44176; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 516

Verse: The scholars are Allah's trustees over His creation.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28675; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 517

Verse: The superiority of the scholar over others is as the superiority of the prophet over his community.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28798; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 517

Verse: The best act of charity is carried out in the month of Ramazan
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16249; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 179

Verse: The one who gives excessive charity is as the one who withholds it.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16246; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 181

Verse: The one who is truly poor does not roam around the streets begging, nor can he be turned away with a date or two, or a bite or two. Rather the one who is truly poor is he who restrains himself from asking people and who does not draw attention to himself   that is the one that should be given charity.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16552; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 181

Verse: The chief of a people should serve them.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 17517; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 184

Verse: Chiding a boy in his childhood [as discipline] leads to an increase in his intellect as an adult.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 30747; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 186

Verse: The timid merchant is often deprived and the bold merchant is often endowed with profit
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9293; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 194

Verse: When you weigh, tip the balance [in favor of the customer]
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9442; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 195

Verse: Verily the merchants are the debauchers.' They asked, 'O Messenger of Allah! But has Allah not made trading lawful?' He said, 'Yes, but they lie when they speak, and they take [false] oaths and incur sins.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9451; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 197

Verse: It is narrated in Kanz al-`Ummal: ' Ali used to go to the market and stand in his usual place to say, 'Peace be upon you, O people of the market! Fear Allah in your oaths, for the oath degrades the commodity and drives away the blessing. The merchant is iniquitous except for he who takes and gives only what is right.'
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 10043; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 197

Verse: The trustworthy honest Muslim merchant will be with the martyrs on the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9216; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 197

Verse: The honest merchant will be in the shade of the Throne on the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9218; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 198

Verse: The All-Merciful, Blessed and most High, has mercy on those who are merciful (towards others). Have mercy on the dwellers of the earth and the [Lord of the] Heavens will have mercy on you.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5969; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 205

Verse: One of the inmates of the Fire will call out: O Affectionate One, O Liberal Giver, save me from the Fire. So Allah will command one of His angels to take him out that he may come and stand before Him, and Allah will ask him, 'Were you ever compassionate towards a sparrow?
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5992; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 206

Verse: Be compassionate towards the destitute.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5983; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 206

Verse: O people, stay with the congregation and stay away from division.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 1028; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 210

Verse: Allah's Hand [i.e. divine aid] is with the congregation. Whenever a straying individual deviates, Satan snatches him up like a wolf snatches a sheep starying from the herd.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 1032; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 210

Verse: Allah's Hand [i.e. divine aid] is with the congregation.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 20241; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 210

Verse: Congregation [upon the truth] is a mercy and division is chastisement.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 20242; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 210

Verse: When sending me a messenger, send one with beauty of face and name.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2834.

Verse: When somebody invites you, accept (his invitation).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2835.

Verse: By Allah, the sunna is the tradition of Muhammad (SAWA); innovation is anything that deviates from it; the congregation is the gathering of people who are with the truth, even if they are few in number; and division is the dissention of people who are with falsehood, even if they be many in number.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 1644; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 211

Verse: If you have assumed the worst [about someone or something], then do not seek to make it true. And if you are jealous [of someone or something] then do not covet them, and if you draw an evil omen from something, ignore it and walk away.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 7585; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 213

Verse: Verily divine mercy does not spread over a people if among them lives one who has cut ties with his kin.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 6978; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 217

Verse: Muslims [make and] fulfil their promises according to what is permissible.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 10909; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 225

Verse: Verily whoever is not true to an agreement, or breaks it, or promises beyond that which he is capable of, or omits something from it without good intention therein, then I will hold it against him on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 10924; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 226

Verse: Truly the son of Adam covets what is prohibited.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 44095; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 230

Verse: The coward has two requitals.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 11298; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 231

Verse: Everything has been created from water.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 15119; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 232

Verse: The sky of this world was created from a controlled surge.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 15188; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 232

Verse: Muhammad b. Muslim narrated, 'I asked Abu `Abdillah [al-Sadiq] (AS): "I hear a tradition from you and then I add to it or subtract from it." He said, 'If you [do this] intending its meanings, then it does not matter.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 164, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 946

Verse: Do you like it for Allah and His Messenger to be called liars?! Then transmit to the people only that which they understand and withhold that which they [i.e. their intellects] reject.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 77, no. 60; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 946

Verse: Truly our traditions are hard and difficult, unbearable except by a near-stationed angel, a sent prophet, or a servant whose heart has been tested by Allah for faith, or a strongly guarded city.' `Amr narrated, 'I then asked Shu`ayb, who had transmitted this tradition to me: 'O Abu al-?asan! What is the strongly guarded city?' He replied, 'I asked Abu `Abdillah (AS) about it, and he said to me, 'It is an all-comprehending heart
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 189, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 947

Verse: Nothing destroys religion like innovations.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 92, no. 98; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 458

Verse: Anyone who calls people to give him their allegiance, knowing that among them is someone superior to him, is an erroneous innovator.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 375; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 459

Verse: I was with Abu `Abdillah [al-Sadiq] (AS), and there was with him a man from al-Mughiriyyah. The man asked him about some practices. He said, 'There is nothing which the offspring of Adam needs except that it has been expounded in the practices set by Allah and His Messenger. Otherwise He would not have the argument over us that He holds.' The man from al-Mughiriyyah then asked, 'And what is His argument?' Abu `Abdillah (AS) said, '[It is] His verse: "Today I have perfected your religion for you, and I have completed My blessing upon you" [Qur'an 5:3].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 169, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 947

Verse: Some of our traditions are ambiguous like the ambiguous verses of the Qur'an, and some are clear like the clear verses of the Qur'an. Then refer its ambiguous ones to its clear ones, and do not follow its ambiguous ones [blindly] without referring to its clear ones lest you go astray.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 1, p. 290, no. 39; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 948

Verse: Travel is a type of chastisement, so when one's travel comes to an end one must hurry back home to one's family
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 222, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No.

Verse: Concern yourself with your companion [on the journey] over the way itself, and with your neighbour [upon your return] before your house
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 948

Verse: During a journey, the chief of the people should be their servant
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 1, p. 536, no. 1866; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 949

Verse: When you go away on a journey, upon your return to your family you should bring them back a gift or a novelty, even if it be a mere stone!
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 283, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 949

Verse: Do not accompany on a journey someone who does not consider you worthier than himself, nor someone who you do not consider worthier than yourself
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 267, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 949

Verse: Commence your journey with the giving of charity, and leave when the time seems right, for verily you buy the safety of your journey [with charity].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 100, p. 103, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 949

Verse: Luqman (a.s.) said to his son When you travel in the company of people, consult with them frequently about each of your affairs, make them smile often, and be generous in sharing your provisions with them. When they call you, answer them, and when they ask for your help, assist them. Try to outdo them in three things: long periods of silence, an abundance of prayer, and open-handedness with them with whatever you possess of riding animal, wealth or food
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 271, no. 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 949

Verse: The ideal courteousness during a journey entails sharing one's provisions freely, joking light-heartedly in matters that do not displease Allah, hardly ever disputing with your travelling companions, and never telling tales about them once you have parted company from them.
VerseRef: Amali al-Mufid, p. 44, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 950

Verse: A man must never go on a journey in which he has cause to fear for his faith or his prayer
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 283, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 950

Verse: Verily the weakest person is the one who is incapable of supplicating.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 89, no. 136; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 900

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.), was asked by Muhammad b. Muslim about the situation of a man who becomes ritually impure (mujnib) during his journey, and has nothing but snow or ice at his disposal [and therefore cannot perform the obligatory bath to purify himself]. Im m (AS) replied, 'This is a situation of primary necessity, and I do not think that he should ever return to such a place where his religion is at stake
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 222, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 950

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.), was once at his brother `Aabdullah b. Muhammad's house when `Aamr b. Hurayth entered and asked him, 'What has brought you to this place?' to which he replied, 'Seeking recreation.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 461, no. 2595; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 950

Verse: We had gone out for a picnic when one of the servants forgot to bring the salt. Even though they had slaughtered the plumpest sheep there was for us, it was of no use to us until we left
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 326, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 951

Verse: Do not cut down fruit trees for Allah will pour down punishment unto you
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 264, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 952

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.), was once asked about cutting down trees, to which he replied, 'There is no objection to it.' `Aammar b. Musa narrates that he asked him further, 'What about the lotus tree?' to which he again replied, 'There is no objection to it. What is objectionable is cutting down lotus trees that grow in the desert, for there are so few of them there. Here, however, it is not a problem
VerseRef: al-Kafi, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 952

Verse: I heard Imam al-Rida (AS) say: "Alif, lam, mim. Do people imagine that they will be left off (on their own) saying: "We believe!" and they will not be tried", and he then asked me, 'What is trial?' I said, 'May my soul be sacrificed for you, what I know is that it is to be tested in religion.' He said, 'They [the believers] will be tried the way gold is tried', he then said, 'They will be purified the way gold is purified (Tradition by Mu`aammar b. Khallad )
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 370, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 952

Verse: I fear for you the trials that are in good times more than in bad times. You have been struck with tests of bad times and you have endured them with patience, while verily the world remains sweet and luxuriant [to you].
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 4, p. 184, no. 74; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 953

Verse: Trials are of three kinds: love of women, and this is the sword of the devil; drinking of wine, and this is the snare of the devil; and the love of dinars and dirhams, which is the arrow of the devil. So those who love women will not benefit from life, and those who love drinking will be barred from Heaven, and those who love the dinar and dirham are slaves of the world
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 140, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 953

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.), who was riding, said to a person by the name of Harb who was walking with him, 'Go back, for the walking of someone like you with me is a trial for a governor and a [source of] humiliation for the believer.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 322; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 953

Verse: Blessed are the sincere. They are the lanterns of guidance, and all dark trials are cleared away from them
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 1, p. 54, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 954

Verse: Know that those who are wary of their duty to Allah will find through Him a way out of the troubles of trials, and a light from darkness.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 183; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 954

Verse: He who ignites the fire of a troubling test will become its firewood
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10109; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 954

Verse: A brutal oppressing governor is better than a continuous trial.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9163; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 954

Verse: Grief is half of oldness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 849, Page No. 120

Verse: Guided and saved will be the ones who keep patient in calamity, who are grateful when gifted a bounty, who forgive in suffering tyranny, and who seek (God's) forgiveness after treating people unjustly.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 850; Page No. 120

Verse: Had God let the dwellers of Paradise do commerce, they would have been merchants of clothes and perfume.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 851; Page No. 121

Verse: Had ten of the Jews believed me, all of them would have done so.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 852, Page No. 121

Verse: Half of the graves dug for my people is due to evil eyes and gluttony.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 853; Page No. 121

Verse: Hand something to the poor even if it is a piece of burnt hoof.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 854; Page No. 121

Verse: Hardships lie on the way to Paradise, and passions pave the way to Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 858; Page No. 122

Verse: Haste in seeking knowledge, for uttering true words is better than the world and its gold and silver.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 859; Page No. 122

Verse: Have mercy (on people) and forgive them to receive divine Mercy and Forgiveness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 860; Page No. 122

Verse: Have mercy on the degraded formerly held in honor, the rich afflicted with poverty and the learned left unknown among the ignorant.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 861; Page No. 122

Verse: Have mercy on those who are on the earth to receive the Mercy of the One who is in the heavens.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 862; Page No. 122

Verse: Have supper, though a handful of bad date might be there, for surely doing the reverse brings old age and weakness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 863; Page No. 122

Verse: Having entered paradise, most of its dwellers I found of the unwise!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 864; Page No. 122&123

Verse: Having hope in God, and having faith (in this world) are sufficient for me.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 865; Page No. 123

Verse: He is not a believer whose neighbors do not feel safe against his evil.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 866; Page No. 123

Verse: He is not a liar who makes peace between two persons through good words or attribution of something good to any one of them.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 867; Page No. 123

Verse: What an excellent companion satisfaction is
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 819

Verse: He is not poor, who begs among people to get one or two morsels of food or one or two dates, but the one who does not have anything to make him needless, who is not attended with alms, and who does not make a request to people at the same time.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 868; Page No. 123

Verse: He who berates you, saves you (from his evil).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 869; Page No. 123

Verse: He who bids a good deed is like unto the doer of it, (indeed).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 870, Page No. 123

Verse: He who breaks the bonds of kinship will not be allowed to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 871, Page No. 123

Verse: He who hurts people the most here will be hurt the most by God in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 872; Page No. 123&124

Verse: He who in the path of truth walks, effectively talks.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 873; Page No. 124

Verse: Whoever does not endure his troubles ends up having to endure his own ruin.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8987; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 687

Verse: He whose patience gives him no deliverance is destroyed by anxiety.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 189; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 688

Verse: The origin of patience is to have strong conviction in Allah.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3084; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 688

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) never used to utter the words 'if only...' with regards to anything that had already passed
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 185, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 898

Verse: Exalt the old ones from amongst you and maintain relations between your kin.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 165, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 649

Verse: One who neither honours our old nor has mercy on our young is not one of us
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p.165, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 649

Verse: Accustom yourself to persevering in the face of adversity, and [you will see] how well persevering with the truth will become part of your natural disposition
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 688

Verse: Perseverance in the face of adversity protects the heart.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, no. 207, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 688

Verse: I have found conciliation   so long as it is does not enfeeble Islam   to be more beneficial than combat.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10138; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 689

Verse: Do not reject the peace to which your enemy may call you, and wherein the pleasure of Allah lies, for verily peace affords composure to your army, relief to you from your worries, and safety for the country. After the peace entreaty however, be extremely wary of your enemy, because often the enemy draws near in order to take advantage of your negligence. Therefore, act prudently and entertain good opinion about them, though always being on your guard.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 53; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 689

Verse: "One who benefits from a brother for the sake of Allah, Allah will permit him to benefit from a house in Paradise."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 198

Verse: The means to purify one's moral virtues is good etiquette.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5520; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 367

Verse: "One who recites after the conclusion of Friday Prayer, Surah Hamd once, Surah Tauheed, Surah Qul a-oo'dhu birabbil falaq and Surah Qul a-oo'dhu birabbinnaas seven times and Ayatal Kursi, Ayat-e-Sakhr and the last verse of Surah Baraat once it would be a compensation of his sins from that Friday to next."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 68

Verse: Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "One who recites after the conclusion of Friday Prayer, Surah Hamd once, Surah Qul a-oo'dhubirabbil falaq seven times, then Surah Hamd once and Surah Qul huwallaahu ah'ad seven times, then Surah Hamd once and Surah Qul a-oo'dhubirabbin Naas, no calamity would befall him and he won't be involved in any mischief. Further if he says: Allaahummaj a'lnee min ahlil jannatillatee h'ashwuhaa barakatunw wa u'mmaaruhal malaa-ikatu ma-a' nabiyyeenaa muh'ammadinw wa abeenaa ibraaheem Allah would keep him in Daarus Salaam (Paradise) along with Muhammad (s.a.w.s.) and Ibrahim (a.s.)."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 68/69

Verse: "Whenever people of the earth commit sins or get involved in wrong deeds, the Almighty Allah intends to send down His chastisement on the people of the world. However when He sees elderly people walking towards Salaat and young children learning Quran, He feels pity on them and postpones it."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 69

Verse: "One who is patient and blind and hopeful of divine rewards and is a lover of the progeny of Muhammad (s.a.w.s.) there would be no accounting of deeds for him."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 69

Verse: It is narrated that Allah does not take away one or both the eyes of a person except that He frees that person from being questioned about sins.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 69

Verse: "Leave laziness aside for your Lord is Merciful. He considers even a small deed of yours. A person who offers even a two rakat Salaat for the pleasure of Allah, He will make him enter Paradise for that. One who gives one dirham as Sadaqah seeking the pleasure of Allah, He would make him enter Paradise for that. One who fasts for a single day seeking the pleasure of Allah, He would make him enter Paradise for that."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 70

Verse: "Surely, the excellence of the Fridays of the month of Ramadan over ordinary Fridays is like the excellence of the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) over other prophets. Similar is the excellence of the month of Ramadan over all months."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 70

Verse: "Two rakat prayer prayed with perfume is equal to seventy rakat prayer offered without perfume."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 70

Verse: "Two rakat Salaat of a married person is equal to seventy rakats of an unmarried person."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 70

Verse: The narrator says that he heard Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) say, "One who offers a four rakat prayer reciting Surah Tauheed fifty times in each rakat all of his sins committed between him and Allah, the Mighty and Sublime, would be forgiven before he concludes it."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 71

Verse: Evil eye exists for sure. Satan and man's envy call it to action.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 572; Page No. 83&84

Verse: Evil eye exists, for sure. It is the only thing, which might change fate.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 573; Page No. 84

Verse: A man who is preoccupied with good manners has fewer vices.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8271; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 367

Verse: The narrator asked Imam Musa Kazim (a.s.) "What is the reward of offering Salaat-e-Ja'far-e-Tayyar?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "Allah would forgive that person even if his sins are equal to the number of grains of sand or number of waves in the oceans." The narrator asked, "Is this reward applicable for us?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "Of course, then for whom else? It is for you only." The narrator asked, "Which Surah should be recited in this Salaat?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "Recite Idhaa zulzilat, idhaa jaa-a nas'rullaah, innaa anzalnaahu fee lailatil qadr and qul huwallaahu ah'ad."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 71

Verse: "The honor of a believer is in offering Salaat-e-Shab and his prestige is in not asking from people."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 71

Verse: "Offer Salaat-e-Shab for it is the Sunnah of Muhammad (s.a.w.s.) and the virtuous that came before you. It removes all the ailments from your body."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 71

Verse: "Salaat-e-Shab brightens the face. It imparts a sweet smell and increase in earnings."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 71

Verse: "As Almighty Allah said, 'Wealth and children are the adornment of life', surely the eight rakat prayer offered in the last part of night is the adornment of the Hereafter."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 72

Verse: That a person came to him and expressed his wish. He was about to complain of his starvation when Imam asked him, "Do you offer Salaat-e-Shab?" He said, "Yes." Imam turned to him and said, "He is a liar that claims to offer Salaat-e-Shab and says that he has to starve during the day, because the Almighty Allah has guaranteed the sustenance of the day in the Salaat-e-Shab."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 72

Verse: You and the Hour will occur in the same epoch
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 190; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 794

Verse: Jesus son of Mary (AS) asked Gabriel (AS), 'When will the Hour come' upon which Gabriel started to tremble so severely that he fainted from it. When he came to his senses, he said, 'O Spirit of Allah, the questioned one does not know that any more than the questioner does. To Him belongs all that is in the heavens and the earth, and it [the Hour] will take you all by surprise.
VerseRef: Qasas al-Anbiya' li al-Rawandi, p. 271, no. 346; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 795

Verse: Man' s worst hours are three in number the hour wherein he will see the angel of death with his own eyes, the hour when he will rise up from his grave, and the hour when he will stand before Allah, Blessed and most High
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 119, no. 108; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 795

Verse: Man will die in the state that he has lived, and will be raised in the same state that he died
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 133; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 795

Verse: Verily you will meet your Lord barefooted, naked and uncircumcised.
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 4, p. 384, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 795

Verse: Listen O negligent and fickle one to someone who exhorts and expounds. The Day of Resurrection has been made a day of exposition, questioning, bestowal and exemplary punishment. It is the day when men' s deeds will be upturned, and all sins will be computed, when people' s pupils will melt with grief and expectant women will deliver what they carry in their wombs.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 653, no. 1353; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 796

Verse: And that is the day when Allah will gather all people from the first to the last, standing in subjugation in order to discuss the account [of their deeds] and the recompense for their actions. They will be bridled with their own sweat while the earth trembles under them. Those amongst them in the best state will be those who manage to find a stable place for their feet to stand and an open space for them to breathe!
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 102; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 796

Verse: The Day We shall gather the Godwary toward the All-beneficent, as incoming guests"[ Qur' an 1985], said, 'Verily these incoming guests will only enter mounted. They are the men who were wary of their duty to Allah, so Allah loved them, distinguished them and is well-pleased with their deeds, and has therefore named them the Godwary.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 95, no. 69; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 796

Verse: He who meets his fellow Muslims two-facedly and hypocritically [lit. having two-tongues] will be raised on the Day of Resurrection with two tongues of Fire
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 319, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 796

Verse: Whoever wrongfully consumes his fellow brother' s property and does not return it to him will be made to devour a burning log of fire on the Day of Resurrection
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 322, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 797

Verse: Whoever recites the Qur' an in order to deceive people thereby will be raised on the Day of Resurrection with a bony face without any flesh therein.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 329, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 797

Verse: Verily the proud ones will be transformed into tiny particles that people will trample underfoot until Allah finishes the account
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 311, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 797

Verse: When the Day of Resurrection comes, a caller will announce [on Allah' s behalf], 'Where are those who obstructed My friends' and a group of people with no flesh on their faces will stand, and it will be said of them, 'These are the people who troubled the believers, who declared enmity towards them, who opposed them and treated them harshly because of their religion.' Then they will be ordered into Hell.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 351, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 797

Verse: We have attached every person' s omen to his neck", said, 'The good and the evil he has done is with him wherever he is, and he cannot separate them until he is given his book about his deeds on the Day of Resurrection
VerseRef: Tafsir al-Qummi, v. 2, p. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 797

Verse: Read your book! Today your soul suffices as your own reckoner' , said, 'The servant will be reminded of everything that he had done and that was recorded against him, as if he had done it that very hour, and because of that they will say, "Woe to us! What a book this is! It omits nothing, big or small, without enumerating it[ Qur' an 1849]-
VerseRef: Tafsir al-`Ayyashi, v. 2, p. 328, no. 35; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 798

Verse: When the Day of Resurrection comes, man will be handed his book and told, 'Read it.' [The reporter of the tradition then asked him], 'And will he know what is in it' to which he replied, 'Verily he will remember it. There will not remain a single moment, a single word, a single footstep or anything that he did which he will not remember, as if he had done it that very hour. And this is why they will say, "Woe to us! What a book this is! It omits nothing, big or small, without enumerating it."
VerseRef: Tafsir al-`Ayyashi, no. 34; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 798

Verse: Verily when Allah, Blessed and most High, will wish to deal with the believer's account, He will give him his book in his right hand and will then take him to account for all that is between him and Himself, and will say, 'My servant, you have committed such and such and have done such and such!' and he will reply, 'Yes, my Lord, I have done that.' And Allah will say, 'I have forgiven you for them and have transformed them into good deeds' , so people will ask, 'Glory be to Allah, did this man not have a single evil deed!' and this is the purport of Allah' s verse "Then as for him who is given his record in his right hand, he shall soon receive an easy reckoning, and he will return to his folks joyfully" [Qur' an 847-9].[
VerseRef: al-Zuhd li al-Husayn b. Sa`aid, p. 92, no. 246; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 799

Verse: Verily when Allah, Blessed and most High, wishes to requite his servant with evil [as a result of his deeds], He will take him to account for them in front of everyone, and will reduce him to tears [on account of the proofs against him], and will give him his book in his left hand, and this is the purport of Allah' s verse "But as for him who is given his record from behind his back, he will pray for annihilation, and he will enter the Blaze. Indeed he used to be joyful among his folk" [Qur' an 8410-13
VerseRef: al-Zuhd li al-Husayn b. Sa`aid, p. 92, no. 246; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 799

Verse: Maymun b. Mihran narrated 'I was once sitting in the presence of al-Hasan b. Ali (AS) when a man came to him, saying, 'O son of the Prophet of Allah, verily x is claiming money from me that I owe him and wants to arrest me.' So he replied, 'By Allah, I do not have money to pay your debt on your behalf.' So he asked, 'Then talk to him.' So he (AS) put on his sandals, whereupon I asked him, 'O son of the Prophet of Allah, have you forgotten the fact that you are in a state of retreat' So he replied, 'No, I have not forgotten, but I have heard my father (SAWA) narrating on the authority of my grandfather, the Prophet of Allah (AS) that he had said, 'He who strives to fulfil a fellow Muslim brother' s need is as if he has worshipped Allah, Mighty and Exalted, for nine thousand years, fasting during the day and standing in prayer at night.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 2, p. 189, no. 2108; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 800

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) used to retreat in the mosque the last ten nights [of Ramadhan], when a tent of fur would be pitched for him, and he would roll up the skirting and lay out his bedding.
VerseRef: al-Tahdhib, v. 4, p. 287, no. 869; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 800

Verse: Retreat can only be in a congregational mosque wherein the congregational prayer is led by a just imam
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 176, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 800

Verse: The reward for your work is better than your work itself
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4688; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 800

Verse: The reward of the Hereafter causes one to forget the toil of this world
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4692; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 800

Verse: Allah, the Exalted, decreed reward for obeying Him and chastisement for disobeying Him, in order to protect His servants against His wrath and to herd them to His Paradise
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 368; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 801

Verse: The reward for any work is proportionate to the toil of performing it
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4690; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 801

Verse: He who makes efforts in favor of orphans and widows is like unto a struggler in the way of God or the one who stands up to prayer at night and keeps fast during the day.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 877, Page No. 124

Verse: He who provides our bazaars with something is like unto the one who struggles in the way of God, and he who hoards goods is like those called `infidels' in the Book of God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 878; Page No. 124

Verse: He who remembers God among the negligent is like unto the one who among the deserters (of the battlefield) remains steadfast and patient.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 879, Page No. 124

Verse: He who remembers God among the negligent is like unto the one who fights the deserters of the battlefield, is like unto a lamp in a dark house, and is like unto a green tree among cold-stricken leafless ones-one whose place of residence in Paradise is shown to him by God, and whose sins will He forgive even if they amount to the number of silent and speaking people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 880, Page No. 124&125

Verse: He who repents is like unto a sinless person, and he who asks God for forgiveness but insists in committing sins is like unto the one who ridicules Him, and he who annoys Muslims is sinful to the extent of palm groves.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 881; Page No. 125

Verse: He who repents is like unto a sinless person, and when God loves someone, he will be safe from sins.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 882; Page No. 125

Verse: He who takes back his gift is like unto a dog eating its vomit.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 883; Page No. 125

Verse: He who teaches good to people but forgets about himself is like unto a candle giving light to people but burning itself.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 884; Page No. 125

Verse: He who undertakes the affairs of a group of people, but carries it out without (enough) care and honesty, will be excluded from the Exalted God's Mercy, which extends to all things.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 885, Page No. 125

Verse: He who utters indecent words about the dead is like unto the one who is at the verge of ruin.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 886; Page No. 126

Verse: He who walks to pay a visit to a patient goes the direction of Paradise till he returns.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 887; Page No. 126

Verse: He whose death is left off to live for sixty years, will be spared any excuses (for his sins) by God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 888; Page No. 126

Verse: Health and relief are two unthanked blessing.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 889; Page No. 126

Verse: Hearsay is no evidence.When the Almighty Lord bespoke to Moses of his followers' tendency towards the Golden Calf, he did not break the tablets, but when he saw their corruption in person, he cast the tablets down and broke them.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 890, Page No. 126

Verse: Hearts are like unto roots in a land, turned over by wind (all the time).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 891, Page No. 126

Verse: Hell has a door through which nobody is allowed to pass, save those who quench their wrath by making the Exalted God angry.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 892; Page No. 126

Verse: Hell is not allowed to burn the eyes having shed tears out of God's fear, the eyes having been wide awake for God's sake, the eyes having been kept away from the unlawful and the eyes having been cut out in the way of God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 895; Page No. 127

Verse: Hell is not allowed to seize a gentle, lenient, and an easy-going man who keeps close relations with people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 896; Page No. 127

Verse: Hell is the abode of fraud, deceit and treachery.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 897; Page No. 127

Verse: Hell is the abode of oppressors and their supporters.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 898; Page No. 127

Verse: Hell is the dwelling of the cunning people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 899; Page No. 127

Verse: HellFire will be the abode of a person whose tongue frightens people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 900; Page No. 127

Verse: Helping a Muslim brother in his requests is more favorite to me than keeping fast for a month and having ritual seclusion in the holy Mosque.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 901; Page No. 127

Verse: Helping the poor, suspends terrible deaths.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 902; Page No. 127

Verse: The governance of senior people [of greater expertise] is one of the greatest advantages whereas the governance of wicked people humiliates noble people
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5112-5113; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 893

Verse: The fall of states can be discerned by four things: neglect of the fundamentals, embracing peripheral matters, bringing contemptible ones to the forefront and relegating the virtuous ones
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10965; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 893

Verse: The greatest of the rights that the Glorified [Allah] has made obligatory on man is the right of the ruler over the ruled and the right of the ruled over the ruler so if the ruled fulfil the rights of the ruler and the ruler fulfils their rights, then the truth attains the position of honour among them, the ways of religion become established, the marks of justice affirmed, the prophetic practice gets implemented correctly, current times improve, the continuance of the state is desired and the ambitions of the enemies are thwarted.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 216; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 893

Verse: Nothing fortifies states like justice
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9574; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 893

Verse: Make religion the fortress of your state, and thankfulness a protection for your bounties, because every state whose fortress is religion is invincible and every bounty encompassed by thankfulness remains.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5831; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 893

Verse: One of the signs of a [stable] government is vigilance in safeguarding matters
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9360; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 893

Verse: There is no need to stay awake at night except in three instances: when staying awake to recite the Qur'an, to gain knowledge, and for a bride to be offered to her husband
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 178, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 894

Verse: There is no need to stay up at night past the last `Aisha' prayer except in the case of two people: the person performing prayers, and the traveller.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 179, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 894

Verse: Staying awake at night is the garden of those who yearn [for Allah].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, p. 666; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 894

Verse: Staying awake at night engaged in acts of obedience to Allah is the springtime of the friends of Allah and the garden of the good-fortuned.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5613; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 894

Verse: The best of worship is for the eyes to remain awake engaged in the remembrance of Allah, Glory be to Him
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3149; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 894

Verse: So be conscious of your duty to Allah, O servants of Allah, with the caution of a wise man whose heart is preoccupied with reflection [about the Hereafter], whose body the fear [of Allah] has afflicted with pain, and whose engagement in the night prayer has turned his already short sleep into wakefulness
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 83; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 895

Verse: He who remains awake on the eve of `Aid al-fitr and on the eve of the 15th of Sha`aban, his heart will not die on the Day when hearts shall die.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, v. 1, p. 102, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 895

Verse: The Commander of the Faithful (AS) did not used to sleep at all on three nights: the 23rd night of the month of Ramazan, the eve of `Aid al-fitr, and the eve of the 15th of Sha`aban. And these are the nights when sustenance is allotted, and prescribed times of death and all that is to happen in that year is decreed.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 97, p. 88, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 895

Verse: For every misguidance there is a cause, and behind every disloyal act is an obscurity.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 148; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 895

Verse: Know that indeed the paths to religion are one, and its courses lead straight ahead. Whoever follows them attains the objective, and whoever stops, moving away from them, strays and ends up regretful
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 142; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 896

Verse: Look at the household of your Prophet and adhere to their direction Do not overtake them, for then you will stray, nor lag behind them lest you fall into ruin
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 97; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 896

Verse: He who seeks guidance from the wrong source goes astray.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7501; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 896

Verse: Verily the most evil of people in the sight of Allah is the tyrannical leader who himself has gone astray and through whom others go astray. He abolishes established practices and revives abandoned innovations.'
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 164; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 896

Verse: Remember God in treating your servants. Dress them, feed them and talk to them gently.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1666; Page No. 236

Verse: Remember God when you are at ease, and He will remember you in hardships.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1667; Page No. 236

Verse: Remember God, for He is your supporter in (all) affairs.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1668; Page No. 236

Verse: Seek its assistance [i.e. the Qur'an's] in your distress, for verily it contains the cure for the deadliest diseases, namely disbelief and hypocrisy, revolt and misguidance
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 176; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 897

Verse: Indeed this Islam is the religion of Allah which he has chosen for Himself   and has smashed the pillars of misguidance with its one pillar.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 198; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 897

Verse: It is narrated in Bihar al-Anwar that Allah, most High, revealed to Prophet David (AS) saying, 'I want [something] and you want [something else], and verily only My will is done. Therefore, if you submit to what I want, I will suffice you in what you want. If you do not submit to My will, however, I will exhaust you in your quest for what you want, until only what I want will be.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 136, no. 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 898

Verse: Out of all that Allah has created, the worthiest person of submission to Allah's decree is he who knows Allah
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 153, no. 63; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 898

Verse: Indeed we desire for ourselves and those we love to be blessed with well-being, but when Allah's command comes, we submit to what He loves
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 46, p. 301, no. 44; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 898

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.), was once asked how a believer may ascertain that he is indeed a believer, to which he replied, 'Through submission to Allah and satisfaction with whatever source of happiness or discontent that comes his way.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 205, no. 91; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 898

Verse: A Muslim is the brother of a fellow Muslim - he neither wrongs him nor insults him.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 745; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 488

Verse: A Muslim is the brother of a fellow Muslim - he neither betrays him nor lies to him nor deceives him.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 747; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 488

Verse: The Muslim is the mirror of a fellow Muslim.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 742; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 488

Verse: The foundation of Islam is love for me and love for my household.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 37631c; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 489

Verse: Islam is that you submit your heart [to Allah], and that all Muslims feels safe from your tongue and your hand.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 490

Verse: No one can gain anything better than the knowledge leading its holder to guidance or saving him/her from danger, and no one's faith gets perfected unless his/her wisdom is improved.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1381; Page No. 196

Verse: No one is allowed to put himself/herself into trouble in serving his guests.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1382; Page No. 196

Verse: No one is deprived of the world(secular benefits) without being rewarded in good.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1383; Page No. 196

Verse: No one is more capable of making a living than others, for God has predestined calamity, death, business and sustenance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1384; Page No. 196

Verse: No one is more superior to God than a leader who tells the truth when speaking and administers justice when judging.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1385; Page No. 197

Verse: Some sins are irremissible, some are not left of account, and some are forgiven, i.e. taking partners with God, oppressing one another, and one's deeds known only to him and the Exalted God respectively.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1779; Page No. 252

Verse: Some sins are remissible, some are irremissible and some punishable, i.e. your deeds known to you and God, taking partners with God and oppressing your brethren respectively.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1780; Page No. 252

Verse: Sons of Adam are entitled to no more than the shade of a house, a dry loaf of bread and a piece of cloth to cover their privy parts.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1781; Page No. 252

Verse: Sons of Adam do not have any deed better than saying prayer, reconciling people and behaving well.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1782; Page No. 252

Verse: Sons of Adam will in the Day of Judgment be surely regretful for times of forgetting God in this world.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1783; Page No. 252

Verse: Souls are like disciplined armies-familiar souls are allied and unfamiliar ones, aliens.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1784; Page No. 252

Verse: Speak well and feed people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1785; Page No. 252

Verse: Spend (in the way of God) but do not count the amount, for God will then count (your sins); and do not be stingy (towards people), for God will do the same to you.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1786; Page No. 253

Verse: Start being charitable to yourself and then proceed to your household, your relatives and others respectively. Again, begin it from your household.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1787; Page No. 253

Verse: Staying at home saves man from seditions.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1788; Page No. 253

Verse: Stomach is the home (source) of all illness, and abstinence from gluttony is the best drug.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1789; Page No. 253

Verse: Stop griefs and sorrows through charity so that the Exalted God save you from them and grant you victory over enemies.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1790; Page No. 253

Verse: Strengthen marriage contract and make it known to people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1791; Page No. 253

Verse: Strengthen the ties of kinship by remembering your family frequently.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1792; Page No. 253

Verse: Strengthen your control of women through (providing them with) insufficient clothing, for when a woman comes to have excessive dresses and ornaments, she tends to roam outside home.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1793; Page No. 253&254

Verse: Strong is the one who has self-control.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1794; Page No. 254

Verse: Struggle (in the path of Deity), healthy and needless to be.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1795; Page No. 254

Verse: An Imam is purified from sins, immune from all flaws.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 200, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 431

Verse: He whose good manners surpass his reason is like a shepherd among numerous sheep.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8886; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 365

Verse: The narrator says that he asked Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.), "What is the best time to offer Morning Prayer?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "It is from the start of dawn; for Allah says, Inna qur-aanal fajri kaana mash-hoodaa. It means the angels of morning and evening hear the Fajr prayer. One who prays this Salaat at the start of dawn its reward would be noted down twice   once by the angels of night and once by the angels of the day."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 65/66

Verse: "The excellence of prime time over the last moments for a believer is more than his children and his wealth."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 66

Verse: "The excellence of prime time over the last moments is like the excellence of Hereafter over this world."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 66

Verse: "If an obligatory prayer is offered in prime time fulfilling all the conditions a sweet smell would come out from it just like the sweet smell that comes out when a branch of tree is broken. Hence it is obligatory on you to offer Salaat at its prime time."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 66

Verse: Amirul Momineen (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "The best among you are those who offer Qasr prayer and do not observe fast during travel."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 66

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that his father said, "If a traveler among you offers Friday Prayer for the sake of devotion and love of Almighty, Allah grants him reward equal to one hundred non-travelers' Friday Salaat."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 67

Verse: "The excellence of congregational prayers is twenty three times that of prayer offered alone and this one congregational prayer is equal to twenty five prayers."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 67

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "For one who offers Salaat in congregation with faith and for seeking divine rewards, a new record of his deeds would be created (blotting out all sins he has committed before)."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 67

Verse: The narrator heard Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) say, "One who gets a Friday, should not get involved in anything except worship because people are forgiven and mercy is showered on this day."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 67

Verse: "None of our Shias gets up for prayer except that he is surrounded by angels equal to the number of enemies around him and they pray behind him and supplicate to Allah, the Mighty and the Sublime for him till he finishes his prayer."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 67

Verse: "After you pray the Asr prayers on Friday recite as follows: Allaahumma s'alli a'laa muh'ammadinw wa aali muh'ammadin alaa aus'iyaa-il mursaleena bi-afz"ali s'alawaatika wa baarik wa baarika a'laihim bi-afz"ali barakaatika was salaamu a'laihim wa a'laa arwaah'ihim wa ajsaamidihim wa rah'matullaahi wa barakaatuh. For one who recites this after Asr, Allah writes for him a hundred thousand rewards, wipes out a hundred thousand sins. Fulfills a hundred thousand wishes of him and increases his position by a hundred thousand levels."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 68

Verse: A neighbor has (specific) rights.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 114; Page No. 24

Verse: The best servants of God to Him are the most good-tempered.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1940; Page No. 271

Verse: The first duty incumbent upon you towards Allah, Glory be to Him, is thanksgiving for His favours and seeking out His pleasure
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3329; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 931

Verse: Every single breath you take necessitates an essential thanks from you, or rather a thousand thanks or more
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 52, no. 77; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 931

Verse: It is narrated in Misbah al-Shari`aa (The Lantern of the Path): 'If there was to be an act of worship for Allah's sincere servants to carry out better in the sight of Allah than thanksgiving to Him in every situation, He would have definitely singled out these worshippers for a mention from amongst the rest of creation for their carrying out this special act of worship. And for the very fact that there is no better act of worship than it [i.e. thanksgiving], He has distinguished it from all other acts of worship and has distinguished those who practice it, saying, "And very few of My servants are truly thankful
VerseRef: Misbah al-Shari`a, p. 55; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 932

Verse: The thankful person prospers more as a result of his thanks than as a result of the bounty which incited the thanks, because bounties are sources of delight whereas [the ability] to thank is not only the consequence [of the bounty] but a source of delight in itself
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 483; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 932

Verse: None but the thankful one knows the true worth of a bounty, and none but the one with inner knowledge [or gnostic] is truly thankful for a bounty.
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, p. 313; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 932

Verse: Allah does not open the door of thanks for His servant and keep the door of increase shut
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 94, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 932

Verse: When Allah bestows a bounty upon a servant, no sooner does the latter feel thankful for it in his heart than he becomes deserving of increase therein before the expression of thanks has even reached his tongue
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 580, no. 1197; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 932

Verse: So how can I ever achieve thanksgiving?! For my thanking You requires thanksgiving in itself. Whenever I say, 'To You belongs Praise [Thanks]', it becomes thereby incumbent upon me to say, 'To You belongs Praise [Thanks].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 94, p. 146, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 933

Verse: Allah, most High, revealed to Prophet Moses (AS) saying, 'O Moses, thank Me with the thanks that is due to Me.' Moses asked, 'O Lord, but how can I thank You with the thanks that is due to You, when every single expression of thanks that I may convey has been bestowed upon Me by You?' He replied, 'O Moses, you thank Me with the thanks that is due to Me when you acknowledge that it is indeed from Me.
VerseRef: Qasas al-Anbiya' li al-Rawandi, p. 161, no. 178; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 933

Verse: True] thanksgiving for every bounty lies in restraining oneself from the things that Allah has prohibited
VerseRef: Mishkat al-Anwar, p. 35; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 933
