VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 29, no. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 96

Verse: He who seeks to please Allah at the expense of displeasing people, Allah suffices him in everything including his affairs with people. But the one who seeks to please people at the expense of Allah's displeasure, Allah relegates him to those very people.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 208, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 97

Verse: The light of inner knowledge is brought about by hunger whereas distance from Allah is caused by satiety. Proximity to Allah is brought about by loving the poor and drawing near to them, so do not eat to your fill lest the light of inner knowledge be extinguished from your hearts.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 71, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 434

Verse: The inner knowledge of the self is the most beneficial of all such knowledge.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9865; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 434

Verse: The one who attains knowledge of his own self has obtained the greatest victory indeed.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9965; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 434

Verse: How can one who is ignorant of his own self expect to know others?!
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6998; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 434

Verse: He who gains inner knowledge of his self combats it, and he who remains ignorant of his self, neglects it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, nos. 7855-7856; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 434

Verse: He who attains inner knowledge of Allah leads a life of unity [reflecting Allah's Divine Unity]; he who attains inner knowledge of his self strips himself [of all that hinders its progress]; he who attains inner knowledge about this world abstains from it; and he who attains inner knowledge about people prefers solitude.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, nos. 7829-7832; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 435

Verse: The person who knows his self the best is he who fears his Lord the most.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3126; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 435

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) said, "I am bearing patiently the bitter behavior of this servant and my family regarding the matter of Hanzal. One who is patient, is like one who stays up at night for prayers, observes fast and one who is martyred while fighting alongside Muhammad (s.a.w.s.).
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 251

Verse: "One who remains patient on a calamity, Allah will increase his honor and make him enter Paradise along with the Holy Prophet and his Ahle Bayt (a.s.).
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 251

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "Saying words of condolence is a way to enter Paradise."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 252

Verse: "One who says words of condolence to a sad person, will be awarded a fine dress to be worn on the Day of Judgment."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 252

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) condoled a person for the death of his son and said, "The Holy Prophet has passed away from this world. Why don't you see the good qualities of this great personality?" He replied, "My son was a sinner." Imam (a.s.) said, "He has three things in front of him. God willing, he won't waste any of them. Firstly, the testimony that there is no god except Allah, mercy of God and intercession of the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.)."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 252

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "One who condoles a person afflicted by calamity, will get reward equal to the latter while the reward of the latter won't be reduced."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 252

Verse: By Allah, they have not been punished with anything more severe than Imla (respite).
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 110; Safinatun Behaar

Verse: The narrator says that he went to a graveyard along with Ibrahim bin Hashim. Ibrahim sat at a grave facing the Qiblah, kept his hands on the grave and recited Surah Qadr seven times. He said, "It is the grave of Muhammad bin Ismail bin Bazee', who had narrated a tradition that one who visits the grave of a believer and recites Surah Qadr seven times, Allah is responsible for the salvation of that person and the dead believer."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 252

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that Amirul Momineen (a.s.) said, "If a believing man or woman strokes the head of an orphan with mercy, Allah will grant him/her a light for each hair of the head of that orphan."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 253

Verse: Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "One who is wary of his hard-heartedness and if he strokes the head of an orphan gently, he will become soft-hearted by the order of Allah and it is the right of an orphan." It is narrated in another tradition that one should make orphans sit in ones gatherings and stroke their heads gently so that one can become soft-hearted. One becomes soft-hearted by the order of Allah as soon as he/she performs this deed."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 253

Verse: "Surely the Divine throne begins to tremble when an orphan cries and the Almighty Allah says: Who has made this servant of Mine cry, whose parents were taken back by me while he was young? I swear by My honor that I will make Paradise obligatory for one who consoles him."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 253

Verse: The narrator says that he was with Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) when the discussion was about a believer. Imam turned towards him and said, "O Abul Fazl! Do you want me to tell you the position of a believer near Allah?" "Yes," he replied. Imam said, "Whenever Allah captures the soul of a believer, two angels go to Allah and say that Your so and so servant was a good person, he used to hasten to Your obedience and shunned Your prohibitions. Now what do You order us after capturing his soul? Allah will order the angels to go near the grave of the believer and glorify Allah. He would write the reward of this deed for His servant till the day he is resurrected." Imam asked, "Do you want me to narrate a few more excellences?" "Yes," replied he and Imam (a.s.) said, "When Allah resurrects that believer, his look-alike will also come out with him and it will move ahead of the believer. Whenever the believer fears the stages of the Day of Judgment, this look-alike will tell him not to fear or aggrieve. It will go on giving him glad tidings about good fortune and divine mercy." "The accounting of deeds will be easy for him and he will be ordered to enter Paradise. This look-alike will walk in front of the believer and the latter will ask: How good you are! You were resurrected from my grave and you are providing me happiness and glad tidings of divine mercy continuously. I have seen everything. After all, who are you? The look-alike will reply: I am the same happiness which you had given to a believer in the world. Allah had created me to give you glad tidings."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 253/254

Verse: "Surely Allah will shower mercy on a person who loves his children greatly."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 254

Verse: He who loves his world has harmed his Hereafter.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 81, no. 43; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1006

Verse: Sorrows are the ailments of the hearts just as illnesses are the ailments of the body
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 118, no. 276; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 883

Verse: "One who goes to the market and buys gifts for his near and dear ones, its reward is equal to that of paying sadaqah to a community of needy people. Present gifts to your daughters before sons. A person who makes his daughter happy will get the reward of freeing a slave from the progeny of Ismail (a.s.). A person who makes his sons happy will get the reward of weeping in the fear of Allah. A person who weeps in the fear of Allah, will be rewarded a Paradise full of bounties."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 255

Verse: "Daughters are good deeds while sons are bounties. One will be rewarded for his good deeds and have to account for bounties received."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 255

Verse: The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) was given the glad tidings of the birth of Fatima Zahra (s.a.). The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) saw signs of sadness on the faces of his companions and said, "What has happened to you? It is a fragrance, which is making me happy and its sustenance is guaranteed by the Almighty Allah."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 255

Verse: A person was present with Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) when he was informed that his wife gave birth to a girl. The color of his face changed. The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) asked what had happened to him. He requested the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) to leave the topic aside. When the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) insisted, he said that his wife was having labor pains when he left the house and now she has given birth to a girl. The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "The burden of that girl is borne by the earth and sky will provide her shelter. Her sustenance is guaranteed by Allah and it is a fragrance you will smell." Then he turned towards the companions and said, "One who has one daughter is burdened. One who has two daughters, you should help him in his problems. One who has three daughters is exempted from jihad and all other difficulties. One who has four daughters, O servants of Allah, help him, give him loans and shower mercy on him."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 255/256

Verse: It is narrated from Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) or Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) that he said, "Whenever a girl is born, Allah appoints an angel near that child, who touches his wings over her head and chest saying: It is created with weakness. One who bears her expenses will be helped on the Day of Judgment."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 256

Verse: A monk from Bani Israel worshipped Allah so much that he become like a dry stick. Allah, the Mighty and Sublime revealed to His prophet of that time to go and say to him that (Allah says), "By My Greatness, Might and Power, even if you worship Me till you melt like something in the cooking pot, also, I will not accept it from you until you come to Me from the door I have ordered for you."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 258

Verse: "Keep away from carelessness because a careless person is careless about himself. Do not underestimate the command of Allah, the Mighty and Sublime because Allah will disgrace such persons on the Day of Judgment."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 258

Verse: Fasting is a shield as long as lying or backbiting does not tear it off.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 594, Page No. 86

Verse: Fasting is half of patience. For everything some alms are due, and for the body, fasting.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 595, Page No. 87

Verse: Fasting is half of patience.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 596, Page No. 87

Verse: The world is the ground of ruin for the intellects.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 921; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 999

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w.s.) said, "Allah, the Mighty and Sublime will resurrect as a Jew one who hates our Ahle Bayt." He was asked, "O Messenger of Allah! What if that person recites shahadatain?" The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) replied, "He is like a Jew who has recited shahadatain to save his life or honor or to exempt himself from payment of Jizyah." Further it is also narrated that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "A person who hates our Ahle Bayt will be resurrected as a Jew." He was asked as to why it is so. He replied, "Because if they live in the age of Dajjal, they will start following his religion."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 258/259

Verse: It is narrated from Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "People who hate us, Ahle Bayt will be raised on the Day of Judgment as lepers (having no hands)."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 259

Verse: The narrator says that Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) told him, "O Mualla! Even if one prays between rukn and maqaam for a hundred years continuously, fasting during the day and passing nights in Qiyam and prostrating so much so that his brows hang in front of his eyes, his back stoops but he is unaware of our rights, there is no reward for him."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 259

Verse: The narrator says that Imam Zainul Abideen (a.s.) asked him, "Which land is excellent?" The narrator said, "Allah, His messenger and the son of His messenger know best." Imam (a.s.) said, "The best place is the area between rukn and maqaam. One who gets a life as long as that of prophet Nuh i.e. of 950 years, and if he fasts during the day and offers prayers at this best place at night for his whole life and if he goes to Allah without our love, he will not get benefit of any of his deeds."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 259/260

Verse: The narrator was in the company of Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) and there were about fifty people sitting there. After a long pause, Imam (a.s.) prompted, "What has happened to you? Probably you are thinking that I am a prophet of Allah. I swear by Allah that it is not so and I am in relation with the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) and I am from his progeny. Whoever does good to us will receive goodness from God. Allah will love one who loves us. Allah will deprive one who deprives us. Do you know which part of land is best in position near Allah?" Everyone remained silent. Imam (a.s.) continued, "This holy Mecca is the land most liked by Allah. He made it His Sanctuary and considered it as His house. Do you know which part of Mecca is most honored?" Everyone remained silent and Imam (a.s.) replied himself, "Masjidul Haraam is the most honored part of Mecca. Do you know which place of Masjidul Haraam is most honored by Allah?" Everyone kept quiet and Imam (a.s.) replied himself once again, "That place is between rukn-e-Aswad, maqaam-e-Ibrahim and the door of Kaaba. This is the place of Hateem of Ismail. He had given his sacrifice over here and offered Salaat. I swear by Allah that one who offers prayers at this place standing all night and fasts during day but if he is unaware of our rights and greatness of we, Ahle Bayt, Allah will never accept any of his deeds."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 260

Verse: The world is a plantation of evil.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 401; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 999

Verse: The world lowers and abases [mankind].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 999

Verse: The narrator asked Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) the meaning of the saying of the Holy Prophet that one who dies without the recognition of Imam, dies the death of ignorance. Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) pointed to his chest and said, "When the state reaches here you will need it (recognition of Imam) much. Your thinking is good regarding this."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 261

Verse: "We are the Imams whose obedience is obligatory. One who denies us, will die as a Jew or a Christian. I swear by Allah, this earth is not deprived of a guiding Imam since the passing away of Prophet Adam (a.s.). They are proofs of Allah on His servants. Whoever kept away from them were destroyed and Allah guarantees salvation for those who obey them."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 261

Verse: Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "Allah, the Mighty and Sublime said: Whoever from the Muslim community obeys an unjust ruler not appointed by Allah, Allah will send chastisement on him even if there are good deeds of that community and even if the people are pious. Whoever from the Muslim community obeys the guide appointed by Allah, Allah will surely forgive him even if he has injustice and sins written in his scroll of deeds."
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, page 261

Verse: By my life, never will I compromise with or be slack when fighting anyone who opposes the truth or one who has fallen into transgression
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 24; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 695

Verse: O Ibn Mas`aud, beware of ever associating anything with Allah for even the twinkling of an eye, even if you are to be cut up with a saw, amputated, crucified or burnt with fire.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 357, no. 2660; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 696

Verse: Verily the Umayyads used to freely point out people's faith to them [condescendingly], but did not freely point out polytheism, so that when it came to their converting them [the people] to it, they would not be able to recognise it
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 415, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 696

Verse: Imam Muhammad ibn 'Ali al-Baqir (a.s.) was once asked what the absolute minimum of polytheism was, to which he replied, 'It is to call fruit kernels stones and vice versa, and to believe them as such.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 397, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 697

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) was once asked what the absolute minimum of polytheism was, to which he replied, 'It is to contrive a ruling and falsely cause people to take sides for and against it
VerseRef: al-Kafi, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 697

Verse: Beware of committing anything that warrants justification, for verily that is hidden polytheism
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 200, no. 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 697

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said when interpreting the Qur'anic verse: "And most of them do not believe in Allah without ascribing partners to Him", 'This is in reference to man's statement: "Were it not for 'x' I would surely have perished", or "Were it not for 'x' I would indeed have been afflicted" or "Were it not for 'x' my family would be at a loss." Do you not see that he has associated a partner to Allah in His Kingdom giving him sustenance and repelling misfortune from him?' He was subsequently asked, 'What if one were to say, "Were it not for Allah granting me x's help, I would have perished ?" Imam replied, 'There is nothing wrong with saying things like this.
VerseRef: Tafsir al-`Ayyashi, v. 2, p. 200, no. 96; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 697

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said when interpreting the Qur'anic verse: "And most of them do not believe in Allah without ascribing partners to Him", 'This refers to ascribing partners in Allah's obedience, not [just] in His worship
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 397, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 698

Verse: Polytheism is more discreet than the crawling of an ant, and includes things like turning one's ring to make a wish, and other such [superstitions].
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 379, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 698

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said when interpreting the Qur'anic verse: "And most of them do not believe in Allah without ascribing partners to Him", 'This refers to when people used to say, 'We are being rained on from the storm of x, or the storm of y [referring to various false gods]. And they used to consult soothsayers and believe whatever they told them
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 58, p. 317, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 698

Verse: Verily possessiveness is part of faith
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 3, p. 444, no. 4541; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 699

Verse: My father Abraham [i.e. the prophet] was very possessive [i.e. guarding of his own self-worth] and I am even more possessive than him. Allah abases the one who has no sense of self-worth from among the believers
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 248, no. 33; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 699

Verse: Verily the fragrance of Paradise can be smelt from a distance of five hundred years, but neither the one who is insolent towards his parents not the cuckold will ever smell it.' When asked, 'O Prophet of Allah, what is a cuckold?' he replied, 'It is one whose wife commits adultery with his knowledge of it
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 3, p. 444, no. 4542; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 699

Verse: The worth of a man is in proportion to his ambition   his courage is in proportion to his self-esteem, and his chastity is in proportion to his possessiveness [i.e. over his own wife].
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 47; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 699

Verse: A man who is possessive [over his own wife] will never commit adultery
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 305; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 700

Verse: Verily Allah is possessive over the believer, so let him who is not possessive become possessive [through a sense of self-worth], for verily he has a degenerative heart
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 204, 455; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 700

Verse: Verily Allah, Blessed and most High, is very possessive and loves every possessive one, and as a result of His possessiveness [over His servants], he has prohibited indecent acts, both those done in public as well as those done in secret.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 535, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 700

Verse: Beware of being overpossessive [of your wife] in a situation that does not necessitate it, for verily that will lead a wife of sound character from among them to become weak. Rather judge them carefully so that when you see a fault, you hasten your reproach of it, both major and minor [faults].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 214, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 700

Verse: A woman's overpossessiveness is [tantamount to] infidelity, whereas a man's overpossessiveness is [part of his] faith
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 124; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 701

Verse: Damned is the one who insults his father and mother.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 432; Page No. 65

Verse: Women's overpossessiveness is jealousy, and jealousy is the root of infidelity. Verily when women are overpossessive, they become enraged, and when they are enraged, they disbelieve, except the Muslim women from among them
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 505, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 701

Verse: There is no jealous possessiveness [warranted] in what is lawful
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 537, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 701

Verse: Poverty is almost infidelity
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 307, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 701

Verse: If it was not for my Lord's mercy on the poor of my community, poverty would just about be infidelity.
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 300 no. 817; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 702

Verse: Poverty is blackness of the face in the two worlds
VerseRef: Aaw`ali al-La'ali, v. 1, p. 40, no. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 702

Verse: Poverty is worse than killing
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 299, no. 816; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 702

Verse: Poverty is the greater death.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 319; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 702

Verse: Poverty silences the sagacious from his proof, and a poor person is a foreigner in his own country
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 702

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) says that the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w.s.) turned towards his companions and said, "Pick up the shield of Allah." The companions asked, "There is no enemy, why should we pick up the shield?" The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "Pick it up for combating the Hell and recite Sub-h'aanallaahi wal h'amdu lillaahi wa laa ilaaha illallaahu wallaahu akbar."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 36

Verse: "Recite Sub-h'aanallaahi wal h'amdu lillaahi wa laa ilaaha illallaahu wallaahu akbar often because this statement will come to you surrounded by angels and will be included among your good deeds."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page37

Verse: "One who says Sub-h'aanallah Allah will plant a tree for him in Paradise. One who says Al-h'amdulillaah then too a tree will be planted for him in Paradise. Similarly, One who says Laa ilaaha illallaah then also Allah will plant a tree for him in Paradise. Allah will also plant a tree for one who recites Allaahu Akbar. A man of Quraish said: O the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w.s.), then there would be many trees in Paradise for us? Yes, but be careful that you do not send fire or they all would get burnt up. That is why the Almighty Allah said: "O you who believe! Obey Allah and obey the Apostle, and do not make your deeds of no effect".(Surah Muhammad 47:33)
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 37

Verse: One day the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w.s.) asked his companions, "Do you know that if your clothes and utensils are gathered in one place and kept one above another they reach the sky?" They replied, "No!" The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "Should I tell you about a thing whose roots are in the earth and branches above the sky?" Everyone replied, "Indeed we want to know it." The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "One who recites Sub-h'aanallaahi wal h'amdu lillaahi wa laa ilaaha illallaahu wallaahu akbar (the roots of this statement are in the earth and its branches are above the sky) thirty times after each obligatory prayers the above statement will safeguard him from being crushed under a wall, drowning, falling in well, falling prey to wild animals, death due to accidents and from dangerous things falling from skies. This statement will remain as permanent good deeds for him.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 37

Verse: "One who recites: Sub-h'aanallahi wa bih'amdihi sub-h'aanallaahil a'z'eemi wa bih'amdih, the Almighty Allah will grant him three thousand rewards, increase three thousand grades and create a bird for him, which will glorify God and its reward will be given to that person."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 38

Verse: "For one who recites Sub-h'aanallaah without surprise Allah will create a bird from it, having a tongue and two wings. It will glorify Allah for that person till the Day of Judgment. The recitation of statement Al-h'amdulillaahi wa laa ilaaha illallaahu wallaahu akbar also holds the same reward."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 38

Verse: Yunus bin Yaqoob says that he asked Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.), "[O son of Messenger of Allah (s.a.w.s.)] One who recites Sub-h'aanallaah a hundred times, will he be counted among the ones who remember Allah a lot?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "Yes."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 38

Verse: All the angels of heaven who write, cannot note the reward of a person who says Al-h'amdulillaahi kamaa huwa ahluh?" Someone asked, "Why is it so?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "(Angels do not know the reward of this statement so they will say to Allah): O Lord! We do not have the knowledge of unseen. Then God will say, 'You write the statement as My servant says, I will reward him accordingly.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 39

Verse: One   who   says: Alhamdulillaahi rabbil a'alameen four times every morning has without any doubt thanked for this day and one who says it in the night has thanked for that night.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 39

Verse: Zurarah narrates that he asked Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.), "What deed Allah likes best?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "His glorification."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 39

Verse: The Almighty Allah glorifies Himself thrice every day and night. One who glorifies Him like this will have good fortune if he had a bad one. Zurarah asked, "How to glorify Him?" Imam (a.s.) replied, "Say: antallaahu laa ilaaha illar rabbul a'alameena antallaahu laa ilaaha illaa antar rah'maanar rah'eema antallaahu laa ilaaha illaa anta a'liyyil kabeeri antallaahu laa ilaaha illaa anta maaliki yaumiddeeni antallaahu laa ilaaha illaa antal ghafoorur rah'eemi antallaahu laa ilaaha illaa antal a'zeezul h'akeemi antallaahu laa ilaaha illaa anta minka bad-u kulli shai-inw wa ilaika ya-oo'da antallaahu laa ilaaha illaa anta lam tazal wa laa tazaalu antallaahu laa ilaaha illaa anta khaaliqul khairi wash sharru antallaahu laa ilaaha illaa anta khaaliqul jannati wannaari antallaahu laa ilaaha illaa antal ah'adus' s'amadu lam yalid wa lam yoolad wa lam yakullahu kufuwan ah'adu antallaahu laa ilaaha illaa antal malikul quddoosus salaamul mu-minul muhaiminul a'zeezul jabbaarul mutakabbiru sub-h'aanallaahi a'mmaa yushrikoona antallaahul khaaliqul baari-ul mus'awwiru lakal asmaa-ul h'usnaa yusabbih'u laka maa fis samaawaati wal arz"i wa antal a'zeezul h'akeemi antallaahu laa ilaaha illaa antal kabeeru wal kibri-yaa-u ridaa-uk."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 40

Verse: God-willing, a wise person will end up in Paradise.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 40

Verse: A wise person is religious and a religious person will enter Paradise.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 40

Verse: There are ten such virtues that one who meets God possessing them will go to Paradise. (They are) bearing witness that there is no God except Allah and Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, having faith in what Muhammad brought from Allah, establishing prayers, payment of Zakat, fasting in the month of Ramadan, Hajj of the House of Allah, faith and love of the friends of Allah, condemning the enemies of God and abstinence from all intoxicants.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 40

Verse: Do not sit at a table on which wine is served, for a man does not know when he is overcome
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 10, p. 98, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 874

Verse: Never sit in the [middle of the] roads.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 8, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 874

Verse: He who believes in Allah and the Last Day must not sit in a suspicious place
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 378, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 874

Verse: Certainly He has sent down to you in the Book that when you hear Allah's signs being disbelieved and derided, do not sit with them until they engage in some other discourse", said, 'It means that [when you hear] someone denying the truth and rejecting it and speaking ill about the Imams, you should stand up and leave him and never sit with him again no matter who he might be.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 377, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 875

Verse: A believer must not sit in a place where Allah is disobeyed if he is unable to make a change
VerseRef: al-Kafi,v.2, p. 374, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 875

Verse: Assemblies are about trust, and exposing your brother's secret [therein] is betrayal. Therefore avoid that, and avoid the tribal assembly.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 89, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 875

Verse: Good manners may substitute for [noble] lineage.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 68, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 364

Verse: There is no personal merit more useful than good manners.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 428, no. 78; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 364

Verse: Spoiled is the noble descent of a man who has no good manners.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 96; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 364

Verse: Good manners are your beauty.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Sa`ada, v. 2, no. 50; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 364

Verse: There is no adornment like good manners.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10466; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 364

Verse: Good manners are the beauty of the mind.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 131, no. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 364

Verse: Everything needs the mind, and the mind needs good manners.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6911; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 365

Verse: Good manners in man resemble a tree whose root is the mind.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2004; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 365

Verse: It is narrated in Tuhaf al-Uqul: Allah, most High, told Jesus [Prophet Jesus (AS) is known in the Arabic tradition as   s ] (AS), 'Refine your heart with piety'.'
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 500; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 366

Verse: Jesus son of Mary (AS) was asked, 'Who gave you good manners?' He replied, 'No one disciplined me; when I saw the ugliness of ignorance I avoided it.'
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 196; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 366

Verse: Sit with scholars to increase your knowledge, to improve your manners and to purify your soul.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1 no. 4786; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 366

Verse: When man's knowledge increases his manners improve and his fear of his Lord increases.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1 no. 5932; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 366

Verse: It suffices you in disciplining yourself to avoid all that you hold in contempt from others.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 73, no. 27; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 367

Verse: It suffices man in disciplining himself to not associate anyone with his Lord in his bounties and desires.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 94, p. 94, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 367

Verse: My father (AS) refined my manners by three [statements]. He said to me: 'O son! A man who befriends a vile person cannot escape blame, and a man who does not restrain his words will live in regret, and a man who enters suspicious places will become subject to accusations.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 376; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 368

Verse: The best of manners is for man to stop at his limits and to not exceed his status.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3241; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 368

Verse: The best of manners is that which prevents you from committing sins.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3298; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 368

Verse: Self-restraint in times of desire and fear is one of the best manners.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5932; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 368

Verse: Honour your children and refine their manners, and your sins will be forgiven.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 104, p. 95, no. 44; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 368

Verse: Imam Ali (AS) said to Imam al-Hasan (AS), 'The heart of a youth resembles an empty land - it receives all that is thrown into it. This is why I have started to teach you good manners before your heart is hardened and your soul is preoccupied.'
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 16, p. 66; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 369

Verse: The service of a believer to his fellow believing brother is [worthy of] a station of which the reward and grandeur can only be perceived by returning the same service.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 12, p. 429, no. 14524; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 840

Verse: Patience is the peak of faith
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 87, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 685

Verse: The believers are servants of each other'. (Jam l narrates), 'I asked, 'How are they servants of each other?' The Im m replied, 'By being of benefit to each other
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 167, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 840

Verse: Serve your brother, but if he makes you toil then do not serve him
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, no. 243; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 840

Verse: When you meet each other, receive each other with the greeting of peace (salam) and a handshake, and when you part company, do so by seeking each other's forgiveness
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 181, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 841

Verse: Shake hands with each other for verily the handshake takes away resentment
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 158, no. 149; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 841

Verse: Shake hands with each other for verily it takes away rancour.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 165, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 841

Verse: When a man shakes his companion's hand, the one who holds on the longest has the greater reward than the one who lets go. Indeed sins fall off from between them [as a result of it] until finally no sin remains
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 181, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 841

Verse: The [early] Muslims were such that when they went on conquests with the Prophet (SAWA) and traversed through dense forests, as they would come back out into the open, they would look at each other and shake each other's hands.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 181, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 841

Verse: When the Prophet (SAWA) used to shake someone's hand, he would never be the first to let go, until the other person let go of his hand
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 182, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 841

Verse: As for any woman whom one can marry [i.e. not one's immediate relative], one must not shake her hand except from under a cloth, nor clasp her palm
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 525, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 842

Verse: Imam Ali (AS) said, I complained to the Prophet (SAWA) about people's jealousy towards me, so he replied, 'O Ali, the first four people to enter Paradise will be myself, you, Hasan and Husayn. The rest of our progeny will be behind us, those who love us will be behind them, and our Shi`aa will be on either side of us.
VerseRef: Kitab al-Irshad, v. 1, p. 43; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 842

Verse: Umm Salama, the wife of the Prophet (SAWA), was once asked about [the status of] Ali b. Abi Talib (AS), to which she replied, 'I have heard the Prophet (SAWA) say, 'Verily Ali and his Shi`aa are the victorious ones
VerseRef: Kitab al-Irshad, v. 1, p. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 843

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) asked Nawf al-Bakali, 'Do you know who my Shi`aa are, Nawf?' to which he replied, 'By Allah, no.' Imam replied, 'My Shi`aa have parched lips and empty stomachs. They are those whose faces disclose asceticism, for they are ascetics by night, lions by day.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 28, no. 95; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 843

Verse: The peak of justice is that a man be just towards his own self.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6368; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 500

Verse: Knowledge is the root of all good whereas ignorance is the root of all evil.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 175, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 501

Verse: Verily I am one of your Shi`aa', 'O `Aabdallah, if you are truly obedient to us in our commands and prohibitions, then you are telling the truth. But if not, then do not add to your sins by falsely claiming such a dignified position that you are not worthy of. Do not say, 'I am one of your Shi`aa', but say rather, 'I am one of your adherents and one of your lovers and an enemy to your enemies.' You are [doing] good and aiming towards good
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 106; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 843

Verse: Our Shi`aa are none other than those who are consciously wary of their duty to Allah and obey Him. They are known solely for their humbleness, their humility, their returning promptly whatever is entrusted in their care and their Abundant remembrance of Allah
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, p. 295; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 843

Verse: Verily the Shi`aa of Ali were those who restrained their stomachs and their sexual desires, who struggled and fought intensely, who worked hard for their Creator, who hoped for His reward and feared His punishment. If you have seen such people, then they are the very Shi`aa of Ja`afar.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 233, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 844

Verse: We are the interpreters of Allah' s command, we are the infallible people
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 269, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 431

Verse: Test our Shi`aa with regard to three things: the prayer times to see how well they observe them, their secrets to see how well they guard them from our enemies, and their wealth to see how they help out their fellow brothers with it
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 83, p. 22, no. 40; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 844

Verse: Verily our Shi`aa are those who possess four eyes: two in their head, as well as two in their heart. Actually, all people are such, except that Allah has opened their [the Shi`aa's] eyes, and blinded others' [as a result of their rejection of His guidance].
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 215, no. 260; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 844

Verse: One who claims to follow us with his tongue, but does the opposite to our actions and deeds is not from among our Shi`aa.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 68, p. 164, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 844

Verse: There is a group of people who claim that I am their Imam, but by Allah, I am no Imam of theirs   may Allah curse them   every time I conceal a secret, they disclose it. Every time I explain a matter, they retort, saying, 'Actually that means such and such.' I am only the Imam of those who obey me
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 80, no. 76; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 844

Verse: The one who rejects four things is not from among our Shi`aa. They are: the Prophet's Ascension to the heavens, the questioning in the grave, the creation of Heaven and Hell, and intercession
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 69, p. 9, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 845

Verse: Once asked a man about his tribe and brothers whom he had left back home, which the latter replied by praising them, attesting to their integrity and extolling them. Then Imam (AS) asked, 'Do the rich among them visit the poor when they are ill?' He replied, 'Not much.' 'Do the rich frequent the poor at all?' asked Imam. The man replied, 'Not much.' 'Then, do the rich maintain relations with the leaders from amongst the poor?' The man replied, 'Verily you are listing virtues that people amongst us rarely possess.' Imam said, 'Then how can these people claim to be Shi`aa?!
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 173, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 845

Verse: One who goes into retreat [in order to achieve spiritual upliftment] and who does not attain piety in his heart as a result is not from among our Shi`aa.
VerseRef: Basa'ir al-Darajat, p. 247, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 845

Verse: Our Shi`aa are of three types: one type dupe people in our name, one type are like glass which discloses everything that is inside it [that they, like glass, cannot keep hidden that which is placed in their trust, like secrets (ed.)], and one type are like red gold, which the more it is brandished in the fire, the purer it becomes.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 186, no. 24; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 845

Verse: The Shi`aa are of three types: one type who loves us and shows affection towards us, and he is one of us. The other type is he who adorns himself through us, and we will serve as an adornment for whoever adorns himself through us. And the third type seeks to cheat people and enrich himself in our name, and whoever does this will be impoverished.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 103, no. 61; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 846

Verse: Women are Satan's hardest weapons.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3187.

Verse: Women are Satan's traps.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3188.

Verse: Women make the largest population of Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3189.

Verse: O community of Shi`aa   the Shi`aa of the household of Muhammad   be like the middle saddle-cushion, on which the extremist who has slid forward falls back, and with which the follower who is yet to come catches up.' Upon hearing this, a man called Sa`ad from among the ansar asked him, 'May I be your ransom, who is an extremist?' He replied, 'They are a group of people who say such things about us that we do not say about ourselves. Neither are these people from among us, nor do we associate ourselves with them.' Then the man asked, 'Who is the follower that is yet to come?' He replied, 'The one who is searching for good and wants it, and who will eventually attain it and be rewarded for it.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 75, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 846

Verse: O `Aabd al-A`ala,   give my greetings of peace and the mercy of Allah to my Shi`aa, and tell them: 'Allah has mercy on the servant who incites love in the people towards himself and towards us [when attracting them towards Islam], by displaying to them that which they already like, and keeping from them that which they would reject.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 77, no. 62; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 846

Verse: A prophet went out with his people to pray to God for rain. He saw an ant raising its leg to the sky, and so he said to the people: "Return to your homes for, God accepted your prayers for the sake of this ant".
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 120; Page No. 25

Verse: A prostitute was passing by a well where she saw a dog at the point of death from thirst. She tied her skirt to her shoe, fetched water from the well and quenched the dog's thirst, and was thus forgiven (by God).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 121; Page No. 25

Verse: A quack vender is just as a usurer accursed.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 122; Page No. 25

Verse: A rich man's request (to people) will be a badge of shame on his face in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 123; Page No. 25

Verse: A rich man's request (to people) will lead him to Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 124; Page No. 25

Verse: A scholar who avails himself of his own knowledge is superior to a thousand simple worshipers (of God).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 125; Page No. 25

Verse: A scholar who does not act upon his knowledge is like unto a niche providing people with light but burning itself.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 126; Page No. 25

Verse: A scholar who teaches people and forgets himself is like unto a candle illuminating people but burning itself.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 127; Page No. 26

Verse: A sparrow killed in vain will come to stand before God's Throne in the Day of Judgment, shouting " O Lord! Ask this man(the killer) why he killed me for no gain?"
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 130; Page No. 26

Verse: A strong believer is like unto a palm tree, and a weak one resembles a stalk.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 131; Page No. 26

Verse: A supposedly postponed affair should not make you do it hurriedly, for the Great and the most Powerful God will not haste for man's hurry.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 132, Page No. 26

Verse: A thankful heart, a mindful tongue, and a virtuous wife who helps man in worldly and otherworldly affairs, are better than whatever people might treasure.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 133; Page No. 26

Verse: A time will come to pass when man has to choose between helplessness and debauchery. Those living at that time should prefer the former on the latter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 134, Page No. 26&27

Verse: A tree branch had blocked people's way and hurt them. Somebody pulled it aside and was thus allowed to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 135; Page No. 27

Verse: A true believer does not taunt, damn, slander and abuse people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 136; Page No. 27

Verse: A true believer is bereft of two attributes: telling lie and stinginess.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 137; Page No. 27

Verse: A true believer should have the following eight characteristics: soberness at hard times, patience in calamities, gratefulness in reliefs, contentment for whatever the Great and Glorified God has given, avoidance from oppressing enemies and hurting friends, and toleration of physical sufferings to make people feel safe from him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 138; Page No. 27

Verse: A true Muslim is the one from whose tongue and hand, Muslims at rest stand.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 139; Page No. 27

Verse: A truthful, trustworthy trader will keep company with martyrs in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 140; Page No. 27

Verse: A truthful, trustworthy trader will keep company with the prophets, the truthful and martyrs (in the Day of Judgment).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 141; Page No. 27

Verse: A wine drinker is like unto an idol worshipper.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 142; Page No. 28

Verse: A woman has two veils: the marriage bond and the grave.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 143, Page No. 28

Verse: A woman is like unto a (tender) rib.If you intend to straighten it, it will break, and if you intend to avail yourself of it, it will offer you the chance, though bent.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 144, Page No. 28

Verse: A woman is not allowed to give in charity anything of her husband's wealth without his permission.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 145, Page No. 28

Verse: A woman was doomed to Hell, for she had kept a cat in bonds without food to die from hunger.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 146, Page No. 28

Verse: Verily Allah, Exalted be His remembrance, protects [from sin] whoever obeys Him, and whoever disobeys Him does not benefit from His protection.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 82, no. 39; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 429

Verse: My God, I have no way to guard myself from sin except through Your protection, and no way to attain good deeds except by Your will. So how can I ever benefit from that which You have preceded with Your will! And how can I ever guard myself from sins as long as Your protection does not cover me therein!
VerseRef: al-Balad al-Amin, p. 315; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 430

Verse: When Allah, most High, knows the good intention of a person, He encompasses him with His protection from all sides.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 188, no. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 430

Verse: He(Imam) is immune from committing all errors, well-protected from all acts of indecency.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 204, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 430

Verse: He [i.e. the Imam] is therefore infallible, divinely supported, aided, and shielded; being immune from all mistakes, errors and lapses. Allah has endowed him that in order to make Him His proof on the servants and His witness over creation.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 203, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 431

Verse: Separation from one' s beloved is the penalty for infatuation.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 11, no. 70; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 431

Verse: The one who is infatuated with something, his eyes become blind and his heart becomes sick, such that he sees with unsound eyes and hears with deaf ears, his base desires having torn apart his reason and [love of] the world having killed his heart.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 109; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 432

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) when asked about infatuation, replied, 'Hearts that are empty of the remembrance of Allah are given to taste by Allah the love of other than Him.'
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 531, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 432

Verse: The fighter who is martyred in the way of Allah has no greater reward than the one who is able to sate his lust but restrains himself.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 474; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 432

Verse: The ones from among you with the best faith are the ones with the best inner knowledge.
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 36, no. 18; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 433

Verse: Knowledge is the first proof whereas inner knowledge is the last step in the conclusion.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2061; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 433

Verse: Inner knowledge is the light of the heart.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 538; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 433

Verse: The acquisition of knowledge is the seed for [the growth of] inner knowledge.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 128, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 433

Verse: Allah does not accept any act without inner knowledge [i.e. awareness of what one is doing], and inner knowledge only comes through prior action. So whoever knows intrinsically, his knowledge will lead him to action, and whoever does not act does not have any inner knowledge.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 44, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 433

Verse: One who speaks truth, first Allah testifies to his words and he considers himself truthful. One who lies, first Allah falsifies his words and that person himself knows that he is a liar.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 231

Verse: "A good deed done secretly is better than seventy good deeds and one who sins openly will not be helped. One who sins secretly, may be forgiven."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 231/232

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said,"The Almighty Allah has said that one who commits a sin thinking that He (Allah) has the choice to either forgive or punish him, He will forgive that person.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 232

Verse: Eat when you desire and stop while you still desire.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 62, p. 290; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 330

Verse: Do not leave your plates uncovered for Satan spits on uncovered plates and takes from them what he wants.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 8, p. 295, no. 9485; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 333

Verse: Imam Mosa ibn Ja'far al-Kazim (a.s.) when he was asked who the contemptible person was, replied, 'The one who eats in the marketplaces.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 16, p. 510, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 333

Verse: Prolong your seating at the dinnertable, for these are times that will not [need to] be accounted for as part of your lives
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, p. 253; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 333

Verse: Foolishness is the worst disease.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 687; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 333

Verse: The greatest poverty is foolishness.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2849; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 333

Verse: A person does not ruin his enemy worse than a fool ruins himself.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Sa`ada, v. 3, p. 225; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 334

Verse: Prophet Isa (a.s.) when asked about the traits of the fool said, 'He is one who is proud of himself and his own opinion, who sees all good traits as coming from himself and sees no one better than himself, who has decided that all rights are his and others have no right over him, so this is the fool for whom there is no cure for his disease.'
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, p. 221; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 334

Verse: The one who pries into the faults of people, rebukes them and then adopts those faults himself is truly a fool.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 349; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 334

Verse: The foolishness of a man is recognised by three things: idle talk, answering something he was not asked, and being careless in matters.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4542; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 334

Verse: Among the signs of the fool is his profusely whimsical nature.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9445; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 334

Verse: Do not refute everything that people say to you for that is enough to classify you as foolish.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10251; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 334

Verse: Imam Zayn al-Abidin (AS) in his counsel to his son al-Baqir (AS) said, 'My son, beware of taking a fool as a companion or mingling with him; keep away from him and do not converse with him for verily the fool is a lowly person whether he is absent or present. When he talks he exposes his foolishness and when he is silent he displays his inability to express himself. If he acts he spoils and when he is given responsibility he fails it. His own knowledge does not suffice him and others' knowledge is of no benefit to him, he does not follow the one who advises him, his associates do not find rest [from him], his mother wishes to be bereaved of him, his wife wishes to lose him, his neighbour wishes to live far from him and the one who sits with him would rather be absent from his company. If he is the lowest [in status] in the gathering he abases those above him and if he is the highest of them he denigrates the others.'
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 613, no. 1278; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 334

Verse: The one who does not refrain from the friendship of a fool will soon adopt his character.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 222, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 335

Verse: The most foolish of people is the one who thinks that he is the most intelligent.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3089; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 335

Verse: The most foolish of people is the one who prevents goodness but expects thanks, and he commits evil and expects the reward of good.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3283; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 335

Verse: The most foolish of people is he who rebukes others for their vices while he possesses the same.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3343; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 336

Verse: Maintaining silence with the fool is the best response.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1160; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 336

Verse: The most wholesome lifestyle is achieved through throwing out unnecessary expenses.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2964; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 569

Verse: The most pleasant [type] of life is [a life of] contentment
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2918; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 569

Verse: The man with the most comfortable lifestyle is he whom Allah, Glory be to Him, has granted contentment and to whom he has given a virtuous wife.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3295; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 569

Verse: There is no lifestyle more wholesome than [living] good-naturedly.
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 560, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 569

Verse: Three things spoil one's lifestyle an oppressive ruler, a bad neighbour, and a loathsome wife.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 320; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 570

Verse: There are five things which if one where to lose just one of them it would render his life incomplete, his intellect short-lived, and his heart preoccupied. The first of these is health of the body; the second is security; the third is ample sustenance; the fourth is a compatible companion. [The narrator says], 'I asked, 'What is a compatible companion' to which he replied, 'The virtuous wife, the virtuous son and the virtuous friend. And the fifth one, which sums up these four things, is mild-temperedness.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 284, no. 34; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 570

Verse: Even if you are not an articulate scholar, at least be an attentive listener.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4090; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 570

Verse: Indeed the most heedful of all ears is that which is attentive to and accepting of a reminder.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 105; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 570

Verse: Not every man with a heart is understanding, nor every man with an ear a listener, and nor every man with eyes able to see.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 88; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 571

Verse: Accustom your ear to listen effectively, and do not listen to anything that will not benefit your progress.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6234; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 571

Verse: The one who listens to the remembrance of Allah in turn remembers [Him].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5579; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 571

Verse: Whoever listens effectively reaps its benefits immediately.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9243; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 571

Verse: The obligation incumbent upon the hearing is that it not be used for acts of disobedience, for Allah, Mighty and Exalted, has said, "Certainly He has sent down to you in the Book that when you hear Allah's signs being disbelieved and derided, do not sit with them until they engage in some other discourse, or else you [too] will be like them" [Qur'an 4:140]
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 1, p. 564, no. 628; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 571

Verse: The one who spends his life seeking out this world has attained a poor deal and has lost divine succour.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 119; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 572

Verse: A man who abandons the world for the sake of the world, and therefore he misses out on the world and loses the Hereafter, and a man who worships, struggles and fasts as a display for others, and thus forbids [himself] the pleasures of this world and also tires himself. And were he to do all that sincerely [for the sake of Allah], he would be deserving of its reward.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 95; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 572

Verse: Verily the biggest loser with the worst end of the deal and the most unsuccessful in his striving is the man who exerts himself in the quest for his wealth even though fate does not help him in his aims, and he consequently leaves this world with regret while heading towards the Hereafter, where he will face its ill consequences.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 430; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 573

Verse: Love is acquired kinship.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 97; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 573

Verse: Love does not need kinship so much as kinship needs love.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 308; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 573

Verse: Three things bring about love: good temperament, kindness, and humbleness.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4684; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 573

Verse: Three things bring about love: piety, humbleness, and generosity.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 316; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 573

Verse: Love for the commoners [in society] breaks up like the breaking up of clouds, and dissolves like the dissolving of the mirage.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9872; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 574

Verse: The friendships that are the quickest to break are the friendships made with evildoers.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3124; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 574

Verse: Beware of loving the enemies of Allah, or of harbouring affection for other than the friends of Allah, for verily man will be resurrected with those whom he loves.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2703; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 574

Verse: Your love for a particular thing makes you blind and deaf.
VerseRef: Aaw`ali al-La'ali, v. 1, p. 290, no. 149; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 574

Verse: The lover's eye is blind to the defects of the beloved, and his ear is deaf to the ugliness of his misdeeds.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9872; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 574

Verse: He who loves you forbids you [from committing sin].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7718; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 574

Verse: A Muslim is he whose hand and tongue people feel safe from, whilst a believer (mu'min) is he whom people trust with their belongings and their lives.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 239, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 488

Verse: Islam is naked, and its clothing is modesty, its adornment loyalty, its valour good deeds, and its pillars piety. Everything has a foundation, and the foundation of Islam is the love for us, the ahl al-bayt (the household of the Prophet).
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 445, no. 1031; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 489

Verse: The jealous one sees a loss for the one he is jealous of as a gain for himself.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1832; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 492

Verse: The bane of piety is lack of contentment.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3935; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 133

Verse: The downfall of judges is greed.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3936; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 133

Verse: Islam has seven fundamentals: the first is reason, on which perseverance is founded. The second is maintenance of one's honour and honest speech. The third is proper recitation of the Qur'an. The fourth is to love for the sake of Allah and to hate for the sake of Allah. The fifth is the right due to the household of the Prophet (SAWA) and their guardianship. The sixth is the right of one's fellow brothers and their protection. The seventh is close contact with people through fair means.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 196; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 489

Verse: Islam has been founded on five pillars: the establishment of prayer, the giving of the alms-tax, the fast of the month of Ramazan, the pilgrimage to the Sanctified House, and [the acknowledgment of] our guardianship, the ahl al-bayt.
VerseRef: Amali al-Mufid, p. 353, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 489

Verse: Verily Imama (divinely appointed leadership of the twelve Imams) is the ever-growing root of Islam as well as its lofty branch.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 200,no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 489

Verse: He who wakes up in the morning unconcerned about the situations of fellow Muslims is not a Muslim.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 163, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 490

Verse: Verily Islam is submission, and submission is conviction, and conviction is certification of something, and certification is attestation, and attestation of something is fulfilment of it, and fulfilment is the performance of required acts.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 125; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 490

Verse: Repel treachery, for verily it repels Islam.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4742; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 490

Verse: Whoever aids and abets wrongdoing towards a fellow Muslim is not a Muslim.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 922; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 490

Verse: answered some questions that a Syrian man had come to ask him, after which the latter said, 'I am a Muslim right now.' Imam said, 'No, rather you have faith right now, for Islam comes before faith [i.e. you were already a Muslim], and is the means by which people inherit each other and marry each other, whereas faith is the means by which they are rewarded.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 173, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 490

Verse: Islam is that through which life is spared, goods are entrusted, and women become lawful [through marriage], whereas faith is that which incurs reward.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 25, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 491

Verse: Allah, Mighty and Exalted, said to Moses son of Amran (AS) [known in the Arabic tradition as `Aimran], 'Verily the jealous is discontented with My bounties, and wards off the shares I have apportioned to My servants.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 307, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 491

Verse: Jealousy is the spirit's imprisonment.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 372; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 491

Verse: Jealousy is the worst disease.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 332; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 491

Verse: The chief of vices is jealousy.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5242; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 491

Verse: How capable jealousy is! And how just it is, that it starts off with its perpetrator and ends up killing him!
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 1, p. 316; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 491

Verse: The fruit of jealousy is the misery of this world and the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4632; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 492

Verse: I have not seen a wrong-doer resemble a wronged person more than the jealous one: he has an exhausted spirit, a wandering heart, and an inherent sorrow.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 256, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 492

Verse: That which he suffers is [torment] enough for the jealous one.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 12, p. 17, no. 13388; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 492

Verse: The jealous one has many regrets, and his vices are manifold.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1520; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 492

Verse: The jealous one can never rule.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1017; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 492

Verse: Seek the assistance of secrecy in fulfilling your needs, for every prosperous person is envied.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 1, p. 316; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 492

Verse: Jealousy consumes faith like fire consumes dry wood.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 306, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 493

Verse: Beware of being jealous of one another, for the origin of disbelief is jealousy.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 8, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 493

Verse: Luqman told his son, 'There are three signs of the jealous person: he backbites someone in his absence, flatters him in his presence, and rejoices at the misery of others.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 121, no. 113; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 493

Verse: You must adopt earnestsness, diligence, preparedness and willingness.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 230; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 493

Verse: When Allah afflicts a servant with illness, sins shed away from him in proportion to the severity of his ailment
VerseRef: Da`aim al-Islam, v. 1, p. 218; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 869

Verse: The illness that afflicts a child is expiation for his parents' sins
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 81, p. 186, no. 40; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 870

Verse: Verily distress takes away the sins of the Muslim.
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 120, no. 285; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 870

Verse: When anyone from among the followers (shi`aa) of Ali commit a sin or perpetrates an evil deed in the morning, it is expiated by any distress he may undergo by nightfall. So how can the Pen ever write down his evil deeds?!
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 68, p. 146, no. 94; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 870

Verse: Maintain the prayer at the two ends of the day, and during the early hours of the night. Indeed good deeds efface misdeeds. That is an admonition for the mindful."[Qur'an 11:114
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 870

Verse: Four qualities, when possessed by a person, cause Allah to transform his evil deeds into good deeds, even if he is sinful from head to toe. They are: honesty, modesty, good character and thankfulness.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 107, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 870

Verse: Verily good character melts away evil deeds as the sun melts away ice, and verily bad character corrupts one's actions like vinegar corrupts honey.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 395, no. 74; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 871

Verse: Among the things that expiate grave sins are: bringing solace to a grief-stricken person, and providing relief to an anguished person
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 24; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 871

Verse: A seeker of knowledge among the ignorant is like unto a living creature among the dead.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 128; Page No. 26

Verse: Verily Allah, Exalted be His Remembrance, has angels who strip off sins from the backs of our followers (shi`aa) like the wind strips the leaves off the trees in autumn, and this is in accordance with His words in the Qur'an, "they glorify the praise of their Lord and seek forgiveness on behalf of those who believe." By Allah this verse refers to none other than you [my followers].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 59, p. 196, no. 61; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 871

Verse: A man once came to the Prophet (SAWA) and said, 'O Prophet of Allah, my sins have increased and my [performance of] good deeds has weakened', to which the Prophet (SAWA) replied, 'Prostrate yourself to Allah frequently for verily this strips off sins as the wind strips off the leaves from the trees.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 404, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 871

Verse: The voluntary pilgrimage (`Aumra) expiates all sins committed since the preceding voluntary pilgrimage, and the reward for an accepted obligatory pilgrimage (Hajj) is Paradise. There are certain sins that can only be forgiven on the plains of `Aarafa [part of the obligatory pilgrimage].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 99, p. 50, no. 46; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 872

Verse: Whoever is not capable of performing actions to expiate his sins should abundantly send blessings on Muhammad and his household for verily this completely eradicates sins.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 68, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 872

Verse: Death acts as a penance for the sins committed by believers
VerseRef: Amali al-Mufid, p. 283, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 872

Verse: There is an honour for everything, and the most honoured seating is the one that faces the Qibla (the direction of Makkah).
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 469, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 873

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) used to sit facing the Qibla most of the time.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 1, p. 66, no. 72; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 873

Verse: Do not be obscene in the way you sit lest people avoid you for your bad behavior; and do not speak privately with a man when you are with another.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 84, p. 354, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 873

Verse: He was never seen stretching his leg out towards someone sitting with him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v.84, p. 16, no. 236; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 873

Verse: When one of you enters his brother's place, he must sit wherever his host asks him to, because the owner of a house knows its private spots better than a visitor to it
VerseRef: Qurb al-Isnad, p. 69, no. 222; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 873

Verse: Whenever the Prophet (SAWA) entered a place, he used to sit in the closest spot from the entrance
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 1, p. 66, no. 71; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 873

Verse: None but a man possessing three virtues is worthy of sitting in the main seat in an assembly: he who answers when asked, speaks when others are not able to, and provides the counsel which is best for his people. He who does not possess any of these and sits there is certainly a fool.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 304, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 874

Verse: Do not hasten to occupy the highest spot in the assembly, for a seat which you are promoted to is better than one you are demoted to
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10283; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 874

Verse: Take charge of the discipline of your selves and shift them away from their rough habits.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4522; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 365

Verse: A man who teaches his own self and disciplines it deserves more reverence than a man who teaches others and disciplines them.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 56, no. 33; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 366

Verse: The most open-handed of people is he who gives freely of himself and his wealth in the way of Allah
VerseRef: Nawadir al-R`awandi, p. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 651

Verse: The best form of open-handedness is that expressed in spite of hardship.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3185; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 651

Verse: The most open-handed of people is he who gives without expectation.
VerseRef: Kashf al-Ghamma, v. 2, p. 242; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 651

Verse: The open-handed cannot be considered open-handed unless he has three [attributes]: he is generous with his wealth both in times of ease as well as hardship, bestows it on the deserving, and finds the gratitude of the one he gave to greater than what he gave him
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 231, no. 27; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 651

Verse: The [valid] opinion comes from balanced judgment, whilst the impetuous and rash opinion is a vile foundation indeed.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 81, no. 76; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 651

Verse: Use some opinions to attack other opinions and the valid one will emerge thereof.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2567; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 652

Verse: Whoever tarries despite the fleeting opportunity, [lengthening] his investigation into the matter, the [passing] days will snatch away the opportunity, because it is the nature of days to snatch away [opportunities], just as it is the path of time to pass away.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 268, no. 181; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 654

Verse: There is no tension or ease, unless it involves Allah's favor and test.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 354, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 654

Verse: There is nothing that has tension or ease from all that Allah has commanded or prohibited except that it involves a test and a judgment from Allah, the Exalted
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 354, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 654

Verse: Know that Allah, most Highig, uncovered the people, not because He was ignorant of their well-kept secrets and inner thoughts, but in order to test them [to see] which of them is best in conduct, so that reward becomes the prize and punishment becomes the penalty.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 9, p. 84; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 655

Verse: Verily Allah, Mighty and Exalted, despises or excludes from His mercy every man who is quick to contract new marriages, and every woman who does so.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 54, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 251

Verse: Verily Allah, Mighty and Exalted, despises every man who is quick to contract new divorces and marriages.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 55, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 251

Verse: Nothing is more abominable to Allah from all that He has made permissible than divorce, and verily Allah despises one who is quick to contract new divorces and marriages.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 54, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 251

Verse: Verily Allah, Mighty and Exalted, loves the house wherein a wedding is taking place, and despises the house wherein a divorce is in process, and nothing is more abominable to Allah than divorce
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 251

Verse: Imam al-Rida (AS) was once asked the reason why a man is not allowed to remarry his divorc e numerous times unless she has married another husband first, to which he replied, 'Verily Allah, Blessed and most High, has permitted revocable divorce twice, and said: "[Revocable] divorce may be only twice; then [let there be] either an honourable retention, or a kindly release" [Qur'an 2:229], meaning the third time around. Because of his contracting this divorce that Allah despises so, three times over, Allah prohibits him from doing it again, so she [his divorc e] is not lawful for him until she marries another husband [and he divorces her], in order that people do not plunge into divorce, taking it as a light matter, and in order that women may not be caused to suffer in the process.'
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 85, no. 27; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 252

Verse: There are four aspects to doubt: unreasonable debating [born out of a desire to doubt everything], fear, wavering and undue submission. The one who always resorts to unreasonable debating never again sees the light after darkness. The one who is afraid of what befalls him [doubting as a result] is always turning back on his heels. The one who wavers between his misgivings is trampled by Satan underfoot, and the one who succumbs to the perils of this world and the next is destroyed in them both.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 255

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) used to change ugly names of people and places [to good names].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 104, p. 127, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 937

Verse: The reasoning behind the divorce being permissible three times is to do with the respite it gives [each party to think] between the first to the third time   for in that time, a desire [for one's spouse] may arise or one's rage may subside. Also, [it has been restricted to three] in order to discipline and deter women from disobeying their husbands [time after time] whereby she may have become deserving of separation and distancing for doing something to disobey her husband. The reason why a woman becomes unlawful for a man after nine counts of divorce, where he is absolutely not allowed a woman and is punishable for it, is in order that people do not make a jest of divorce and so that women are not abased, and so that man may consider his situation carefully and vigilantly [before plunging into marriage and divorce], and that he may feel despair at ever coming back together with a woman after having divorced nine times.
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 507, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 252

Verse: You must adhere to conviction and keep away from doubt, for there is nothing more detrimental to a man's faith than for doubt to overpower his conviction.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6146; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 253

Verse: I have never doubted the truth since I have been shown it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9482; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 253

Verse: Verily I am absolutely convinced about my Lord, and do not entertain any obscurity in my religion.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 253

Verse: with regards to Allah's verse in the Qur'an: "Indeed Allah desires to repel all impurity from you "[ Qur'an 33:33], said, 'Impurity is doubt, and by Allah, we never doubt in our Lord.'
