VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 288, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 253

Verse: When people sleep, their spirits go out into the sky. Whatever the spirit sees while in the sky is true, and whatever it sees on the way in the wind are just muddled dreams.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 125, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 256

Verse: There are three types of dreams: glad tidings from Allah for the believer, ominous dreams from Satan, and muddled dreams.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 90, no. 61; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 256

Verse: A dream should only ever be related to a believer who does not harbour jealousy or wrongdoing.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 336, no. 530; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 257

Verse: Eloquence is that which is easy [for the speaker] to pronounce and light on the [listener's] intellect.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1881; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 257

Verse: Do not blame a person who tries to seek his ration, for he who does not have a ration, his mistakes increase. O son, a poor person is humiliated, his words are not heard, and his status is not recognized. If a poor person speaks the truth, they call him a liar, and if he is an ascetic, they call him ignorant. O son, those who are tried with poverty are tested in four things: weakness in their certainty, deficiency in their intellect, fragility in their devotion, and lack of shame on their face. So, we seek refuge in Allah from poverty.
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 300, no. 818; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 703

Verse: O son, I fear for you because of poverty, so seek refuge in Allah from it, for poverty brings diminishment in one's faith, confusion to the intellect and a motive for hatred.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 319; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 703

Verse: Poverty in one's homeland is like being foreign in it.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 56; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 703

Verse: Poverty is my honour, and I am proud of it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 55, no. 85; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 703

Verse: The poor are the friends of Allah
VerseRef: al-Firdaws, v. 3, p. 157, no. 4423; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 704

Verse: Poverty is more decorative for a believer than a beauty spot on the cheek of a horse
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 265, no. 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 704

Verse: Calamities are endowments from Allah, and poverty is stored with Allah
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 260, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 704

Verse: Poverty is better than wealth, save those who relieve others' debts [with their own wealth] and give during tragedies
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 56, no. 86; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 704

Verse: Allah said in an intimate conversation with Moses (AS), 'O Moses, when you see poverty coming, then say to it, 'Welcome O mark of the righteous', and when you see wealth coming, say, 'A sin whose punishment has been hastened.
VerseRef: al-Kafi,v. 2, p. 263, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 705

Verse: Bihar al-Anwar: 'It is narrated in the scriptures of Prophet Enoch (AS) There is no wealth with those who are not in need of Me, and there is no poverty for those who are in want of Me {Prophet Enoch (AS) is known as Idris in the Arabic tradition (ed.)}
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 95, p. 462; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 705

Verse: Everything decreases with giving away except knowledge.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6888; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 510

Verse: O people!   Who are the utterly destitute?' They said, 'A person who does not have any money.'He said, 'No, rather the real destitute is he who has not offered any of his money regarding it to be for Allah, even though he has a lot more after that.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 150, no. 86; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 705

Verse: [True] Poverty is the poverty of the heart.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 56, no. 86; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 705

Verse: There is no poverty like ignorance
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 706

Verse: The greatest of poverty is stupidity
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, Saying 38; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 706

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when asked what was the severest of poverty, said, 'Disbelief after faith
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 377, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 706

Verse: Poverty of the soul is the most evil poverty
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6547; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 706

Verse: Wealth and poverty come after submission to Allah
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 452; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 706

Verse: There will remain no poverty after Heaven, and no wealth after the Hellfire
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 216; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 706

Verse: Imam Hasan ibn 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when asked about poverty, said, 'It is the greed of the self for everything
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 225; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 706

Verse: Poverty is the greed of the self and the extremity of despair
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 368, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 706

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) when asked about the [meaning of the] saying of Abu Dharr: "There are three things that people hate but I love: I love death and I love poverty and I love tribulation", said, 'This is not as they have understood it. What he meant is that death in the obedience of Allah is more beloved to me than a life of disobedience to Allah; poverty in the obedience of Allah is more beloved to me than wealth [accompanied] with disobedience to Allah, and tribulation [accompanied] with obedience to Allah is more beloved to me than good health with disobedience to Allah
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 165, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 707

Verse: Poverty with us [i.e. our guardianship] is better than wealth with other than us, and death with us is better than life with other than us
VerseRef: al-Khara`ij wa al-Jara`ih, v. 2, p. 739, no. 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 707

Verse: Wealth that prevents you from oppression is better than poverty that drives you to sin
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 3, p. 166, no. 3614; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 707

Verse: He who thinks perceives.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 937

Verse: Poverty is red death.' The narrator said, 'I asked Abu `Aabdullah [al-Sadiq] (AS), 'Poverty of dinars and dirhams?' He said, 'No, rather poverty in one's faith
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 266, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 707

Verse: Whoever degrades a believer, male or female, or humiliates him because of his poverty or lack of ability, Allah, most High, will promulgate him on the Day of Resurrection and then disgrace him
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 44, no. 52; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 708

Verse: Do not humiliate the weak ones from among your brethren; for whoever humiliates a believer, Allah Almighty will not bring them together in Heaven until he repents.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 614, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 708

Verse: "Cornelian is an amulet in journey."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 226

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his ancestors that Amirul Momineen (a.s.) said, "Keep a cornelian ring in your hand so that Allah gives you abundance and you remain safe from calamities."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 226/227

Verse: A man complained to the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) about highway robbers. He said, "Why didn't you wear a cornelian ring? It protects one from all evils?"
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 227

Verse: "One who wears a cornelian ring in his hand will continue to see goodness till the ring is present in his hands and will always remain in the protection of Allah, the Mighty and Sublime."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 227

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that:"One who wears a ring inscribed 'Muh'ammadun nabiyyullaahi wa a'liyyunw waliyyullaah' Allah will save him from unpleasant death and he will die a natural death only."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 227

Verse: "No hand raised in front of Allah is loved by Him more than one which has a cornelian in it."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 227

Verse: "One who seeks sustenance through cornelian will get a huge share."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 227

Verse: Imam Musa Kazim (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that Imam Husain (a.s.) said, "Allah created Musa bin Imran and talked to him on Mt. Sina and looked at the earth with mercy and created cornelian with the light of his face and said, 'I swear by Myself, I have made it obligatory on Myself that I will never punish with fire (of Hell) one who wears cornelian in his hand and is the lover of Ali (a.s.)."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 227

Verse: "The hand having a turquoise ring will never be needy."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 228

Verse: The narrator went to visit Imam Musa Kazim (a.s.) and saw a turquoise ring in his hand inscribed with: Allaahul Malik. He went on seeing that ring continuously. Imam (a.s.) asked, "Why are you looking at this stone like this? Jibraeel had brought this stone for the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) from Paradise as a gift. It was given to Ali (a.s.) by him. Do you know what its name is?" He replied, "It is turquoise." Imam said, "That is the Persian name. Do you know its name in Arabic?" "No," he replied. Imam said, "It is Zafar."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 228

Verse: "Wear a ring of Jiz-e-Yamani in your hand for the deceit of Satan is destroyed through it."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 228

Verse: It is narrated from Imam Musa Kazim (a.s.) who read out from a book: "There are lots of comforts for a person wearing the Emerald ring and there is no hardship for him." The narrator wrote down these words of Imam (a.s.).
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 228

Verse: Imam Reza (a.s.) narrates that Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) said, Wear a Ruby ring for it puts an end to poverty."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 228

Verse: "Billaur (Crystal) is an excellent gem."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 228

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that Amirul Momineen (a.s.) said, "The forehead of every person from the progeny of Adam is in the hands of an angel. When he says Takbir, the angel bends his forehead down and tells him: Do so with humility otherwise Allah will disgrace you. If he remains humble he holds his head straight up and says: Keep your head up. There is a lot of honor for you near Allah and you won't be disgraced due to your humility."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 229

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "All the eyes will cry on the Day of Judgment except three   an eye which cried out of fear of Allah, an eye which remained awake for the sake of Allah and an eye which refrained from seeing what Allah has prohibited."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 229

Verse: "Tooba (Congratulations) be for the face to look at which is so nice whose eyes are weeping over sins committed by him that are not known to anyone."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 229

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "Tooba (Congratulations) be for one who avoids lust today for the sake of those promised things he has not seen."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 229/230

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that whenever Allah, Whenever Allah, the Mighty and Sublime intends to chastise the people of the earth, He says, "But for those who love each other, build mosques and repent at dawn, I would surely have chastised the people of the earth."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 230

Verse: Imam Muhammad Baqir (a.s.) narrates that Amirul Momineen (a.s.) said, "All the good deeds are hidden in three qualities   seeing, silence and speech. One who's seeing is not a lesson is useless. One who is not a fountain of silence and deep thought is ignorant. One whose speech is not the remembrance of Allah is worthless. A person whose seeing is a lesson, silence is thought, conversation is remembrance of Allah, who cries over his sins and from whom people remain safe, is indeed fortunate (there is Tooba for him)."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 230

Verse: "There is nothing among the worship of Allah better than silence and going to the house of Allah walking."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 231

Verse: Ali bin Mahziyar narrates that Imam (a.s.) said, "Soon a time will come when good things will rest on only ten things. Nine of them are keeping away from people and one is keeping silent."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 231

Verse: "Good deeds are written for a Muslim till he is silent. As soon as he speaks, either a good deed or a sin is written down for him."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 231

Verse: One who patches his clothes, stitches his shoes and carries his own luggage will remain away from pride.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 231

Verse: Patience in the face of tribulation is better than well-being in times of comfort.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1821; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 684

Verse: A man who wants to be healthy and have a light body must decrease his dinner.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v.62, p. 324; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 330

Verse: A man who is eating and is being watched by another, to whom he does not offer to share his food will be afflicted with an incurable disease.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 47; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 331

Verse: The believer eats according to the desire of his family, while the hypocrite makes his family eat according to his own desires.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 62, p. 291; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 331

Verse: Whoever mentions the name of Allah at the beginning of [eating his] food or drink and thanks Allah at the end will never be asked about the favor of this food.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 16, p. 484, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 331

Verse: Start with salt before you eat. If people knew what [benefits] salt has, they would prefer it to tested medicine.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 16, p. 520, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 331

Verse: Set hot food aside until it cools off, for when the Prophet (SAWA) was given hot food, he said, 'Set it aside until it cools down, for Allah, Mighty and Exalted, would not feed us fire when blessings lie with that which is cool.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 321, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 332

Verse: There are twelve things that every Muslim should know about the table [manners]; four are mandatory, four are recommended, and four are general manners. The mandatory are: knowledge [of the food], to be content with it, mentioning the name of Allah [before it], and offering thanks to Him [afterwards]. The recommended acts are: ablution before eating, sitting on one's left side, eating with three fingers, and licking the fingers [after the meal]. And the general manners are: eating from the closest spot to you, taking small bites, chewing well, and rarely looking at people's faces [while eating].
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 16, p. 539, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 325

Verse: He who washes his hands before and after eating will be blessed at the beginning and at the end of his food. As long as he lives, he will be in comfort, and he will be cured of the ills of his body.
VerseRef: al-Mahajjat al-Baydha, v. 3, p. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 332

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) narrated, on the authority of his fathers about the tradition entailing certain prohibitions of the Prophet (SAWA), 'He prohibited blowing on food or drink.'
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 16, p. 518, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 332

Verse: Through patience are great things accomplished.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4276; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 684

Verse: Abu al-Bakhtari said, 'A man entered the mosque and said, 'There is no rule save Allah's.' Then another man said, 'There is no rule save Allah's.' So [Imam] Ali said, 'There is no rule save Allah's. "Allah's promise is indeed true. And do not let yourself be upset
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 375

Verse: When your rulers are the best ones from among you, and the richest people from among you are the most generous, and your affairs are settled by counsel (shura) between yourselves, then being above the ground [i.e. life in this world] will be better for you than being under it [i.e. death]. But when your rulers are the wicked ones from among you, and the richest the most miserly, and your affairs are left for your women [to settle], then being under the ground will be better for you than being above it.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, p. 36; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 376

Verse: He who tackles all sides of an opinion will know where the pitfalls lie.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 173; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 652

Verse: The man with the best opinion is he who does not write off the need for a second opinion from someone else
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3152; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 652

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) said to ['Abdullah] Ibn 'Abbas, who entered his tent while he was mending his sandal, and told him, 'The pilgrims have gathered to listen to you'   'I swear by Allah, these [sandals] have more value to me than ruling over you, except for being able to do right and prevent injustice.'
VerseRef: al-Manaqib li Ibn Shahr ashub, v. 2, p. 101; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 376

Verse: When innovations arise in my community, the scholar must display his knowledge; and those who do not do this deserve the curse of Allah.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 54, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 461

Verse: Eyesight is useless if the insight goes blind.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9972; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 461

Verse: Indeed, the insightful one is he who listens and contemplates, looks and sees, derives benefit from lessons, then he takes a clear path on which he avoids the falls into abysses.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 9. p. 158; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 462

Verse: Vision is not dependent on the eyes, for the eyes may often belie their owners, yet the mind never deceives a man seeking its counsel.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 19, p. 173; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 462

Verse: Losing one's eyesight is easier than losing one's insight.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6536; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 462

Verse: The most insightful person is he who sees his own flaws and refrains from sins as a result.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3061; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 462

Verse: Careful Qanbar! Leave your insulter to his disdain and you will please the Beneficent Lord, displease Satan and punish thereby your enemy, for by the One who split the grain and created the breeze, there is no stance better than clemency with which a believer can please his Lord, and nothing like silence to offend Satan, and an idiot is best punished by ignoring him.
VerseRef: Amali al-Mufid, p. 118, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 463

Verse: The initiator is the more unjust and bears his own sin as well as the sin of his opponent as long as the latter does not retort.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 412; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 463

Verse: Whenever two people insult each other, the more superior of the two sinks to the level of the more inferior one.
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, p. 305; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 464

Verse: Whoever insults any of the prophets, kill him; and he who insults a vicegerent is as one who has insulted a prophet.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 365, no. 769; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 464

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) when he was asked about someone who insulted the Prophet (SAWA), replied, 'The most inferior person [in society] must kill him, and if not him, then the second most inferior, and so on until at the last resort he must be killed by the im?m [leader of the congregational prayer].'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 7, p. 259, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 464

Verse: The very basis of man is his intellect, and the man devoid of intellect has no religion.
VerseRef: Rawdhat al-Wa`aizin, p. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 465

Verse: Allah has only assigned man with an intellect so that it may one day deliver him.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 407; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 465

Verse: The intellect is the strongest foundation.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 475; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 465

Verse: Verily Allah, exalted be His praise, created the intellect, and it is the very first thing He created amongst all the spiritual beings from the right hand side of His Throne out of His Light.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 589, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 466

Verse: Allah created the intellect out of four things from knowledge, power, light and volition. Then He caused it to subsist through knowledge and be eternal in the divine Dominion.
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, p. 244; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 466

Verse: O merchants! Knowledge [of trading laws and ethics] first, then the trade itself! Knowledge first, then trade! Knowledge first, then trade!
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 150, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 194

Verse: O merchants! Start off by seeking a good outcome from Allah, seek the blessing in easy conduct, draw near to customers, beautify yourselves with clemency, refrain from oaths, abandon lies, avoid wronging, be fair to those being wronged, stay away from usury, and "Observe fully the measure and the balance, with justice, and do not cheat the people of their goods, and do not act wickedly on the earth, causing corruption
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 54, no. 100; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 194

Verse: Whoever wants to trade must learn his religion thoroughly in order to know what is allowed and what is forbidden for him; and whoever does not learn about his religion and then practice trading will certainly get entangled into uncertainties.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 12, p. 283, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 194

Verse: Any Muslim who excuses another Muslim for a regrettable deal, Allah, the Exalted, will forgive his lapse on the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 12, p. 287, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 194

Verse: The deal is not fulfilled until the balance is tipped [in favor of the customer].
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 159, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 195

Verse: May Allah bestow mercy on someone who is liberal when he sells, when he buys, when he judges, and when he is judged.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 159, no. 9453; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 195

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) once admonished a man who was selling something, 'I heard the Prophet (SAWA) saying, 'Leniency is one way to profit.'
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 12, p. 288, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 195

Verse: O Ali! Do not bargain for four things: when selling the sacrificial animal [for the obligatory pilgrimage], the shroud, the servant, and transportation to Makkah.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 245, no. 103; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 196

Verse: Bargain with the buyer, even if he makes a generous offer, for the loser in selling or buying is neither praised, nor rewarded.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 12, p. 335, no. 2] ; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 196

Verse: said regarding a man who has a commodity and marks it for sale at a certain price; he would sell it to any silent buyer for the marked price, but he would make a better offer for the bargainer: 'If he were to make a better offer for two or three men, it would not be a problem; but if he does that for everyone who bargains with him and not for non-bargainers, his deed would not appeal to me. He must be singular in his sale.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 152, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 196

Verse: The downfall of the strong man is underestimating the foe.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3939; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 134

Verse: The profit of a believer from another is usury, unless he buys with more than one hundred dirhams, whereupon you can profit as much as your day's sustenance; or if he buys it for trading, then you can profit, but be moderate with them.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 154, no. 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 196

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) when he was asked about the statement: 'The profit of a believer from another is usury', replied, 'That is when equity prevails, and our Qaim [i.e. the Mahdi] appears; but for now, it does not matter.'
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 12, p. 294, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 197

Verse: Three types of men at whom Allah will not look [mercifully]:   and the one who promotes his commodity by lying.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 211, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 198

Verse: O brokers! Curb your use of oaths, for they promote the commodity while obliterating the profit.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 162, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 198

Verse: Allah, Blessed and most High, loathes the one who promotes his commodity by oaths.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 390, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 198

Verse: All that you see with your own eye and that your heart finds pleasing, make it for Allah, for this is the trade of the Hereafter. Allah says, "What is with you depletes, while what is with Allah is eternal".
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 106, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 198

Verse: The merchant of this world risks his money and and his soul, while the merchant of the Hereafter is a profiting winner: his first profit is his soul and then the eternal Paradise.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 120; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 199

Verse: There is no [goods for] trade like good deeds, and no profit like the [divine] reward.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 69, p. 409, no. 122; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 199

Verse: The most profiting, among people, is the one who buys the Hereafter at the expense of this world.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3076; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 199

Verse: Whoever sells himself for [a price] less than Paradise, his ordeal is indeed severe.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3474; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 199

Verse: Whoever takes the obedience of Allah as a commodity will see profits without even trading.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8864; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 199

Verse: It is narrated in Fiqh al-Ridha (AS): 'When you are engaged in your trade and prayer time arrives, let not your trading divert you from it; for Allah described a certain people and praised them, saying, "Men whom neither trade nor sale can divert " These people used to trade, but when prayer time arrived they would leave their trade and stand for their prayer. They deserved more reward than non-traders who prayed.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 69, p. 409, no. 122; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 199

Verse: Whoever seeks to eat by sacrificing his religion will only have from his religion as much as he eats.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 223; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 200

Verse: Whoever seeks this world through the work of the Hereafter will have his goal set at a greater distance.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8901; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 200

Verse: Performing common acts of courtesy, bringing solace to a grief-stricken person, and being hospitable to guests is the instrument of leadership.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6585; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 200

Verse: Acts of courtesy are treasures for eternity.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 980; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 200

Verse: The harm of poverty is more praiseworthy than the exuberance of wealth
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5904; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 705

Verse: The loser is the one who is negligent of reforming his Hereafter.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 118; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 572

Verse: Know that acts of courtesy earn praiseworthy results, and end in rewardable gains. If you were to see acts of courtesy personified as a man, you would perceive him to be good and handsome, pleasing for people to behold and transcending all the worlds. And if you were to see acts of vileness personified, you would perceive an ugly, revolting, disfigured man, whom the hearts would be averse to and whom the eyes would turn away from in disgust
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 12, p. 343, no. 14242; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 200

Verse: "One who goes to meet a Muslim brother, the Almighty Allah will call out to him, 'O one who is going for visiting! You have become pure and your reward is pure Paradise."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 238

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said,"One who builds a new house, slaughters a healthy animal, distributes its meat among the poor and recites the following supplication: Allaahummad h'ar a'nnee maradatal jinni wash shayaat'eeni wa baarik lee fee binaaee will get whatever he wishes."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 239

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors, who narrate from Amirul Momineen (a.s.), who narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "Allah showers mercy on the father who helps his son in doing good. He showers mercy on a person who helps his neighbor in doing good. One who helps his friend in doing good Allah showers mercy on the former. Similarly one who helps his companion in doing good, Allah showers mercy on the former too. Also one who helps his master in doing good, Allah showers mercy on that person."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 239

Verse: "Moderation is best liked by Allah and He does not like extravagance even though it be equal to a few seeds of dates and a little leftover water."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 239

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors, who narrate from Amirul Momineen (a.s.), who narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "One who goes to a journey and recites the verse: Wa lammaa tawajjaha tilqaa-a madyana  till Allaahu a'laa maa naqoolu wakeel [Surah Qasas 28:22-28] Allah will protect him from every wild animal, thief, oppressor and poisonous animals till he returns home. This deed keeps poverty and Satan away. Once Adam (a.s.) became seriously ill and began to fear. He complained about it to Jibraeel (a.s.) who told him, 'Take a branch of a bitter almond and keep it on your chest'. He did so and was relieved from the fear by Allah. One who wants that the distance becomes short for him while traveling should carry a stick of bitter almond."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 239/240

Verse: "I guarantee that one who leaves the house wearing a turban will return safe and sound to his family."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 240

Verse: "The sins of the lovers of Ahle Bayt (a.s.) are destroyed in the same way as dry leaves of a tree fall off due to wind."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 241

Verse: "One who fulfils a desire of a Muslim brother, Allah calls out to the former, 'Your reward is with Me and I won't be satisfied unless I send you to Paradise."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 241

Verse: "One who is not aware of the status of Allah is not aware of the status of the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) also. And one who is not aware of the status of the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) is not aware of the status of a believer also. If someone sees a believing brother and shakes hands with him, sins are wiped off from their faces like dry leaves fall off a tree due to wind, till they (the believers) separate from one another."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 241

Verse: "O Abu Ishaq! When Allah grants a bounty to His servant and he recognizes it with his heart and he praises and glorifies Allah openly, Allah will grant him a better bounty as soon as this bounty gets finished."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 241/242

Verse: "When a person reaches the age of forty, Allah keeps him safe from three diseases like insanity, leprosy and white spots. When he reaches the age of fifty, Allah curtails his accounting. When he reaches the age of sixty, Allah makes him return to Himself. When he reaches the age of seventy, the people of heavens start loving him. When he reaches the age of eighty, Allah orders that his good deeds be written down and sins not be written. When he reaches the age of ninety, Allah, the Mighty and Sublime forgives his past and present sins and writes him as a prisoner of Allah on His earth."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 242

Verse: "Surely Allah honors a person aged seventy and grants modesty to a person aged seventy."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 242

Verse: "Allah feels ashamed to punish a person aged eighty. An elderly person will be brought on the Day of Judgment and his scroll of deeds will be handed over to him. People will see nothing in it except unpleasant things. He will say, 'O Lord! Will you throw me also into Hell?' Allah will reply, 'O elderly! You used to offer Salaat in the world for. I feel ashamed to throw you in Hell', and he will be ordered to be taken to Paradise."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 242

Verse: "One who knows the excellence of an elderly person and honors him, Allah, the Mighty and Sublime will grant him salvation from fear on the Day of Judgment." And he said, "Respecting an elderly believer is a way of showing respect to Allah, the Mighty and Sublime."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 243

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said that Jibraeel (a.s.) told him, "O Muhammad (s.a.w.s.)! One who from your Ummah participates in a battle in the way of Allah, each and every drop of rain falling from the sky will bear witness on the Day of Judgment to the trouble he had to take."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 243

Verse: "One of the doors of Paradise is called 'the door of soldiers'. All the people will have to wait while the soldiers will enter through this door with swords hanging from their necks. Angels will be congratulating them. Those who keep away from Jihad in the world, Allah will give them disgrace and poverty in this world and make them wear the dress of destruction in the hereafter. Surely the Almighty Allah has kept the greatness of my Ummah in the hooves of horses and points of the lances."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 243

Verse: "One who takes a letter of a warrior to its destination, will be like one who has freed a slave and will get the reward of participating in that Jihad."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 244

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his father that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "The horses of warriors are from Paradise."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 244

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates from his predecessors that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "All the good lies in the sword and its shade. Nothing except sword can improve people. Sword is the key of Paradise and Hell."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 244

Verse: "One who looks after an 'Ateeq horse' his three sins will be forgiven daily. He will be given twenty one rewards. One who looks after a 'Hajin horse' his two sins will be wiped off daily and he will be given seven rewards. One who keeps a Birzaun horse for his use and for protection against enemy, a sin will be wiped off daily for him and he will be granted six rewards.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 244

Verse: Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "The reward till the Day of Judgment is tied to the forehead of a horse."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 244

Verse: "If you buy a domestic animal you will benefit from it and its sustenance is with Allah."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 244

Verse: "One who domesticates a horse having white forehead or a part white for the sake of Allah, his house will not have poverty as long as the horse is present in it. He will not face any difficulty as long as this horse is with him." It is also narrated that Imam Musa Kazim (a.s.) said, "One who keeps a horse to scare or destroy an enemy, gets help as long as the horse is with him and his house will not have poverty."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 244/245

Verse: "One who sees a horse having a part of its body white while coming out of his or someone's house, he will have lots of happiness on that day. If he is going for some work and sees such a horse on his way, Allah will accomplish that task and fulfill his desire."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 245

Verse: Imam Musa Kazim (a.s.) narrates that the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said,"One who says Bismillaah before mounting an animal, an angel sits behind that person and protects him till he gets down from that animal. However if he does not say Bismillaah, the Satan sits behind him and asks him to sing. If he says that he does know how to sing he asks him to make a wish. Now the person continuously goes on wishing for something or the other till he gets down. One who recites: Bismillaahi wa laa h'aula wa laa quwwata illaa billaahil h'amdu lillaahilladhee hadaanaa lihaadhaa wa sub-h'aanalladhee sakhkhara lanaa haadhaa wa maa kunnaa lahu muqrineen, he and his mount reach the destination safely."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 245

Verse: Be openhanded with whatever you find, and you will be commended
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4716; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 650

Verse: Man's open-handedness endears him to his opponents, and his stinginess makes him hated even by his children
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4729; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 650

Verse: Open-handedness is of the nobility of [man's] nature
VerseRef: Kitab al-Irshad, v. 1, p. 303; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 650

Verse: Open-handedness is a present honour.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 330; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 650

Verse: He who obstinately holds his own opinion is ruined, and he who consults other people shares in their collective understanding.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 161; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 652

Verse: Only an ignorant person is proud of his own opinion.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9471; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 652

Verse: The one who adamantly holds his own opinion has based it on a shaky and erroneous argument.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 105, no. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 652

Verse: Leaving opportunities brings regret
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 165, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 653

Verse: Opportunity passes away quickly the way clouds pass
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 653

Verse: Opportunity is quick to pass on, and slow to come back
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2019; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 653

Verse: Opportunity is a treasure
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 194; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 653

Verse: Losing an opportunity is distressful.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 118; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 653

Verse: Matters are secured [depending] on their own time
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 165, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 653

Verse: Hastening before the possibility [of a matter] is clumsiness, as is delaying after an opportunity [arises].
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 363; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 653

Verse: It is the duty of a king to manage his own self before his army.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9333; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 590

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when asked about what Allah first created, said, 'He created light.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 57, p. 73, no. 49; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 233

Verse: The first thing that He created from His creation was the substance that all things come from, and that is water.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 68, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 233

Verse: He did not create things from eternal matter nor after ever-existing models, rather He created whatever He created and fixed limits to them and He shaped whatever He shaped and gave them the best form.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 163; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 233

Verse: Verily Allah, Blessed and most High created things not from a thing and whoever claims that Allah, most High, created things from something has indeed disbelieved
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 207, no. 81; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 233

Verse: Glory be to you! How great is Your creation that we see! But how small is every greatness when compared to Your power! How awe-striking is what we see from Your kingdom! But how low this is when compared to what is hidden from us by Your authority.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 109; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 234

Verse: Perhaps you think that Allah has only created this single world, and you think that Allah has not created anyone other than yourselves! Nay by Allah, verily Allah has created a million worlds and a million Adams and you are in the last of these worlds and of the last Adams.
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 234

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said to `Abd al-Karim b. Abel `Awja who was a denier of the origin and the end [resurrection], 'If the matter is as you say [i.e. denial], which of course it is not, then both of us will be saved, however if the matter is as we say, which is of course the truth, then we will be saved and you will be destroyed.' Then `Abd al-Karim turned to his disciples and said, 'I have found anguish and anxiety in my heart, take me from here', so they took him and he died thereafter.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 298, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 234

Verse: Every newborn is born upon the origination (fitra) of Allah, meaning [born] with inner knowledge that affirms that Allah is his Creator and this is the meaning of His words, "If you ask them, 'Who created the heavens and the earth?' they will surely say, 'Allah'."
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 331, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 235

Verse: Allah is the one whom all creation deify when they are in need or in difficulty or when all their hopes have been severed from all except Him, and when their means of attainment have been cut off from all except Him.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 231, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 235

Verse: He created a thing whereby nothing existed before it. Were He to have created from something then there would be infinite regress and there would always have been something existing alongside Allah when in actual fact Allah existed when nothing else was in existence.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 66, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 235

Verse: I found within myself that there can only be one of two possibilities, that either I created everything myself or that someone other than me created, so if I created, then that can only mean one of two possibilities, either I created and that thing was in existence beforehand or I created it from non-existence, so if I created and that thing was already in existence beforehand then it is free of any need to be created by the fact that it already exists. If the thing was in non-existence then surely you know that non-existence cannot bring about anything into existence. Thus, the third meaning affirms that I have a creator and He is Allah, the Lord of the Worlds.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 290, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 236

Verse: It is narrated in Sharh Nahj al-Balagha that Imam Ali (AS) used to frequently say once he had completed his night prayers, 'I bear witness that the heavens and the earth and what is between them are signs that indicate to You and they bear witness to what You have called us towards. Everything that is a proof for You and demonstrates your Lordship carries the effects of Your bounties and the marks of Your administration and management.'
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 20, p. 255; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 236

Verse: O creature that has been equitably created and that has been nurtured and looked after in the darkness of wombs with multiple veils, you were originated from an extract of clay then you were taken out of your abode to another place you had not seen, and you did not know the means of acquiring its benefits, so who guided you to attain your sustenance from the breast of your mother and who taught you the location of what you required or wanted?
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 163; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 236

Verse: Woe is the one who lies to make people laugh! Woe is he! Woe is he!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3181.

Verse: Woe is the one who violates a Muslim and tramples his rights!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3182.

Verse: Woe is the rich for the poor!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3183.

Verse: Imam Muhammad ibn 'Ali al-Baqir (a.s.) said with regards to the following verse of Allah   most High  "But whoever has been blind in this [world], will be blind in the Hereafter", said, 'Whoever does not see that there is a great creator behind the creation of the heavens and the earth, the alternating night and day, the orbits of the sun and the moon and all the other wondrous signs "will be blind in the Hereafter."' He (AS) then said, 'This means he is blind to what he did not witness and (even) more astray from the (right) way.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 3, p. 28, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 237

Verse: If you saw a single door [on its own], from what normally comprises a pair [of doors], with a protruding attachment, would you ever imagine that this [single door with a protrusion] was created in such a way without purpose? Rather you would certainly know that it was made in such a way to connect with another part [thus comprising the pair and providing a purpose for the protrusion]. So you would expose the other component in order to unite it [with the first one] and hence reach a useful purpose. In the same way you find a male animal as if he is part of a pair equipped for its female partner, and they unite in order to procreate and preserve [the human race]. So destroyed, defeated and wretched are the claimants of philosophy [Philosophy here denotes the fallacious philosophy of the atheists, not the commonly known philosophy that is used to provide demonstrations and proofs for the Existence of God (ed.)]. How did their hearts get blinded from this wonderful creation so as to deny the organization and purpose in it?'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 3, p. 75; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 237

Verse: Wisdom is sinlessness, and sinlessness is a bounty.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 430

Verse: Reflect, O Mufazzal, upon the actions that have been designated for mankind such as eating and sleeping  if man were to have to go to sleep while having to think about relaxing his body and reviving his powers, he would probably find it burdensome and turn away [from sleeping], and refuse himself [sleep] till his body would wear out and waste away.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 3, p. 78; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 237

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when asked for a proof to affirm the existence of a creator, said, 'Three things: the changing of states, the weakness of the body's limbs, and the thwarting of ambition.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 3, p. 55, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 238

Verse: With great people keep company, to the learned make (your) enquiry, and converse with men of philosophy.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3174.

Verse: With self-respect secure your needs, for predestined are all affairs and deeds.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3175.

Verse: Witnessing his enemies in disobedience of God suffices to make of man a sinner.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3176.

Verse: Woe is my people for bad scholars!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3177.

Verse: Woe is the learned for the ignorant and woe is the ignorant for the learned!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3178.

Verse: Woe is the one who deprives his family from good and approaches God with evil!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3179.

Verse: Woe is the one who does not know (the truth of something), and woe is the one who knows it but does not act upon it!
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3180.

Verse: Worldly affairs bring nothing but hardship, the world causes nothing but adversity, and people are on the way to unceasing avarice.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3194.

Verse: Worldly joys entail otherworldly grief, and worldly grief entails otherworldly joys.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3195.

Verse: Worship God as much as your ability permits you, for God does not get tired of you as long as you do not get tired (of worshiping Him).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3196.

Verse: Worship God in such a way as if He were in your view, for if not so, surely He sees (me and) you.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3197.

Verse: Worship God to the extent of your ability, for God will not get tired (of you) till you get tired (of worshipping Him).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3198.

Verse: Worshipping God suffices to show man's deep knowledge and vaunting personal views, to show his ignorance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3199.

Verse: Would you like to have a compassionate heart and to achieve your goals? Be merciful to orphans, treat them with tender care and your food, let them share.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3200.

Verse: Continuously taking lessons gives rise to the faculty of insight, and brings about self-restraint
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5150; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 620

Verse: He who abundantly and frequently takes lessons [from his experiences] rarely stumbles
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8056; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 620

Verse: It is incumbent upon you to attend the mosques, for verily they are the houses of Allah on earth. And whoever enters them having purified himself, Allah will purify him of his sins and will record him down as one of its frequenters, so perform many prayers and supplications therein
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 293, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 621

Verse: Voices should not be raised therein, nor engrossment in wrongdoing. There should be no buying or selling, and all vain talk must be shunned as long as you are inside. If you do not do this, then you will have no one to blame but yourself on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 374, no. 2661; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 621

Verse: He who builds a mosque, Allah will order a house to be built for him in Paradise.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 378, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 621

Verse: He who walks to a mosque asking people to join him along the way gets the equivalent of seventy thousand good deeds for every step he takes, and he is raised as many levels, and if he dies on the way, Allah assigns seventy thousand angels to visit him in his grave to keep him company in his loneliness and to seek forgiveness for him until the day he is raised again.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 336, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 621

Verse: O Abu Dharr, verily for as long as you remain seated in the mosque Allah, most High, will grant you an extra level in Paradise for every breath you take, the angels send salutations on you, and ten good deeds are recorded and ten evil deeds wiped away for every breath you take therein
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 85, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 622

Verse: The prayer of one who lives neighbouring the mosque [yet prays at home] is null and void unless he prays inside the mosque, except if he has an excuse or if he is sick.' When asked who was considered as neighbouring the mosque, he replied, 'Anyone who hears the call to prayer.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 83, p. 379, no. 47; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 622

Verse: The sanctuary of the mosque extends to forty cubits*, and its neighbouring precinct extends to forty houses on all four sides. {* dhira`a: cubit   unit of measurement between 0.6 and 0.8 metres}
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 544, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 622

Verse: Whoever has eaten this pungent herb [i.e. garlic] should not approach our mosque. As for one who has eaten it and does not come to the mosque [as a result], there is no blame on him for it
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 84, p. 9, no. 83; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 623

Verse: Do not use the mosques as mere passageways until you have prayed two units of prayer therein
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 344, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 623

Verse: Verily Allah, Mighty and Exalted, sent me as a mercy to the worlds, and in order to eradicate string instruments, the flute and others pre-Islamic pagan practices
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 250, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 623

Verse: Singing (or music) is one of the things that Allah, Mighty and Exalted, has threatened to requite with the Fire, and this is the purport of Allah's verse: "Among the people is he who buys diversionary words that he may lead [people] astray from Allah's way without any knowledge, and he takes it in derision" [Qur'an 31:6]
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 624

Verse: Music is a charm of adultery
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 247, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 624

Verse: Three things harden the heart: listening to diversionary words (lahw), seeking [game] to hunt, and frequenting the sultan. {Translators note: lahw: translated as 'diversionary talk' in the translation of the Qur'an, and often interpreted as music in exegeses of the Qur'an }
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 252, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 624

Verse: Music engenders hypocrisy.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 241, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 624

Verse: The best of my community are the most abstemious in the world and the most desirous of the Hereafter
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 123; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 626

Verse: The best of my community are those who spend away their youth in Allah's obedience, wean themselves away from the worldly pleasures and are infatuated with the Hereafter. Surely their reward upon Allah is the highest levels of Paradise
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 123; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 626

Verse: The best of my community are those who when treated foolishly are tolerant, and when attacked they forgive, and when they are hurt are patient.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 123; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 626

Verse: Clipping one's nails prevents the worst disease, and yields abundant sustenance
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 490, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 626

Verse: Do cut your nails indeed for verily they are Satan's resting place, and from him ensues forgetfulness
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 490, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 627

Verse: Verily the most hidden and subtle way that Satan has managed to gain control over man is that he has made himself an abode under his nails
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 490, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 627

Verse: It is narrated in al-Kafi on the authority of al-Sakuni that the Prophet of Allah (AS) said to men, 'Cut your nails', and to women, 'Leave them for verily that is more beautiful for you.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 490, p. 491, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 627

Verse: Grant to whomsoever you please and you will be his emir; ask your need from whomsoever you please and you will be his prisoner; be free of need from whomsoever you please and you will be his equal
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 420, no. 14; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 627

Verse: Whoever you have sought your need from, you have lowered yourself in his eyes
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8610; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 627

Verse: The one who endeavours to help his brother and benefit him has the reward of the warriors in the way of Allah
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 340, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 628

Verse: The one who grants the need of a fellow believing brother is as one who has worshipped Allah his entire life
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 481, no. 1051; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 628

Verse: When the verse: "O you who have faith! Protect yourselves and your kin from the Fire " was revealed, people asked, 'O Messenger of Allah! How do we protect ourselves and our kin?' He replied, 'Do good deeds and remind your kin about them, and discipline them to obey Allah.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 12, p. 201, no. 13882; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 369

Verse: Instruct the child to give charity with his own hand, be it a piece of bread or a handful of [food] or any other small thing, for everything   no matter how little it is   if done for the sake of Allah and with an honest intention is very great.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 4, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 369

Verse: A child is a master for seven years, a slave for the next seven years, and a minister for another seven years. By the age of twenty one, you must either approve of his manners or cut him loose, for [by then] you would have fulfilled your obligation toward Allah, most High.'
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 1, p. 478, no. 1649; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 370

Verse: A child should be trained to fast between the ages of fifteen and sixteen.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 162, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 370

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) prohibited disciplining (teaching good manners) in times of anger.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 102, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 370

Verse: Punish the wrongdoer by rewarding the good-doer.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 18, p. 410; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 370

Verse: You may improve the doers of good by honoring them, and rehabilitate the wrongdoers by disciplining them.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 82, no. 81; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 370

Verse: Reprimand your brother by being kind to him, and react to his wrongdoing by being generous to him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 427, no. 76; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 371

Verse: Rehabilitate the wrongdoer by your good deed [towards him], and indicate towards good through your good words.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2304; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 371

Verse: A man said, 'I complained to Ab  al- asan M s  [al-K  im] (AS) about a son of mine. He said, 'Do not beat him, but rather ignore him [i.e.depriving him of your company], but not for too long.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 104, p. 99, no. 74; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 371

Verse: A man who disciplines himself by following the etiquette of Allah, the Exalted, will have lasting prosperity.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 92, p. 214, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 371

Verse: A man who is not reformed through the etiquette of Allah will not be rehabilitated through his self-discipline.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9001; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 371

Verse: Misfortune is a form of discipline for the wrongdoer.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 81, p. 198, no. 55; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 372

Verse: O Lord! Discipline me not through Your punishment, and plot against me not by Your artfulness.
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, v. 1, p. 157; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 372

Verse: The most miserly of people with his wares is the most liberal of them with his own reputation [in that he gives it up readily].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3190; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 372

Verse: The best form of wealth is that which is used to safeguard one's reputation.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3038; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 372

Verse: He who cares for his reputation must desist from disputation.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 362; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 372

Verse: When reputation wanes, it becomes very difficult to restore.
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, p. 303; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 373

Verse: He who refrains from tarnishing fellow Muslims' reputations, Allah, Mighty and Exalted, regards his offence as undone on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Sahifat al-Imam al-Reza (a.s.), p. 85, no. 195q; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 373

Verse: He who guards the reputation of his fellow brother is veiled from the Fire.
VerseRef: Amali al-Mufid, p. 338, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 373

Verse: He who guards the reputation of his fellow Muslim brother definitely becomes deserving of obligatory entrance into Paradise.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 8, p. 606, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 373

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) said regarding the arbitration, 'These [people] say, 'There is no need for government!' Indeed there has to be a ruler under whose rule the believer toils and the wicked seeks to make merry.'
VerseRef: Nahj al-Sa`ada, v. 2, p. 333; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 374

Verse: The people have to have a ruler over them, be he pious or wicked, under whose rule the believer toils and the wicked seeks to make merry, and in which Allah decrees the final outcome, and under which the booty is collected, the enemy is fought, the roads are made safe, and the weak is protected from the powerful, until the pious rests and the wicked is cast aside.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 358, no. 72; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 375

Verse: A wild lion is better than an oppressive ruler, while an oppressive ruler is better than lasting schisms.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v.75, p. 359, no. 74; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 375

Verse: There is no wealth more productive than the intellect and no poverty lower than stupidity.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 29, no. 34; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 466

Verse: To insult a believer is a gross iniquity, to kill him is infidelity, and to backbite him is an act of disobedience of Allah.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 148, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 463

Verse: Do not insult the winds for verily they are commanded [to blow], nor insult the mountains, nor time, nor the days, nor the nights, lest you transgress thereby and it comes back to you
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 577, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 463

Verse: Do not insult people lest you procure animosity from them.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 360, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 463

Verse: Do not punish my sins by letting me to be heedless of your retribution
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 114; Dua-e-Abu Hamza Thumali

Verse: Those of His servants only who are possessed of knowledge fear Allah.
VerseRef: Greater Sins Vol 1, part 3, page 115; Surah Fatir:28

Verse: The zakat of power is equity
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5448; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 100

Verse: The zakat of beauty is chastity
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5449; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 100

Verse: The zakat of prosperity is goodness to one's neighbours and maintaining relations with one's kin.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5453; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 100

Verse: The zakat of health is exerting oneself in Allah's obedience
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5454; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 100

Verse: The zakat of courage is fighting in the way of Allah.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5455; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 100

Verse: Fast, for that is the zakat of the body
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 99, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 100

Verse: Good moral conduct is the zakat of bounties, intercession is the zakat of high status, ailments are the zakat of the body, amnesty is the zakat of victory, and all that you give out zakat on is protected from being snatched away from you.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 268, no. 182; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 101

Verse: He who pays the obligatory alms-tax at the end of Ramazan, Allah uses it to make up for any deficit in the alms-tax paid on his wealth.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 6, p. 220, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 101

Verse: Giving the alms-tax at the end of the month of Ramazan constitutes fasting just as sending blessings on the Prophet (SAWA) at the end of the prayer completes and constitutes the prayer. Verily the one who fasts and yet intentionally does not pay the alms-tax due, his fasting is invalid.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 2, p. 183,no. 2085; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 101

Verse: Allah has commanded me to treat people amicably just as He has commanded me to fulfil the religious obligations.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 117, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 102

Verse: Beautiful hair is part of Allah's dressing [for you], so make sure to honour it.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 1, p. 432, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 141

Verse: On the Day of Resurrection a ruler will be brought forth who had inflicted one lash less than the punishment prescribed. He will plead, 'O my Lord! I did it out of mercy for Your servants.' He will be told, 'Are you [trying to be] more merciful to them than Me?' Then he will be ordered into the Fire. Another man who had added one lash [to the punishment] will be brought forth, and he will plead, '[O Allah! I did it] to make them stop committing acts of disobedience to You.' Then he too will be ordered into the Fire.'
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 18, p. 37, no. 21948; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 553

Verse: The Commander of the Faithful (AS) had ordered Qanbar to execute a man's punishment. Qanbar was rough and beat him three more lashes. So Ali (AS) forfeited on his behalf by beating Qanbar three lashes.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 7, p. 260, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 553

Verse: When Allah punishes a faithful servant in this world, He is too Bountiful and too Glorious to re-punish him [for the same sin] on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 12966; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 554

Verse: When the Prophet (SAWA) stoned a man for adultery, a man said to his friend, 'He died on the spot like a dog.' So when the Prophet (SAWA) was passing with them by the carcass of a dead animal he told them to take a bite out of it. They said, 'O Messenger of Allah! May Allah bless you. How can we bite a carcass?!' He replied, 'What you have bitten from your brother is fouler than that.'
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 116; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 554

Verse: No sooner is leniency added to something than it adorns it, and no sooner is it taken away from something than it spoils it.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 119, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 555

Verse: When two people become friends or accompany each other, the one with the greater reward and the most beloved in Allah's eyes is the one who is the most gentle towards his companion.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 120, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 555

Verse: When Allah wishes to bestow good on a household, he introduces leniency into it.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 6, p. 339; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 555

Verse: The most intelligent person is he who is the most obliging towards people.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 28, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 555

Verse: Moderation is the key to success.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 294; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 556

Verse: Verily the knowledgeable man is superior to the [mere] worshipper as the sun is to the stars, and the worshipper is superior to the one who does not worship as the superiority of the moon to the stars.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 19, no. 49; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 505

Verse: The knowledgeable man is superior to the [mere] worshipper by seventy degrees, the distance between two degrees spanning the gallop of a horse for seventy years; and this is because Satan plants an innovation amongst people which the knowledgeable man notices and prohibits, whilst the worshipper attends to his worship neither taking any notice of it nor recognising it.
VerseRef: Rawdhat al-Wa`aizin, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 505

Verse: Revising knowledge for an hour is better than staying up the whole night in worship.
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, p. 245; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 505

Verse: Sheer cowardice ensues from the impotence of the soul and the weakness of conviction.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5773; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 231

Verse: The knowledgeable man who is beneficial [to others] as a result of his knowledge is better than seventy thousand worshippers.
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 62, no. 153; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 506

Verse: Looking at the face of a scholar out of love for him is an act of worship.
VerseRef: Nawadir al-R`awandi, p. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 506

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) was once asked regarding the Prophet (SAWA)' s saying, 'Looking at the faces of scholars is an act of worship' , to which he replied, 'It refers to the scholar whom looking at reminds you of the Hereafter, and whoever is not thus, then looking at him is a trial.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 84; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 506

Verse: Seeking knowledge is an obligation on every Muslim. Indeed how Allah loves those who strive in their quest for knowledge.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 30, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 507

Verse: He who cannot endure the submissiveness entailed in learning for an hour will remain submissive to ignorance forever.
VerseRef: Aaw`ali al-La'ali, v. 1, p. 285, no. 135; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 507

Verse: If people knew [the benefits] of seeking knowledge, they would seek it in spite of having to shed blood or dive into the deepest seas.
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 1, p. 97, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 507

Verse: When death comes to the seeker of knowledge whilst he is in that state [of seeking knowledge], he dies as a martyr.
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 1, p. 97, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 508

Verse: He who seeks knowledge is as one who spends his day fasting and his night praying. Verily a chapter of knowledge that a man learns is better for him than for him to have as much gold as a mountain and give it all away in the way of Allah.
VerseRef: Munyat al-Murid, p. 100; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 508

Verse: He who traverses a path in order to gain knowledge thereupon, Allah makes him traverse the path to Paradise.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 58, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 509

Verse: Verily everything seeks forgiveness for the seeker of knowledge, including the fishes in the sea, the reptiles on the land, and the predators and livestock of the earth.
VerseRef: Amali al-Mufid, p. 29, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 509

Verse: He who is overtaken by death whilst he is seeking knowledge, there remains but a difference of one level between him and the Prophets.
VerseRef: Majma`a al-Bayan, v. 9, p. 380; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 509

Verse: He who has knowledge, acts upon what he knows and teaches it to others is regarded as great in the greatest Kingdom [of the heavens].
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 82; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 509

Verse: The best form of charity is for a man to gain knowledge and then teach it to his fellow brother.
VerseRef: Munyat al-Murid, p. 105; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 510

Verse: Any man who has been granted knowledge by Allah but who suppresses it, in spite of knowing it, will meet Allah, Mighty and Exalted, on the Day of Resurrection bridled with a rein of fire.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 377, no. 808; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 510

Verse: Allah does not obligate the ignorant to learn until He has obligated the knowledgeable to teach.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 478; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 510

Verse: He who teaches someone a matter of guidance receives the same reward as he who practices it, without any decrease in the latter' s reward thereof.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 297; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 510

Verse: Verily upon everything is its zakat, and the zakat of knowledge is to teach it to those who are worthy of it.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 364; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 510

Verse: It is narrated in Tanbih al-Khawatir Allah, most High, revealed to Prophet Moses (AS) saying, O Moses, learn good and teach it to people, for verily I enlighten the graves of the teachers and the learners of good, so that they never feel afraid in their resting place.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 212; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 511

Verse: If you make your religion secondary to your worldly affairs, you have destroyed both your religion and your worldly affairs, and thus you will be among the losers in the Hereafter. But if you make your worldly affairs secondary to your religion, you have safeguarded your religion and your worldly affairs and you will be among the victorious ones in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3750-3751; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1008

Verse: Allocate for yourselves a portion of the world by taking from it that which is lawful of what you desire, and that which does not breach the honourable virtues and that wherein there is no extravagance. And in this way, use it to assist [and improve] the matters of religion, for it has been narrated that, 'The one who abandons their worldly affairs for their religion is not from us, and neither is the one who abandons their religion for their worldly affairs.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 321, no. 18; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1008

Verse: The parable of this world is like your shadow - if you stop, it stands still, and if you chase it, it distances itself from you.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9818; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1009

Verse: The parable of this world is like that of a snake, it is soft to touch but it contains a deadly poison. Men of intellect are cautious whereas children extend their arms towards it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 311, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1009

Verse: The parable of this world is that of sea water, however much the thirsty man drinks from it, his thirst intensifies until it kills him.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 396; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1009

Verse: The world was embodied to Jesus (AS) in the form of a blue-eyed woman, and he said to her, 'How many have you married?' she said, 'Lots', so he asked, 'So all of them divorced you?', she replied, 'No, rather I killed all of them', then Jesus (AS) said, 'Woe upon your current spouses, for how do they not take a lesson from your previous ones?!
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1009

Verse: It is narrated in Tanbih al-Khawatir that the archangel Gabriel (AS) said to Prophet Noah (AS), 'O prophet who has lived for the longest number of years, how did you find this world?' he replied, 'Like a house which has two doors, I entered through one and then left through the other.'
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 131; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1009

Verse: Verily this world is a bridge, so cross over it but do not build on it.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 65, no. 95; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1010

Verse: This world when compared to the Hereafter is just as if one of you dips his finger in the sea and sees what he comes out with.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 119, no. 110; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1010

Verse: The world is a transitory and mobile thing, even if it waits for you, do not wait for it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1802; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1010

Verse: O people, verily the world is a passage while the Hereafter is a permanent abode, so take [as much as you can] from the passage for the permanent abode.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 203; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1010

Verse: This world is a transitory place and not a permanent one. The people therein are of two types, the man who has sold his self [to his passions] and thus ruined it, and the man who has purchased his self [by control against his passions] and thus freed it.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 133; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1010

Verse: [Consider] your sojourn in this world just as a house that you stayed in and [soon] departed from, or an object of perfection that you witnessed in a dream then you awoke and not a thing from it remained with you. I have given you this parable because this world, according to the people of intellect and knowledge of Allah, is just as the shadow in the shade.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 133, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1011

Verse: The world in the eyes of the learned ones is like a shadow.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 126, no. 123; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1011

Verse: Luqman(a.s.) said to his son: the world is a deep ocean in which many worlds have already drowned, so make Godwariness your boat, faith its content, trust in Allah its sail, reason its custodian, knowledge its guide and patience its inhabitants.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 16, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1011

Verse: [The world] is a house surrounded by trials, well-known for treachery, whose conditions do not last, whose inhabitants do not remain safe, its states are variable, its ways are changing, life in it is shameful and security in it is non-existent.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 226; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1011

Verse: Work, for everybody earns what s(he) has been created for.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3193.

Verse: A small family is one way to comfort.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 129; Page No. 26

Verse: The best of people is he who longs for worship and embraces it, loves it with his heart, throws himself into it with his whole body, and devotes himself exclusively to it, such that he is not concerned in what worldly state he wakes up in the morning: in difficulty or in ease.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 83, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1012

Verse: Worship suffices as an occupation.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, p. 35; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1012

Verse: When Allah loves a servant He inspires him to carry out the best forms of worship.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4066; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1012

Verse: Adoration [of Allah] consists of five things: keeping the stomach empty, reading the Qur'an, performing the night prayer, imploring Allah at dawn, and crying much from fear of Allah.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 11, p. 244, no. 12875; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1012

Verse: There is no use to worship without conviction.
VerseRef: Kanz al-Fawa' id li al-Karajiki, v. 1, p. 55; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1012

Verse: Worship without understanding is no good.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 204; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1013

Verse: Prophet Isa (a.s.) asked a man, 'What are you doing?' The man replied, 'I am worshipping.' So he asked, 'Then who is it that supports you [financially]?' He replied, 'My brother', to which Prophet Jesus (AS) said, 'Your brother is a better worshipper than you.'
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 65; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1013

Verse: Worship consists of ten parts, nine of which are to do with earning a lawful living.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 18, no. 81; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1013

Verse: Looking at [the face of] a scholar is worship, looking at [the face of] a just Imam is worship, looking at one's parents with kindness and mercy is worship, and looking at the face of a brother whom you love for the sake of Allah is worship.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 454, no. 1015; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 1014

Verse: He who stands in a suspect place cannot blame anyone for thinking suspiciously of him.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 250, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 214

Verse: The one who enters bad places naturally stands to be accused, and the one who exposes himself to accusation cannot blame anyone for thinking suspiciously of him
VerseRef: Kanz al-Fawa' id li al-Karajiki, v. 2, p. 182; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 214

Verse: Sitting in the company of bad people engenders suspicious thoughts about good people.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 197, no. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 214
