Verse: The person in the worst state is the one who does not trust anybody because of his suspiciousness, and who is not trusted by anybody because of his evil actions.'
VerseRef: Kanz al-Fawa' id li al-Karajiki, v. 2, p. 182; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 214

Verse: The one who does not think well of people feels alienated from everybody.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9084; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 214

Verse: Guard yourselves against people with suspicion.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 158, no. 142; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 214

Verse: At a time when good prevails over an era and among its people, if a man suspects another person who has never been seen committing an offence, then he has indeed wronged him. And when corruption prevails over an era and among its people, if a man assumes the best about somebody, then he has indeed jeopardised himself.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 114; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 215

Verse: At a time when injustice is more prevalent than good, it is not permitted for anyone to entertain good opinions about another unless he knows him to be such.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 298, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 215

Verse: Verily the good deed to be rewarded the fastest is reconciliation with one's kin.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 152, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 215

Verse: If you want to be happy the whole year, reconcile with your kin.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 103, no. 61; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 215

Verse: Allah made the maintenance of relations with one's kin obligatory in order to maintain growth in population.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 94, no. 23; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 216

Verse: Whoever would like an increase in his lifespan and in his sustenance should maintain relations with his kin.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 91, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 216

Verse: Maintaining relations with one's kin purifies one's actions, brings about an increase in wealth, repels misfortunes, eases the account [on the Day of Resurrection], and delays one's appointed time of death .
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 150, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 216

Verse: Maintaining relations with one's kin improves one's character, brings about open-handedness and cheerfulness, increases in one's sustenance, and delays one's appointed time of death.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 152, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 216

Verse: When Allah allowed [Prophet] Moses son of Amran (AS) to converse with Him, Moses (AS) asked, 'My God, what is the reward of one who maintains relations with his kin?' He replied, 'O Moses, I delay the appointed time of his death, and ease the pangs of death for him.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 173, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 216

Verse: Do not cut off your kin even if they cut you off.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 347, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 217

Verse: The best reconciler is he who reconciles with one who cut him off.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 400, no. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 217

Verse: If they cut off ties with their kin, their wealth will be placed at the disposal of evil people.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 348, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 217

Verse: The sin that hastens one's death is cutting off ties with one's kin.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 94, no. 23; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 218

Verse: Maintain relations with your kin even if it be with a mere greeting (salam).
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, p. 57; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 218

Verse: Maintain relations with your kin even if it be by offering them a drink of water. The best way to maintain relations is to refrain from hurting them in any way.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2,p. 151, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 218

Verse: If a servant [of Allah] was to secretly sin, he would only harm himself, and if he was to commit it openly and not change, people would be harmed by it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 100, p. 74, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 218

Verse: By Allah, no sooner does a community dissent after their prophet than falsehood prevails over the truth, save that which Allah wills
VerseRef: Amali al-Mufid, p. 235, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 218

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) said, 'A community who does not let the weak uphold his rights from the strong without obstacle will never be sanctified.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 258, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 218

Verse: There are two kinds of people from my community who if they are sound [of faith] my community will be sound, and if they are corrupt my community will become corrupt.' The Prophet was asked, 'And who are they O messenger of Allah?' He replied, 'The jurists and the leaders.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 37, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 219

Verse: Verily, from corruption comes the loss of sustenance.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 23, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 219

Verse: Of the things that are corruptive are blocking dirhams and dinars [i.e. blocking their circulation in society through hoarding] and relinquishing one's determination.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 3, p. 167, no. 3625; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 219

Verse: Imam Hasan ibn 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when asked about cowardice, replied, '[It is] aggressiveness with one's friends, and flight from one's enemy.'
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 225; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 231

Verse: A coward is not allowed to participate in a campaign, because he would flee fast. However, he must take whatever he was going to use for the conquest [i.e. weaponry] and give it to someone else. Thus, he will have the same reward, without decrease in the reward of the other thereof.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 100, p. 49, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 231

Verse: Habbat al-`AUrani said, 'One day I heard Ali (AS) take an oath saying, 'By the One who created the sky from smoke and water'.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 58, p. 104, no. 35; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 232

Verse: The first thing that Allah created was my light.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 1, p. 97, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 232

Verse: Verily the first thing that Allah   Mighty and Exalted   created was our spirits and then He spoke to them of His Unity and Majesty, then He created the angels.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 1, p. 262, no. 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 233

Verse: Drawing lessons [from past experiences] gives rise to sinlessness.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 879; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 430

Verse: Verily Godwariness is a protection [against sin] for you in your life, and a great profit for you after your death.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3466; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 430

Verse: Sinlessness is fastened with Godwariness.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4316; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 430

Verse: The intellects are most often destroyed as a result of their subservience to bursts of avid desires.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 19, p. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 382

Verse: Piety and greed can never come together.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10578; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 382

Verse: How wretched the servant who is a slave of his own greed, which controls him.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 320, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 382

Verse: Imam al-Hasan (AS) said to man who came to ask his advice about getting his daughter married, 'Marry her to a pious man, for if he loves her he will honour her, and if he comes to dislike her, at least he will not be unjust towards her.'
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 1, p. 446, no. 1534; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 596

Verse: The best women of my community are those that have the prettiest faces and the smallest dowries.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 237, no. 25; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 596

Verse: The bane of a woman is her excessive dowry and her disrespect of her husband.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 152, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 596

Verse: Beware of the verdure growing in manure.' When asked what verdure growing in manure was, he replied, 'It is the beautiful woman that comes from an evil environment.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 232, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 597

Verse: Beware of marrying a stupid girl for her company is a waste and her offspring are [like] hyenas.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 237, no. 35; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 597

Verse: Imam al-Sadiq (AS) narrated that Umm Salama [the Prophet's wife] asked the Prophet (SAWA) about the status of women when being of service to their husbands, so he (SAWA) replied, 'Any woman who so much as moves something from one place to another in her husband's house with the intention of improving it is regarded with mercy by Allah, and whoever Allah regards [with mercy] He does not punish.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 251, no. 49; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 599

Verse: The sacred war (jihad) of a woman is to be of excellent service to her husband.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 507, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 599

Verse: A man's sitting beside his family is more beloved in the sight of Allah than his spending the night in worship in this mosque of mine
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 122; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 599

Verse: Verily the man who lifts a morsel of food to his wife's mouth is well rewarded
VerseRef: al-Mahajjat al-Baydha, v. 3, p. 70; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 599

Verse: If a man has a wife who mistreats him, Allah does not accept her daily prayer, nor any other good deed she performs, even if she was to fast all her life, until and unless she relieves him and pleases him and the husband will bear the same burden and punishment if he mistreats or oppresses his wife
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 14, p. 116, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 599

Verse: I am truly astonished at the man who beats his wife when he is more deserving of the beating than her!
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 447, no. 1259; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 600

Verse: Cursed! Cursed indeed is the woman who troubles and distresses her husband; and blessed! Blessed indeed is the woman who honours her husband, does not trouble him and obeys him in all matters
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 253, no. 55; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 600

Verse: Whoever patiently tolerates and puts up with his wife's bad character [for the sake of Allah], for every day and night of his endurance Allah will grant him the same reward as that granted to Prophet Job (AS) for enduring his afflictions, and for every day and night of her evildoing she will bear a burden as heavy as the sandhills of Arabia.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 339, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 600

Verse: She who patiently tolerates her husband's bad character will be rewarded equivalent to the reward granted to Asiya bint MuzaIim [Pharaoh's wife].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 247, no. 30; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 600

Verse: A virtuous wife is part of a man's prosperity
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 327, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 601

Verse: The most evil of all things is the evil wife
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 240, no. 52; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 601

Verse: The believer's worst enemy is an evil wife.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 3, p. 390, no. 4370; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 601

Verse: One of the Prophet's supplications was as follows: I seek refuge in You from a wife who causes me to age before my time
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 326, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 601

Verse: Be on your guard against evil women and be wary of even the best of them   if they enjoin you to do good, go against them and do the opposite so that they abandon all hope of your obeying them in doing evil
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 224, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 602

Verse: He who goes to the market and buys a gift to take back to his family is as one who is taking charity to a group of needy people. He should begin [giving gifts] to the female members of his family before the males
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 104, p. 69, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 602

Verse: Expectation makes one forget death.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 874; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 276

Verse: The closest thing is death, and the remotest thing is expectation.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2920-2921; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 276

Verse: A soul does not depart from his expectation until it enters the realm of death.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10844; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 276

Verse: Indeed you are in the days of expectation that is followed by death. So he who works in the days of his expectation before death arrives will benefit from his work and will not be hurt by death.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 333, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 276

Verse: If times of death were revealed, expectations would be debunked.
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, p. 305; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 276

Verse: Part of what Allah, the Exalted, told Prophet Moses (AS): 'O Moses! Do not extend your expectation in this world's life lest your heart become hard, for the hard-hearted is far from Me.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 329, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 277

Verse: A man who has high expectations is deficient in his action.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 421, no. 40; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 277

Verse: As for high expectation, it causes you to forget the Hereafter.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 336, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 277

Verse: Holy Prophet Muhammad al Mustaf? (s.a.w.w.) told Ibn Mas  d, 'Lower your expectation such that when you wake up in the morning, you say, 'I will not see the night' and when you go to sleep at night, you say, 'I will not see the morning.' And be prepared to depart from this life and yearn to meet Allah.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 101, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 277

Verse: A man who is sure about leaving his loved ones, dwelling under the earth, facing the final Account, and that he will be needless of what he leaves behind, and needy of what he has sent forth [for the Hereafter] deserves to shorten his expectation and lengthen his action.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 167, no. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 278

Verse: Equip yourself with low expectation for this world's life.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 286; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 278

Verse: Allah, Mighty and Exalted says, 'I will cut off the expectation of every believer who places it in someone other than Me [and replace it] with despair.
VerseRef: Sahifat al-Imam al-Reza (a.s.), p. 276, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 278

Verse: He who places his expectation in a human is indeed fearful of him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 79, no. 61; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 278

Verse: Experiences are a beneficial knowledge.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1036; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 279

Verse: Everything has a zakat, and the zakat of the bodies is to fast
VerseRef: Faza'il al-Ashhur al-Thalatha, p. 75, no. 57; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 308

Verse: Fast and you will be healthy.
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 76, no. 179; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 308

Verse: said to his son (AS), 'I started teaching you manners before your heart hardened and your mind became preoccupied in order for you to comprehend with your mind what experienced people have spared you from searching and experiencing. Thus you were spared the hardship of search and the pain of experience.'
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 70; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 279

Verse: A man who does not test things out is bound to be deceived.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 420, no. 40; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 279

Verse: A man who masters his experiences will be safe from harm, while a man who is devoid of experiences will be blind to consequences [of actions].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8040, 8680; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 279

Verse: Experience suffices as a trainer.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7016; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 279

Verse: The worth of a man's opinion is measured by his experience.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5426; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 279

Verse: A man with little experience and admiration of his own opinion must not aspire for power
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 434, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 279

Verse: Reason is an instinct that is enhanced by knowledge and experience.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1717; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 280

Verse: Reason is to retain [and learn from] one's experiences.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 673; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 280

Verse: Do not elevate me above my rightful position, for verily Allah has made me a servant before He made me a prophet.
VerseRef: Nawadir al-R`awandi, p. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 280

Verse: Two types of people will not be included in my intercession: the tyrannical and iniquitous ruler, and the heretical extremist in matters of religion, who has digressed from it and who is neither repentant nor willing to give up [his heresy].
VerseRef: Qurb al-Isnad, p. 64, no. 204; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 280

Verse: O Ali, your example in this community is as the example of Jesus son of Mary   one group of people loved him and exceeded the bounds in their love for him, and one group of people hated him and exceeded the bounds in their hatred. The following verse was therefore revealed: "When the son of Mary was cited as an example, behold, your people raise an outcry" "[ Qur'an 43:57]
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 25, p. 284, no. 34; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 280

Verse: Two types of people will perish in my name: the one who is an extremist in his love for me, and the one who loathes me with a vengeance.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 469; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 281

Verse: O Allah, verily I disclaim association with the extremists as Jesus son of Mary's disassociation with the Christians. O Allah degrade them forever, and do not ever help any of them.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 25, p. 284, no. 32; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 281

Verse: Verily Allah despises the two forms of attention-seeking: attention-seeking clothes and attention-seeking prayer.
VerseRef: Mishkat al-Anwar, no. 320; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 307

Verse: Renown for one's prayer is a form of deception.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 297, no. 27; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 308

Verse: The fasting person is in constant worship of Allah, even when he is sleeping in his bed, as long as he does not backbite a fellow Muslim.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 75, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 308

Verse: No sooner does a fasting person come upon a group of people eating than his limbs glorify Allah on his behalf, the angels invoke blessings on him, and this invocation of theirs is counted as seeking forgiveness on his behalf.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 77, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 309

Verse: Fasting acts as a shield from the Fire.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 62, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 309

Verse: Allah made fasting obligatory in order to reinforce sincere devotion [to Him].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 96, p. 368, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 309

Verse: The fast and the obligatory pilgrimage (Hajj) pacify the heart.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 296, no. 582; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 309

Verse: Verily Allah, Blessed and most High, says, 'The fast is solely for Me and I am its reward.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 63, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 309

Verse: A fasting person's sleep is worship, his silence is glorification of Allah, his good deeds are accepted, and his supplication is answered.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 2, p. 76, no. 1783; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 309

Verse: A fasting person has two sources of joy: his joy when he opens his fast and his joy at meeting his Lord.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 65, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 309

Verse: Whoever offers a fasting person something with which to open his fast obtains the same reward as him.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 68, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 309

Verse: That the rich may experience the pain of hunger and bestow his generosity thereby upon the poor.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 96, p. 369, no. 50; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 310

Verse: He who fasts a single day of his own accord is rewarded to such an extent that even if he was to be given the whole world's worth of gold for it, the reward he deserves would not be fulfilled until the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 409, no. 91; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 310

Verse: He who fasts a single day of his own accord, wishing to procure the reward of Allah, [Allah makes] his forgiveness mandatory.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 443, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 310

Verse: Whoever [voluntarily] fasts three days every month is considered as having fasted his whole life, for verily Allah, Mighty and Exalted, says, "Whoever brings virtue shall receive ten times its like" [Qur'an 6:160]
VerseRef: Da`aim al-Islam, v. 1, p. 283; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 310

Verse: Verily when a man fasts a single day of his own accord, desiring thereby what is with Allah, Mighty and Exalted, Allah gives him entrance into Paradise because of it.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 63, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 310

Verse: Allah, Mighty and Exalted, says, 'He whose limbs do not fast by refraining from what I have prohibited, then there is no need for him to refrain from food and drink for My sake.
VerseRef: al-Firdaws, v. 5, p. 242, no. 8075; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 311

Verse: Fasting is just as much keeping away from prohibited things as it is keeping away from food and drink.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 96, p. 294, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 311

Verse: What is the fasting person doing with his fast if he is not guarding his tongue, his hearing, his sight and his limbs [from sins]?!
VerseRef: Da`aim al-Islam, v. 1, p. 268; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 311

Verse: Muhammad b. Muslim narrated, 'Abu `Aabdillah (AS) [i.e. Imam al-Sadiq] said, 'When you fast, your hearing must fast, along with your sight, your hair, your skin ' and he listed a number of other things, and said, 'The day that you fast must not be like a day that you do not fast.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 87, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 311

Verse: Fasting in cold weather is an easy thing to do.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 4, p. 356, no. 5762; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 312

Verse: Winter is the springtime of a believer   its nights are long, so he can make use of them to stand in prayer, whereas its days are short and he can make use of them to fast.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 228, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 312

Verse: Blessed be the one whose own fault preoccupies him from finding faults in others.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 176; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 312

Verse: The most intelligent of people is he who is well aware of his own faults and blind to others' faults.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3233; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 312

Verse: We [the Prophet's household] are like the saddle-cushion in the middle. He who slides behind has to come forward to it, while he who has slid too far forward has to return back to it.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 18, p. 273; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 547

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) mentioning the status and qualities of the Imams said, 'Allah has made them the [source of] life for mankind, the lamps in the darkness, the keys to expression and the pillars of Islam.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 204, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 547

Verse: As regards the oppression against us in this matter   in spite of being the foremost in descent and bearing the strongest relationship to the Messenger of Allah (SAWA) - it was [a result of] selfishness. The hearts of some people coveted it [the leadership] whereas the hearts of others did not care for it. And the Arbiter is Allah.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 162; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 548

Verse: O Allah! You know that what we did was neither to compete for power nor to acquire anything from the vanities of the world. Rather we only wanted to restore the original characteristics of Your religion and to usher prosperity into Your lands, so that the oppressed from among Your servants may be safe and that Your abolished commands may be re-established.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 131; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 548

Verse: By Allah, were it not for fear of dissention among the Muslims, that they would return to disbelief and that the religion would be damaged, we would indeed have changed the situation [of leadership] as much as possible.
VerseRef: Amali al-Mufid, p. 155, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 549

Verse: The affairs of the people will continue to progress as long as the twelve men govern them   all of them will be from [the tribe of] Quraysh.
VerseRef: Sahih Muslim, no. 1821; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 549

Verse: Verily Ali was knowledgeable and knowledge is something that is inherited. In fact, no sooner does a knowledgeable man die than there remains after him one who knows his knowledge or whatever Allah wishes.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 221, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 549

Verse: By Allah, certainly I know the Book of Allah from its beginning to its end, as if it is in my palm. In it is contained the information about the heavens and the earth, about all that existed and all that is to be. Allah, Mighty and Exalted, has said: "In it is clarification of all things"
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 229, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 550

Verse: Whenever Allah selects a person to manage the affairs of His creation, He opens his breast for that purpose, and he makes springs of wisdom flow in his heart, and bestows knowledge to him by way of inspiration, after which he never again lacks the capacity to answer, nor is confused from finding the right way out.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 202, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 550

Verse: Truly Allah, Blessed and most High   has set a bound for everything, and has made for each one a sign indicating to it, and He has designated a punishment for whoever transgresses that bound.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 59, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 550

Verse: Avert the punishments through uncertainties.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 4, p. 74, no. 5146; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 551

Verse: Upholding one of the penal laws of Allah is superior to forty nights of rain on Allah's land.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 7, p. 174, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 551

Verse: A penal law that is exercised on earth is purer than sixty years of worship.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 18, p. 9, no. 21843; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 551

Verse: A woman who was honoured amongst her people was once brought to the Prophet (SAWA) charged with theft. He ordered her [hand] to be cut. A group from the tribe of Quraysh came to the Prophet (SAWA) and said, 'O Messenger of Allah! Must [the hand of] a noble lady such as her be cut like that of so and so for such a small mistake?!' He replied, 'Yes! Indeed those before you perished because of such a deed. People used to uphold the punishments for the weak ones among them and exempt the strong and the noble ones of them, and therefore they perished.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, p. 7, no. 21834; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 552

Verse: There is no intercession, bail, or oath in a legal punishment.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 4, p. 74, no. 5146; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 552

Verse: There is no bail for any of Allah's punishments.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 13, p. 439, no. 15846; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 552

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.), narrating on the authority of his father, from his forefathers, from the Prophet (SAWA) - 'He prohibited the use of intercession against the punishments and that he (SAWA) said, 'He who intercedes against one of Allah's punishments in order to annul it, and tries to abolish His punishments will be chastised by Allah, most High, on the Day of Resurrection.'
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 18, p. 24, no. 21901; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 552

Verse: Imam al-Baqir (AS) narrated saying, 'Three people gave witness against a man for committing adultery. Then the Commander of the Faithful (AS) asked, 'Where is the fourth [witness]?' They said, 'He is arriving just now.' The Commander of the Faithful said, 'Punish them, for there is not even one hour of respite to be given in punishments.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 7, p. 210, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 553

Verse: Work in such a way as if you would never pass away, and fear so as if you would die tomorrow.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3192.

Verse: The treasurers of wealth perish during their own lifetimes, whereas the knowledgeable ones remain alive for all time, their individual selves may pass away, but the likes of them continue to remain in the hearts.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha,; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 504

Verse: The scholar is alive even when he is dead, whereas the ignorant man is dead even though he may be alive.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1124-1125; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 504

Verse: Verily the scholars are the heirs of the prophets.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 32, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 504

Verse: A little knowledge is better than a lot of worship.
VerseRef: al-Mahajjat al-Baydha, v. 1, p. 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 504

Verse: To sleep having knowledge is better than to pray in ignorance.
VerseRef: Munyat al-Murid, p. 104; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 504

Verse: The peak of betrayal is disloyalty to a beloved friend and the breaking of vows.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6374; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 144

Verse: One of the worst forms of betrayal is being disloyal with things entrusted in one's possession.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 931; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 144

Verse: Verily the worst betrayal is the betrayal of the [religious] community, and the most repulsive deceit is that of the leaders
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 145

Verse: He has made me blessed, wherever I may be", said, '[Blessed means] very beneficial [to others].
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 165, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 145

Verse: Blessing consists of ten parts: nine parts are contained in trade [i.e. working to earn one's living] and the tenth part lies in endurance.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 5, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 145

Verse: Four things, of which even if only one enters a house, it will destroy it such that it will never again be able to flourish through blessing: betrayal, theft, wine-drinking, and adultery.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 19, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 146

Verse: Blessings are multiplied with justice.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4211; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 146

Verse: When crimes prevail, blessings are lifted away.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4030; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 146

Verse: Beware of bribery for verily it is sheer infidelity, and the briber will not even smell the fragrance of Paradise.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 104, p. 274, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 146

Verse: Were it not for the praying servants of Allah, the young suckling children, and the grazing animals, punishment would pour down on you.
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 1, p. 353, no. 1007; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 219

Verse: If people were to fear and return to their Lord when calamities befall them and blessings are taken away from them, returning with truth in their intentions, and reverence in their hearts, He would return to them every runaway, and correct every corrupt person.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 178; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 219

Verse: The root of the intellect is power, and its fruit is happiness.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 7, no. 59; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 395

Verse: Verily knowledge is but three things a decisive verse [of the Qur' an], an upright obligatory act, or an established recommended act, and anything else apart from these is a virtue.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 32, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 525

Verse: The most knowledgeable of people is he who adds other people' s knowledge to his own.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 27, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 528

Verse: The most knowledgeable of people is he who is infatuated with knowledge.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3079; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 528

Verse: If you were to acquire knowledge from its source, and drink water at its freshest, and amass good at its origin, and adopt a path at its clearest point, and adopt the path of truth at its most proper, the paths would open themselves to you indeed and the signs would become manifest to you.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 32, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 529

Verse: Imam Muhammad ibn 'Ali al-Baqir (a.s.) said to Salama b. Kuhayl and al-Hakam b. `Autayba, 'Go to the east and go to the west but you will never find true knowledge except for what comes from us, the household of the Prophet.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 92, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 529

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA)'s laughter was a smile.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 522, no. 1156; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 529

Verse: When you laugh boisterously, say, 'O Allah do not despise me' when you have finished.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 664, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 529

Verse: Loud boisterous laughter is from Satan.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 664, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 530

Verse: The laughter of a believer is a smile.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 664, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 530

Verse: He who smiles at his brother gets the reward of a good deed.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 206, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 530

Verse: Beware of laughing too much for verily it kills the heart.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 335, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 530

Verse: If you knew what I know, you would laugh but a little and you would cry much.
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 2, p. 249, no. 261; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 530

Verse: It is narrated within the tradition about the Prophet (SAWA)'s ascension that Allah said, 'How I wonder at the servant who laughs while he does not know whether I am pleased or displeased with him!'
VerseRef: Irshad al-Qulub, p. 200; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 530

Verse: The earnestness of one who laughs too much deteriorates.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, p. 96; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 530

Verse: Whoever meets a poor Muslim and greets him differently to the way he would greet a rich person, will meet Allah, Mighty and Exalted, on the Day of Judgment, and He will be angry with him
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 359, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 708

Verse: Keeping relationships with one's kin prolongs one's life and repels poverty.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 103, no. 61; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 708

Verse: Cure poverty with charity and giving generously
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 9, no. 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 708

Verse: Righteousness and almsgiving in secret banishes poverty.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 81, no. 83; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 708

Verse: Poverty is decreed on those who indulge in it - meaning the world (duny?) - and those who turn away from it will be helped with ease.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, p. 221; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 709

Verse: Whoever opens the door of begging to themselves Allah will open for them a door of poverty
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 20, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 710

Verse: Do not earn a living from people through us [i.e. in our name], for by that Allah will increase you in nothing but poverty.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 184, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 710

Verse: Whoever does not ask for Allah's grace will be empoverished.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 316, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 710

Verse: Any man who invokes Allah against his son will be empoverished.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 104, p. 99, no. 77; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 710

Verse: Allah, Exalted be His praise, apologizes to His believing servant who is needy in this world the same way that a brother would apologize to his fellow brother, saying, 'By my Honour and Majesty, I did not make you needy in this world because you were low in My view, so raise this veil and look at what I have compensated you with for this world.' He (AS) then said, 'And he will then raise his head and exclaim, 'That which You deprived me of does not harm me when offset against that which you have compensated me with
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 264, no. 18; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 710

Verse: Allah has made poverty a trust with His creation. So, those who conceal it, Allah will give them the equivalent of the reward of a fasting and praying person
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 260, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 711

Verse: Self-restraint is the adornment of poverty
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 68; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 711

Verse: The hardest thing to store is hiding one's neediness
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 249, no. 87; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 711

Verse: Blessed are the needy for their patience, and they are the ones who will see the Kingdom of the heavens and the earth.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 263, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 711

Verse: The poor will be the kings of the people of Heaven. All people long for Heaven, whereas Heaven itself longs for the poor
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 49, no. 58; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 711

Verse: I gazed into Heaven, and I saw that most of its people were the poor
VerseRef: Musnad Ibn Hanbal, v. 1, p. 504, no. 2086; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 711

Verse: Whoever dies and does not leave behind him a dirham or dinar, there is no person that will enter Heaven richer than him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 267, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 712

Verse: The last of the Prophets to enter Heaven will be Solomon, because of what he was given in this world.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 52, no. 76; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 712

Verse: Do you not go to the market? Do you not see the fruit that is sold, and the things that you desire?' al-Khazzaz said, 'Yes.' He (AS) said, 'For everything you see but you cannot [afford to] buy, you receive the reward of a good deed
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 25, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 712

Verse: Everything has a face, and the face of your religion is the prayer.
VerseRef: Da`aim al-Islam, v. 1, p. 133; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 714

Verse: Allah, Exalted be His praise, has made prayer the light of my eyes, and has made prayer as beloved to me as food is to a hungry man, and water to a thirsty man. The hungry man, however, is satiated when he eats, and the thirsty man is quenched when he drinks, but I can never be sated by my prayer.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 366; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 714

Verse: Prayer elicits the descent of divine mercy.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2214; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 714

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) never put anything before his prayer, neither his dinner nor anything else. When the time for prayer would set in, it was as if he knew neither family nor close friend.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 87; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 714

Verse: Prayer is the sacrificial offering of every pious one
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 620, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 714

Verse: Allah's wrath is indeed severe on the married woman who fulfils her desires through any other man apart from her husband or looks lustfully at anyone other than her unmarriageable kin [i.e. husband], upon which Allah thwarts every single good deed she has ever committed. And if she welcomes anyone other than her husband in his bed, Allah will rightfully burn her in the Fire after He has chastised her in her grave.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 366, no. 30; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 336

Verse: A man who is possessive [over his own wife] will never commit adultery.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 305; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 336

Verse: The one to face the severest punishment on the Day of Resurrection will be the man who deposited his sperm in a womb that was forbidden to him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 26, no. 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 337

Verse: Fornication has been prohibited due to the corruption it engenders, from murder to illegitimacy to ill-breeding of children to broken lineages and all sorts of other social ills.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 24, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 337

Verse: O Ali, there are six consequences that result from fornication, three of which are in this world and three in the Hereafter. In this world, it takes away one's beauty, hastens one's death and cuts off one's sustenance. In the Hereafter, it results in an evil reckoning, solicits the indignation of the Merciful Himself and makes one deserving of eternity in the Fire.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 22, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 337

Verse: Fornication brings about poverty.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 23, no. 18; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 337

Verse: We found written in the book of the Prophet (SAWA), 'If fornication prevails after my death, incidences of sudden death will increase.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 374, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 337

Verse: When fornication becomes widespread earthquakes occur as an upshot.
VerseRef: al-Tahdhib, v. 3, p. 148, no. 318; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 337

Verse: Every woman that perfumes herself and leaves her house intending for her perfume to be sensed by others is an adulteress, and every eye [that looks lustfully] is fornicating.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 338

Verse: The Friday prayer is the pilgrimage (Hajj) of the poor.
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 37, no. 91; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 341

Verse: Do not look intently at one who does not belong to you, for verily your genitals will not commit fornication as long as you guard your gaze [from fornicating]. So if you are able to keep yourself from looking at the apparel of a woman who is not permitted to you, then do so.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, p. 62; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 338

Verse: There are five attributes such that whoever does not even possess one of them does not have much to admire: loyalty, organisation, modesty, good temper, and the last which brings together all these attribute is freedom.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 284, no. 33; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 339

Verse: O people! Indeed Adam did not beget a bondsman or bondswoman, so all people are free.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Sa`ada, v. 1, p. 198; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 339

Verse: Do not ever be a slave to others when Allah, glory be to Him, has made you free
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 339

Verse: The free is free in all his states: when he is inflicted by a calamity, he shows patience; when afflictions bear down on him, they do not break him, even though he be taken in captivity or defeated and his prosperity turns into poverty, just like the truthful trustworthy Prophet Joseph - blessings of Allah upon him - whose freedom was not affected even when he was enslaved, defeated and captivated.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 89, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 339

Verse: Cheerfulness is the distinguishing trait of the free.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 467; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 339

Verse: Truly modesty and chastity are of the traits of faith, and they are the attributes of the free and the distinguishing marks of the righteous.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3605; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 339

Verse: The servant of Allah is free so far as he remains content. The free man is a slave as long as he is greedy.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 413; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 340

Verse: Friday is the chief of all days and deemed greater by Allah, the Exalted, than the day of al-Adhha and the day of al-Fitr.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 89, p. 267, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 340

Verse: Treat your families to some fruits every Friday, so that they rejoice on Fridays.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 104, p. 73, no. 24; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 340

Verse: Good and evil are given double the requital on Friday.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 89, p. 283, no. 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 340

Verse: The charity given on Friday is considered double, because of the superiority of Friday over other days.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 220, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 340

Verse: said, interpreting the above verse, 'The witness is the day of Friday, and the witnessed is the day of `Arafa.'
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 299, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 340

Verse: O Ali! People must bathe [at least] once every seven days, so bathe every Friday, even if you have to buy the water with [the money set aside for] your provision of that day and go without food, for there is no recommended act of worship greater than it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 81, p. 129, no. 18; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 341

Verse: Whoever misses three Friday prayers, being indifferent to them, Allah seals his heart.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 5, p. 6, no. 25; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 341

Verse: Whoever attends the Friday prayer faithfully and contentedly is able to resume his work [immediately thereafter].
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 1, p. 427, no. 1260; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 341

Verse: The Friday prayer is an obligation, and congregating for it in the presence of an Imam [Imam as in one of the twelve divinely appointed Imams (AS) (ed.)] is an obligation, so if someone misses three Friday prayers without an excuse, it is as if he has abandoned the performance of three obligations, and none but a hypocrite abandons three obligations without an excuse.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 89, p. 184, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 342

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) asked Ibn 'Abbas [according to another account], 'What is the value of this sandal?' Ibn 'Abbas said, 'It is worthless.' He (AS) said, 'I swear by Allah, it has more value to me than ruling over you, except for being able to do right and prevent injustice.'
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 33; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 376

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) wrote to Ibn 'Abbas: 'Do not let your share as a result of your rule be wealth that you derive [personal] gain from, nor rage that you satisfy [by revenge], but [let it be] the killing of injustice and the revival of equity.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 40, p. 328, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 377

Verse: Imam ?usayn ibn 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) was asked about jihad, as to whether it was a recommended act or an obligatory one, to which he replied, 'Jihad comes in four forms, two of which are obligatory, one of which is recommended but can only be undertaken with an obligation, and one which is recommended. The first obligatory jihad is that which a man wages against his own self in keeping away from acts of disobedience to Allah. This is one of the greatest forms of jihad. Waging jihad against those disbelievers who persecute you is also an obligation. As for the jihad which is recommended but can only be undertaken with an obligation is to fight the enemy, which is an obligation upon the whole community, and which if they abandon, they are all punishable for it. It is a recommendation upon an Imam, the limit of which is to come and face the enemy and fight them with his community. As for the jihad which is recommended, it is [embodied in] every recommended practice which a person performs and strives in its performance, its completion and its revival. Such an act, and the striving to perform it is one of the best deeds because it is a revival of the Prophetic practice, and the Prophet (SAWA) has said, 'Whoever establishes a good habitual practice, he will get his own reward for it as well as the reward of whoever performs it after him until the Day of Resurrection, without any decrease in their reward thereof.'
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 243; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 378

Verse: The jihad of a woman is being a good wife to her husband.
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 378

Verse: Jihad of the self is the dowry for Paradise.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4755; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 378

Verse: Prevent your self from fulfilling its desires, and make it hold fast to the Book of Allah during misgivings.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5406; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 378

Verse: No one is more despicable than a greedy person.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10593; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 381

Verse: Tyrants and their supporters (will be the dwellers) of the Fire.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2376.

Verse: Combat your self to avert it against its desires, for this as incumbent upon you as fighting your enemy.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 399; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 378

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) dispatched troops [to a mission]. On seeing the returning armies from the battlefront, he said, 'Blessed are those who have performed the lesser jihad, and have yet to perform the greater one.' When asked, 'O Messenger of Allah, what is the greater jihad?' the Prophet replied, 'The jihad of the self', and added, 'The best jihad is that of one who combats his own self that is between his two sides.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 160, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 379

Verse: The best jihad is combatting one's self against its desires, and weaning it from the pleasures of this world.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3232; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 379

Verse: There is no greater distinction than jihad, and no jihad like combatting one's self.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 286; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 379

Verse: Struggle against your self in Allah's worship just as one fights one's enemy, and overcome it just as one overcomes one's opponent, for the strongest of people is he who has triumphed over his self.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4761; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 379

Verse: Gain control of your souls through constant self-struggle.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2489; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 379

Verse: Through constant self-struggle are bad habits overcome.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 119; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 380

Verse: Struggle against the desires of your self and wisdom will enter your hearts.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 122; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 380

Verse: Struggle against your selves through reducing food and drink, and the angels will protect you and Satan will flee from you.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 122; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 380

Verse: Struggle against your lower desires, overcome your anger, oppose your bad habits, purify your self, perfect your intellect, and bring to completion the reward that is with your Lord.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4760; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 380

Verse: Controlling the self and combatting with it against its lower desires raises one's stations and multiplies one's rewards.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5407; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 380

Verse: Salvation for the soul is [attained] through self-struggle.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4319; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 380

Verse: Verily greed is a slippery fluid on which the feet of knowledgeable men never become firmly rooted.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 49; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 381

Verse: Greed is an eternal slavery.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 180; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 381

Verse: Whoever wishes to spend the days of his life as a free man must not allow greed to abide in his heart.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 49; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 381

Verse: The greedy person is shackled in disgrace.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 19, p. 50; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 381

Verse: The person most neglectful of his own soul is the one who is full of greed.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 18, p. 84; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 381

Verse: Woe unto the woman who angers her husband, and blessed is the woman whose husband is pleased with her.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103,p. 246, no. 24; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 597

Verse: If I was in a position to command anyone to prostrate in front of anyone else, I would command the woman to prostrate in front of her husband.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 508, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 597

Verse: The archangel Gabriel continues to bring down so much advice with regard to the [treatment of the] woman that I think she must never be divorced unless she has committed adultery.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 253, no. 58; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 598

Verse: The right of a woman on her husband is that he feeds her, clothes her, and does not cause her to lose face [by insulting her or chiding her].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 254, no. 60; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 598

Verse: A man's telling his wife 'I love you' never leaves her heart.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 569, no. 59; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 598

Verse: Whichever woman serves her husband for seven days, Allah locks seven doors of Hell to her and opens eight doors of Paradise instead whereof she may enter as she pleases.'
VerseRef: Irshad al-Qulub, p. 175; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 598

Verse: Every man who is controlled by his wife is indeed cursed
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 518, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 602

Verse: The best and worst of [seeking] fame lands one in the Fire.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 445, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 308

Verse: When a man stands to pray, Iblis [Satan] approaches and looks at him jealously because of the mercy of Allah that he can see covering him.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 717

Verse: The prayer of one who does not humble himself in his prayer does not count.
VerseRef: al-Firdaws, v. 5, p. 195, no. 7935; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 717

Verse: Holy Prophet Muhammad al Mustaf? (s.a.w.w.), when he was asked about humbleness in prayer, said, 'It is to abase oneself in the prayer, and for the servant to come to his Lord wholeheartedly.
VerseRef: Da`aim al-Islam, v. 1, p. 158; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 717

Verse: When the Prophet (SAWA) used to stand for prayer, his face would become sullen from fear of Allah, the most High. (Tradition by Ja`afar b. Ali al-Qummi )
VerseRef: Falah al-Sa'il, no. 161; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 717

Verse: Man should be humble in his prayer, for verily he whose heart is humble before Allah, Mighty and Exalted, his limbs will humble themselves too and will not fidget around
VerseRef: al-Khisal, no. 628; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 717

Verse: When Imam Ali (AS) used to stand for prayer, he would be like a fixed structure or a straight pillar, not moving at all, and sometimes when he would bow or prostrate, [he would be so still that] a bird would perch itself on him. Nobody was ever able to match the prayer of the Prophet (SAWA) apart from Ali b. Abi Talib and Ali b. al-Husayn [i.e. Imam Zayn al-Abidin] (AS).
VerseRef: Da`aim al-Islam, v. 1, p. 159; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 718

Verse: Verily moderation is the fountainhead of wisdom.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 5444; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 993

Verse: When the Commander of the Faithful, Ali (AS) used to start performing his ablution, the colour of his face would change due to the fear of Allah, most High.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 400, no. 72; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 718

Verse: Fatima al-Zahra' (AS) used to pant in her prayer due to fear of Allah, most High.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 23, p. 30, p. 46; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 718

Verse: If you were to pray so much that you became [as thin as strings], and fasted so much that you [bent over] as arches, Allah would not accept any of it unless it was accompanied by piety.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 84, p. 258, no. 56; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 719

Verse: Allah, most High, revealed to me saying, 'O brother of the prophets and the warners, warn your people not to enter any of My places of worship while having committed a wrong to another servant who holds it against him, for verily I curse him as long as he stands to pray before Me, until he makes amends for that wrong
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v.84, p. 257, no. 55; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 719

Verse: Verily the prayer of one who drinks alcohol is not counted for forty days
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 345, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 719

Verse: Two things are amazing: a silly man's wise sayings, which you have to welcome, and a wise man's bad words which you should ignore.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2364.

Verse: Two things are penalized (by God) in this world: tyranny and ungratefulness to parents.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2365.

Verse: Two things entice me out of the world you love: sweet smell and women, but my utmost pleasure in prayers lies.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2366.

Verse: Two things I have left with you to stop you going astray: the Book of God and my way (of life).They will remain inseparable to join me by the Pool (on the Resurrection Day).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2367.

Verse: Two units of prayer by a married person weigh over eighty-two units by a bachelor.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2368.

Verse: Two units of prayer by a married person weigh over seventy units by a bachelor.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2369.

Verse: Two units of prayer by the learned weigh over seventy units by laymen.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2370.

Verse: Two units of prayer by the one who knows God (well) weigh over a thousand by the one who knows Him not.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2371.

Verse: Two units of prayer by the pious weigh over a thousand by the impious.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2372.

Verse: Two units of prayer set with brushed teeth weigh over seventy units unbrushed, one case of praying privacy is better than seventy cases in public, and a covert act of charity excels seventy overt ones.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2373.

Verse: Two(real) friends enjoy each other's company.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2374.

Verse: Tyranny is of three kinds: one which God does not forgive, i.e. polytheism, God says," Verily, polytheism is great injustice", one which God forgives, i.e. peoplee's oppressing their own souls (of which God) and they themselves are aware), and one which God does not ignore, i.e. people doing injustice to one another.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2375.

Verse: Unhappily lived the one who came to know the (intentions of the) people, and happily lived among them s(he) who knew them not.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2377.

Verse: Unite with each other to have unity of hearts and keep company with one another to share a feeling of compassion.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2379.

Verse: Unity fruits in mercy, and discord in distress.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2380.

Verse: Use olive as food and lubricant, for it is the fruit of the Blessed Tree.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2381.

Verse: Using perfume for other than one's husband, brings a woman shame and fire (of Hell).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2382.

Verse: Usury is of seventy three forms, the best being like unto committing adultery with one's own mother, and the worst being (like unto) aggression upon a Muslim's fame.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2383.

Verse: Usury might lead to gain, but finally ends in loss.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2384.

Verse: Vanity originates from ignoring the truth and belittling people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2385.

Verse: Veil yourself after having intercourse with your wives, and be not naked like unto camels.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2386.

Verse: Verily good-temperedness wipes out sins as sunlight melts ice.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2387.

Verse: Verily should a servant of God be fond of the eternal life, the Exalted God will grant him sufficient wealth and fill his heart with richness, so that he will constantly live in needlessness; and should he be attached to the (material) world, the Exalted God will grant him abundance in wealth, but will appoint poverty ahead of him, so that he will constantly live a life of poverty.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2388.

Verse: Verily, in the Day of Judgment, the Exalted God will forgive the masses but not the elite for the same doings.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2389.

Verse: Verily, (man's) heart is like unto a string hanging from a tree in a desert, which is turned upside down by wind.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2390.

Verse: Verily the truth is not known through men; know the truth [first] and you will know its people
VerseRef: Majma`a al-Bayan, v. 1, p. 211; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 961

Verse: The truth is the widest thing in description, but the narrowest in practicing justice. No sooner does it side with someone than it will side against him [at another time], and no sooner does it side against someone than it will side for him later. And if anyone is to side with it, never going against it, then that would be purely for Allah, glory be to Him
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 216; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 961

Verse: Do not let consideration for a person's right hinder you from upholding the truth when it is against him
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10338; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 961

Verse: Truthfulness is incumbent upon you, for verily it is one of the doors of Paradise.
VerseRef: Tarikh Baghdad, p. 11, no. 82; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 962

Verse: Truthfulness is the congruity of logic with divine convention, whereas lying removes logic from divine convention
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, nos. 1552-1553; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 962

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.), when he was asked about the most truthful saying, replied, 'The testimony that there is no god but Allah
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p378, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 964

Verse: The most truthful of sayings is that which the tongue of the present utters.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3302; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 964

Verse: A recalcitrant tyrant is anyone who refuses to say: 'There is no god but Allah.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 22, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 964

Verse: The tyrants and the arrogant people will be raised on the Day of Judgment in the form of tiny particles, which the rest of the people will trample underfoot   as a sign of their low esteem before Allah
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 199; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 964

Verse: The work of a tyrant can never be pure.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10587; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 965

Verse: Do not address me the way tyrants are addressed, nor should you be reluctant in my presence as it is done in the presence of the oppressors, nor should you associate with me with hypocrisy.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 216; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 965

Verse: Beware of behaving tyrannically with the servants of Allah, for [eventually] Allah annihilates every tyrant
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2695; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 965

Verse: [It is] when the inner self becomes identical to the outer behavior, and even better than it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 6, p. 22, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 788

Verse: If you commit a misdeed, hasten to erase it with repentance.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 208, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 788

Verse: The one who procrastinates in repenting for himself faces the greatest danger from the [sudden] attack of death.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 12, p. 130, no. 13707; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 788

Verse: Postponing repentance is an illusion, and long procrastination is perplexity
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 456; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 789

Verse: The man who has no debt to people is more comfortable than the one indebted, even if he repayed his debt; and similarly the man who has not committed any sins is more comfortable than he who has committed sins, even if he has sincerely repented and returned [to the right path].
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 392; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 789

Verse: Abandoning sin is easier than asking for forgiveness
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 364, no. 96; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 789

Verse: Allah turns mercifully to the one who repents, and his limbs are ordered to keep his secret, and all the places on earth to conceal for him [his sin], and the record-keeping angels to forget whatever they wrote about him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 6, p. 28, no. 32; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 789

Verse: Allah, the Exalted, revealed to Prophet David [Prophet David (AS) is known in the Arabic tradition as Dawud (ed.)]   peace be upon him and on our Prophet, 'O David! When My believing servant commits a sin and then returns [to Me] and repents for that sin and is ashamed in My presence every time he remembers it, I will forgive him and cause the recording angels to forget it and change it to count as a good deed, and I will not care about it further, for I am the most Merciful
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 6, p. 28, no. 30; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 790

Verse: A man said one day, 'I swear by Allah that He will not forgive so and so.' Allah, the Exalted, said, 'Who is he to foretell about what I will do   that I will not forgive this man? I indeed have forgiven him and annulled the work of the foretelling man because of his saying, 'Allah will not forgive him.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 11, p. 267, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 790

Verse: Resentment is the basest of defects
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 966; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 790

Verse: Resentment is the instigator of anger
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 530; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 791

Verse: Resentment is the distinguishing characteristic of the jealous
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 422; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 791

Verse: Resentment is a fire that is only extinguished by triumph [over one's opponent].'
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2203; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 791

Verse: Resentment is the cause of problems.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5522; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 791

Verse: The resentful person has a tormented soul and his anxiety is manifold.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1962; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 791

Verse: Reproof [expressed] is better than resentment [harboured within].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 369, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 791

Verse: Among people, the person with the least comfort is the resentful one
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 488; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 791

Verse: The believer's resentment lasts as long as he is seated [in an assembly], but as soon as he rises it vanishes
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 310]; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 792

Verse: Be careful of your duty to Allah with respect to His people as well as His places, for verily you will be answerable even for the places [you frequented] and the animals. Obey Allah and do not disobey Him
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 167; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 792

Verse: Indeed each of you is a shepherd responsible for his own herd. The commander of the people is their shepherd and responsible for his herd, just as a man looks after his household and is responsible for them, and a woman tends to her husband and children and is responsible for them.
VerseRef: Sahih Muslim, no. 1829; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 792

Verse: Every single person is answerable for all that he possesses and all who depend on him
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7254; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 793

Verse: It has been narrated in Man La Yahzuruhu al-Faqih that a man once came to Imam al-Sadiq (AS) saying, 'I have a neighbour whose slave girls sing and play the lute, and sometimes when I go to the outhouse I take my time there so I may listen to them ? So Imam al-Sadiq (AS) said to him, 'By Allah! Have you not heard the verse of Allah, Mighty and Exalted, [in the Qur'an], "Verily the hearing and the sight and the heart, each of those shall be answerable for it"?![
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 1, p. 80, no. 177; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 793

Verse: O my son, if you are in doubt about death, then try to avert yourself from falling asleep and you will not be able to, and if you are in doubt about the Resurrection, then try to avert yourself from waking up and you will not be able to do that either.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 7, p. 42, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 793

Verse: (The Day of) Resurrection will be a field of activity wherein a successful man will be delighted at what he has bagged for himself, and a regretful man will grieve at what he has missed out on".
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, p. 341; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 794

Verse: Know O son of Adam that beyond this [life] is something greater, more horrendous and more painful for the hearts   the Day of Resurrection. That is the day when people will be gathered and that will be an eventful day wherein Allah will gather people from the first to the last
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 73, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 794

Verse: The time between when I was sent down [as a messenger] and the Hour is as these two', indicating to the space between his index finger and his middle finger. He then continued, 'By the One who has my soul in His Grasp, verily I find the Hour to be upon me already
VerseRef: al-Ja`afariyyat, p. 212; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 794

Verse: They (Evil Scholars) cause more harm to the weak ones from among our shi`aa than the army of Yazid did to Husayn b. Ali (AS) and his companions, for they snatched away their lives and their property, whereas these evil scholars   enter doubt and obscurity into the weak ones from among our shi`aa and lead them astray.
VerseRef: al-Ihtijaj, v. 2, p. 512, no. 337; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 524

Verse: Knowledge is not acquired through learning. Rather it is a light that illuminates in the heart of one who wants Allah, Blessed and most High, to guide him. So if you want knowledge, first seek out within yourself true servitude [to Allah], and seek knowledge according to its use, and ask Allah to make you understand, and He will make you understand.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 1, p. 225, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 525

Verse: Imam al-Sadiq (AS) narrated, 'A man once came to the Prophet (SAWA) asking, 'O Prophet of Allah, what is knowledge' to which he replied, 'Paying attention.' The man asked, 'Then what' He replied, 'Listening.' He asked, 'Then what' The Prophet replied, 'Learning.' The man asked, 'Then what' He replied, 'Acting upon it.' He asked, 'Then what O Prophet of Allah' , to which he replied, 'Spreading it.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 48, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 525

Verse: And know that there is no good in knowledge that is of no use, and that one cannot benefit from knowledge that is not worthy of being learnt.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 526

Verse: Imam al-Kazim (AS) narrated, 'The Prophet (SAWA) once entered the mosque to find a large group of people gathered around a man, so he asked, 'Who is this' to which they replied, 'A most learned scholar ('allama).' He then asked, 'And what is a most learned scholar' to which they replied, '[He is] the most knowledgeable of all people about Arab ancestry and events, and pre-Islamic history, and Arab poetry.' So the Prophet said, 'That is knowledge which neither harms one who remains ignorant of it nor avails one who knows it.'
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 220, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 526

Verse: There are two types of knowledge the knowledge of ideologies, and the knowledge of physical bodies.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 1, p. 220, no. 52; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 526

Verse: Knowledge is too great to be encompassed, so take the best from each thing.
VerseRef: Kanz al-Fawa' id li al-Karajiki, v. 2, p. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 526

Verse: There are four categories of sciences juristic science for religions, medicine for physical bodies, grammar for language, and astronomy for knowledge of the ages.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 1, p. 218, no. 42; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 527

Verse: The best type of knowledge is that which improves you.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4962; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 527

Verse: Know that there is no knowledge like the quest for integrity, and there is no integrity better than the integrity of the heart [i.e. the soul].
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 286; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 527

Verse: If only there were whips over my companions' heads that they may gain an understanding of the difference between the lawful and the unlawful.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 358, no. 765; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 527

Verse: He who acts upon what he knows is taught by Allah that which he does not know.
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, p. 301; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 528

Verse: Know that the earliest time is always the best, so hasten to perform good whenever you can. The most beloved acts in the eyes of Allah, Mighty and Exalted, are those that the servant performs regularly, even though they be few in number
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 274, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 724

Verse: The virtue of the earliest opportunity over the latest is as the virtue of the Hereafter over this world's life
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 58, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 724

Verse: Al-Reza (AS) went out to await the arrival of some people who were coming to visit him when the time for prayer set in. He went towards a nearby fort and took shade under a rock, saying, 'Announce the call for prayer.' I replied, 'Why don't we wait for our companions to catch up with us?' He replied, 'May Allah forgive you. Do not ever delay the prayer from the earliest moment of its onset to the latest without a good excuse. You must always pray at the earliest time', so I announced the call for prayer and we prayed. (Tradition by al-Qazzaz )
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 83, p. 21, no. 38; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 724

Verse: It only takes for a Muslim to deliberately abandon the performance of the daily obligatory prayer or to not perform it out of carelessness, for him to become an infidel (kafir
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 275, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 724

Verse: Imam al-Sadiq (AS) was once asked why the one who abandons the prayer is considered an infidel and not the fornicator, to which he replied, 'Because the fornicator and other [such sinners] commits the sin out of a desire that overcomes him, whereas the one who abandons the prayer only does so because he does not take it seriously, deeming it insignificant
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 339, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 725

Verse: When Allah wants good for a community, He increases their scholars and decreases their ignorant ones, so when the scholar speaks, he finds supporters, but when the ignorant one speaks, he is defeated.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28692; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 355

Verse: The one who guides towards good is just as its doer.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16052; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 359

Verse: I have found the good deed to be a light in the heart, an adornment on the face, and strength in action, but I have found the sin to be blackness in the heart, weakness in action, and a blemish on the face.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 44084; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 359

Verse: Salman b. `Amir al-Zabbi narrated: I asked, 'O Messenger of Allah! My father was hospitable to guests, honoured the neighbours, fulfilled his promises, and donated in misfortunes. Of what use will that be to him?' He asked, 'Did your father die a polytheist?' I said, 'Yes!' He said, 'Truly they will be of no use to him, but they will remain for his children, in that they will never be disgraced or humiliated, nor suffer poverty.'
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16489; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 362

Verse: Teach your children to pray when they reach the age of seven, and coerce them to perform it when they reach the age of ten. And make them sleep in separate beds.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 4533; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 369

Verse: No one can straighten people other than a ruler   be he pious or wicked.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 14286; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 374

Verse: Muawiya will prevail over you.' They asked, 'Why do you fight [him] then?' He replied, 'People must have a ruler   be he pious or wicked.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 14366; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 374

Verse: said regarding the Haruriyya who say that there is no rule other than Allah's, 'The rule is Allah's, and there are rulers on earth, but they [retort and] say, 'There is no government'   'There must be a government for the people under which the believer toils and the wicked and the unbeliever seek to make merry, and in which Allah decrees the final outcome.'
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 31567; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 374

Verse: The one who truly wages jihad is the one who combats his self for the sake of Allah.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 11261; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 378

Verse: Greed takes away wisdom from the hearts of the knowledgeable men.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 7576; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 381

Verse: Beware of greed for it is ready poverty.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 8852; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 381

Verse: was once offered a sweetmeat called faludhaj, so he placed it in front of him, saying, 'Verily you have a fragrant smell, are of a beautiful colour, and taste delicious, but I hate to habituate my soul [to anything] since it has not yet formed any habits.'
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 36549; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 384

Verse: When someone with good habits does something good it is accepted from him, and even if he makes a mistake, he is forgiven for it
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 911; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 386

Verse: Whoever establishes a good habitual practice that people follow even after him, he will get his own reward for it as well as the like of their reward for performing it, without any decrease in their reward thereof. And whoever establishes an evil habitual practice that is followed by people after him, he will be responsible for the burden of his own sin as well as the burden of their sins, without any decrease in their burdens thereof.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal,no. 43079; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 386

Verse: There is a place in Paradise called the House of Happiness which none shall enter except those who cheered up the orphans from amongst the believers.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 6008; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 395

Verse: There is a place in Paradise called the House of Happiness which none shall enter except those who cheered up children.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 6009; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 395

Verse: The people of the Fire to experience the least pain will be wearing slippers of fire, whilst their brains will be boiling due to the [intensity of the] heat of their slippers.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 39507; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 402

Verse: The person to experience the greatest pain on the Day of Resurrection will be the scholar who did not benefit from his own knowledge.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 28977; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 402

Verse: He who has even an atom's weight of faith in his heart will leave the Fire.
