VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 284; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 403

Verse: Only the perfidious ones hoard.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9738; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 404

Verse: Only an offender hoards.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9723; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 404

Verse: The hoarder in our market is like the apostate in the Book of Allah.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9717; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 406

Verse: Compare my tradition with the Book of Allah. If it corresponds with it, then it is from me and I have indeed said it.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 907; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 945

Verse: It does not matter if you change the order of the words of a tradition, as long as you render its meaning [exactly].
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 29179; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 946

Verse: Do not narrate to my people from my traditions except those which are perceptible to their intellects
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 29284; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 946

Verse: Travel and you will be healthy and wealthy.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 17470; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 948

Verse: If three people are travelling together, they must place one of them in charge
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 17550; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 949

Verse: When the Last Hour comes, if any of you happens to be holding a seedling in his hand, then if he is able to, let him not stand until he has planted it
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9056; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 951

Verse: Every single Muslim that cultivates or plants anything of which humans, animals or birds may eat from is counted as charity towards them on his behalf.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9051; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 951

Verse: Every single person that cultivates something, Allah rewards him as much as the fruit produced by that plant
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9075; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 951

Verse: Whoever plants a tree and patiently maintains it and tends to it until its fruition, every single fruit consumed from that tree is regarded by Allah as charity [on his behalf].
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 9081; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 951

Verse: There are three tempting trials: beautiful hair, a beautiful face, and a beautiful voice
VerseRef: Kanz al-'Ummal, no. 44129; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 953

Verse: There will come a time with trials where a person will rise in the morning a believer and turn a disbeliever in the evening, save those whom Allah, most High, revive with knowledge
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 30883; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 954

Verse: Know that my community after me will become swathed with trials like parts of a dark night. At that time a person will be a believer in the morning and a disbeliever in the evening; he will sleep a believer and wake up a disbeliever. Groups will sell their religion for a small offer of the world.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 30893; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 954

Verse: Lo! Fear of people must never prevent any man from telling the truth when he knows it; truly the best jihad is a true word spoken before an unjust ruler
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 43588; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 960

Verse: Accept the truth from anyone who comes to you with it   be he lowly or noble, even if he himself is detestable to you. And reject falsehood from anyone who comes to you with it   be he lowly or noble, even if he is beloved to you
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 43152; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 961

Verse: He who usurps someone's land wrongfully will meet Allah [on the Day of Resurrection] wrathful towards him
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 30366; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 968

Verse: It is not permissible for a Muslim to seize the property of his fellow brother without right to it, and that is because Allah, Mighty and Exalted, has forbidden the property of a Muslim to another Muslim.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 30343; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 968

Verse: During my Night-Journey up to the heavens, I was taken to a people whose bellies were as large as houses and contained serpents that could be seen from outside their bellies. I asked, 'Who are these people, O Gabriel?' He replied, 'They are the usurers
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 31857; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 969

Verse: Verily venerating Allah' s Exaltedness involves honouring the old, the bearer of the Qur' an and the just Imam
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 25507; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 972

Verse: when he heard a man ask Allah for patience, said, 'You have asked Allah to be tried, so now ask Him for vitality
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 4935, 3272; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 977

Verse: Allah is not asked anything more beloved to Him than to be asked for vitality
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, nos. 3130-3153; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 977

Verse: Whoever acts tyrannically will be broken.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7697; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 965

Verse: Befriend people, give them time, and do not raid them unless you first call them [to Islam]. For you to call all the people of the earth, those who live in houses and those who live in tents, to Islam is dearer to me than for you to bring me their womenfolk and children [as captives], and to kill their men.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 11300; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 981

Verse: Truly the martyrs of the sea are more meritorious with Allah than the martyrs of the land.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 11108; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 984

Verse: Eating anything and everything that one desires is wasting.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 7366; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 986

Verse: The world is cursed along with what is in it, except that through which the pleasure of Allah is sought.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 6088; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 997

Verse: Imam Mosa ibn Ja'far al-Kazim (a.s.) said to Hashim, exhorting him, 'You must beware of greed, and despair of acquiring anything in the possession of others. Suppress the greed in others for verily greed is the key to disgrace, it exploits the intellect, fabricates valorous qualities for itself, tarnishes one's reputation, and does away with one's knowledge.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 315, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 382

Verse: Greed is an evil characteristic.
VerseRef: al-Durrah al-Bahirah, p. 42; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 382

Verse: How revolting it is for the believer to have an avid desire that disgraces him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 374, no. 35; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 382

Verse: When I consider my sins my Lord, I am horrified [at them], and when I consider Your pardon, I am avidly eager [for it].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 98, p. 83, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 383

Verse: For indeed I ask You because of my eternal hope in You and because of the great desire that I entertain about You; which is the graciousness and mercy that You have made obligatory upon Yourself.
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, v. 1, p. 168; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 383

Verse: Habit is second nature.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 702; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 383

Verse: A habit holds every man under its authority.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7327; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 383

Verse: He who obeys habits does not attain high levels.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6409; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 383

Verse: Your tongue will urge you to whatever you have accustomed it [to say], and your inner self will require you to do whatever you have made it fond of.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7634; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 384

Verse: Do not hasten to resort to anger lest it prevail over you by becoming a habit.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10288; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 384

Verse: Allah will humiliate and depose whoever acts tyrannically
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8471; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 965

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) in his will to his son, al-Hasan (AS), 'Verily the heart of a young person is like the untilled earth, which accepts whatever is placed therein. I, therefore, urge you to hasten to self-discipline before your heart hardens, and your mind becomes preoccupied.'
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 384

Verse: Habituate yourself to performing noble actions and to bear the burdensome consequences [of your actions], and your soul will be elevated as a result, your Hereafter will flourish, and your admirers will increase.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6232; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 384

Verse: Habits are overpowering, for he who forms a habit to something in secret and during his free times is plagued by them in public and when occupied.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 113; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 384

Verse: Virtue is overcoming one's habit.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 357; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 385

Verse: The best of worship is to overcome one's habit.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2873; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 385

Verse: [Only] Through overcoming one's habits are the highest of stations attained.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4300; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 385

Verse: Change your habits and your acts of obedience will become easier for you.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6405; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 385

Verse: Subjugate your souls to abandon their habits, drive them to perform acts of obedience, make them bear the burdensome consequences of their actions, adorn them with the performance of noble acts, and protect them against the pollution of sins.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5199; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 385

Verse: The most difficult of things to manage is the removal of habits.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2969; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 385

Verse: Everything is achievable, except the removal of an ingrained habit.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6906; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 385

Verse: O people, take upon yourselves your own training, and turn away from the voracious dictates of your habits.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 359; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 386

Verse: The best of deeds in the sight of Allah are those that are performed habitually, even if they be few in number.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 70, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 386

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) wrote in one of his letters to al-Ashtar, when he appointed him governor of Egypt, 'Do not discontinue a good practice that the pioneers of this community acted upon, by virtue of which there was general unity and through which the subjects prospered. Do not innovate a practice that will infringe on these earlier practices in any way, for the reward of those who had laid them down will continue, whereas you will be the one to bear the burden for discontinuing them.'
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 53; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 387

Verse: I exhort you, by Allah, by Allah, to take care of the House of your Lord! Do not leave it empty for as long as you live, for if it is deserted you will be given no respite.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 47; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 387

Verse: The pilgrimage is the jihad of every weak person.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 620, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 387

Verse: Spending one dirham in charity during the pilgrimage equals one thousand dirhams.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 628, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 387

Verse: Those who go to Makkah for obligatory and voluntary pilgrimage (Hajj and `umra) are the envoys of Allah, and His gift to them is forgiveness.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 630, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 388

Verse: Prayer is the pillar of religion and its likeness is as the likeness of the pillar of a tent. If the pillar is stably fixed, the pegs and the ropes remain stable, but if the pillar inclines and breaks, neither peg nor rope remains fixed
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 116, no. 117; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 714

Verse: The most beloved of all acts to Allah, Mighty and Exalted, is the prayer, and it is the legacy of the prophets
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 1, p. 210, no. 638; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 715

Verse: Chiefdom is achieved through tolerating hardships.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 224; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 184

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) when asked about the best and most beloved deed to Allah, replied, 'I do not know anything after true knowledge [of Allah] to be better than this prayer. Do you not see that the righteous servant Jesus son of Mary even said, " and he has enjoined me to [establish] the prayer "[
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 264, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 715

Verse: Holy Prophet Muhammad al Mustaf? (s.a.w.w.) said with regards to a man who prays in spite of committing sins, 'Verily his prayer will prevent him [from them] some day or other, and then he will soon repent.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 198; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 715

Verse: Verily the pillar of religion is the prayer. It is the first thing to be considered from amongst the deeds of man, so if his prayer is valid, the rest of his deeds will be considered, and if his prayer is void, then the rest of his deeds will not be taken into consideration.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v.82, p. 227, no. 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 715

Verse: Whoever performs his prayer with full knowledge of the right due to it is forgiven
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 628, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 715

Verse: Allah made the prayer incumbent in order to eliminate one's pride.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 209, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 716

Verse: The first thing that the servant will have to account for is his prayer   if accepted, all else will be accepted
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 268, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 716

Verse: Prayer reinforces sincerity and eliminates pride
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 296, no. 582; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 716

Verse: If there was to be a river outside one's house into which he bathed five times a day, would there remain any dirt on his body? Similarly the prayer is the river which purifies [one's soul]   every time one performs a prayer it acts as atonement for one's sins, except for that sin which takes him and keeps away from his faith
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 236, no. 66; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 716

Verse: As long as you are praying, [know that] verily you are knocking at the door of the Almighty King, and the King's door opens for whoever knocks persistently thereat
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 366, no. 2661; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 716

Verse: If the praying one knew about the Sublimity of Allah covering him, he would never wish to raise his head up from prostration
VerseRef: al-Khisal, no. 632; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 716

Verse: It is narrated in Bihar al-Anwar that when Imam al-Hasan (AS) used to perform his ablution the colour of his face would change and his joints would tremble. When he was asked about this once, he replied, 'It is only fitting for one who stands before the Lord of the Throne that his face should change colour and his joints should tremble
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 80, p. 346, no. 30; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 718

Verse: It is narrated in Da`aa'im al-Islam that when Imam Zayn al-Abidin (AS) used to perform his ablution and prepare to begin his prayer, his face would become pale and change colour. When asked about this, he replied, 'Verily I am going to stand before the Great King
VerseRef: Da`aim al-Islam, v. 1, p. 158; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 718

Verse: When Ali b. al-Husayn (AS) used to stand in his prayer, he was as straight as a tree trunk, and no part of him moved except for that which the wind caused to move
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 300, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 718

Verse: When Abu Ja`afar and Abu `Aabdillah [i.e. Imam al-Baqir and Imam al-Sadiq (AS)] used to stand to pray, their faces would change colour, sometimes reddening and sometimes paling, and it was as if they were intimately conversing with someone they could see
VerseRef: Falah al-Sa'il, p. 161; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 719

Verse: The resentful person knows no friendship.'
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10436; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 791

Verse: Whoever loses three children in death, will not be put to the fire of Hell by God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3056.

Verse: Whoever loves and hates, grants and avoids granting (something to people) for the sake of God, stands at the peak of faith.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3057.

Verse: Whoever loves something remembers it a lot.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3058.

Verse: Whoever loves the world damages the Hereafter, and whoever loves the Hereafter damages the world. So, prefer the immortal to the mortal.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3059.

Verse: Whoever lowers himself in obedience to God, is more honorable than the one who has earned dignity through disobedience to Him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3060.

Verse: Whoever marries a woman with the intention not to pay her marriage portion, will die as an adulterer, and whoever buys something intending not to pay its cost, will die as a traitor, and traitors will dwell in Fire.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3061.

Verse: Whoever mentions a defect which is not to be found in someone, will be kept in Hell so long as to prove his saying.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3062.

Verse: Whoever mentions the name of a man for the trait he possesses, is actually backbiting him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3063.

Verse: Whoever makes another believer happy makes me happy, and whoever makes me happy makes Allah happy
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 188, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 396

Verse: Hoarding is a vice.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 112; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 405

Verse: Hoarding is the mount of hardship.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 19, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 405

Verse: One of the characteristics of the idiots is exhausting themselves by hoarding.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9349; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 405

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) said in a letter he wrote to al-Ashtar when he appointed him governor of Egypt, 'Know - along with this - that most of the merchants and traders are very narrow-minded, and awfully avaricious. They hoard goods for profiteering and fix high prices for goods. This is a source of harm to the people, and a source of shame for the governors in charge. So stop people from hoarding, because verily the Messenger of Allah (SAWA) has prohibited it.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 53; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 405

Verse: There is no good in any act of hoarding that brings loss to the people and inflates the prices for them.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 13, p. 274, no. 15337; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 405

Verse: One who aids you in your obedience [to Allah] is the best of companions
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1142; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 347

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) said about the verse: "It is We who have dispensed among them their livelihood", 'Allah, the Exalted, told us that employment is one of the means of people's livelihood. He, in His wisdom, diversified their energies, will, and conditions. Thus, He made man's employment of one another one of the means of people's livelihood   If every one of us was forced to build for himself, make his own furniture, and produce everything himself   the world's conditions would not be bearable and people would not be able to endure them, and would find them impossible. But He ensured its management by diversifying their energies so that everyone performs for others that which is compatible with his own capacity, in order for some of them to be served by others and for their conditions to be sound.'
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 13, p. 244, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 259

Verse: Ammar al-Sabati narrated, 'I asked Ab  Abdill h (AS) about a man who trades but he can make the same money by working for someone else. He said, 'He should not work for someone else. Rather, he must seek Allah's bounty by trading, for by working for someone else, he restricts Allah's bounty for him.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 90, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 259

Verse: Muhammad b. Muslim narrated from one of the Imams (AS), that he was asked about a man who accepts a job and before doing any work, he passes it on to another and profits from it himself; to which he replied, 'No, [it is not allowed] unless he does some work on it.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 273, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 260

Verse: A man who wrongs a worker in his wage, will have Allah annul his worship and prevent him from smelling the breeze of Paradise, which can be smelled from a distance of five hundred years.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 347, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 260

Verse: Wronging the worker in his wage is a grave sin.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 170, no. 27; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 260

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) forbade using the services of a worker before he is informed of his wages.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 4, p. 10, no. 4968; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 261

Verse: Verily Allah, Mighty and Exalted, despises the weak believer who has no religion [i.e. has no devotion to his religion].' When asked who a believer with no religion is, he replied, 'He who does not prohibit wrong.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 59, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 263

Verse: The basis of Islamic law is the enjoinment of good and the prohibition of wrong.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6817; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 263

Verse: All acts of righteousness and striving in the way of Allah are as mere spittle in the deep sea compared to enjoining good and prohibiting wrong.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 374; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 263

Verse: Enjoinment of good is the best of all acts performed by creation.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1977; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 263

Verse: Know that enjoinment of good and prohibition of wrong never reach an end, and never cut off sustenance.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 57, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 263

Verse: It is not permissible for a believing eye to watch Allah being disobeyed and close without first changing the situation.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 179; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 263

Verse: Verily the enjoinment of good and the prohibition of wrong is the path of the prophets, the way of the righteous, a great obligation on which all other obligations are founded and on which ideologies are secured, by which earnings are made lawful, by which iniquities are redressed, through which the earth flourishes, justice is sought from enemies and [Allah's] command is kept upright.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 56, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 264

Verse: You must enjoin good indeed and you shall prohibit wrong otherwise the chastisement of Allah will surely overtake you.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 11, p. 407, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 264

Verse: Never abandon the enjoinment of good and the prohibition of wrong lest the evil ones amongst you gain mastery over you whereafter you will supplicate [Allah] but you will not be answered.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 47; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 264

Verse: The one who contents himself with the wrong action of a group of people is as one who plunges into it with them, and every person who plunges into wrongdoing is guilty of two sins: the sin of having committed the wrong and the sin of being content with it.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 254; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 264

Verse: He who approves of a wicked deed partakes in it.
VerseRef: Kashf al-Ghamma, v. 3, p. 139; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 264

Verse: Meet your brother with a cheerful face.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 103, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 182

Verse: You will not be able to encompass all people with your money, so meet them with cheerful faces and joy.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 103, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 182

Verse: The smile is the trap of amity.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 69, p. 409, no. 120; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 183

Verse: Cheerfulness is the trait of the free.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 656; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 183

Verse: The cause of love is cheerfulness.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5546; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 183

Verse: The cheerfulness of the believer is on his face, his strength is in his religion, and his sorrow lies in his heart.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3454; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 183

Verse: Your cheerfulness shows the generosity of your soul.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4453; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 183

Verse: When you meet your brothers, shake hands with them and show them cheerfulness and joy; thus when you part company all your sins will have gone
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 20, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 183

Verse: The best thing with which people can win the hearts of their loved ones and remove the animosity from the hearts of their enemies is cheerfulness upon meeting, asking about them in their absence, and smiling at them in their presence.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 57, no. 124; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 184

Verse: when asked by his father about what chiefdom involves, replied, '[The ability] To make one's tribe flourish, and [the capacity] to bear the burden of their crimes.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 194, no. 14; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 184

Verse: The truly noble one is he who has been ennobled by his knowledge, and true chiefdom belongs to he who is wary of his duty to Allah, his Lord.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 82, no. 82; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 185

Verse: The virtue characteristic of chiefs is the beauty of their worship.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6559; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 185

Verse: There are four virtues that qualify a man for chiefdom: chastity, courtesy, magnanimity and intelligence
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 1, p. 94, no. 23; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 185

Verse: The greatest characteristic of chiefdom is giving before one is asked.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 113, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 185

Verse: Engaging in disputes with the lower classes is a source of disgrace for chiefs.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9813; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 185

Verse: The person guilty of petty sins should not be coveting chiefdom, and neither should the inexperienced person who proudly holds his own opinion be coveting leadership.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 434, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 185

Verse: A fool can never be chief.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 271, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 185

Verse: He who does not exert himself in his childhood will not be high-minded when he grows up.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8272; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 186

Verse: He who asks questions as a child is able to answer them himself as an adult.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8273; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 186

Verse: He who does not learn as a child does not progress as an adult
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8937; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 186

Verse: The ignorant man is a child even though he may be old, while the knowledgeable man is an adult even though he be young.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 1, p. 183, no. 85; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 186

Verse: It is recommended to discipline a boy in his childhood in order that he be clement as an adult.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 3, p. 493, no. 4748; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 186

Verse: The clement person is almost a prophet.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 43, p. 70, no. 61; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 187

Verse: Clemency is the completion of the intellect.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, v. 1055; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 187

Verse: Clemency arranges the affair of the believer.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1420; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 188

Verse: The beauty of a man is his clemency.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4718; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 188

Verse: Every single ordeal contains a favor from Allah that encompasses it
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 373, no. 34; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 658

Verse: said, when he set out to pray for rain, 'Allah tries His servants when they commit evil deeds, with shortage of crops, disallowance of blessings and closing the treasury of bounties, so that a repenting man may repent, a man likely to quit may quit, a man likely to remember may remember, and a man likely to be deterred may be deterred
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 123; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 658

Verse: The greater the ordeal and test, the greater the reward and recompense. Do you not see that Allah, the Praiseworthy, tested our precursors from the time of Adam, peace be upon him, to the last generations in this world, with [the creation of] stones that neither harm nor benefit, nor do they see or hear, and He made from them His sacred House, which He made a standing place for people?! But Allah tries His servants with various ordeals, and obligates them with various forms of struggle, and tests them with various dreads, in order to eradicate vanity from their hearts and instill humility in their souls and that this may open the doors to His favor and the feasible means to His forgiveness.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 13, p. 156; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 655

Verse: Verily you will be put in tense perplexity and be finely filtered, until you are turned upside down; then certain people will surpass [others] after having lagged behind, while those who were ahead fall back
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 5, p. 218, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 655

Verse: Do not rejoice at wealth and luxury, nor dread poverty and ordeal; for verily gold is tested by the fire and the believer is tested by an ordeal.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10394; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 656

Verse: Verily the ordeal is faster in descending upon a pious believer than rain to the bottom of the earth.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 67, p. 222, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 656

Verse: The prophets have the hardest ordeals from among people, then they scale down according to their piety.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 252, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 656

Verse: when he was asked about the believer's trial with leprosy and similar diseases, said, 'Were ordeals reserved for other than the believers?!
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 67, p. 221, no. 27; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 656

Verse: Allah, most High, revealed to Prophet Job [Prophet Job (AS) is known as Ayy b in the Arabic tradition (ed.)], 'Do you know what your sin against Me was that brought ordeals down upon you?' He said, 'No.' He said, 'You entered the court of the pharaoh and uttered two flattering words
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 123, no. 304; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 657

Verse: Allah loathes the withdrawn wicked man, who never sustains any harm to his body or wealth.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 81, p. 174, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 657

Verse: I hate for a man to be immune [to ordeals] in this world's life and not suffer any affliction
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 81, p. 176, no. 14; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 657

Verse: Allah feeds His believing servant with ordeals like a mother feeds her child milk.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 81, p. 195, no. 52; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 657

Verse: When Allah wants good for a people, he tries them
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 310, no. 855; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 657

Verse: Allah, the Exalted, brings trial to the believer like a man brings his family a gift upon his return from a trip; and He denies him this world like a doctor puts a patient on diet
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 255, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 658

Verse: You will not be believers until you consider the ordeal as a bounty and ease as an affliction, for patience during an ordeal is greater than oblivion during ease
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 313, no. 870; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 658

Verse: No more than forty nights can pass on a believer without something that saddens him and causes him to remember [Allah's admonition].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 67, p. 211, no. 14; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 659

Verse: When Allah wants good for a servant who commits a sin, He follows it with a punishment and reminds him to ask for forgiveness. But if Allah, wants bad for a servant who commits a sin, He follows it with a favor that makes him forget to ask for forgiveness and continue sinning. This is the meaning of Allah's verse, "We will draw them imperceptibly [into ruin], whence they do not know"81: with favors whenever they sin.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 229, no. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 659

Verse: Praise be to Allah, Who offset the sins of our followers (shi`aa) through their hardships, so that their obedience remains immune through it and they become deserving of reward as a result of it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 232, no. 48; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 659

Verse: Whenever Allah punishes a believing servant in this world, [it is only because] He is too Clement, too Glorious, too Generous, and too Kind to requite him with punishment on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 243, no. 82; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 660

Verse: When Allah, Blessed and most High, wants to honour a servant who has previously committed a sin, He tries him with illness, and if not with that then with need. And if not with that, then He makes his death difficult. But when He wants to humiliate a servant who has done some good previously, He makes his body healthy, or makes his sustenance abundant, or makes his death easy
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, no. 433; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 660

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said, in the presence of Sadir, 'When Allah loves a servant, He immerses him completely in ordeal. O Sad r! We and you are in it day and night.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 253, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 660

Verse: Unite with each other and be not divided among yourselves, for it causes separation in your hearts.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 2378.

Verse: When Allah loves a people, or a certain servant, He pours ordeals down heavily on him, so that whenever he exits from a [source of] anguish he falls into another
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 148, no. 32; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 660

Verse: The more faith a servant attains, the harder his life becomes.
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 314, no. 874; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 661

Verse: A man is tested according to the level of his love [for Allah].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 67, p. 236, no. 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 661

Verse: It is written in the Book of Ali, 'The believer is tested according to the level of his good deeds, so whoever is sound of faith and good deeds, his ordeals are more intense. And that is because Allah, the Exalted, did not make this life a [source of] reward for a believer, nor a [source of] punishment for a disbeliever. However, he whose faith and deeds are weak, his ordeal is also little
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 67, p. 222, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 661

Verse: A believer is like the two sides of a balance: the more faith he has the more ordeal he sustains, so that he meets Allah, the Exalted, without any sins
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 67, p. 243, no. 82; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 661

Verse: There is a rank in Paradise which no servant can reach except through suffering harm in his body.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 67, p. 212, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 662

Verse: Look carefully at what [attire] you pray in. If it is not among that which is fitting or permissible for it, then it is not accepted
VerseRef: Basharat al-Mustafa, p. 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 720

Verse: Imam `Ali ibn Husayn (a.s.), when he was asked about the condition for the acceptance of the prayer, replied, 'Our guardianship and disassociation from our enemies
VerseRef: al-Manaqib li Ibn Shahr ashUb, v. 4, p. 131; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 720

Verse: Whoever Allah accepts even one prayer from, He will not chastise, and whoever He accepts even one good deed from He will not chastise.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 266, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 720

Verse: Allah does not accept a single prayer from one who looks at his parents loathingly, even if they oppress him.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 349, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 720

Verse: There are eight categories of people whose prayer is not accepted: the slave who has escaped from his master, until he returns to him; the defiant wife whose husband is displeased with her; the one who withholds payment of the alms-tax; the one who neglects to perform the ablution; the discerning woman who prays without covering her head; the leader of a community who leads them in prayer while they detest him; the intoxicated one; and the one who resists the urge to urinate or defecate [before commencing the prayer].
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 324, no. 2656; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 720

Verse: Allah does not accept the prayer of the servant whose heart is not present alongside his body.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 406, no. 921; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 721

Verse: Verily the servant performs a prayer where neither a sixth nor a tenth of it may be accepted. Verily only that part of his prayer is accepted from him wherein he was fully conscious
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 84, p. 249, no. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 721

Verse: The tyrants will be the farthest away from Allah on the Day of Judgment
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 11, p. 304, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 965

Verse: Two simple units of prayer performed with contemplation are better than standing the whole night in prayer
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 68, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 721

Verse: Only that part of your prayer in which you engaged with your full attention is accepted. So if one is inattentive in all of it or careless in his performance of it, that same prayer is crumpled up and thrown back at his face
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 84, p. 260, no. 59; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 721

Verse: Whoever performs a two unit prayer fully knowing what he is saying in it, gets up from it with not a single sin left [unforgiven] between him and Allah.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 266, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 721

Verse: The prayer of one who does not complete the bowing and prostration is not counted
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 198, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 722

Verse: The one who is deliberately aware of who is on his left and who is on his right is not counted as having prayed.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 84, p. 249, no. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 722

Verse: It is narrated within the tradition about the Prophet's ascension that [Allah addressed the Prophet (SAWA) saying], 'O Ahmad, how I wonder at three types of servant: one who starts his prayer knowing full well Who he raises his hands to and in front of Whom he stands, and yet remains drowsy
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 22, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 722

Verse: When sleep overcomes you while you are in your prayer, then break your prayer and go to sleep, for verily [in that state] you do not know if you are praying for or against yourself!
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar,, v. 84, p. 283, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 723

Verse: Do not stand for prayer lazily, drowsily or sluggishly for verily these are from among the disturbances brought about by hypocrisy, and verily Allah has prohibited the believers from standing for prayer while they are intoxicated, which means when intoxicated by sleep
VerseRef: Tafsir al-`Ayyashi, v. 1, p. 242, no. 134; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 723

Verse: The worth of a man with respect to his religion is measured by his diligence to keeping up his daily prayers [at their specific times].
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 122; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 723

Verse: Observe the timing of the prayer and perform it at its prescribed time, neither hastening to pray it earlier in order to be free of it, nor delaying it because of some work.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 83, p. 14, no. 25; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 723

Verse: Do not neglect your prayer, for verily the Prophet (SAWA) said while he was on his death bed, 'The one who takes his prayer lightly is not of me
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 269, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 725

Verse: Abu Basir narrated, 'I went to Humayda, to condole her for the death of Abu `Aabdillah (AS) [i.e. Imam al- Sadiq], so she cried and said, 'O Abu Muhammad, if you saw him as death came upon him, he placed his hand over one eye and said, 'Call my relatives and my friends to come to me.' When everyone had gathered around him, he said, 'Verily our intercession will not avail one who takes his prayer lightly.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 3, p. 25, no. 2923; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 725

Verse: Allah has made generosity the greatest moral virtue.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 15926; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 348

Verse: Allah has created every single vicegerent of His with generosity as their natural disposition.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16204; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 348

Verse: Relinquish the generous person's sin for verily Allah takes him by the hand every time he slips.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 16212; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 349

Verse: When Allah wants good for a servant, He censures him in his dreams.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 30765; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 354

Verse: When Allah wants good for a servant, He sweetens his affairs', at which he was asked, 'How does He sweeten affairs?' The Prophet (SAWA) replied, 'He opens the way for him to do righteous deeds before his death and causes him to die in the state of doing good.
VerseRef: Kanz al-`Ummal, no. 30763; Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 355

Verse: Do not cut off a friend, even if he disbelieves
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 347

Verse: The one who sows good is bound to reap good.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 76, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 351

Verse: Allah is the greatest name from among the names of God, Mighty and Exalted, and it is the name that cannot be used to name anyone but Allah, and no creature has ever been named with it
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 231, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 94

Verse: Allah means the One who is worshipped and by Whom people are too bewildered to comprehend His essence and to fathom His identity.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 89, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 94

Verse: In the name of Allah, Mighty and Exalted, is the attestation to His Lordship and His Oneness
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 93, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 94

Verse: Allah is the One \to Whom every creature resorts when he is in need or in hardship, when there is no hope in anyone but Him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 3, p. 41, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 94

Verse: Prophet Moses (as) addressed Allah, saying, 'My Lord, guide me to an action the performance of which will earn me Your good pleasure.' So Allah revealed to him, 'O son of Amran, verily My pleasure lies in that which you will be averse to and you will not be able to endure it.' So Moses fell prostrate, weeping and cried out, 'My Lord! You have selected me to speak to when You have not spoken to any before me, and yet You do not guide me to that action by which I may earn Your pleasure!' So Allah revealed to him, 'Verily My pleasure lies in your pleasure with whatever I decree.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 143, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 95

Verse: Three things enable a servant to attain Allah's pleasure: persistence in seeking forgiveness, affability towards people, and frequent giving of charity.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 81, no. 74; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 95

Verse: He who dissatisfies his body earns Allah's pleasure, and he who is not willing to dissatisfy his body defies Allah.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 312, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 95

Verse: He [Allah] has advised you to be Godwary in all things, and has made it the height of His good pleasure and His sole requirement from His creatures.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 183; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 95

Verse: Allah's pleasure is linked to His obedience.'
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5410; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 96

Verse: Verily the one who Allah is most pleased with from among you is the one who is the most generous towards his own dependents.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 136, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 96

Verse: O My Lord, what is a sign of Your pleasure with a servant of Yours?' So Allah revealed to him, saying, 'When you see Me preparing My servant for My obedience and averting him from My disobedience, [know that] it is a sign of My pleasure.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 26, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 96

Verse: The sign of Allah's pleasure with His servant is the satisfaction found in the servant himself with all that Allah decrees, be it in his favour or not.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6344; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 96

Verse: The ruination of scholars is the love of leadership.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3930; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 132

Verse: The ruination of subjects is abandoning obedience.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3934; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 133

Verse: The bane of clemency is submissiveness.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3940; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 134

Verse: The bane of giving is procrastination.'
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3941; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 134

Verse: The bane of economy is parsimony.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3942; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 134

Verse: The bane of awe is humor.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3943; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 134

Verse: The bane of the quest is failure
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3944; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 134

Verse: The bane of sovereignty is lack of protection
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3945; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 134

Verse: The bane of pacts is lack of compliance
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3946; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 135

Verse: The bane of rule is pride
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3950; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 135

Verse: The bane of narration is lying
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3947; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 135

Verse: The bane of knowledge is not putting it into practice.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3948; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 135

Verse: The bane of work is abandoning sincerity.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3949; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 135

Verse: The bane of generosity is poverty.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3951; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 135

Verse: The ruin of ordinary people is a treacherous scholar.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3952; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 136

Verse: The bane of justice is a powerful oppressor.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3953]; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 136

Verse: The bane of civilization is the tyranny of rulers.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3954; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 136

Verse: The bane of power is blocking kind deeds.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3955; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 136

Verse: The bane of the heart is self-admiration.'
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3956; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 136

Verse: And He made obligatory for you the pilgrimage to His Sacred House which he made the 'qibla' for all people. They come to it like the cattle coming to water, and eagerly turn to it like the birds eagerly returning to their nest; He, glory be to Him, made it a sign of their humility before His greatness and their yielding to His Might.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 388

Verse: Perform the Hajj [obligatory pilgrimage] and the `umra [voluntary pilgrimage] so that your bodies become healthy, your sustenance expanded, and your faith improved; and suffice yourselves with the expenses of people and the expenses of your families.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 70, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 388

Verse: Pilgrimage calms the hearts.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 296, no. 582; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 388

Verse: Allah has made a measure for everything and for every measure an end
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4778; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 731

Verse: The one who plants the tree of goodness will reap the sweetest fruit.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam,. no. 6442; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 351

Verse: And this is the house by which Allah has demanded the devotion of His creatures to test their obedience in their coming to it, so He prompted them to glorify it and visit it. He made it the station of the prophets and the focal point (qibla) for those who pray to Him. It is a branch of His good pleasure and a way that leads to His forgiveness, founded on absolute perfection and ultimate grandeur.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 493, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 389

Verse: There is no place dearer to Allah, most High, than the mas`aa [place of running between the mounts of al-Safa and al-Marwa in Makkah], for every overbearing person is lowered and debased before Him there.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 99. p. 45, no. 34; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 389

Verse: If someone asks why He commanded the pilgrimage, it is answered: in order for people to perform the journey to [i.e. for] Allah, Mighty and Exalted, and ask for increase  in addition to the benefits it has of understanding religion and relating the reports of the Imams (AS) to every side and region.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 119, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 389

Verse: Pilgrimage repels poverty.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 389

Verse: He who goes to perform the obligatory pilgrimage (Hajj) three times will never be afflicted with poverty.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 117, no. 101; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 389

Verse: I have never seen anything faster at attracting wealth and at repelling poverty than habitual pilgrimage (Hajj) to this house.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 694, no. 1478; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 389

Verse: Imam al-Sadiq (AS), when Ishaq b. `Ammar said to him: 'I have made up my mind to go for pilgrimage every year either personally or by sending one man of my household at my cost'   asked, 'Are you determined to do that?' He said, 'Yes'. The Imam said, 'If you do that, then be certain of abundance in your wealth, and take glad tidings of abundance in your wealth.'
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 70, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 390

Verse: Complete your pilgrimage by visiting the Messenger of Allah (SAWA) when you leave to visit the House of Allah, for deserting it is unkind, and that is what you have been commanded to do [i.e. in the Qur'an: and complete  ] by observing the rights of the graves that Allah has made incumbent upon you to visit, and ask for [increase in] your sustenance thereat.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 616, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 390

Verse: The pilgrimage is completed by meeting the Imam.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 262, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 390

Verse: Indeed people have been ordered to come to these stones [i.e. the edifice of the Ka`aba] to circumambulate them, and then to come to us to inform us of their friendship, and to declare their support for us.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), no. 30; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 390

Verse: He who postpones the obligatory pilgrimage until he dies, Allah will resurrect him as a Jew or a Christian on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar,v. 77, p. 58, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 391

Verse: He who abandons the pilgrimage for one of his worldly needs will not be able to satisfy that need until he sees the shaven heads [i.e. after the return of the pilgrims from Makkah].
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 281, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 391

Verse: Imam al-Sadiq (AS), when `Abd al-Rahman told him: 'Some of these narrators are saying that it is better for a man to go for pilgrimage once and then to gives alms and maintain his kinship with his relatives [with that money than to go for pilgrimage again]'   said, 'They are wrong. If people were to do that the House would become deserted. Allah has made this House a [means of] sustentation for mankind.
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, v. 1, p. 452; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 391

Verse: Abd al-Rahman b. Kathir narrated: 'I went for pilgrimage with Abu `Abdillah [al-Sadiq] (AS). When we had gone a certain way, he climbed a hill and looked down at the people and said, 'What a lot of clamour and what few pilgrims!
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 27, p. 181, no. 30; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 391

Verse: The pilgrim to this House is of no worth unless he has three attributes: piety that restrains him from acts of disobedience to Allah, most High; clemency with which he controls his anger; and good companionship with whoever accompanies him.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 148, no. 180; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 392

Verse: When he who makes pilgrimage by means of unlawful money says: "Here I am O Allah! Here I am (labbayk All?humma labbayk)", Allah will say to him, 'No labbayka and no welcome for you. Your pilgrimage is returned to you.'
VerseRef: al-Durr al-Manthur, v. 2, p. 63; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 392

Verse: Pilgrimage is of two kinds: the pilgrimage [performed] for Allah and the pilgrimage for the people. So he who goes on pilgrimage for Allah, his reward is upon Allah and will be Paradise, and he who makes pilgrimage for the people, his reward on the Day of Resurrection will be with the people.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 74, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 392

Verse: Anas b. Malik narrates, One year I went on pilgrimage with al-Sadiq (AS). When his mount came to the place of ihram, whenever he intended to say labbayka [here I am  ] his voice would cut off in his throat, and he nearly fell off his mount. So I said to him, 'O son of the Prophet, say it, for you must say it', to which he replied, 'O Ibn Abi `Amir, how can I dare say: 'I am here O Allah! I am here' whilst I fear lest He say, 'No labbayka and no welcome for you!
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 167, no. 219, `Ilal al-Sharay`e, p. 235, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 393

Verse: Indeed they have been ordered to be in the state of ihram in order that they humble themselves before entering the sanctuary and the safe place of Allah, and so that they do not divert and preoccupy themselves with anything of the affairs of this world and its adornments and pleasures; and so that they be serious in what they are engaged in, journeying to Him and approaching Him with all their being.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 9, p. 3, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 393

Verse: Whoever dies on the road to Makkah, on the way there or back, will be safe from the Great Terror on the Day of Resurrection
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 263, no. 45; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 393

Verse: Whoever dies in the state of ihram, Allah will raise him [obedient to Him] saying, 'Here I am, O Allah' (labbayka)
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar,v. 7, p. 302, no. 56; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 393

Verse: The people miss their Imam, but he witnesses the season [of Hajj] and sees them, though they do not see him.
VerseRef: Kamal al-Din, p. 346, no. 33; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 394

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) said to `Aabdallah b. `Aabbas, 'I have not benefited from any saying after the sayings of the Prophet, apart from this one, 'Verily man feels happy when he manages to grasp something that he was about to miss, and he is saddened when he misses something that was within his grasp. So let your happiness lie in all that you can seize of the Hereafter, and let your regret lie in all that which passes you by of it.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 15, p. 140; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 394

Verse: Happiness is useless without tenderness.
VerseRef: Masalib al-Sa' ul, no. 50; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 394

Verse: Abstaining from eating even one morsel of prohibited food is dearer to Allah than a voluntary prayer of one thousand units
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 120; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 738

Verse: When a man accumulates wealth from prohibited sources, neither his obligatory pilgrimage (Hajj) nor his voluntary pilgrimage (`umra) nor his maintaining kinship will be accepted from him, and it even spoils marriage
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 680, no. 1447; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 738

Verse: Then We shall attend to the works they have done and then turn them into scattered dust", said, 'By Allah, even though their deeds were whiter than Egyptian cotton, when the prohibited presented itself before them they did not leave it
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 81, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 739

Verse: He who has unlawful access to enjoy a woman or a maid but leaves her for fear of Allah, He - Mighty and Exalted - will keep him safe from the Fire, preserve him from the Great Terror, and make him enter Paradise
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 334, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 739

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) used to visit the people of the ledge [of the mosque], who were his guests and had migrated to Medina without their families and belongings. The Prophet (SAWA) had lodged them on the ledges of the Mosque. They were four hundred men, and he greeted them every morning and every night. One day he came to them while some of them were mending their sandals, some were patching their garments, and some were cleaning their heads from lice. The Prophet (SAWA) used to provide them with half a bushel of dates every day.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 12, p. 56, no. 13499; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 740

Verse: I hereby reiterate what I have said: establish the performance of the prayer, pay the alms-tax, enjoin what is good, and forbid evil. Verily the peak of enjoining what is good and forbidding evil is to heed to my words and propagate them to those who are absent; you must command them to accept [my words] and prohibit them from going against them, for they are the commands from Allah, the Exalted, and from me
VerseRef: al-Ihtijaj, v. 1, p. 157, no. 32; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 741

Verse: O Ali! When Allah guides a man through you, it is better for you than all that the sun shines on
VerseRef: al-Mustadrak `ala al-Sahihayn, v. 3, p. 691, no. 6537; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 741

Verse: Render Allah beloved to His servants, and He will love you
VerseRef: al-Mu`jam al-Kabir, v. 8, p. 91, no. 7461; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 741

Verse: Whoever becomes a cause for a man's converting to Islam is guaranteed entry into Paradise.
VerseRef: al-Mu`jam al-Kabir, v. 17, p. 285, no. 786; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 741

Verse: Anyone who calls to what is right will have the same reward as he who follows him, without any decrease in each of their rewards thereof.
VerseRef: al-Muwatta', v. 1, p. 218, no. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 741

Verse: Sharif b. Sabiq al-Taflisi narrated on the authority of Hammad al-Samdari: 'I said to Abu `Abdillah, J`afar b. Muhammad [al-Sadiq] (AS), 'I often go to the lands of the idolaters, and people say that if I die there, I will be resurrected with them.' He said to me, 'O Hammad! When you are there, do you mention our cause and call people to it?' I said, 'Yes.' He said, 'And when you are in these cities   the cities of Islam   do you mention our cause and call people to it?' I said, 'No.' He said, 'If you die over there, you will be resurrected as a whole community in yourself, and your light will run before you.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 46, no. 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 742

Verse: No one can support [the cause of] the religion of Allah, the Exalted, except for one who is well-versed in all its aspects.
VerseRef: al-Firdaws, v. 1, p. 234, no. 897; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 742

Verse: Abd al-Salam b. Salim al-Harawi said, 'I heard Abu al-Hasan al-Ridha (AS) saying, 'May Allah have mercy on anyone who revives our cause.' I asked, 'How does he revive your cause?' He replied, 'He learns our sciences and teaches them to the people, for verily if people were to know the goodness in our speech, they would follow us.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 180, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 743

Verse: Every single servant who delivers a sermon, Allah, the Exalted, will ask him about it and what he meant by it
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 743

Verse: Speak the truth, and let no one's blame for obeying Allah affect you.
VerseRef: Hilyat al-Awliya, v. 1, p. 241; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 743

Verse: Let not the fear of people prevent any of you from speaking the truth, when he sees or witnesses it, for telling the truth or reminding [others] of a great consequence will neither hasten death nor delay sustenance
VerseRef: Musnad Ibn Hanbal, v. 4, p. 102, no. 11474; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 743

Verse: said, in what is attributed to him in The Lantern of the Path: 'The best advice is that which does not carry the statement beyond the limits of honesty, nor the act the limits of sincerity
VerseRef: Misbah al-Shari`a, p. 395; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 744

Verse: Learn honesty before speech
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 334, no. 522; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 744

Verse: Ease and do not cause hardship [when propagating], and comfort and do not nauseate
VerseRef: Sahih al-Bukhari, v. 5, p. 2269, no. 5774; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 744

Verse: Sustenance comes to those who feed others faster than a knife can cut though flesh.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 147, no. 1388; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 412

Verse: I have been commanded to be amicable towards people as much as I have been commanded to deliver the Message.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 48; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 744

Verse: Umar b. Hanzala, 'O `Umar! Do not overburden our followers (shi`a), and be kind to them, for people cannot endure what you can
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 334, no. 522; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 744

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) mentioning the virtue of the honourable Prophet (SAWA), 'He [Allah] sent him while the people were straying in perplexity, and engaged in corruption  He (SAWA) advised extensively and kept on the [right] path, and called for wisdom and gentle exhortation
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 95; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 745

Verse: When a word comes from the heart, it falls onto the heart; but when it merely comes from the tongue, it will not go farther than the ears
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 20, p. 287, no. 279; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 745

Verse: Invite people to what is good with other than your tongues, so that they see tenacity, veracity, and piety in you
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 105, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 745

Verse: May Allah have mercy on the people who are a lamp and a beacon. They call to our cause with their actions and the best of their efforts
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 301; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 746

Verse: said to the Commander of the Faithful, Ali (AS), 'Verily the truly prosperous person is the one who loves you and obeys you
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 426, no. 953; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 746

Verse: Prosperous is he who is sincere in his acts of obedience
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1293; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 746

Verse: Eloquence is to answer without delay, and to be correct without mistakes.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2150; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 257

Verse: Brevity may suffice in accomplishing eloquence.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6666; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 257

Verse: Eloquence is not exemplified by the sharpness of the tongue, nor through excess babbling; rather it is through capturing the intended meaning and aiming at the proof.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 312; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 257

Verse: Eloquence lies in three things: coming close to the intended meaning, avoiding waffling, and communicating more meaning in fewer words.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 317; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 258

Verse: The most expressive eloquence lies in that which is metaphorically correct and easy to grasp, and that which is pleasantly brief.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3307; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 258

Verse: The best speech is that which is decorated by a pleasant structure and is understood by the elite as well as the laymen.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3304; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 258

Verse: The believer is continuously fearful of a bad end [to his life] and remains uncertain of attaining the pleasure of Allah until the angel of death appears and takes his soul.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 366, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 261

Verse: Relying on this world in spite of all that you face therein is ignorance.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 384; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 425

Verse: If you want Allah to protect you from an evil final outcome [to your life], then know that whatever good that comes is from Allah's grace and divine succour, and whatever bad that comes, know that Allah has delayed it for you and you have already been given respite for it, so be aware of Allah's clemency and pardon for you.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 392, no. 60; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 262

Verse: If you want a good final outcome to your actions and for your soul to be taken while you are in the best of actions then observe the rights of Allah, do not use His bounties to disobey Him, do not allow the fact that Allah is clement with you to delude you [into negligence], and respect and honour everyone whom we praise or those who embrace our love.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 4, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 262

Verse: Whoever enjoins good and prohibits wrong is the deputy of Allah and the deputy of His Prophet on the earth.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 12, p. 179, no. 13817; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 262

Verse: Do not oppose that which you are ignorant of; for most knowledge lies in that which you cannot fathom.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, no. 10246; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 426

Verse: It is incumbent upon the Imam to imprison the reckless from among the scholars, the ignorant from among the physicians, and the bankrupt from among the lease-holders.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 3, p. 31, no. 3266; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 426

Verse: If a Muslim woman becomes an apostate, abandoning Islam, she is not killed but is imprisoned for life.
VerseRef: Tahdhib al-Ahkam, v. 10, p. 142, no. 569; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 426

Verse: It is narrated in al-Kafi: Verily the Commander of the Faithful (AS) restricted imprisonment to only three cases: a man consuming the property of an orphan unlawfully, or usurping it, or a man who takes off with what he has been entrusted with.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 7, p. 263, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 427

Verse: A man was brought to the Commander of the Faithful (AS), who had bailed the life of another man. He imprisoned him, saying, 'Ask for your companion now.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 13, p. 156, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 427

Verse: Imam Muhammad ibn 'Ali al-Baqir (a.s.) said about a man who had ordered another man to kill someone, which he had done   'He who killed him must be killed, and he who ordered the killing must be imprisoned until he dies.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 7, p. 285, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 427

Verse: He who loves something constantly mentions it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7851; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 575

Verse: O my son, everything has a distinguishing characteristic by which it is recognised and witnessed   the negligent person has three distinguishing characteristics: absent-mindedness, amusement, and forgetfulness
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 121, no. 113; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 633

Verse: The most beloved and nearest to me on the Day of Resurrection will be the most good-natured, and the one who is most humble
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 385, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 170

Verse: The believers with the most perfect faith are those who are the most good-natured.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 140, no. 227; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 170

Verse: Ill nature causes life to be miserable and torments the soul.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5639; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 173

Verse: He expresses information but not through a tongue or voice. He listens but not with the holes and organs of hearing. He speaks but does not utter words; He remembers but does not learn  When He wishes to create something, He says to it 'Be' and it is, but not through a voice that can strike the ears, nor a calling that can be heard. Rather, His speech, Glory be to Him, is an act of His that He creates and incorporates, which did not exist before, for were it an ever-existing thing it would be a second god
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 186; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 452

Verse: Verily things come into being solely by His will and His wish; without the need for speech, alternation of breath or utterance with the tongue.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 100, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 453

Verse: He manifests the wonders of His management for the onlookers, but by virtue of the exaltedness of His Might He is Hidden from the imagination of the thinkers.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 213; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 453

Verse: He who observes his own faults is preoccupied from others' faults.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 88; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 312

Verse: The most beneficial thing for a man is his precedence over others at knowing his own fault.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 243, no. 337; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 312

Verse: When you see a man inspecting other people' s sins and forgetting his own sins, then know that he is deluding himself.
VerseRef: Mustatrafat al-Sara' ir, p. 48, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 313

Verse: O iniquitous servants, you blame others based on what you conjecture about them and do not blame yourselves in that which you know for certain!
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 501; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 313

Verse: The fault that lies within a man' s own self is more than enough to prevent him from prying into other people' s faults, which he himself possesses but to which he is blind; or from blaming others for that which he himself is unable to abandon; or from bothering the one he is sitting next to by prying into matters that are none of his business.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 110, no. 81; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 313

Verse: The one who pries into others' faults, disapproves of them, and then adopts them for himself, is truly a fool.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 349; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 313

Verse: The greatest fault is when one criticises others for the same faults present in oneself.'
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 353; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 313

Verse: He who knows a fellow brother' s evil deed and conceals it [from others], Allah will conceal his faults on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 3, p. 239, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 314

Verse: It is the duty of a believer towards a fellow believer to conceal seventy of his grave sins!
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 207, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 314

Verse: It is narrated in Tanbih al-Khawatir that Prophet Jesus (AS) was passing with his disciples by the corpse of a dog, when the disciples exclaimed, 'What an awful stench this dog has!' to which Prophet Jesus (AS) retorted, 'How white are his teeth!
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 117; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 314

Verse: A man's soul is his steps towards his death
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 18, no. 221; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 731

Verse: He who informs you of your faults will guard you in your absence, whereas he who flatters you with respect to your faults will point the finger at you in your absence.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8260, 8261; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 314

Verse: Nothing prevents anyone from among you from disclosing to a fellow brother a fault that he fears in him, except for the very fear that he too will disclose the same fault to him. You are all accomplices in your rejection of the next world and loving this world.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 113; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 315

Verse: The most beloved of my brothers to me is he who confers my faults to me.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 366; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 315

Verse: Do not seek to pursue believers' shameful acts, for verily whoever pursues believers' shameful acts, Allah will pursue his shameful acts, and whoever' s shameful acts Allah pursues, He will expose, even if it be in the confines of his own home.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, v. 2, p. 288, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 315

Verse: Anticipating attentively for a fault [in someone] is a fault in itself.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4489; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 315

Verse: The furthest of your subjects from you, and the worst of them in your view should be the one who is the most eager to pursue people' s shortcomings, because people do have faults and the ruler is the most appropriate person to conceal them, so do not ever seek to discover those faults which are hidden from you.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 53; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 315

Verse: Do not ever rejoice at someone else' s mistake, for verily you yourself will never be immune to committing mistakes.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10294; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 315

Verse: He who finds faults will be accused of them himself, and he who insults will be retorted to [with worse].
VerseRef: Kanz al-Fawa' id li al-Karajiki, v. 1, p. 279; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 316

Verse: The furthest a servant can be from Allah is when he associates in a brotherly manner with someone while at the same time making note of all his faults in order to one day shame him.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 355, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 316

Verse: Tolerance is the grave of faults.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 316

Verse: The intellect is the coverer of faults.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6434; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 316

Verse: He who covers himself with the cloak of modesty, people cannot see his flaws.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 223; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 316

Verse: He who covers himself with the cloak of knowledge, his faults remain hidden from people.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 215; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 316

Verse: Your faults will remain concealed as long as your good fortune assists you.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 51; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 316

Verse: He who is incapable of getting to know something will find fault with it.
VerseRef: Kitab al-Irshad, v. 1, p. 301; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 317

Verse: The fountainhead of wisdom is the fear of Allah.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 133, no. 43; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 317

Verse: Holy Prophet Muhammad al Mustaf? (s.a.w.w.) said regarding a group of people who used to delay from praying [in congregation] in the mosque [praying instead in their own houses], 'A people who neglect to pray in the mosque almost become deserving of having firewood piled at their doors and set alight so that their houses burn down on them
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 3, p. 478, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 726

Verse: He who prays all five prayers in congregation, you must only believe to be good
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 371, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 726

Verse: Look carefully at what your prayer is like, for verily as the leader of the community, you must pray it perfectly and not be careless in its performance. Every leader who leads the prayer for a people is responsible for any defect in their prayer, so perfect it and be mindful with regards to it and you will have the same reward as them without there being any reduction in their reward thereof.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 29, no. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 726

Verse: Lead them in prayer, praying as the weak ones among them do [in consideration towards them], and do not torment them [by performing lengthy prayers].
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 52; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 726

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) was asked how to determine the most rightful person to lead the congregation, to which he replied, 'Verily the Prophet (SAWA) said, 'The person who recites the Qur'an the best [i.e. with correct pronunciation] should lead them, and if they all recite similarly, then the one who migrated [from Makkah to Medina] the earliest, and if they all migrated around the same time, then the oldest from among them, and if they are all the same age, then the most knowledgeable from among them with regards to the prophetic practice and the laws of jurisprudence. No one from among you should lead a man in prayer in his own home, nor a man of authority within the sphere of his authority.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 376, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 727

Verse: Your religion is your brother so take precaution with your religion however much you can
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 110, no. 1680; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 727

Verse: It is upon you to be resolute and precautious with your religion.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 259, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 727

Verse: Be precautious with all things that you have the ability to carry out.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 260, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 727

Verse: If it were like this, the concepts of reward, punishment, command, and prohibition would be erroneous. The meaning of promise [of Paradise] and threat [of the Hellfire] would be futile, and there would be no blame for a wrongdoer, nor praise for the good-doer. Furthermore, the good-doer would be more blameworthy than the wrongdoer, and the latter would deserve more praise than the former. This [i.e. predestination] is the claim of the idolators and the foes of the Merciful
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 5, p. 13, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 728

Verse: Death suffices as a guard
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 5, p. 142, no. 14; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 731

Verse: Death is a fortified castle
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 494; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 731

Verse: Everything has a fixed duration and an end
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 190; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 731

Verse: Anything that you can blame a servant [of Allah] for is his own doing, and whatever you cannot blame him for is Allah's doing. Allah, the Exalted, will ask the servant, 'Why did you disobey [Me]? Why did you commit sins? Why did you drink wine? Why did you commit adultery?' All of this is the the servant's doing. But He will not ask him, 'Why were you sick? Why were you short? Why were you white? Why were you black?' because all of this is Allah's doing
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 5, p. 59, no. 109; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 728

Verse: Sins cannot be other than one of three cases: either they originate from Allah   which they do not   and in this case it would not be proper for the Lord to punish His servant for what he has not committed; or that they originate from Him and the servant together   which they do not   and in this case it would not be proper for the strong partner to wrong the weak partner; or that they originate from the servant   which they do   and in this case, if Allah forgives, it is due to His kindness and liberality, or if He punishes, it is as a result of the sin and crime of the servant
