VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 323, no. 23; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 728

Verse: Allah, the Exalted, is too merciful to coerce His servants to sin and then punish them for it. He is also too mighty to want something and it not be accomplished.' Then they were asked whether there is a stance between free will and predestination, to which they replied, 'Yes, [a stance] wider than the space between the earth and the sky.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 360, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 728

Verse: Allah, the Exalted, is too merciful to coerce His servants to sin and then punish them for it. He is also too mighty to want something and it not be accomplished.' Then they were asked whether there is a stance between free will and predestination, to which they replied, 'Yes, [a stance] wider than the space between the earth and the sky
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 360, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 729

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said, according to what Mufadhal b. `Umar narrated on his authority, 'There is neither predestination nor free will, but a stance in between them.' [Mufadhal] asked, 'What is the stance in between?' He replied, 'It is like when you observe a man in sin and you advise him against it but he does not desist from it, so you leave him to his sin. Leaving him to sin after he has rejected your advice does not mean that you commanded him to sin
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 5, p. 17, no. 27; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 729

Verse: Allah, most High, said, 'O son of Adam! By My will you attained free will, and with the help of My favor, you perform your obligations towards Me, and with My power you feel empowered to disobey Me. I created you with sight and hearing, so I deserve more credit for your good deeds than you, while you are to blame for your own misdeeds.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar,v.5, p. 4, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 729

Verse: He who claims that Allah coerces His servants to disobey Him or burdens them with that which they cannot endure [i.e. acts of obedience], you must not eat from an animal that he has slaughtered, nor should you believe his testimony, nor pray behind him, nor give him any part of your alms
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar,v.5, p. 11, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 730

Verse: He [i.e. Allah] created the duration [of every life] and made them short or long; He expedited some and postponed others, and connected their causes with the death.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 7, p. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 730

Verse: said, interpreting the above verse: 'The first   undetermined   term is suspended; He can expedite and postpone it as He wishes. As for the specified term, that is what He wills to occur as a result of the Night of Ordainment (laylat al-qadr) to the next year's Night of Ordainment; and that is Allah's statement: "when their time comes, they shall not defer it by a single hour nor shall they advance it
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 5, p. 139, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 732

Verse: People's terms are extended by charity
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4239; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 732

Verse: There must be no talking while the leader of the prayer is giving the sermon, nor looking around except to the extent permissible in the prayer.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 1, p. 416, no. 1230; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 342

Verse: Man follows the same creed as his friend, so consider carefully who it is you befriend.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 518, no. 1135; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 342

Verse: One's friend is the closest of one's relations.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 674; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 342

Verse: He who lacks friends lacks a bare necessity.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8760; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 342

Verse: Friends are a single soul divided between different bodies.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2059; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 343

Verse: Souls resemble other souls, and those that resemble each other are in harmony, that is why people are attracted towards those they resemble.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 92, no. 100; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 343

Verse: Every person is inclined towards one who is like him.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6865; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 343

Verse: The most prosperous of people is he who mingles with honourable people.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 185, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 343

Verse: The most goodness and righteousness is to be found in the company of people of reason and understanding.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3129; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 343

Verse: The one who invites you to the everlasting abode and helps you work towards it is a compassionate friend indeed.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8775; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 343

Verse: Do not call a man your friend with the true stamp of friendship until you have tested him in three matters: anger him so that you may see whether his anger takes him away from right into wrong; test him with the dinar and the dirham [in money matters]; and travel with him.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 646, no. 1339; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 344

Verse: Befriend one who gives you a good image, and do not befriend one who uses you to boost his own image.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 267, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 344

Verse: It is not good for you to befriend someone who does not have your best interests at heart as he does his own.
VerseRef: al-Durrah al-Bahirah, p. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 344

Verse: Verily ill nature spoils one's deeds just as vinegar spoils honey.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 309, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 173

Verse: He who, in his friendship with you, is of no aid to you against your base self, his friendship is a curse on you, if only you knew.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9041; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 344

Verse: Beware of befriending corrupt people, immoral people, and those who openly commit acts of disobedience to Allah.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2601; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 344

Verse: The friend of an ignorant man is always wearied and miserable.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5829; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 344

Verse: Beware of befriending immoral people, for verily only evil accompanies evil.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 199, no. 36; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 344

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) in his will to his son al-Hasan (AS), said, 'O my son, beware of befriending a stupid person, for although he will surely want to be of benefit to you, he will only bring you trouble.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 198, no. 35; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 344

Verse: Imam `Ali ibn Husayn (a.s.) in his advice to his son al-Baqir (AS), said, 'Beware of befriending one who has cut off relations with his kin, for verily I have seen him cursed in the Book of Allah, Mighty and Exalted, on three different occasions.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, v. 2, p. 377, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 345

Verse: The ignorant man's friend is always wearied.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, v. 78, p. 352, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 345

Verse: When a man puts his friend to shame, he has indeed parted from him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, v. 74, p. 165, no. 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 345

Verse: Jealousy of one's friend stems from weakness in one's love [for him].
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 218; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 345

Verse: Do not let bad opinion of people overcome you, for verily it will not leave any pardon between you and your friend
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 207, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 345

Verse: He who penetrates deeply into his friend's affairs, his love for him comes to an end
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8582; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 345

Verse: He who argues with his brothers has few friends
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8772] ; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 346

Verse: If you want the exclusive love of your brother, then do not ever make fun of him, nor quarrel with him, nor compete against him, nor be malicious to him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 291, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 346

Verse: The quarrel corrupts a long friendship and dissolves strong ties, because it only really consists of strife, and strife is the main cause of a break in friendship
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, no. 311; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 346

Verse: The farmers are the treasures of mankind for they plant and harvest the good things that Allah has made grow. On the Day of Resurrection, they will occupy the best and nearest position [to Allah] and will be called the blessed ones.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 261, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 90

Verse: The bane of training is the triumph of [one's] habit.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3933; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 133

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said that the verse of Allah in the Qur'an: "And on Allah do the believers rely" refers to the farmers.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 66, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 90

Verse: There is no occupation more beloved to Allah than agriculture, and every single prophet that Allah sent down was a farmer except Prophet Enoch [Prophet Enoch (AS) is known as Idris in the Arabic tradition (ed.)] (AS) who was a tailor
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 13, p. 461, no. 15898; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 91

Verse: Alcohol and faith will never be together in the breast or heart of a man.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 152, no. 64; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 91

Verse: All evil in its entirety has been gathered in one house and drinking alcohol is the key to that house.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 148, no. 63; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 91

Verse: Allah imposed the abandonment of drinking alcohol in order to safeguard the intellect.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 252; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 91

Verse: Allah forbade alcohol due the corruption that accompanies it, and due to the way in which it alters the drinkers' reason, and how it encourages them to deny Allah, Mighty and Exalted, and to slander Him and His messenger, and for all the other accompaniments of corruption and murder.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 98, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 92

Verse: When the alcoholic one meets Allah, Mighty and Exalted, he will meet him as an idol worshipper.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 632, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 92

Verse: The one who drinks an intoxicant, his prayers will not be accepted for forty days and nights.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 632, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 92

Verse: When one who drinks alcohol speaks, do not believe him, and if he proposes do not marry him, if he falls sick do not visit him, and if he dies do not attend his funeral, and do not entrust him with anything.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 127, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 92

Verse: The alcohol drinker is like sulphur, so keep away from him lest he pollute you with his stench for sulphur has a bad stench.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 127, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 92

Verse: The ones who have quenched themselves in this world with an intoxicant [alcohol] will die thirsty, will be resurrected thirsty and will enter the Hellfire thirsty.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 290, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 93

Verse: Whoever abandons alcohol for other than the sake of Allah, Allah will quench his thirst [in Paradise] with the sealed wine'. Imam Ali (AS) exclaimed, 'For other than Allah?' The Prophet (SAWA) replied, 'Yes, by Allah, for his own protection and well-being.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 412, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 93

Verse: Allah did not prohibit alcohol because of its name, rather He prohibited it due to its effects, so whatever produces the same effects as alcohol is [treated as] alcohol.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 412, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 93

Verse: Allah means the worshipped one, by Whom people are bewildered, and to Whom they are submissive. Allah is the One veiled from the grasp of sights, and the One hidden from imagination and contemplation.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 89, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 94

Verse: The downfall of rulers is weak management.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3931; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 132

Verse: Never hold any act of common courtesy in contempt, even simply meeting a fellow brother with a face displaying pleasure at seeing him.
VerseRef: Kanz al-Fawa' id li al-Karajiki, v. 1, p. 212; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 203

Verse: Never deem any act of common courtesy that you are able to carry out as insignificant in comparing it to a greater act, for verily the simple act performed when the need for it arises is more beneficial to its receptor than the great act for which there is no need. Perform for each day good acts that befit it and you will grow on the right course.
VerseRef: al-Ja`afariyyat, p. 233; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 203

Verse: The best act of common courtesy is that which good people are able to benefit from.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4983; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 204

Verse: The mark of acceptance of a servant with Allah is that his good acts reach the objects of their intention. If not, then that is not the case.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 419, no. 47; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 204

Verse: He who leads a blind man forty steps on level ground, even if he was to be rewarded the whole world's worth of gold, it would not be enough to recompense a needle's worth of what that act deserves. And if there is a danger on the path which he averts him from, he will find that act on the Day of Resurrection within his balance of good deeds, larger than one hundred thousand times the expanse of the earth.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 15, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 204

Verse: The bane of power is aggression and tyranny.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3972; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 138

Verse: The fountainhead of all afflictions is infatuation with vain pleasures.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5244; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 138

Verse: The worst affliction of the intellect is arrogance.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5752; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 138

Verse: The best of houses is the bathhouse for in it the Fire [of Hell] is remembered and [bodily] dirt is removed.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 1, p. 115, no. 237; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 139

Verse: Three things cause weight gain and three others cause weight loss. As for those that cause weight gain   excessive use of the bathhouse, smelling sweet fragrance and wearing soft clothing. And as for those that cause weight loss, they are: eating too many eggs, fish and unripe dates.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 155, no. 194; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 139

Verse: Three things destroy the body and may even kill it: eating [cooked] meat that has been left overnight, entering the bathhouse after overeating and having intercourse with the elderly.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 75, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 139

Verse: Do not enter the bathhouse except after you have put something in your belly that will cool the heat of the stomach for that strengthens your body. And do not enter the bathhouse with a full stomach.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 1, p. 125, no. 298; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 139

Verse: Going to the bathhouse every alternate day causes weight gain, and going every day causes the fat around the kidneys to melt away.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 1, p. 126, no. 303; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 140

Verse: Allah likes for His servant, when he leaves to meet his brothers, to dress himself well and to beautify himself.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 1, p. 85, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 140

Verse: Each one of you should trim his moustache and the hairs in his nose and he should groom himself for this enhances his beauty.
VerseRef: Qurb al-Isnad, p. 67, no. 215; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 140

Verse: Dress up and beautify yourself, for Allah is beautiful and He loves beauty; and make sure it is lawful [beautification].
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 3, p. 340, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 140

Verse: The bane of beauty is vanity.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 59, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 141

Verse: Look for goodness in people with beautiful faces for their deeds are more likely to be good.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 74, no. 344; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 141

Verse: The beauty of a believer's face is a sign of Allah's care for him.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4848; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 141

Verse: People live by their goodness towards others more than they do according to their [predestined] life terms; they also die due to their sins more than they die due to the end of their terms.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 5, p. 140, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 732

Verse: Allah revealed unto me that we should be humble, so that nobody shows pride over anybody else, and no one intimidates another
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 3, p. 558, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 733

Verse: There are two things that have ruined people: fear of poverty and going after pride
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 69, no. 102; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 733

Verse: Let go of your pride, put down your arrogance, and remember your grave.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 398; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 733

Verse: Whoever does something out of vainglory, Allah will resurrect him black on the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 292, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 733

Verse: The worst state of the rulers among righteous people is for them to be assumed to love pride and be regarded as haughty.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 216; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 733

Verse: What is it with the son of Adam [human being] and pride?! His beginning is a sperm and his end is a carcass. He cannot sustain himself, nor can he repel death.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 454.] ; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 733

Verse: It is surprising to see an arrogant and proud person who yesterday was but a sperm and tomorrow will be but a carcass
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 328, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 734

Verse: The bane of [noble] lineage is pride of it.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 329, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 734

Verse: When the Prophet (SAWA) would mention a merit of himself, he would say, 'And with no pride'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 16, p. 341, no. 33; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 734

Verse: The Commander of the Faithful [ Imam Ali (AS)] visited Sa`asa`aa b. Suhan when he was sick, so when he wanted to leave he stood up and said, 'O Sa`asa`aa, do not display pride in front of your brothers that I visited you, and fear Allah
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 12, p. 90, no. 13599; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 734

Verse: Poverty is my pride.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 30, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 734

Verse: He whose manners deviate, recite the adhan in his ear.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 104, p. 122, no. 61; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 167

Verse: There are three things that are the pride of a believer and his ornament in this world and the Hereafter: prayer at the end of the night [night vigil], his despair of [possessing] that which others own, and his allegiance to the Imam from the progeny of Muhammad (SAWA).
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 234, no. 311; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 735

Verse: O Abu Dharr, beware of procrastinating with your [high] hopes, for verily you have today [at your disposal] and have not yet reached tomorrow. When tomorrow comes to you, then be in it as you are in the present; [that way] even if you do not have tomorrow, you will not have regret for all that you neglected today
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 75, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 735

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) said in a letter he wrote to one of his companions, 'Seize what you have left of your life, and do not keep [deferring] saying, 'Tomorrow, and the day after tomorrow', for verily those before you were ruined because of their persistent wishful thinking and their procrastination, until suddenly the command of Allah [i.e. death] overtook them while they were heedless
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 75, no. 39; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 735

Verse: He whom death overtakes early calls for more time, and he whose death is deferred continues to put forth excuses with further procrastination
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 285; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 735

Verse: Do not be like one who hopes for [bliss in] the Hereafter without performance of good deeds, and delays repentance by holding high hopes [of being forgiven]   when faced with a desire, he is quick to commit a sin but delays the repentance
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 150; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 736

Verse: And help me [by allowing me to] weep on account of my self, for indeed I have wasted my life away with procrastination and high hopes, and I have now stooped to the level of those who despair of any good to come
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 98, p. 88, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 736

Verse: Beware of procrastination for verily it is the sea in which losers drown
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 164, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 736

Verse: Delaying repentance is an act of self-delusion, and lengthy procrastination is an act of bewilderment
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 365, no. 97; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 736

Verse: It is narrated in al-Khisal that whenever the Prophet (SAWA) looked at a man who pleased him, he used to ask, 'Does he have a profession?' If they said, 'No', he would say, 'He has lost his worth in my eye.' They would then ask, 'O Messenger of Allah! Why is that?!' He would reply, 'Because when the believer has no profession, he subsists off his religion.'
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 390, no. 1084; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 737

Verse: Undertake yourselves to trading, for there lies therein your independence from what others possess, and verily Allah, Mighty and Exalted, loves the trustworthy servant who is engaged in a profession
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 621, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 737

Verse: Your desire for the impossible is ignorance.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5384; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 425

Verse: It(Ignorance) is hastening to snatch up an opportunity before having made oneself capable [of fulfilling it], and it is to refuse to answer.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 401, no. 62; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 425

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) once asked one of his companions about his means of income. He said, 'May I be your ransom. I have given up trading.' Imam asked why, and he answered, 'I am waiting for this rule [i.e. the reign of your government].' Imam said, 'That is strange from you. Your wealth will perish. Do not abandon trading, and seek out the bounty of Allah. Open your door and exhibit your goods, and seek out the sustenance of your Lord.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 13, p. 10, no. 14578; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 737

Verse: If you wish for noble traits, then avoid the prohibited things.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4069; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 737

Verse: One of the best noble traits is the avoidance of prohibited things.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9382; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 737

Verse: Even if Allah, glory be to Him, had not forbidden that which He has prohibited, it would have been mandatory for the one possessing intellect to avoid them [at least].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7595; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 738

Verse: Worship alongside consumption of the prohibited is like erecting a building on sand or on water [according to other narrations].
VerseRef: Uddat al-Da`ai, p. 141; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 738

Verse: He whose intellect is weak has bad oratory.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7985; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 475

Verse: Evidence of lack of intellect is keeping company with ignorant people.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9299; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 476

Verse: Overly high aspirations are a result of a corrupt intellect.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7093; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 476

Verse: The fruit of the intellect is steadfastness.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4589; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 476

Verse: The fruit of the intellect is adherence to the truth.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4602; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 476

Verse: The fruit of the intellect is contempt for this worldly life and repression of one' s whims.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4654; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 476

Verse: The intellect is a tree the fruit of which is generosity and modesty.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1254; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 476

Verse: The caprice is the intellect' s adversary.
VerseRef: Masalib al-Sa' ul, p. 56; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 476

Verse: Many a slavish mind is subservient to an overpowering caprice!
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, no. 211; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 477

Verse: Allah has imposed   the abandonment of drinking alcohol in order to safeguard the intellect.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 252; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 477

Verse: Know that entertaining high hopes distracts the intellect and causes one to forget their remembrance [of Allah].
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 86; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 477

Verse: The caprice is awake while the intellect is asleep.'[al-Durrah al-Bahirah, p
VerseRef: al-Durrah al-Bahirah, p. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 477

Verse: When I stand at the Glorious Station, I will intercede on behalf of those of my community who have perpetrated grave sins, and Allah will accept my intercession for them. By Allah, I will not intercede for anyone who hurts my progeny.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 242, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 478

Verse: Every prophet was given the right to a special request which they asked [from Allah], but I suppressed my request in return for the permission to intercede for my community on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 29, no. 103; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 478

Verse: Imam Muhammad ibn 'Ali al-Baqir (a.s.) said with regards to Allah's verse in the Qur'an [addressing the Prophet (SAWA)]: "Soon your Lord will give you [that with which] you will be pleased"[ Qur'an 93:5], '(This is) intercession, by Allah it is intercession, by Allah it is intercession.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 8, p. 57, no. 72; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 479

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said with regards to Allah's verse in the Qur'an: "No one will have the power to intercede [with Allah], except for him who has taken a covenant with the All-beneficent", '[This means] except for him who has been allowed intercession through his acceptance of the guardianship of the Commander of the Faithful, Ali (AS) and the Imams after him, as this is the covenant with Allah.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 36, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 479

Verse: Two types of people will not be included in my intercession: the tyrannical and iniquitous ruler and the heretical extremist in matters of religion.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 63, no. 93; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 479

Verse: My intercession is intended for those who have committed grave sins [from among the Muslims], except for those guilty of polytheism and injustice to others.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 355, no. 36; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 479

Verse: He who does not take his daily prayers seriously will neither benefit from my intercession nor meet me at the Heavenly Pool [of Kawthar], no by Allah
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 159, no. 323; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 479

Verse: My intercession on behalf of one who does not believe in my intercession will not be accepted by Allah.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 1, p. 136, no. 35; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 480

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.), when he asked for his relatives to be gathered around him as his death approached, said to them, 'Verily our intercession will not avail one who takes his prayer lightly.'
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 159, no. 225; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 480

Verse: Even if the most favoured angels and all the prophets were to intercede for a Nasibi*, their intercession would not be accepted.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, p. 294, no. 587; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 480

Verse: When they break a covenant, Allah allows their enemy to gain mastery over them.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 100, p. 46, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 226

Verse: He who does not keep a promise has no religion.
VerseRef: Nawadir al-R`awandi, p. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 226

Verse: Agression removes [Allah's] favor.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 382; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 87

Verse: Agression brings about destruction.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 795; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 88

Verse: A man called Abu Ayman once came to Imam al-Baqir (AS) saying, 'O Abu Ja`afar, you delude people by saying, 'Muhammad's intercession [will help you], Muhammad's intercession!' At this, the Imam (AS) got so angry that his face was glowering, and said, 'Woe betide you Abu Ayman! If your belly and your private parts keep you away from sin, does that mean they delude you? You would only have to see the atrocities of the Day of Resurrection to need Muhammad (SAWA)'s intercession. Woe unto you! In any case, do you think that he will only intercede for those whose punishment in the Fire is obligatory?!' Then he continued, saying, 'Every single person, from the first to the last, will need the intercession of Muhammad (SAWA) on the Day of Resurrection.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 8, p. 38, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 480

Verse: Three types of people have the right to intercede with Allah, and their intercession will be accepted: the prophets, then the scholars, and then the martyrs.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 156, no. 197; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 481

Verse: [The right of] Intercession belongs to the prophets, their vicegerents, the believers and the angels.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 8, p. 58, no. 75; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 481

Verse: The sights do not apprehend Him " said, 'The hearts' fancies cannot apprehend Him so how can the eyesights apprehend Him?!
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 334, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 447

Verse: Verily Allah, Blessed and most High, displayed to His Prophet in his heart, whatever He liked from the light of His Greatness.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 95, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 447

Verse: Praise be to Allah, the First before every first, and the Last after every last, and His Firstness necessitates that there is no beginning to Him, and His Lastness necessitates that there is no end to Him.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 101; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 447

Verse: He never ceases to exist and will always be, the First before all things without a beginning, and the Last after all things without an end.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 448

Verse: was once asked by a Jew, 'When did our Lord, Mighty and Exalted, come to be?', to which he replied, 'O Jew, It is not that our Lord was not and then came to be, for the question 'When did x come to be?' is posed regarding something that is not there and then comes to be. He exists without coming into being; He is ever existing having nothing before Him. He is before 'before' itself, before any limit. Limits do not apply to Him for He is the ultimate limit of all limits.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 331, no. 18; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 448

Verse: Verily Allah, Blessed and most High, existed when nothing else did, He is light not darkness, truthful with no falsehood about Him, all-knowing with no ignorance about Him, ever-living with no death about Him, and He is such today, and thus will He remain forever.'
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 141, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 448

Verse: Verily Allah is all knowledge with no ignorance about Him, He is all Life without any death around Him, and all Light with no darkness about Him.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 137, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 448

Verse: Allah is Omnipresent without any external source of life   rather He lives through Himself.'
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 142, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 448

Verse: The number of droplets of water, or of stars in the sky, or of gusts of wind in the air are not unknown to Him, and neither is the crawling of ants on rocks, nor the settling place of tiny particles in the darkness of the night. He knows the spots where leaves fall and the subtle movement of the pupils of the eyes.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 178; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 449

Verse: He knows the howls of beasts in the forests, the sins of the people committed in secret, the fish's frequenting the deep seas and the rising of the waters by tempestuous winds.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 198; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 449

Verse: His knowledge pierces through the inside of unknown secrets and encompasses the innermost beliefs of the hearts.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 108; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 449

Verse: He always knows what is to be, such that His knowledge of it before its coming into being is the same as His knowledge after its coming into being.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 107, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 449

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) was once asked about Allah's knowledge of space [i.e. the concept] and whether He knows it before its coming into existence or during it or after it, to which he replied, 'Most High is Allah! He always knows space before its conception just as He knows it after He has created it, and such is His knowledge of all things like His knowledge of space.'
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 137, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 449

Verse: Knowledge is His very essence and not the object of knowing [or a known], such that when He created things, knowledge projected from Him onto the known things.
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 5, p. 237, no. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 450

Verse: The knowledge of Allah cannot be defined by where, nor can Allah's knowledge be described by how. Allah's knowledge cannot be separated from Him, nor can Allah be distinguished from it, and there is no barrier between Allah and His knowledge.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 138, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 450

Verse: And I bear witness that He is just and acts justly, and is an arbitrator who decides fairly.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 214; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 450

Verse: [Faith in] divine justice is that you do not accuse Him of anything.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 470; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 450

Verse: But I know that there is no wrong in Your decree and no hurry in Your vengeance. He alone hurries who fears to miss, and only the weak needs to wrong. But You are exalted, my God, high indeed above all that!
VerseRef: al-Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya, p. 297, Supplication 48; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 450

Verse: [It is faith in] Allah's divine Unity and divine Justice   [Faith in] Allah's divine Unity is that you do not deem applicable to your Lord that which applies to you, and [faith in] His divine Justice is that you do not attribute to Him that of which you are blameworthy.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 96, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 451

Verse: Marwan b. Muslim narrated: 'Ibn Abi al-`Aawja' once came to Abu `Aabdillah (AS) [i.e. Imam al-Sadiq], and asked, 'Is it not true that you claim that Allah is the Creator of all things?' to which Abu `Aabdillah (AS) replied, 'Yes.' So he retorted, 'I create!' So Imam asked him, 'How do you create?!' He replied, 'I defecate in a place, then wait for it, and it becomes a creature, which I have created!' So Abu `Aabdillah (AS) said, 'Is it not true that the creator of something should know what he has created?' to which he replied yes. Imam continued, 'Well do you know the female from the male [of what you have supposedly created], and do you know its lifespan?' to which he had no answer.'
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 295, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 451

Verse: The Originator of all things from their conception, and their Inventor from the very beginning with His Power and Wisdom, [He creates] not from anything otherwise the very concept of invention would be nullified, nor for any cause otherwise the very concept of origination would be inapplicable. He creates whatever He pleases however He pleases.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 98, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 451

Verse: Verily Allah, Mighty and Exalted, cannot be attributed with incapacity, but that which you are asking cannot ever be.
VerseRef: Mishkat al-Anwar, p. 259; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 452

Verse: Woe betide you! Verily Allah can never be ascribed with incapacity, and who is there more powerful than the One who can shrink the earth and enlarge the egg [if He so wills]?!
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 127, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 452

Verse: Pray in congregation, even if you have to stand on an arrowhead [to do so].
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 126, no. 1348; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 725

Verse: Nothing is truer than death
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10648; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 730

Verse: What a good remedy death is!
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9905; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 730

Verse: Ignorance lies in three things: in compromising one's brothers, declaring war without the command to do so, and spying into affairs that do not concern one.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 317; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 425

Verse: Ignorance is to laugh without any reason.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 487; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 425

Verse: People are antagonists of what they are ignorant of.
VerseRef: Masalib al-Sa' ul, no. 57; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 426

Verse: He who is ignorant of something finds fault with it.
VerseRef: Kashf al-Ghamma, v. 3, p. 137; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 426

Verse: I have said four things which Allah has verified with verses He has revealed in His Book   I said: 'He who is ignorant of something will oppose it', and He revealed: "Rather, they deny that whose knowledge they do not comprehend" Qur'an 10:39
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 426

Verse: Avoid agression, for it expedites death and makes of its doer a lesson to others.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2657; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 88

Verse: My father used to say, 'When you think of doing something good, rush to do it immediately for verily you do not know what could happen later [to prevent you from doing it].
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 142, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 399

Verse: Beware of the Fire whose din is ready, whose flames are fierce, and whose pain is ever fresh.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2620; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 400

Verse: The Fire whose rage is fierce, its din is high, its flame is glowing, its blaze is stirring up, its exhalation is furious, its extinction is remote, its fuel is blazing, and its threat is fearful.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, 9995; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 400

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said, relating what Gabriel (AS) once said to the Prophet (SAWA), 'If only one link of the chain whose length is seventy cubits was to be tied down on this world, the world would melt by its heat.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 8, p. 280, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 400

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) relating what Gabriel (AS) said to the Prophet (SAWA), 'If only one garment from among the garments of the people of the Fire was to be hung between the sky and the earth, the people of this world would die of its smell.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 533, no. 1162; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 400

Verse: If a bucket of the pus [of Hell] was to be poured where the sun rises, the skulls of the people living where it sets would boil.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 8, p. 280, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 401

Verse: Beware of going to extremes with respect to us. Instead take us as servants that have been endeared [by Allah], and say whatever you wish about our virtues.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 614, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 281

Verse: Be on your guard that the extremists do not corrupt your youth, for verily the extremists are the most evil of Allah's creation for they belittle the Greatness of Allah, and falsely attribute divinity to the servants of Allah. By Allah, verily the extremists are worse than the Jews, the Christians, the Magians, and the polytheists. The extremist may return to us but we do not accept him again, whereas we do accept the negligent one when he tries to adhere to us. At this, he was asked, 'How can that be O son of the Prophet (SAWA)?' to which he replied, 'Because the extremist has become accustomed to abandoning the prayer, the alms-tax, fasting, the pilgrimage, and cannot give up his habit and return to Allah's obedience ever again, whereas the negligent one, when he attains inner knowledge, begins to act and carry out acts of obedience.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 650, no. 1349; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 281

Verse: A group of people once came to the Commander of the Faithful Ali (AS) saying, 'Peace be upon you O our Lord!' so he asked them to repent to Allah for what they had said, but they refused to repent, so he dug a hole and lit a fire therein, and dug a second hole around it, leaving a space between them. So when they refused to repent, he flung them in the hole, and ignited a fire in the second hole, so that they would die.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 7, p. 259, no. 18; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 282

Verse: The bane of hope is the arrival of death
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3959; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 137

Verse: The bane of loyalty is betrayal.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3960; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 137

Verse: The bane of resolve is the passage of opportunity.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3961; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 137

Verse: Abu Basir narrated, 'I told Abu `Aabdillah [i.e. Imam al-Sadiq (AS)]: 'Verily they are saying things [about you]!' He asked, 'What are they saying?' to which I replied, '[They are saying], 'He knows the number of drops of rain, the number of stars and the leaves on the trees, and the weight of all that is in the sea, and the number of grains of sand.' So he raised his hands to the sky, saying, 'Glory be to Allah, Glory be to Allah. No, by Allah, no one knows this except Allah.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 25, p. 294, no. 52; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 282

Verse: The extremists are disbelievers and the mufawwiza are polytheists.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 25, p. 273, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 282

Verse: Whoever exceeds the bounds [of their love] for the Commander of the Faithful Ali (AS) into worship [of him] is indeed among those who incur Allah's wrath and are astray.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 25, p. 274, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 282

Verse: Faith is to attest and to act, whereas Islam is to attest without action.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 297; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 283

Verse: Verily faith is that which is embedded in the hearts, whereas Islam is the means by which marriages, inheritances and safeguarding blood take place.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 26, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 283

Verse: Faith is not [acquired] through embellishment or wishing. Rather faith is that which is pure in the heart and is certified by actions.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 69, p. 72, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 283

Verse: Faith is sincerity of action.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 873; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 284

Verse: Faith is patience during calamity, and thanksgiving during ease
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1350; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 284

Verse: The fountainhead of faith is honesty.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5222; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 285

Verse: A servant's faith is not true until his confidence in that which rests in Allah's Hand is more than that which rests in his own hands.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 37, no. 79; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 285

Verse: Verily the reality of faith is for you to prefer right, even if it is to your detriment, over wrong, even if it is to your benefit.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 106, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 285

Verse: If faith was a mere statement, then fasting, prayers, the lawful and the unlawful things would not have been prescribed for it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 69, p. 19, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 286

Verse: Faith is all action, and the statement is but part of the action that Allah has made mandatory, which He has explained in His Book.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 38, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 286

Verse: Imam Mosa ibn Ja'far al-Kazim (a.s.) when asked about the grave sins and whether they expel one from faith?', replied, 'Yes.' [And when asked about other than grave sins], said, 'The Prophet (SAWA) said, 'An adulterer would never commit adultery whilst still a believer and a thief would never steal whilst still a believer.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 69, p. 63, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 287

Verse: The bane of trust is treachery.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3962; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 137

Verse: The ruin of the jurists is lack of piety
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3963; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 137

Verse: A servant's faith in Allah is not complete until he has five attributes in him: complete reliance upon Allah, entrusting [his affairs] to Allah, submission to Allah's will, contentment with Allah's decree, and patience in Allah's tribulations. Certainly one who loves for the sake of Allah, hates for the sake of Allah, gives for the sake of Allah, and withholds for the sake of Allah has in fact completed faith.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 10, p. 177, no. 77; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 288

Verse: The most perfect in faith from among you is the one with the best character.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 387, no. 34; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 288

Verse: Three attributes, when present in an individual, complete his faith: intellect, clemency and knowledge.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4658; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 288

Verse: A servant's faith is not complete until he loves one whom Allah, the Glorious, loves and hates one whom Allah, the Glorious, hates.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10849; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 288

Verse: A servant cannot attain the reality of faith until there exist in him three attributes: learning the religion, good [i.e. economical] assessment of his living expenses, and patience in sufferings.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 239, no. 78; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 289

Verse: The best of faith is excellent conviction.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2992; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 290

Verse: Certainly faith is ten levels, like the rungs of a ladder, where each rung is climbed one after the other. The one on the second rung cannot say to the one on the first: 'You are nothing' until he completes the ten. Therefore do not knock the one below you down, lest the one above you knocks you down. And when you see one below you in rank, lift him up to your level with gentleness. And do not burden him with that which he cannot bear lest you break him, for verily one who breaks a believer must put him back together again.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 45, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 290

Verse: Certainly Allah has divided faith into seven parts: goodness, honesty, conviction, contentedness, loyalty, knowledge and clemency.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 42, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 290

Verse: Faith is in ten things: inner knowledge, obedience, knowledge, action, piety, striving, patience, conviction, contentedness and submission. And if the individual lacks any one of them, it nullifies the whole structure of his faith.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 69, p. 175, no. 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 291

Verse: Faith rests on four pillars: reliance upon Allah, entrusting one's affairs to Allah, submission to the will of Allah, and contentment with Allah's decree.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 63, no. 154; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 291

Verse: By the cancellation of firm intention and the thwarting of ambition, I made a firm intention and it got cancelled, and I had ambition and it was thwarted.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 289, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 238

Verse: The bane of liberality is squandering.'
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3964; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 137

Verse: The ruin of livelihood is lack of prudence [in spending].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3965; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 137

Verse: The bane of speech is lengthy elaboration.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3966; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 138

Verse: The bane of wealth is miserliness.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3969; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 138

Verse: was asked by Mufazzal, 'O my master, there is a group of people that claim that this [creation] is the doing of nature [itself]', the Imam (AS) said, 'Ask them about this nature, does it have knowledge and power to carry out such actions [as creation] or not? For if they answer that it has knowledge and power, then what is preventing them from acknowledging the existence of a creator?   for verily this is His creation. If they claim that nature does these actions without knowledge or without purpose while having witnessed the exactness and wisdom therein, it is [obviously] known that this is the work of a very wise creator, and what they have called 'nature' is the very system running through creation.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 3, p. 67; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 238

Verse: Beware of debt for verily it is a source of anxiety in the night and a source of disgrace during the day.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 141, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 239

Verse: Copious debts transform the truthful man into a liar and an achiever into one who is unreliable.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7105; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 239

Verse: Lighten your debts, for verily with little debt comes longer life.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 145, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 239

Verse: One who seeks to gain sustenance for himself and his family in a lawful manner is as the one who fights in the way of Allah. But if he is unable to do so he may incur debt, trusting in Allah and His Prophet, in order to ensure provisions for his family.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 93, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 239

Verse: There are certain types of people whose supplications are not answered. From among them is the man who lends money to someone for a specified time and neither writes it down nor has anyone witness it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 104, p. 301, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 240

Verse: Whoever postpones repaying someone their right while he is capable of doing has the sin of an extortionist written down for him as every day passes by.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 146, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 240

Verse: A wealthy man's postponement [in repayment of a debt] is oppression.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 13, p. 397, no. 15713; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 240

Verse: The most miserly person with regards to his wealth is the most liberal in squandering away his reputation.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3190; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 240

Verse: Blessed be the one whom the assassins of delusion have not killed.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5973; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 240

Verse: The intoxication of heedlessness and delusion are harder to resume consciousness from than the intoxication of wines.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5651; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 240

Verse: The one whom a mirage deludes is at his wit' s end.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9224; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 241

Verse: Between you and the moral exhortation is a veil of inadvertency.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, no. 282; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 241

Verse: Many a deluded and captivated man [by his own desires] awakes in the morning oblivious and joyful, eating and drinking, unaware that perhaps Allah' s wrath has already befallen him for something and as a result of which he will enter the Fire of Hell.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 282; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 241

Verse: He who places his trust in three things is indeed deluded he who believes in the impossible, relies on someone who cannot be trusted, and avidly desires that which he does not possess.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 319; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 241

Verse: O Ibn Mas`aud, do not be under any delusion about Allah, and do not be under any delusion with respect to your righteousness, your knowledge, your deeds, your goodness or your worship.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 350, no. 2660; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 241

Verse: Verily part of keeping oneself immune from sins is that you do not delude yourself about Allah.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, p. 150; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 242

Verse: Verily being under a delusion about Allah is when the servant persists in committing acts of disobedience and expects Allah to forgive him.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 72; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 242

Verse: Many a person is given respite by Allah simply as a result of His good favour towards him, and many a person is deluded as a result of Allah' s concealment of his sins, and many a person is captivated by the good things said about him!
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 116; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 242

Verse: Be wary of this world' s delusion, for verily it always reclaims the charms and attractions with which it deceives people, and it troubles the one who adopts it as a place of tranquillity and a permanent dwelling.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2562; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 242

Verse: The soul's trust in this world is one of the greatest delusions
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5650; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 242

Verse: Your own sense of honour has deluded you, such that your resulting slackness has become a source of disgrace for you. So fear the indecent acts that you commit, for perhaps through that you will be guided.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 83, no. 86; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 243

Verse: He who is ignorant deludes himself, and his present is consequently worse than his past.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8744; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 243

Verse: Before Prophet Noah (AS), they [mankind] were a single community upon the fitra [The special origination or innate nature deposited in man by Allah which calls him to his Creator (ed.)] of Allah, neither guided nor in error, thereafter Allah sent the prophets.
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 1, p. 209, no. 784; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 243

Verse: Stay with the greater majority, for verily Allah's hand is with the [larger] group. Beware of separation for verily the deviant amongst you is the victim of Satan just as the deviant amongst the cattle is the victim of a wolf.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 127; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 244

Verse: By Allah, verily I believe that this community of yours will turn around and change, by congregating upon their falsehood and you having to separate through your truth.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 25; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 244

Verse: The first people to enter Paradise will be those who performed acts of common courtesy to others.
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 108, no. 240; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 201

Verse: The bane of hope is death.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3970; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 138

Verse: The bane of goodness is a corrupt companion.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3971; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 138

Verse: The people who perform acts of courtesy in this world will be the same ones to perform them in the Hereafter, for verily in the Hereafter their scales will be so laden with their good deeds that they will be able to bestow them generously on the sinners [in order to assist them].
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 304, no. 610; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 201

Verse: People who perform acts of courtesy towards others benefit more from them than the receptors of their kindness, for verily they have the reward for them, the [rewarding feeling of] pride for having helped someone as well as a mention. So however much good a man may do for others, it ultimately always starts by benefiting himself, such that he never seeks thanks for the benefit incurred by himself through helping others.'
VerseRef: Kashf al-Ghamma, v. 3, p. 137]; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 201

Verse: The peak of good reason after religious devotion is treating people with love, and doing good to both good and bad people.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 401, no. 44; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 201

Verse: Perform acts of courtesy to those who are worthy of them as well as those who are not worthy of them, and even if they have no effect on those who deserve them, you are at least worthy of [performing] them.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 35, no. 76; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 201

Verse: He who offers charity to a poor man gets the reward befitting the action, but if forty thousand people pass the same offering from hand to hand until it reaches the poor man, they all receive a complete reward for it.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 342, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 202

Verse: If an act of charity [or courtesy] goes through eighty changes of hands, all of them receive the reward for it, without any decrease in the reward of the initiating good-doer.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 18, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 202

Verse: Give life to your act of courtesy by killing it [i.e. by killing your expectation of receiving anything in return].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2282; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 202

Verse: If an act of courtesy is done unto you, then be sure to remember it, and if you do an act of courtesy unto someone else, then be sure to forget it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, nos. 4000-4001; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 202

Verse: The yardstick [used to measure the goodness] of an act of courtesy is the absence of expectation accompanying it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9724; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 202

Verse: Bringing a good act to completion is better than [merely] initiating it.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 596, no. 1235; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 203

Verse: One who does not sustain his good action loses it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9115; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 203

Verse: A good turn done to a fellow believer is not considered complete until accompanied by three things: underestimation of the act, concealing it, and hastening its completion. He who underestimates his good turn to a fellow believer has esteemed his brother highly indeed, whereas he who esteems his good turn to be great has deemed his brother to be insignificant. He who conceals the good turn that he has done has honored his action, and he who hastens to fulfill his promise takes pleasure in the gift too.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 403; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 203

Verse: A servant [of Allah] entered Paradise because of a thorn branch that he removed from the path of fellow Muslims.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, v. 32, p. 111; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 204

Verse: He who builds a structure on the road affording shelter to a traveller, All?ah will raise him on the Day of Resurrection mounted on a fine-bred camel made of pearls, and his face will radiate light for all the dwellers of Paradise.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 343, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 205

Verse: He who averts an impediment of water or fire from a group of Muslims becomes deserving of obligatory entrance into Paradise.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 55, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 205

Verse: I have witnessed the act of common courtesy to be exactly as its name suggests, and nothing excels the act of common courtesy than its own reward.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 1, p. 294, no. 915; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 205

Verse: Have mercy and you will be had mercy upon.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 174, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 206

Verse: How I wonder at the one who hopes for the mercy of the One above him and yet himself does not have mercy on the one below him.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6255; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 206

Verse: Be compassionate towards a mighty person who has been dishonoured, a rich man who has become poor, and a scholar who has been forgotten amidst a generation of ignorant people.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 405, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 206

Verse: Show compassion to the young in your family and reverence to the old.
VerseRef: Amali al-Mufid, p. 222, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 206

Verse: Prophet al Khizr (a.s) in his advice to Prophet Musa (A.S.) said, 'O son of `AImran, do not ever condemn somebody for a mistake, and cry over your own mistake [instead].'
VerseRef: Qasas al-Anbiya' li al-Rawandi, p. 157, no. 171; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 207

Verse: Whoever alleviates a fellow believer's anguish, Allah will alleviate him of the anguish of the Hereafter, and will bring him out of his grave with a light heart.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 199, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 396

Verse: When Allah will raise the believer out of his grave, another presence will also come out with him and walk ahead of him, and whenever the believer will come across one of the terrors of the Day of Resurrection, the presence will console him saying, 'Do not worry or be saddened ' and the believer will ask, 'Who are you?, at which it will reply, 'I am the happiness that you used to bring upon your fellow believer.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 190, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 396

Verse: Whoever alleviates a believer's worries, Allah will alleviate his heart on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 200, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 396

Verse: Abstain from harming others for this is your charity towards yourself.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 54, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 397

Verse: A man who keeps his hand from harming people is keeping one hand from [harming] them, whilst they would keep many hands from [harming] him [as a result].
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 17, no. 60; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 397

Verse: By Allah, the righteous have won indeed! Do you know who they are? They are the ones who do not even harm the dust.
VerseRef: Tafsir al-Qummi, v. 2, p. 146; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 397

Verse: Allah, Mighty and Exalted, said, 'Let a man who harms a believing servant of Mine expect a war waged by Me'.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 350, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 397

Verse: There is no good in determination without a firm resolution
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10682; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 752

Verse: Prudence is careful consideration of the consequences and consultation of people of reason
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1915; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 752

Verse: The essence of prudence is stopping in the face of the dubious
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 214; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 752

Verse: Feeling certainty and quietude before experience is against prudence
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1514; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 753

Verse: The prudent one is he who is not preoccupied by the delusion of this world from working for his Hereafter
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1984; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 753

Verse: The prudent one is he who is selective in his friendships, for man is judged according to his friend.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2026; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 753

Verse: The prudent one is he whose prosperity does not stop him from working towards the end goal
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1878; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 753

Verse: The prudent one is he who puts off punishment when anger prevails, and hastens to reward the good, taking the first possible opportunity to do so.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2179; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 753

Verse: The most prudent of people is he who is best at controlling his rage
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 28, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 753

Verse: The most sagacious one from among you is he who remembers death the most, and the most prudent one from among you is he who is the most prepared for it
VerseRef: alam al-Din, no. 333; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 754

Verse: The most prudent one from among you is the one who is most abstemious
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2832; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 754

Verse: By Allah! I fear for you the barzakh!' He was asked, 'What is the barzakh?' He replied, 'The grave, from the day one dies until the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 3, p. 554, no. 124; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 754

Verse: The souls of the believers will be in chambers in Paradise, eating of its food and drinking its drinks, and visiting one another, saying, 'Our Lord! Bring the Final Hour, so that You may fulfil what You promised us
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 258, no. 562; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 754

Verse: The souls of disbelievers are in the Fire of Hell, exposed to it, saying, 'Our Lord! Delay the Final Hour, and do not fulfil what You warned us against, nor make the last of us catch up with the first
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 6, p. 270, no. 127; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 755

Verse: Allah has created water to be a purifier where nothing can make it impure, except for that water whose colour, taste or smell has changed.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 1, p. 101, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 756

Verse: Everything that the sun shines on becomes purified.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 2, p. 1043, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 756

Verse: Allah   exalted be His remembrance   has not obligated anything more difficult for this community than paying the alms-tax, and the downfall of the majority of people lies in [their failure to pay] it.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 693, no. 1474; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 97

Verse: The prayer of one who does not give the alms-tax is void, and the alms-tax of the impious is void.
VerseRef: Mishkat al-Anwar, no. 46; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 97

Verse: The alms-tax has been prescribed as a test for the rich and an aid to the poor. If people duly paid the alms-tax on their wealth, there would not remain a single poor or needy Muslim, and all would suffice themselves through what Allah has prescribed. Verily people are only impoverished, needy, hungry and naked as a result of the sins of the wealthy.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 2, p. 7, no. 1579; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 97

Verse: If you want Allah to enrich your wealth then give the alms-tax from it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 96, p. 23, no. 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 98

Verse: Strengthen your capital by paying the alms-tax
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 60, no. 138; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 98

Verse: The giving of the alms-tax never diminishes wealth.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 96, p. 23, no. 56; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 98

Verse: We found the following written in the book of the Prophet (SAWA):  When the alms-tax is withheld, the earth withholds all its yield of plants, fruits and minerals.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 374, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 98

Verse: Verily Allah has fixed the alms-tax as a provision for the poor and a proliferation of your wealth.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 498, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 98

Verse: When the alms-tax is not paid, livestock die as a result.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 373, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 98

Verse: He who refuses to pay the alms-tax, on the Day of Resurrection Allah will transform his wealth into a cobra with two venom glands that will coil itself around him and be told, 'Tighten your grip on him just as he was tight-fisted with you in the world.' This is in accordance with Allah's verse in the Qur'an: "They will be collared with what they grudge " Qur'an 3:180
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 99

Verse: Those who refuse to pay the alms-tax ask to be returned to the world at the time of death, as per Allah's verse in the Qur'an: "When death comes to one of them, he says, 'My Lord! Take me back, that I may act righteously in what I have left behind" Qur'an 23:99
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 99

Verse: There are three types of people that are considered thieves: the one who refuses to pay the alms-tax, the one who spends his wife's dowry unlawfully, and the one who takes a loan with no intention to repay it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 12, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 99

Verse: He who refuses to pay [as meagre an amount as] a sixteen of a dirham in alms-tax may as well die a Jew or a Christian.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 281, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 99

Verse: with regards to Allah's verse in the Qur'an: "Charities are only for the poor...", said, 'The poor man is he who does not beg from people [despite his poverty], the destitute lives in even harsher conditions than him, and the wretched one lives in the most straitened circumstances of all.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 501, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 99

Verse: Whoever keeps his hair long should care for it well, otherwise, he must cut it.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 1, p. 432, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 141

Verse: Beauty is in the tongue.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 37; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 142

Verse: There is no beauty better than the intellect.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Sa`ada, v. 1, p. 51; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 142

Verse: There is no clothing more beautiful than good health.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 381, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 142

Verse: Allah, the Exalted, placed the beauty of woman in her face and of man in his speech.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 293, no. 63; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 142

Verse: Physical beauty is the outer beauty, and the beauty of the intellect is inner beauty.
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, no. 313; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 142

Verse: Do not betray the one who betrays you lest you be like him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 175, no. 3] ; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 142

Verse: The one who betrays his trust is not from us.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 172, no. 14] ; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 143

Verse: Betrayal is the fountainhead of hypocrisy.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 969; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 143

Verse: The believer is naturally disposed to all the traits except betrayal and lying.
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, p. 231; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 143

Verse: Mu'awiyah b. `Ammar narrated, 'I asked Imam al-Sadiq (AS), 'If I entrust some money with a man and he denies that I entrusted him with anything, and then he [in the future] entrusts me with money, can I keep that money [to make up for the money that he took from me]? Imam al-Sadiq (AS) replied, 'No, that is betrayal.
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 2, p. 144, no. 68; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 143

Verse: Abu Thumama narrated: 'I came to Imam al-Sadiq (AS) and said to him, 'May I be your ransom! I am a man who wishes to go to Makkah but I have an overdue debt so can you please advise me?' The Imam (AS) replied, 'Pay your debt and focus on meeting your Lord without any debt on your shoulders, for verily a believer does not betray [his trust].'
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 528, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 143

Verse: Disclosing the secret of your brother is betrayal, so keep away from that.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 89, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 144

Verse: As for the signs of the betrayer, there are four: disobedience to the All-Beneficent, disturbance to neighbours, loathing his associates, and being close to tyranny and oppression
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 144

Verse: The betrayer is the one who busies himself with [the affairs of] others and his today is worse than his yesterday.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2013; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 144

Verse: Whoever from among our companions seeks assistance from one of his brothers, who does not exercise his full efforts [in trying to help him], then he has betrayed Allah and His messenger and the believers.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 175, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 144

Verse: It is sufficient for someone to be classified as a betrayer if he is the trustee of a disloyal person.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 364, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 144

Verse: Allah repels [corruption] from those of our followers who do not pray, with those of our followers who do pray, and if they were to all agree to not pray, they would be destroyed. And verily Allah repels [corruption] from those of our followers who do not pay the alms-tax with those of our followers who do pay the alms-tax. And this is the purport of Allah's verse in the Qur'an: "Were it not for Allah's repelling the people by means of one another, the earth would surely have been corrupted." [Qur`an 2:251]
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 451, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 220

Verse: Seeking to consult someone [in one's affairs] is guidance in itself, and the one who suffices himself with his own opinion endangers himself.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 211; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 220

Verse: There is no better support than good counsel.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying no. 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 220

Verse: Seeking counsel has been highly emphasised because the opinion of the counselor is unadulterated whereas the opinion of the one seeking counsel is polluted with his own whims.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3908; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 220

Verse: O Ali, do not seek counsel from a coward for verily he will confine the way out for you, nor from the miser for verily he will hold you back from your goal, and nor from the covetous one for verily he will make greediness fair-seeming to you.
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 559, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 221

Verse: Do not seek counsel from a liar for verily he is like a mirage   he makes that which is far appear near, and he makes that which is near appear far.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10351; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 221

Verse: Counsel should only be sought whilst fulfilling its four terms. Firstly that the one whose counsel you seek must be a man of intellect. Secondly that he must be a free and religious man. Thirdly, he must be brotherly and friendly, and fourthly that when you disclose your secret to him whereby he knows as much about it as you do, he would keep your secret and guard it well.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 98, no. 2280; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 221

Verse: The right of the one who seeks your counsel is that you point him in the right direction if you know that he is inclined towards a certain opinion, and if you do not know [which way to point out], then you must guide him to someone who does
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 570, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 222

Verse: Whoever seeks counsel from a fellow brother who refuses to advise him with even an opinion either way, Allah wrests him of his opinion.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 438, no. 2521; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 222

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) said in a letter that he wrote to Muawiya, ' rather counsel is confined to the muhajirun and the ansar [muhajirun   early Muslims who migrated from Mecca to Medina with the Prophet (ed.) ansar   Medinan Muslims who helped the Meccan Muslim migrants settle in Medina (ed.) ]. If they agree on an individual and take him to be their leader, it will be deemed to mean Allah's pleasure.'
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 222

Verse: Do not desist from speaking the truth, nor from offering your counsel with fairness, for verily I do not regard myself above erring, nor do I consider myself immune from erring in my actions. It is only that Allah makes up for my shortcomings and helps me avoid errors in all these matters wherein He is more powerful than I.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 216; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 222

Verse: Muawiya b. Abi Sufyan has no right to delegate anybody after him to power. Rather the matter will be for the Muslims to decide in counsel amongst themselves.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 44, p. 65, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 222

Verse: Courage is might at hand.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 572; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 223

Verse: Courage is a ready victory and an obvious virtue.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1700; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 223

Verse: If qualities were to be classified, honesty would be with courage, and cowardice with dishonesty.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7597; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 223

Verse: The bane of works is the incompetence of workers.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3958; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 136

Verse: Imam Hasan ibn 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) was once asked about courage, to which he replied, 'It is to know when to stand up to one's opponents, and when to be patient in the face of criticism.'
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 226; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 223

Verse: Courage has been created based on three natural characteristics, each of which has an exclusive merit over the rest. They are: self-esteem, dignity [in the face of humiliation], and seeking a good reputation. If they all attain perfection in the courageous man, he is an invincible hero, distinguished for his boldness in his generation. And if some of them are perfected in him more than others, then his courage will far supercede in those particular qualities over the rest.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 236, no. 66; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 224

Verse: A man's worth is in proportion to the extent of his ambition, his honesty is in proportion to the extent of his gallantry, and his courage is in proportion to the extent of his dignity [in the face of humiliation].
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 47; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 224

Verse: A man's courage is in proportion to the extent of his ambition, and his zeal in proportion to the extent of his ardour.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5763; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 224

Verse: [A man's] courage is in proportion to the extent of [his] ardour.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6180; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 224

Verse: Shall I tell you who is the toughest and strongest from among you?' They replied, 'Yes, O Prophet of Allah, do tell us', so the Prophet (SAWA) said, 'The strongest and toughest of you is he who, when he is happy, his happiness does not lead him to committing a sin or anything wrong, and when he gets angry, his anger does not prevent him from speaking the truth, and when he is empowered in any way, he does not take hold of that which is not lawfully his.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 366, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 224

Verse: The most courageous of people is the most generous of them.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2899; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 224

Verse: The most courageous of people is he who conquers his rashness with clemency.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, 3357; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 225

Verse: The strongest of people is the one with the greatest authority over his own self.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3188; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 225

Verse: The bane of courage is losing one's judiciousness
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3938; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 225
