Verse: By the One whose Hearing encompasses all voices, no sooner does one fill somebody else's heart with happiness than Allah creates a special grace for him from that very happiness, such that when he is faced with a calamity, he is able to pass over it like water flows over a slope, until he chases it away as wild camels are chased away.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 257; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 395

Verse: When one of you brings joy to another believer, let him not see it as having only made him happy. Rather, by Allah, he makes us happy, and by Allah, he makes the Prophet (SAWA) happy too.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 189, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 395

Verse: He who harms a believer is as if he has harmed me.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 68, p. 72, no. 40; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 398

Verse: He who looks at a believer with a look that scares him, Allah, most High, will scare him on the Day when no shade will avail except His Shade.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 150, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 398

Verse: He who saddens a believer then bestows him the whole world will not have done enough to discharge his sin, and nor will he be rewarded for the gift.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 68, p. 72, no. 40; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 398

Verse: Verily haste has ruined people, and if instead people proceeded with caution no one would be ruined.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 340, no. 697; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 398

Verse: Deliberateness is from Allah whereas haste is from Satan.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 340, no. 698; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 398

Verse: Haste causes stumbling
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 432; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 399

Verse: Mistakes happen frequently [when work is done] with haste.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 974; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 399

Verse: Wholesome results follow cautious procedure whereas regret follows haste.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 100, no. 52; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 399

Verse: Verily Allah loves the good that is embarked upon immediately.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 142, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 399

Verse: Deliberateness is recommended in everything except when embarking on opportunities for good-doing.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1937; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 399

Verse: The bane of talking is lying.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3957; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 136

Verse: Any man who buys food and hoards it for forty days waiting for its demand to rise among the Muslims and then sells it, even if he were to donate its value in charity, it would not atone for what he did.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 676, no. 1427; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 407

Verse: The hoarder is deprived of his bounty.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 465; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 407

Verse: The miserly hoarder gathers for those who will not thank him, and will come to Him who will not excuse him.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1842; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 407

Verse: Anyone honored by other than Allah is actually disgraced.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 10, no. 67; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 408

Verse: Know that the one who does not abase himself in front of Allah has no honor, and that the one who does not humble himself before Allah has no elevation.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 366; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 408

Verse: There is no honor like clemency.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 113; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 408

Verse: Obedience to the [divinely appointed] authorities of command is a completion of one's Honor.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 283; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 408

Verse: Whichever one of our brothers comes to one of our followers (shi`aa) and seeks help from him regarding a need and he does not help him, Allah will afflict him by fulfilling the need of one of our enemies, and for that Allah will punish him on the Day of Resurrection
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 297, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 630

Verse: Whichever believer withholds his wealth from another believer who is in need, by Allah he will not taste the food of Paradise and he will not drink from the sealed wine [of Paradise].
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 287, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 630

Verse: Verily if a man requests from me a need that he has, I will undertake to grant it fearing that his need gets fulfilled and he will no longer find any use for me [in helping him].
VerseRef: `Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 179, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 630

Verse: O Allah please do not make me require a need from bad people from among Your creation, and whatever You make me need, let it be from those with the most beautiful [happiest] faces, who are the most open-handed, have the most eloquent tongues and the least likely to remind me of their favour
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 56, no. 111; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 630

Verse: Someone once said in the presence of Imam Zayn al-Abidin (AS), 'O Allah, free me of need from Your creation'. The Imam immediately responded, 'Not like that! People are in need of each other, rather say, 'O Allah, free me of need from the bad people from among Your creation.'
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 278; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 630

Verse: Verily the example of one who is in need from someone who has recently attained wealth is that of a dirham [coin] in the mouth of a viper. You are in need of it but at the same time you are in danger of the viper.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 294; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 631

Verse: Negligence is deviation [from the straight path].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 196; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 631

Verse: Pitiable indeed is every negligent person that his whole life can be used as evidence against him and that his days lead him to wretchedness!
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 64; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 631

Verse: So come to your senses, O listener, from your intoxication, wake up from your neglect, and reduce your hasty activity.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 153; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 631

Verse: O people who are not neglected [by Allah] and yet who neglect that which will be taken to account from them - how is it that I see you moving away from Allah and longing for others?!
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 175; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 632

Verse: How many a negligent person weaves himself a garment in order that he might wear it whilst in reality it is his burial shroud, and who builds himself a house in which he may live but which is in fact his grave
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 401, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 632

Verse: If Satan is indeed an enemy, then why the negligence?!
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 190, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 632

Verse: O Abu Dharr, intend to perform good actions even if you do not actually manage to perform them, so that you are not included amongst the negligent
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 378, no. 2661; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 632

Verse: Through constant remembrance of Allah is negligence dispelled
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4269; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 632

Verse: Negligence is [manifest] in your abandonment of the mosque and in your obedience of the corrupt.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 115, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 633

Verse: He who prolongs his negligence hastens his own destruction
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8318; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 633

Verse: A believer's dream is one among the forty-six units of prophethood.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 39; Page No. 14

Verse: A believer's intention is better than his deed, while a hypocrite's deed is better than his intention, and everybody acts upon his own intention. When a believer does an action, a (sort of) light passes through his heart.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 40; Page No. 14

Verse: A believer's intention is more significant than his deeds.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 41; Page No. 14

Verse: A believer's promise is a binding commitment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 42; Page No. 14

Verse: A believer's promise is a debt, and a binding commitment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 43; Page No. 14

Verse: A believer's promise is a must (he should not miss).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 44; Page No. 14

Verse: A believer's sickness is the atonement of his sins.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 45; Page No. 15

Verse: A boaster has three traits: flattering in (people's) presence, backbiting in (people') absence, and clapping in people's calamities.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 46, Page No. 15

Verse: A bondservant should be fed and dressed properly and be not burdened with intolerable tasks.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 47, Page No. 15

Verse: A child is a flower of Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 48; Page No. 15

Verse: A child is the fruit of one's heart, and thereby the source of fear, miserliness and grief.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 49; Page No. 15

Verse: A counselor is people's trust. He is allowed to give a counsel or keep silent, but if he gives a counsel, it should be such that he himself would follow, were he to take a counsel.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 50; Page No. 15

Verse: A counselor is people's trust. He is allowed to give a counsel or keep silent.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 51; Page No. 15

Verse: A covert prayer equals seventy overt ones.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 52; Page No. 15

Verse: A coward trader a loser remains, but a courageous one gains.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 53; Page No. 15

Verse: A creature who loses his power of sight but keeps patient and is satisfied with the divine will, will surely be allowed to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 54; Page No. 15&16

Verse: A creditor will be in chains in his grave, and nothing can make him free but paying his debts.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 55; Page No. 16

Verse: A curb of fire will be put on the mouth of whoever conceals his knowledge when asked to offer it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 56; Page No. 16

Verse: Whoever keeps his temper while being able to reveal it, will be overflowed with faith and security.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3044.

Verse: A day will come to pass when people would belie the truthful and approve of the liars and would regard the honest treacherous and the treacherous honest, when men will bear witness without being required and will swear without being asked to, and when the most fortunate people would be ignoble, sons of the ignoble, who would be bereft of the belief in God and His prophet.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 57, Page No. 16

Verse: A Dirham earned in usury is worse for a man in the sight of God than committing adultery thirty six times.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 58; Page No. 16

Verse: A fast person will be worshipping God from early morning till night, if (s)he does not backbite people, but his fast will be ruined as soon as (s)he begins to do so.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 59, Page No. 16

Verse: A fast person's praying will surely be granted.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 60, Page No. 16

Verse: (61) A fast person's silence is praising God, his sleep is an act of worship, his praying is granted, and his deeds are (rewarded) twice.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 61, Page No. 16&17

Verse: A fast person's sleep is an act of worship, his silence is praising God, his deeds are (rewarded) twice, his prayers are granted, and his sins are forgiven.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 62, Page No. 17

Verse: A father's praying for his child is like unto a prophet's for his nation.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 63; Page No. 17

Verse: A fertile woman is more favorite to the Exalted God than a (barren) beautiful one. Verily, I will pride myself on the multitude of my nation in the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 64, Page No. 17

Verse: A generous man's food is cure, and a miser's is disease for sure.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 65; Page No. 17

Verse: Any house which is not visited by guests is not visited by angels either.
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 412

Verse: Every single believer whose eyes shed tears for the martyrdom of al-Husayn (AS) such that they roll onto his cheeks, Allah prepares chambers for him in Paradise as a result of them wherein he will dwell for ages
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 108, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 65

Verse: Imam al-Baqir (AS) in his discourse about the visitation (ziyara) of al-Husayn (AS) on the day of Aashura, be it from near or far, said, 'Then let him mourn for al-Husayn (AS) and weep over him, and let him enjoin weeping for him on others in his house who are not in a state of dissimulation, and they should condole with each other for their bereavement of al-Husayn (AS).   I [i.e. the narrator] asked, 'How should they condole with each other' to which he replied, 'They should say 'May Allah make our reward great for our bereavement of al-Husayn, and place us and you among those who avenge his blood with his representative, the Imam Mahdi from the family of Muhammad, peace be upon them
VerseRef: Misbah al-Mutahajjid, p. 772; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 65

Verse: Whoever recites a single verse of poetry about al-Husayn (AS), crying as a result and making ten other people cry, becomes deserving of Paradise and so do they.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 110, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 65

Verse: He for whom the day of Aashura' is a day of grief, sorrow and crying, Allah, Mighty and Exalted, will make the Day of Resurrection a day of joy and happiness for him.
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 227, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 66

Verse: Let the weepers weep over someone like Husayn, for verily weeping over him reduces the burden of great sins. Then he continued, saying, 'As soon as the month of Muharram would set in my father (AS) was never seen laughing, and he would be overcome by melancholy until after the first ten days had passed. When the tenth day dawned, it was a day of grief and sorrow and crying for him, and he used to say, 'This is the day when al-Husayn (AS) was martyred.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 1, p. 394, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 66

Verse: Verily Allah gives succour to this community only as a result of [the presence of] the weak among them, their supplication, their prayer and their sincerity
VerseRef: al-Durr al-Manthur, v. 2, p. 724; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 67

Verse: Imam Ali (AS), with regards to the Qur'anic verse: "And we desired to show favour to those who were abased " said, 'This refers to the progeny of Muhammad. Allah will send them their rightly guided Saviour [the Mahdi] after their struggle, and he will raise their status and abase their enemy
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 4, p. 110; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 67

Verse: The term 'weak' cannot be applied to those whom the divine proof has reached, whose ears have heard it and whose hearts have heeded it
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 189; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 67

Verse: Imam al-Baqir (AS), with regards to the Qur'anic verse: "Except the ones who are deemed weak ", said, 'This refers to one who is not capable of disbelieving that he may be considered a disbeliever, though neither has he been guided the path of faith that he may have faith. [It also refers to] children, and those people from among men and women who have intellects of children and who are therefore not accountable for their deeds
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 201, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 67

Verse: A good action is an ever-remaining store and a pure yield.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6545; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 351

Verse: The [spiritually] weak person is one whom the divine proof has not reached, and who would not be able to differentiate [even if it did reach him]. If he is able to differentiate [between truth and falsehood] therefore, then he is not considered weak
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 125, no. 95; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 68

Verse: Truly right now you live the day of action with no accounting therein, and very soon you will live the day of accounting with no action therein
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, no. 345; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 68

Verse: Accountability [for one's actions] will come before the punishment, and the reward will come after the account
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 380; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 68

Verse: Take account of your selves before you are held to account, and evaluate them before you are held for evaluation, and prepare yourselves for the Greatest Exposure
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 73, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 69

Verse: Restrict your lower selves by holding them accountable and control them by opposing them
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6794; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 69

Verse: O son of Adam! You will continue to thrive as long as you are the admonisher of your self, and as long as accounting for yourself is one of your concerns
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 280; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 69

Verse: The one who does not take account of himself every single day is not one of us. And when he performs a good deed, he should ask Allah to enable him to do more, and when he commits an evil deed, he must seek Allah's forgiveness and repent for it
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, p. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 69

Verse: He who takes account of his soul will understand his defects and know his sins. He will repent for the sins and amend the defects.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8927; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 69

Verse: He who takes account of his self profits, he who neglects it is at a loss, and he who fears will be safe
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 73, no. 27; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 69

Verse: He who takes account of his self prospers
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 12, p. 154, no. 13761; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 70

Verse: The first thing that man will be asked about is our love, the people of the Household (ahl al-bayt).
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 62, no. 258; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 70

Verse: The first thing that man will be asked about when he stands before Allah, Exalted be His Grandeur, is the obligatory prayers, the obligatory alms-tax (Zakat), the obligatory fasting, the obligatory pilgrimage (Hajj), and our guardianship (wilaya), the people of the household. If he attests to our guardianship and dies believing that, his prayer, fasting, alms and pilgrimage will all be accepted.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 212, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 70

Verse: Every bounty will be asked about on the Day of Resurrection except for what was [used] in the way of Allah, most High.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 7, p. 261, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 70

Verse: Whoever utters the name of Allah on some food that he eats will never be asked [to account for] the bounty of that food.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 246, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 70

Verse: Generosity has a set limit, and if taken to extremes becomes squandering.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 69, p. 407, no. 115; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 350

Verse: There are three things which the servant will not be asked about: the cloth he used to cover his private parts, the piece of bread he used to sate his hunger with, and the house that used to protect him from the heat and the cold.
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 5, p. 665, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 70

Verse: On the Day of Resurrection, the feet of the servant will not slip until he is asked about four things: his years and how he spent them, his youth and how he wasted it, his wealth, whence he earned it and how he spent it, and our love, the people of the household (ahl al-bayt).
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 253, no. 125; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 71

Verse: You will surely be asked on that day concerning the blessing", said, 'This community will be asked about the bounty that Allah bestowed on them in the form of the Messenger of Allah (SAWA), and then his household (AS).
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 7, p. 272, no. 39; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 71

Verse: Be content with what you have been given and your account will be lighter.
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, no. 344; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 71

Verse: Whoever is tried with having a number of daughters whom he treats kindly, will be a shielded by them from the fire of Hell.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3039.

Verse: Whoever is ungrateful to the small (gifts of God), is surely the same to the great (abundance of Him).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3040.

Verse: Whoever is worried about his sins, will be forgiven (by God), though he does not request it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3041.

Verse: Whoever joins a tribe as a guest, should avoid arbitrary fasting without their permission.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3042.

Verse: Whoever keeps aloof from the society, will die as in the Age of Ignorance.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3043.

Verse: Whoever leads one person to Islam, will be allowed to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3048.

Verse: Whoever leads others to good, will be rewarded as good-doers.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3049.

Verse: Whoever leads people to a right direction, will be rewarded as those who follow it, without any reduction in the latter's reward, and whoever shows people a wrong direction, will be punished as those who follow it, without any reduction in the latter's punishment.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3050.

Verse: Whoever learns shooting but does not put it to practice, is guilty of ingratitude.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3051.

Verse: Whoever lies about me in purpose, will have an abode of fire in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3052.

Verse: Whoever longs for eternal magnanimity, should forsake the world's (passing) beauty.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3053.

Verse: Whoever longs for Paradise should haste towards the good, whoever is afraid of Hell should abandon passions, whoever is worried about death should connive at pleasures, and whoever does not attach (his heart) to this would, will face calamities with ease.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3054.

Verse: Whoever loses hope in what (s)he has lost will reach comfort, and whoever is pleased with his/her destined share will feel relief.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3055.

Verse: It is You Who removed the strangers from the hearts of Your lovers so that they never love other than You  What does the one who loses You find [besides You]?! And what does the one who finds You lose [out on]?! He indeed fails who is satisfied with a substitute for You.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 98, p. 226, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 575

Verse: Man's faith in Allah will not be pure until Allah becomes more beloved to him than his own self, his father, his mother, his children, his wife, his wealth, and all people.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 25, no. 25; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 575

Verse: The heart is the sanctuary of Allah, so do not lodge other than Allah in Allah's sanctuary.
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 518, no. 1468; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 575

Verse: Love [of Allah] is better than fear [of Him].
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 129, no. 98; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 575

Verse: It is related in the tradition of the Prophet (SAWA)'s Ascension, 'O Muhammad, My love is due to those who love each other for My sake, and My love is due to those who are kind to each other for My sake, and My love is due to those who maintain communication with each other for My sake, and My love is due to those who trust Me, and there is no ensign, end or culmination to My love, and whenever I raise an ensign for them I lower another ensign for them.'
VerseRef: Irshad al-QulUb, no. 199; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 576

Verse: Whoever wants to know the status of his position with Allah must first find out what status of position Allah holds with him, for Allah places the servant in the same position whereat the servant places Allah with respect to himself.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 156, no. 74; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 578

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said, regarding what Allah, most High, revealed to Prophet Moses (AS), said, 'He lies who claims that he loves Me, yet when the night covers him up he sleeps away from Me [forgetting Me]. Is it not that every lover loves to be alone with his beloved?!'
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 292, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 578

Verse: Allah, Mighty and Exalted, says, "My servant endears himself to Me with nothing more beloved to Me than what I have made obligatory upon him, and he endears himself to Me through performance of the supererogatory prayers until I love him. Once I love him, I become his hearing with which he hears, his sight with which he sees, his tongue with which he speaks, his hands with which he acts, and his foot with which he walks. When he calls Me I answer him, and when he asks Me I grant him.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 454, no. 1047; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 579

Verse: The love for Allah and the love for the world cannot ever coexist in one heart.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 122; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 579

Verse: By Allah, Allah does not love him who loves this world and befriends other than us.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 129, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 579

Verse: Allah, Mighty and Exalted, said to Prophet David (AS), "Love Me and encourage My creatures to love Me." He said, 'My Lord, I do love You, but how can I encourage Your creatures to love You?' Allah said, "Remind them of My blessing and kindness, for if you remind them of that they will love Me.
VerseRef: Qasas al-Anbiya' li al-Rawandi, p. 205, no. 266; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 580

Verse: I am sometimes reduced to poverty, so I trade with Allah through charity.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 206, no. 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 177

Verse: O servant of Allah! Love for the sake of Allah and hate for the sake of Allah, and befriend for the sake of Allah and contest for the sake of Allah, for Allah's guardianship is attained only by that, and man will not find the taste of faith   though his prayers and fasting be much   unless he behaves thus. In this present day, the brotherhood and friendship of the people are mainly for the sake of this world; they love each other for its sake and hate each other for its sake.
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 140, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 580

Verse: No sooner do two believers meet than the better of them is he who loves his brother more.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 411, no. 937; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 580

Verse: Every single person who does not love for religion or hate for religion has no religion.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 127, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 580

Verse: Allah revealed to one of the prophets, "Your asceticism in this world hastens your comfort, and your devotion to Me endears you to Me. But did you oppose an enemy [of Mine] for My sake or did you befriend a friend for Me?
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 455; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 581

Verse: Man is not considered a believer until I am dearer to him than his own self, my household dearer to him than his own household, my family dearer to him than his own family, and my being dearer to him than his own being.
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 140, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 581

Verse: Love Allah for the blessings that He bestows on you every morning; love me because of the love of Allah; and love my household because of love for me.
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie,; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 581

Verse: Imam Mosa ibn Ja'far al-Kazim (a.s.), when asked about whether owning ten shirts was considered a waste, replied, 'No, and in fact that is more conducive to longer wear of your clothes. Waste is when you wear your formal finery to unclean places [as casual wear].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 317, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 987

Verse: Blessed is a face upon which Allah gazes while it is weeping for a sin out of fear of Allah, the Exalted, even if no one else knew about that sin.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 93, p. 331, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 987

Verse: said during the Farewell Sermon, 'And he whose eyes shed tears for the fear of Allah, he will have for every drop of his tears a reward equivalent to the size of Mount U ud which will be added to the balance of his [good deeds].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 93, p. 334, no. 25; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 987

Verse: Seven people will be in the shade of the Throne of Allah, the Exalted, when no shade will avail but His:   and a man who remembered Allah, the Exalted, alone, and his eyes flooded with tears out of fear of Allah.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 84, p. 2, no. 71; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 988

Verse: Whoever sheds a tear as small as the size of a fly out of fear of Allah, Allah will grant him safety on the Day of the Great Terror.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 93, p. 336, no. 30; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 988

Verse: The tears in the eyes and the fear in the hearts are part of the mercy of Allah, exalted be His remembrance. When you find them, seize the opportunity for making supplications
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 96, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 988

Verse: Weeping out of fear of Allah is the key to [His] mercy.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2051; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 988

Verse: Weeping out of fear of Allah illuminates the heart and shields against returning to the sin.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2016; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 988

Verse: No drops are more beloved to Allah, the Exalted, than two: a drop of blood [shed] for the sake of Allah, and a teardrop shed by a servant in the darkness of the night solely for Allah's sake.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 69, p. 378, no. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 989

Verse: Every eye will cry on the Day of Judgment except for three: an eye that stayed up [in worship] for the sake of Allah, an eye that filled with tears out of fear of Allah, and an eye that looked away from things prohibited by Allah.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 7, p. 195, no. 62; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 989

Verse: If weeping does not come naturally to you, force yourself [to weep], for even if a tear as small as a fly's head is shed by you, then congratulations to you.
VerseRef: Uddat al-Da`ai, p. 161; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 989

Verse: Every single thing has a measure or a weight, except for tears; for one drop of them can extinguish seas of Fire. If an eye is filled with tears, the face will never be burdened with neediness or humiliation; and if it floods with tears then Allah will make it unlawful for the Fire to touch it. Indeed, if a teary man cries for a community, they all receive mercy.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 93, p. 331, no. 14; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 989

Verse: Dryness of the eye is one of the signs of wretchedness.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 52, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 990

Verse: Love is purified through cultivating friendship for the sake of Allah.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6191; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 150

Verse: Tears only dry up as a result of the hardness of the hearts; and the hearts only harden as a result of an abundance of sins.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 354, no. 60; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 990

Verse: Verily wisdom is the light of every heart.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 14, p. 317, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 990

Verse: Luqman Al Hakeem (a.s.) said [advising his son], 'My son, learn wisdom and you will become noble, for verily wisdom directs towards religion, it honours the slave with freedom, it raises the poor above the rich and it precedes the young over the old.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 13, p. 432, no. 24; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 990

Verse: A word of wisdom that the believer hears is better than the worship of one year.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 172, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 991

Verse: Wisdom is the garden of the intelligent ones and the amusement of the noble.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1715; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 991

Verse: Wisdom is a tree that grows in the heart and produces fruit on the tongue.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1992; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 991

Verse: The one who is known for [his] wisdom is regarded by the eyes with dignity and awe.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 97; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 991

Verse: Wisdom is the lost property of the believer, so seek it even from the polytheist for you will be more deserving and worthier of it [than him].
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 625, no. 1290; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 991

Verse: Wisdom is the lost property of the believer, so take wisdom even from the people of hypocrisy.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 80; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 991

Verse: The one who seeks fulfilment of his need from an unwise person is [himself] not a wise person.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2092; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 992

Verse: A person who does not deal amicably with someone for whom amicableness is the only option is not a wise man.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 218; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 992

Verse: The opening of wisdom is abandoning the [illicit] pleasures, and the peak of it is to detest the transient things.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3054; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 992

Verse: From among [the matters of] wisdom is to avoid dispute with one who is above you, to not disesteem anyone other than yourself, to not undertake a task which is outside of your capability, to not have your tongue contradict your heart and neither your word [contradict] your action, to not speak of that which you do not know, and to not abandon a matter as it approaches only to pursue it as it retreats.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9450; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 992

Verse: Imam Muhammad ibn 'Ali al-Baqir (a.s.), when he was asked by Abu Basir regarding the words of Allah's verse, "and he who is given wisdom " said, 'It [wisdom] is obedience to Allah and true knowledge of the Imm.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 1, p. 251, no. 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 992

Verse: The ruin of your predecessors lay in the fact that they deprived people of their rights and subsequently resorted to buying them back, and they handled people using unethical means, which they followed.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 79; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 147

Verse: Whoever kisses his/her mother's forehead, will be immune from the Hellfire.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 3045.

Verse: You know full well that he who is in charge of honour, people's lives, war booty, legal commandments and the leadership of the Muslims must not be a miser  nor should he accept bribes whilst governing for he would forfeit their rights, and base his rulings upon them [the bribes] rather than proper judgment.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 131; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 147

Verse: said about Allah's verse in the Qur'an: "eaters of the unlawful"385, 'This refers to the man who fulfils a need for a fellow brother and then accepts a gift from him.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 104, p. 273, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 147

Verse: Accepting bribes as a judge or ruler is tantamount to disbelief in Allah.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 7, p. 409, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 147

Verse: The believers are brothers, their blood is coequal, and they are one hand against others, the most inferior among them is empowered by their protection [of him].
VerseRef: Amali al-Mufid, p. 187, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 147

Verse: Many a brother was not given birth by your own mother.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5351; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 148

Verse: A believer is the brother of another believer [as if] from his own mother and father.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 166, no. 2 and 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 148

Verse: A believer is the brother of another believer, his eye and his guide; he does not betray him, nor wrong him, nor deceive him, and nor does he rescind a promise he made to him.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 166, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 148

Verse: The one who does good will be the first to reap its result.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam,. no. 8177; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 351

Verse: A believer is the brother of another believer, like a single body. If any part of him suffers, he will feel its pain in his entire body; and their souls are also made of one soul
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 166, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 148

Verse: Adopt [the friendship of] true brothers and increase in your acquisition of them, for they are an asset in times of prosperity, and a shield during afflictions.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 250, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 149

Verse: Do not let your brother be stronger than you are in your amity for him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 165, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 149

Verse: Love brothers in proportion to [their] piety
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, no. 226; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 149

Verse: A man's love for his brother is part of his love for his religion.
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, no. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 149

Verse: O Ibn al-Nu'mani If you want your brother's amity for you to be pure, do not make fun of him, do not dispute with him, do not exchange bragging with him, and do not vie with him in evil acts.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 291, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 149

Verse: Brothers need three things among them   they either use them, or else dispute and hate one another   fairness, benevolence, and evasion of jealousy.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 322; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 150

Verse: Looking at a brother you love for the sake of Allah, the Exalted, is [an act of] worship.
VerseRef: al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 279, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 150

Verse: A Muslim cannot acquire anything as beneficial as his embracing Islam than a brother he benefits from for the sake of Allah.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 179; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 150

Verse: Brothers, [whose brotherhood is] for the sake of Allah, enjoy an enduring amity, due to the firmness of its foundation.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1795; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 150

Verse: Brotherhood for the sake of Allah is fruitful.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4225; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 151

Verse: A man whose friendship is not for the sake of Allah must be avoided, for his friendship is vile, and his company is doomed.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8978; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 151

Verse: A man whose brotherhood is for the sake of Allah is bound to gain, while a man who seeks brothers for the sake of this world is bound to lose
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7776-7777; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 151

Verse: A man who draws close to you for a purpose will abandon you when it is fulfilled.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8552; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 151

Verse: When one of you likes his companion or brother, he should let him know.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 415, no. 953; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 151

Verse: A man passed through the mosque, where Abu Ja'far and Abu 'Abdullah [Imam al-Baqir and Imam al-Sadiq (AS)] were seated, when one of the people present said, 'By Allah, I like this man.' Abu Ja'far replied, 'Then let him know, for this will maintain the amity and enhance the affection.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 181, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 152

Verse: Ask your hearts about their amities, for they are witnesses that take no bribes.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5641; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 152

Verse: Know the amity that your brother has for you in his heart through what you harbour of the same in your own heart.
VerseRef: Kashf al-Ghamma, v. 2, p. 331; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 152

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) relating what Gabriel said to the Prophet (SAWA), 'If one drop of the cactus [of Hell] was to drop in the drink of the people of this world, they would die of its stench.'
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 401

Verse: When the Zaqqum and the cactus will boil in the stomachs of the people of the Fire, like boiling water, they will ask for a drink, and will be given a drink made of pus and festering matter. One will swallow it painfully but will not enjoy it, and death will come to him from all sides though he will not die.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 8, p. 302, no. 58; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 401

Verse: The first to enter the Fire will be a domineering ruler who did not maintain justice, a rich man possessing wealth who does not give his due from his wealth, and a poor man who is arrogant.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 28, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 401

Verse: The [categories of] people to experience the greatest pain on the Day of Resurrection will be: the man who killed a prophet or was killed by a prophet, the leader of deception, and the sculptor.
VerseRef: al-Durr al-Manthur, v. 1, p. 178; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 402

Verse: The person to experience the greatest punishment will be the man who recompenses good done unto him with evil.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3217; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 402

Verse: The person to experience the greatest pain on the Day of Resurrection will be the one who was dissatisfied with the decree of Allah.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3225; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 402

Verse: Verily there is a valley in Hell reserved for the arrogant, called Saqar, which complained to Allah, Mighty and Exalted, about its severe heat and asked His permission to breathe. So it breathed, and thus ignited Hell!
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 310, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 403

Verse: Allah will not retain anybody in the Fire permanently except the people of disbelief, denial, error and polytheism. And whoever shuns the grave sins from among the believers will not be asked about the minor ones.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 407, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 403

Verse: Some people will burn in the Fire, until they are burned to ashes [and become pure]   then they will be taken out through intercession.
VerseRef: al-Zuhd li al-Husayn b. Sa`aid, p. 96, no. 260; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 403

Verse: The people of the Fire will be kept permanently in the Fire because their intentions in the world were such that if they were to live forever therein, they would disobey Allah forever. And verily the people of Paradise will also be made to remain in Paradise permanently because their intentions in this world were to obey Allah if only they were to live there forever. So, it is due to their intentions that these and those have their permanent residence.' Then Imam recited the word of Allah, the Exalted: "Say, 'Everyone acts according to his character" 170 and said that it means according to his intention.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 85, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 404

Verse: Hoarding is the cause of deprivation.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 256; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 404

Verse: Hoarding is the habit of the dissolute.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 607; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 405

Verse: Truly Allah, Mighty and Exalted, showed His bounty to His servants in the seed, but He also plagued them with lice; otherwise the kings would have hoarded it as they hoard gold and silver.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 87, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 406

Verse: The hoarder is damned.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 62, p. 292; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 406

Verse: He who hoards food for forty days waiting for the rise of its price, he indeed disassociates himself from Allah and Allah disassociates Himself from him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 62, p. 292; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 407

Verse: The one who strives for the sake of Allah to fulfil the need of his Muslim brother, Allah has written for him a million good deeds
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 197, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 628

Verse: The one who engages himself in fulfilling the need of his Muslim brother, Allah fulfils his need as long as he remains engaged in fulfilling the need of his brother
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 97, no. 147; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 628

Verse: Allah said, '[My] Creatures are my dependants, the most beloved ones to Me are those who are the kindest to each other and strive to fulfil others' needs
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 199, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 628

Verse: The one who strives to fulfil the need of his brother is like the one who runs between al-Safa and al-Marwa [al-Safa and al-Marwa: hills in Makkah. Running between them seven times is among the obligatory acts performed during the obligatory pilgrimage (Hajj) (ed.)
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 303; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 629

Verse: The one who grants the need of his believing brother, Allah will grant him one hundred thousand of his needs on the Day of Resurrection, the first of them being Paradise.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 193, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 629

Verse: Verily granting the need of a fellow believer is more beloved to Allah than twenty obligatory pilgrimages (Hajj) wherein each Hajj the pilgrim donates one hundred thousand (dinars or dirhams).
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 193, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 629

Verse: Whichever Muslim comes to another Muslim's home to visit or to seek a need, and asks permission to enter but he does not come out [to meet him], the curse of Allah will continuously be upon that Muslim [host] until they both meet again
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 365, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 629

Verse: One who asks his believing brother a need in time of difficulty and he refuses him while being capable of fulfilling that need, either himself or through someone else, Allah will raise him on the Day of Resurrection in chains from his hands to his neck until Allah completes the account of all of creation
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 287, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 629

Verse: Only three types of people are imprisoned for life: he who holds another hostage to prevent himself from being killed, the woman who becomes an apostate, and the one who steals even after having had his hand and foot cut [as corporal punishment for previous thefts].
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 3, p. 31, no. 3264; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 427

Verse: It is unjust for the Imam to imprison the culprit after punishment.
VerseRef: Tahdhib al-Ahkam, v. 6, p. 314, no. 870; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 428

Verse: Imprisonment after acknowledgment of the truth is injustice.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 17, p. 403, no. 21672; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 428

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) used to inspect the prisons every Friday; he punished the convicts and released those who had no charge against them.'
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 18, p. 36, no. 21943; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 428

Verse: It is the duty of the Imam to release the prisoners on financial charges on Fridays and `Ayd [religious festivals] to observe the congregational prayer. He may send them guarded, and when they complete the prayers and the feast, he should return them to the prison.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 3, p. 31, no. 3265; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 428

Verse: He who is divinely granted infallibility is safe from error.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8469; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 429

Verse: An Imam from among us can only be infallible. Infallibility is not an outward physical feature that can be noticed which is why it must be documented [in the Qur'an or traditions].' He was then asked, 'O son of the Prophet, and what does infallible mean' to which he replied, 'It refers to one who clings fast to the rope of Allah, and the rope of Allah is the Qur'an. They do not separate from each other until the Day of Resurrection, and the Imam guides to the Qur'an and the Qur'an guides to the Imam, which is the purport of Allah' s saying [in the Qur'an] "Verily this Qur'an guides to what is most upright"[ Qur'an 179].'
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 132, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 429

Verse: Imam al-Sadiq (AS), in reply to Hisham' s question about the meaning of infallible, said - The infallible [Imam] is prevented by Allah from all acts which Allah has prohibited, and Allah, Blessed and most High, says "And whoever takes recourse in Allah is certainly guided to a straight path" "[ Qur'an 3:101].
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah page No. 429

Verse: A sincere friend is he who advises you with regard to your shortcomings, protects you in your absence, and prefers you over himself
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1904; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 346

Verse: Shower all your love on your friend but do not shower all your trust on him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 165, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 346

Verse: Verily the one who knows the vicissitudes of time will not neglect preparation.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 74, no. 27; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 632

Verse: Verily any believer who is mindful of the obligatory prayers and prays them on time is not of the negligent ones
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 270, no. 14; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 633

Verse: Friendship can only succeed when its conditions are fulfilled, and he who fulfils all or some of these conditions may be befriended, and if not, then do not attribute any of your friendship to him. The first of these conditions is that he should treat you in public the same as he treats you in private. Secondly, that your source of pride is a source of pride for him, and your source of shame is a source of shame for him too. Thirdly, that neither friendship [with others] nor wealth should render him envious of you. Fourthly, that he must not prevent you from obtaining that which you have the capacity for, and fifthly   and this sums up all the other qualities   that he must not give up on you in times of misfortune
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 249, no. 90; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 347

Verse: The best of companions is he who has little discord about him and much harmony
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 123; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 347

Verse: The right of your companion is that you share his company with bounty and fairness. You should honour him as he honours you, and should not let him be the first to extend his generosity. And if he is the first to do so, then repay him. Wish for him as he wishes for you, and restrain him from any act of disobedience that he might contemplate. Be a mercy for him, and not a chastisement
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 7, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 348

Verse: Generosity is a means of nearness [to Allah].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 193, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 348

Verse: The heart can only be made use of [to the best of its capacity] with generosity.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 7, no. 59; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 348

Verse: Generosity is the fruit of the intellect, and contentment is the proof of magnanimity.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2145; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 348

Verse: Generosity cultivates love.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 306; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 348

Verse: Generosity imparts love and adorns one's character.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1600; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 349

Verse: Generosity is one of the noble traits possessed by prophets. It is the pillar of belief, such that only a true believer will be generous, as well as one who possesses great certainty and high aspiration, for generosity is a gleam from the light of certainty, and the one who knows what he wants finds it easy to give away.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 355, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 349

Verse: The best ones from among you are those who are liberal and the worst ones from among you are the miserly.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 350, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 349

Verse: Allah, Mighty and Exalted, revealed to Prophet Moses (AS), 'That you kill not the Samiri*, for verily he is a generous man.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 41, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 349

Verse: The generous person is close to Allah, close to people and close to Paradise.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 308, no. 37; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 349

Verse: A generous youth burdened by sins is more beloved to Allah than a worshipping but miserly old man.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 307, no. 34; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 350

Verse: The generous person partakes of other people's food in order that they may [feel comfortable to] partake of his food, whereas the miser does not partake of others' food so that they may not eat from his.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 352, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 350

Verse: The most generous of people is he who fulfils payment of the alms-tax due upon him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 112, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 350

Verse: Generosity is that you contribute willingly from your own wealth, and restrain yourself from other people's wealth.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1928; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 350

Verse: The kind and generous person is he who spends his wealth for a right cause.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 353, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 350

Verse: Generosity is when the act of giving is initiated. When it is prompted by a request however, it is merely out of a sense of embarrassment or obligation.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 357, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 350

Verse: Do not seek sincere amity from a man you have insincere sentiment for, nor honest advice from someone you direct your distrust towards, for another's feelings [lit. heart] towards you are similar to your feelings towards him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, no. 181; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 152

Verse: If you want to cut off relations with your brother make sure to leave a place for him in your heart, so he can return to it one day when he so wishes.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 153

Verse: How awful it is to cut off relations after having maintained them, to turn away after brotherhood, and to have animosity after amity.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 210, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 153

Verse: A man who places his amity in the wrong place is bound to suffer abandonment.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 415, no. 950; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 153

Verse: Do not let your brother be stronger in his avoidance of you than you are in your maintaing relations with him, and do not be stronger in your harm to him than in your kindness towards him.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 153

Verse: The best person is the one who maintains relations with one who cuts him off.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 121, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 153

Verse: The most scarce things at the end of time will be a trustworthy brother and a legitimately earned dirham.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 154

Verse: The most scarce things at the end of time will be a trustworthy brother and a legitimately earned dirham.'[Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 54]Imam al-Sadiq (AS) said, 'Brothers are of three [kinds]: one, like food, is needed all the time and he is the wise [friend]. Another is similar to disease, and this is the fool. And the third is like medicine, and this is the tactful [friend].
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 323; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 154

Verse: Brothers are three [kinds]: one helps with his own self, and another helps with his money, and these are true in their brotherhood. A third is the one who takes from you what he needs and keeps you for some of his pleasure - do not consider him trustworthy.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 324; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 154

Verse: The one you need to safeguard yourself against is not your brother.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7503; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 154

Verse: Do not take for brother a man who hides your virtues and exposes your lapses.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1042; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 155

Verse: The worst brother is the one who stays with you in your affluence and abandons you in your poverty.
VerseRef: Kitab al-Irshad, v. 2, p. 166; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 155

Verse: Do not take for brothers or companions: the fool, the miserly, the coward, and the liar.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 244, no. 100; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 155

Verse: Be warned against having a brother who wants you for greed, avoidance of fear, or getting food and drink. Instead, seek the brotherhood of the pious even if they are in the darkness of the earth and even if you have to spend your life seeking them.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 282, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 155

Verse: Choose the new of everything, but the oldest one from among brothers.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2461; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 156

Verse: Your true brother is the one who forgives your lapse, fulfils your need, accepts your excuse, hides your vices, removes your fear, and lives up to your expectation.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3645; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 156

Verse: Your brother is the one who does not abandon you in difficulty, does not forget you at the time of trouble, and does not cheat you when you seek his advice.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 269, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 156

Verse: A man who shuns his brothers for every lapse has few friends.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8166; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 156

Verse: A man who does not befriend [anyone] unless they are flawless will have few friends.
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, no. 304; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 157

Verse: Tolerate the lapse of your friend for the time of your enemy's attack.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 166, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 157

Verse: Tolerance is the splendor of companions.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 752; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 157

Verse: A man who does not endure the lapses of a friend will die in loneliness.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9079; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 157

Verse: The best of your brothers is the one who helps you to obey Allah, prevents you from disobeying Him, and orders you to please Him.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 123; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 157

Verse: The best of brothers is the one with the least hesitance in offering [harsh] advice.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4978; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 158

Verse: The best of your brothers is the one who stands by you, and better than him is he who suffices himself with you, and even when he is in need of you, he spares you.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4988; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 158

Verse: The best brother is the one whose amity is for the sake of Allah.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5017; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 158

Verse: The best of your brothers is the one who rushes to do good and draws you alongside him, and orders you to do good and helps you with it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5021; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 158

Verse: Honor is to submit oneself to the truth when it comes to you.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 228, no. 105; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 408

Verse: It is narrated in Bihar al-Anwar: Allah, most High, revealed to Prophet David (AS) said, 'O David, verily   I have placed Honor in My obedience whilst they seek it in servitude to the ruler and do not find it therefore.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 453, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 408

Verse: Luqman Al Hakeem (a.s.) said to his son, exhorting him, 'If you want to attract Honor in this world, then cut off your greed of drawing advantage from what other people have in their possession; for verily the prophets and the veracious ones achieved what they did by cutting off their greed.'
VerseRef: Qasas al-Anbiya' li al-Rawandi, p. 195, p. 244; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 409

Verse: There is no Honor higher than piety.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 371; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 409

Verse: My God, it is Honor enough for me that I am Your servant, and it is a source of pride for me that You are my Lord.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 420, no. 14; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 409

Verse: Know that verily the one who treats people fairly in spite of himself is only increased by Allah in Honor.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 144, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 409

Verse: Be content and you will attain Honor.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 53, no. 90; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 409

Verse: Giving up all hope of benefit from what people possess is an Honor for a believer in his religion.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 149, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 409

Verse: There are three things through which Allah only increases the Muslim in Honor: his pardon of one who has wronged him, his giving one who has deprived him, and his reconciliation with one who has cut him off.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 109, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 409

Verse: He who wishes for Honor without noble lineage, wealth without riches and dignity without rulership should remove himself from the disgrace of Allah's disobedience to the Honor of His obedience.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 169, no. 222; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 410

Verse: Every single servant who swallows his anger is increased in Honor by Allah, Mighty and Exalted, in this world and in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 110, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 410

Verse: No sooner does an Honorable man abandon the truth than he is abased, and no sooner does a disgraced man adopt it than he is Honored.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 374, no. 24; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 410

Verse: Seek for everlasting Honor through killing greed.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 286; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 410

Verse: The modesty in one's reservation preserves one's Honor longer than the intimacy of encounter [when interacting with people].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 180, p. 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 410

Verse: Every hopeful person continues seeking, and every fearful one runs away.
VerseRef: Amali al-Mufid, p. 207, no. 38; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 411

Verse: Do not be of those who hope for [bliss in] the life of the Hereafter without action, and delay repentance by having high expectations [of being forgiven], and who utter words like the ascetics with regard to this world, though in practice they behave like those who covet it.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 150; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 411

Verse: Someone came to Imam al-Sadiq (AS) and told him that there was a group of people who were disobeying Allah, but at the same time they were saying that they hoped [in His mercy], and remained thus until death overtook them. Imam (AS) said, 'These are people who swing back and forth between their desires. They are lying and are not really hopeful, for the one who hopes for something seeks it, and the one who fears something flees from it.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 68, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 411

Verse: Place all your hope in Allah, glory be to Him, and do not hope from anyone else apart from Him, for no sooner does anyone place his hope in anyone other than Allah than he fails.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2511; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 411

Verse: He who has faith in Allah and the Last Day must honour his guest.
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 377, no. 1053; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 412

Verse: The guest arrives bringing his own sustenance and leaves taking away the sins of his hosts.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 461, no. 14; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 412

Verse: He who has been granted wealth by Allah must use it to maintain relations with his kin and to entertain guests.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 142; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 412

Verse: Imam Ali (AS) was once seen sad and asked the reason for it, so he replied, 'Because it has been seven days since we have had no guests.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 41, p. 28, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 412

Verse: It is an abominable act to accept the invitation of someone whose banquet is only attended by the rich and not the poor.
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 141, no. 358; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 413

Verse: I advise both the present and the absent ones from my community to accept the invitation of a fellow Muslim, even if it be five miles away, for verily that is a part of religion.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 180, no. 1510; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 413

Verse: It is loathsome that a man be invited to a meal and does not accept, or accepts but does not eat.
VerseRef: Qurb al-Isnad, p. 160, no. 583; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 413

Verse: Allah, Mighty and Exalted, says, 'The servant endears himself to Me by no better means than what I have made obligatory upon him.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 82, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 576

Verse: When the believer abandons this world, he is elevated and finds the sweet taste of Allah's love; he appears to the people of this world as if he is confounded in his mind, whereas truly it is they who have confounded the sweetness of Allah's love such that they do not occupy themselves with other than Him.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 130, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 576

Verse: Indeed Allah loves the bashful, clement, chaste and virtuous servant.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 112, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 576

Verse: Indeed Allah loves every sorrowful heart and loves every grateful servant.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 99, no. 30; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 576

Verse: Allah loves the one who is jolly among people without being obscene, is monotheistic in his thought, adorned by patience, and priding himself with the prayer.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 456, no. 1056; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 577

Verse: The most beloved of Allah's servants to Him are those that are the most useful to His servants, and the most persistent of them in establishing His right, those who endear virtue and its practices.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 49; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 577

Verse: The most beloved of people to Allah, Mighty and Exalted, is a man who is truthful in his speech, careful about his prayer and all that Allah has made obligatory for him, along with returning whatever he is entrusted with.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 243, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 577

Verse: When Allah loves a servant He inspires him with good acts of devotion.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4066; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 577

Verse: Whoever would like to know that Allah loves him must work in the obedience of Allah and follow us. Has he heard not the speech of Allah, Mighty and Exalted, to His Prophet (SAWA): "Say, 'If you love Allah "?
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 14, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 578

Verse: It suffices for a man to depend on his brother to charge him with his need.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 198, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 162

Verse: Ignorance is to display all that you know.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 122; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 425

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) was once asked whether one should give charity to those who beg at people's doors, or whether to withhold it from them and give it to one's poor relatives instead, to which he replied, 'No, rather one should send it to a [poor] relative, for that holds a greater reward.'
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 171, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 181

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said with regards to Allah's verse in the Qur'an: " the beggar and the deprived", 'The deprived is the disabled one who is deprived of the use of his hands for working in trade.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 500, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 182

Verse: Give in charity without conceitedness, for verily conceitedness does away with your reward [for it].
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 120; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 182

Verse: Delaying [one's promise of] giving and reproaching someone for a gift embitters the goodness of the favor.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1595; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 182

Verse: Cheerfulness removes the grudge [of others].
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 103, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 182

Verse: Being amicable towards people is half of faith, and being gentle and kind to them is half of life.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 117, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 102

Verse: There are three things that if are not present with someone then their actions are incomplete: piety preventing one from disobeying Allah, a character through which one is amicable towards people, and clemency with which to deal with the rashness of the ignorant.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 116, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 102

Verse: The fruit of [strong] intellect is amicableness with people.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4629; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 102

Verse: The security of this world and the Hereafter lies in amicableness with people.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5610; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 102

Verse: Whoever is amicable towards his enemies is secure from war.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8539; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 102

Verse: Whoever is not improved by the goodness of amicableness will be improved by the evil consequences [of the absence of it].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8202; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 103

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when reprimanding his companions said, 'How long should I continue to be amicable with you the way one is amicable with camels with a hollow hump, or to worn clothes which when stitched on one side give way on the other  and verily I know what can improve you and how to straighten your crookedness, but I shall not improve your condition by marring myself.'
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 69; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 103

Verse: Moving mountains is easier than bringing hostile hearts together.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 11, no. 70; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 103

Verse: The speed of amity between the hearts of pious people when they meet   even if they do not show their mutual love on their tongues   is like the speed of the rain water when it mixes with the water of rivers. And the distance between the hearts of the wicked when they meet   even if they make a show of love on their tongues   is like the distance between beasts that cannot have mutual affection no matter how long they eat from the same trough.'
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 373; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 104

Verse: The best among you are the ones who have the best moral traits, those who like others and are well-liked.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 45; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 104

Verse: The best of the believers is the one who is loved by the believers, and there is no good to be found in someone who does not like others nor is he liked by them.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 265, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 104

Verse: Anger is a smouldering ember [kindled by] Satan.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 265, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 104

Verse: Rage is a type of madness because the one enraged feels regret later on, and if he does not feel regret, then his madness has become ingrained.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 255; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 105

Verse: Anger is such that it destroys the heart of even the wise man.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 305, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 105

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) said, 'Shall I tell you who is the toughest and strongest from among you? The one who controls himself when he is angry
VerseRef: Nathr al-Durar, v. 1, p. 183; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 105

Verse: There is no strength like being able to repel one's anger.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 286; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 105

Verse: He who has no control over his anger has no control over his reason.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 305, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 105

Verse: Verily there is a door to Hell, the entrance into which will be reserved for one who vented his anger through committing an act of disobedience to Allah, most High.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 121; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 105

Verse: He who curbs his anger, Allah will curb His punishment from him
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 263, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 106

Verse: He who suppresses his anger despite being able to vent it, Allah will fill his heart with peace and security on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 110, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 106

Verse: What a good dose anger is for he who can swallow it
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 109, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 106

Verse: O Ali, do not get angry, and if you do get angry, then sit down and reflect upon the power of your Lord over His creation and His clemency towards them in spite of it. And whenever anyone tells you [condescendingly] to fear Allah, expel your anger and remind yourself of your clemency.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 14; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 106

Verse: Remedy your anger with silence, and your carnal desire through your reason.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5155; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 106

Verse: Prophet Musa (a.s.) [addressed Allah] saying, 'O Lord, who are your special people whom You will shade with the shade of Your Throne on the day when no shade will avail except Your Shade?' So Allah revealed to him, '  and those who are angered when the things that I have prohibited are deemed lawful [by people], the way a leopard is angered when it is wounded!
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 11, p. 416, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 107

Verse: He (SAWA) [i.e. the Prophet] never used to get angry over worldly matters, but when he did get angry for the sake of the truth, he was unrecognisable and nothing could restrain his anger until he had triumphed in his case [for the truth].
VerseRef: al-Mahajjat al-Baydha, v. 5, p. 303; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 107

Verse: He who displays his ill-feeling towards the immoral people and gets angry for the sake of Allah, Allah will get angry for his sake and will render him well-pleased on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 107

Verse: The best of your brothers is the one who is roused to anger for your sake in [standing up for] what's right
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5009; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 158

Verse: The best of brothers is the one who does not let his fellow brothers need anyone other than himself.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4985; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 158

Verse: The most beloved of my brothers to me is he who confers my faults to me
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 282, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 159

Verse: The worst of brothers is he for whom one [is made] to go out of one's way.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 479; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 159

Verse: The Commander of the Faithful (AS) was asked, 'Which is the worst companion?' He replied, 'The one who glamorizes acts of disobedience to Allah to you.'
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 198, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 159

Verse: A man who takes a brother after careful selection is bound to have a lasting companionship and a firm amity, whereas a man who takes a brother without careful testing is bound to resort to the friendship of evil people.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, nos. 8921 and 8923; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 160

Verse: Test your brothers with two things, which they must possess; otherwise avoid them, avoid them, avoid them: observing the prayers at their prescribed times and helping brothers during hardship as well as ease.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 672, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 160

Verse: A believer is a mirror for his believing brother; he stays faithful to him in his absence and spares him from what he would hate to see.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 233, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 160

Verse: He who advises his brother in private adorns him, and he who advises him publicly makes him look bad.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74 p. 166, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 160

Verse: A man who observes bad behavior in his brother without forbidding him from it   whilst he is able to   has indeed betrayed him.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 65, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 160

Verse: Any person in my community who acts kindly towards his brother in faith, Allah will grant him the service of the servants of Paradise.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 206, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 161

Verse: A man who honors his believing brother when he comes to [visit] him is, by doing so, honoring Allah, Mighty and Exalted.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 298, no. 32; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 161

Verse: Let none of you compel his brother to ask, if you already know about his need.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74 p. 166, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 161

Verse: Allah helps the believer as long as the believer helps his brother.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74 p. 322, no. 89; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 161

Verse: A man who fulfils one need of his believing brother's Allah will fulfil one hundred thousand needs of his on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74 p. 89, no. 90; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 162

Verse: When one of you takes a brother, he must ask him his name, his father's name, his tribe and his address. This is part of true brotherhood, otherwise it is a foolish amity.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 166, no. 30; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 162

Verse: Meet your brother with a joyful face.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74 p. 171, no. 38; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 162

Verse: It is narrated in Bihar al-Anwar: When the Prophet (SAWA) missed the company of any of his brothers for three days, he would ask about him. If he was absent, he would pray for him; and if he was in town, he would visit him; and if he was ill, he would go to see him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 16, p. 233, no. 35; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 162

Verse: If it were not for the fact that it would inconvenience my community, I would have commanded them to brush their teeth before every prayer.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 22, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 163

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) also said in his advice to Imam Ali (AS), 'O Ali, you must brush your teeth as frequently as possible, for verily a single prayer that you perform after having brushed your teeth is better than forty days worth of prayers performed without doing so.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 137, no. 48; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 163

Verse: Gabriel continuously advises me about brushing teeth, that I really thought he would lay it down as an obligation.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 126, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 164

Verse: was once asked, 'Do you consider all of these people as being real human beings [true to their nature]?' to which he replied, 'Exclude from them the one who does not brush his teeth,
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 128, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 164

Verse: Brushing one's teeth increases one's articulacy.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 135, no. 48; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 164
