Verse: There are twelve distinctive features to brushing one's teeth: it is a recommended prophetic practice, it purifies one's mouth, brightens one's eyesight, pleases the Beneficent Lord, whitens the teeth, does away with wretchedness, strengthens one's gums, whets one's appetite for food, takes away phlegm, improves one's memory, multiplies one's rewards for good deeds, and gives pleasure to the angels.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 481, no. 53; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 164

Verse: You must brush your teeth for it removes whisperings of the heart.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 139, no. 52; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 164

Verse: Brushing one's teeth brightens the eyesight, increases hair growth, and removes the tendency for frequent weeping.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 137, no. 48; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 164

Verse: Self-admiration in one's knowledge is sufficient to be considered ignorance.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 56, no. 78; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 424

Verse: It suffices as ignorance to be unaware of one's status.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7050; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 424

Verse: Do not utter all that you know since that is enough to be considered ignorance.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10187; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 424

Verse: [Possessing] fear of Allah suffices as knowledge, and being conceited towards Him suffices as ignorance.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 379, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 424

Verse: Good naturedness is found in three things: abstaining from the forbidden, seeking the lawful and providing peace and comfort for your family.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 394, no. 63; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 170

Verse: Giving greetings comes from beautiful character.'
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3404; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 170

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) when he was asked about the meaning and bounds of good naturedness, said, 'Be lenient, make your words pleasant and meet your brother joyfully.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 253, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 170

Verse: I urge you towards the most noble traits for verily they are exalted and possess a high rank, and beware of [adopting] vile traits for verily they derogate noble people and destroy the famous and celebrated.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 53, no. 89; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 171

Verse: Guard your tongue, for verily this is a charitable act that you perform for your own sake.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 114, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 178

Verse: Abandoning evil [acts] is an act of charity.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 160, no. 168; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 178

Verse: A charitable act that Allah loves indeed is reconciling people when they have become estranged to one another, and bringing them close together when they have become distanced from each other.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 209, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 178

Verse: Making a deaf person hear without becoming irritated is a wholesome act of charity.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 388, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 178

Verse: The best form of charity is charity with one's tongue through which lives are spared, adversities repelled, and benefits attracted towards one's Muslim brother.
VerseRef: Qasas al-Anbiya' li al-Rawandi, p. 188, no. 235; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 179

Verse: Holy Prophet Muhammad al Mustaf? (s.a.w.w.) when asked about the best act of charity, replied, '[It is the act of charity] towards a kin against whom one harbours secret enmity.'
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 171, no. 18; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 179

Verse: The best form of charity is to cool down someone's internal heat [by quenching their thirst].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 96, p. 172, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 179

Verse: Your assistance of the weak is one of the best forms of charity.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, p. 414; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 179

Verse: Among the best means by which those who seek nearness to Allah may have recourse to His nearness, Blessed and most High, are: faith in Him and in His messenger  , giving charity secretly for verily it atones for one's misdeeds, and giving charity openly for verily it protects against an undignified death.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 110; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 180

Verse: Imam Muhammad ibn 'Ali al-Baqir (a.s.) describing his father Imam Zayn al-Abidin (AS), 'He used to go out in the dark night carrying a sack on his back and going from door to door, knocking on each and giving to whoever came out to answer it. He used to cover his face when giving to the poor in order that they may not recognise him.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 46, p. 89, no. 77; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 180

Verse: Whoever is ill-natured, his family is rendered weary of him.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8595; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 173

Verse: Do not give charity openly for people to see and commend you for it, for verily when you do that, you have already received your reward for it [in their commendation]. However, if you give with your right hand such that your left hand does not come to know it, then the One for whose sake you have secretly given charity will surely reward you for it openly.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 284, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 180

Verse: By Allah, charity given secretly is better than charity given openly, just as, by Allah, worship performed secretly is better than worship performed openly.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 8, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 180

Verse: Verily charity given at night [i.e. secretly in the dark of the night] extinguishes the wrath of the Lord, wipes away grave sins and facilitates one's account [on the Day of Resurrection]. Charity given during the day [in broad daylight] makes one's wealth thrive and increases one's lifespan.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 96, p. 125, no. 39; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 181

Verse: Do not give away of yourself to your brothers so much that the loss incurred by you supercedes the benefit to them.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 4, p. 33, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 181

Verse: Imam Zayn al-Abidin (AS) said in his supplication "and divert our hearts from every other act of remembrance through Your remembrance, our tongues from every other act of thanksgiving through [being preoccupied with] thanking You, our limbs from every other act of obedience through [being preoccupied with] obedience to You! If You have ordained for us idleness in an occupation, make it an idleness of safety, wherein no ill consequence visits us nor weariness overtakes us as a result! Then the writers of evil deeds may depart from us with a page empty of the mention of our evil deeds, and the writers of good deeds may leave us happy with the good deeds of ours which they have written".
VerseRef: al-Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya, Supplication 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 420

Verse: Imam Zayn al-Abidin (AS) said in his supplication'O Allah, bless Muhammad and his Household, and spare me the concerns which distract me, employ me in that which You will ask me about tomorrow, and let me pass my days [engaged] in that for which You have created me!
VerseRef: al-Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya, supplication 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 420

Verse: Imam Zayn al-Abidin (AS) said in his supplication and grant me health for the sake of worshipping [You], and idleness for the sake of reclusion.'
VerseRef: al-Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya, supplication 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 420

Verse: Imam Zayn al-Abidin (AS) said in his supplicationn on the day of `Aarafa, 'Let me taste, through some of Your boundless plenty, the flavour of being free for what You love, and striving in what brings about proximity with You and to You, and give me a gift from among Your gifts! Make my commerce profitable and my return without loss, fill me with fear of Your station, and make me yearn for the meeting with You.'
VerseRef: al-Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya, supplication 47; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 420

Verse: Verily Allah, most High, hates the servant who sleeps much; verily Allah, most High, hates the idle servant.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 3, p. 169, no. 3635; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 420

Verse: Ignorance is the worst affliction.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 820; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 421

Verse: Ignorance is death for the living and perpetuates wretchedness.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1464; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 421

Verse: Ignorance is the ruination of every affair.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 930; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 421

Verse: Ignorance is the root of every evil.'
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 819; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 421

Verse: You will not see an ignorant person except that he is either committing excess in what he does or falling short of what he ought to do.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 70; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 422

Verse: The ignorant is one whose desires have enslaved him.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3864; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 422

Verse: The deeds of the ignorant are doomed and his knowledge is error.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6327; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 422

Verse: Whoever has low tolerance will see his comfort reduce.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9192; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 174

Verse: Whoever is ill-natured, his sustenance will be straitened.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8023; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 174

Verse: If you are reduced to poverty, then trade with Allah through giving in charity.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 258; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 177

Verse: The ignorant is one who considers himself knowledgeable about what he is [in actual fact] ignorant of, and he is content with his own opinion. His attachment to scholars only increases his estrangement [from knowledge] since he is constantly finding fault with them. He deems invalid the views of those who oppose him, and that which he does not understand he sees as fallacious. If he comes across something that he does not know, he denies it and falsifies it saying, 'I have never heard of this!' or 'I do not see it as possible! or 'How can it be!' or 'Where is this from?' This is due to his confidence in his own opinion and the paucity of his awareness of his own ignorance.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 73; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 423

Verse: The attributes of the ignorant are that: he answers before listening, objects before understanding, and passes judgment on that which he does not know.
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, no. 303; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 423

Verse: The ignorant is a prisoner of his tongue.
VerseRef: al-Durrah al-Bahirah, no. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 423

Verse: The most ignorant of people is one who is deluded by the praise of a flatterer who beautifies evil to him and renders a sincere advice detestable.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3262; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 423

Verse: The utter extremity of ignorance is for one to glorify his own ignorance.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6371; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 424

Verse: The greatest form of ignorance is for a person to be ignorant of the condition of his own self.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2936; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 424

Verse: It suffices for one to be considered ignorant if he commits that which is forbidden.
VerseRef: Masalib al-Sa' ul, no. 55; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 424

Verse: Do not partake of the food of corrupt people.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 84, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 413

Verse: It is enough of a sin for a man to deem that which brings him close to his fellow brothers as burdensome, and it is enough of a sin for a people to deem burdensome that which draws a fellow brother close to them.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 186, no. 1533; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 414

Verse: If your brother comes to your house [uninvited] then offer him whatever you have in the house, and if you invite him, then make a special effort for him.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 179, no. 1506; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 414

Verse: The best aid for supplication is humility.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9945; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 417

Verse: I seek refuge in you from a soul which is never content, a stomach which is not satisfied and a heart which has no humility.
VerseRef: Iqbal al-A`amal, p. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 418

Verse: Agression leads its perpetrators to the Hellfire.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 327, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 88

Verse: Make sure that you never utter one aggressive word, even if you admire [the strength of] yourself and your tribe.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 327, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 88

Verse: Verily Allah, Mighty and Exalted, made the earth a purifier just as he made water a purifier
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 1, p. 109, no. 224; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 756

Verse: A man once invited the Commander of the Faithful, Ali (AS) for a meal, so Imam said to him, 'I will accept your invitation provided you fulfil three conditions.' The man asked, 'And what are they, O Commander of the Faithful?' to which he replied, 'Do not bring any special food from outside for me, do not preserve anything in the house especially for me, and do not impose any difficulty on your family.' The man replied, 'You shall have that O Commander of the Faithful' and Ali b. Abi Talib accepted his invitation.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 42, no. 138; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 414

Verse: Whoever wants to be loved by Allah and His Prophet should eat with his guest.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 116; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 414

Verse: When one of you is invited for a meal, he must not bring along his son with him too, for verily it is prohibited for him to do so and he enters the house unlawfully.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 181, no. 1515; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 414

Verse: A guest may expect to be honoured for two nights, then from the third night onwards he is considered to be one of the family and must eat whatever he gets.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 183, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 415

Verse: Hospitality towards a guest is incumbent for the first day, the second day and the third day. After that, anything you give him is considered as charity towards him on your behalf.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 183, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 415

Verse: Hosting a banquet the first day is reasonable, the second day is an act of courtesy, and any more than that is showing-off and seeking repute.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 368, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 415

Verse: When someone enters the house of his fellow brother, he must sit wherever the host tells him to sit for the owner of the house knows the flaws of his own house better than the guest.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 451, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 415

Verse: Ibn Abi Ya`afur narrated, 'I saw a guest once at Abi `Aabdillah's [i.e. Imam al-Sadiq (AS)] house, who stood up to get something he needed, so Imam refused for him to do so, and stood up to get it himself, saying, 'The Prophet of Allah (AS) prohibited that a guest be allowed to do work.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 283, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 415

Verse: Part of a Muslim's prosperity is living in spacious housing
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 526, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 416

Verse: A misfortunate way of life entails living in a cramped house.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 416

Verse: It is a distressful situation that man amasses what he does not eat and builds wherein he does not live, then he goes to Allah, most High, neither carrying the wealth with him, nor shifting the building!
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 114; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 416

Verse: Every building exceeding the bounds of sufficiency will be a dire curse on its owner on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 531, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 416

Verse: He who builds in addition to his own house [unnecessarily] will be made to bear its burden on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 446, no. 2531; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 416

Verse: In the tradition recounting the Prophet's Ascension, Allah says, 'No sooner does a servant come to know Me and humble himself before Me than everything is humbled before him.'
VerseRef: Irshad al-Qulub, p. 203; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 417

Verse: There are four distinguishing marks of the humble ones: they pay constant attention to Allah in private and in public, they carry out good works, they contemplate about the Day of Resurrection, and they engage in intimate supplication with Allah.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 418

Verse: One whose heart is humble, his limbs also humble themselves.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8172; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 418

Verse: The one to be the most harshly judged on the Day of Resurrection will be the capable yet idle [people]. If work is endeavor, idleness is corruptive.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 60; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 418

Verse: Verily Allah hates the healthy-bodied idle person, who is neither concerned with his worldly life, nor the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 17, p. 146; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 419

Verse: There are two things most people are tested with: health and idleness.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 152, no. 136; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 419

Verse: From idleness comes desire.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9251; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 419

Verse: Know that the world is a place of trial wherein there is no time a person can afford to be idle, for that time will be a source of regret for him on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 59; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 419

Verse: How deserving man is of having an hour where no one disturbs him!
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9684; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 419

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) was asked about noble moral traits, to which he replied, 'Pardoning someone who has oppressed you, repairing broken ties, giving to the one who has deprived you, and speaking the truth even if it is against yourself.'
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 191, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 171

Verse: The best noble moral trait is self-sacrifice

VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 48

VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 49

Verse: The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w.s.) got the news that some people of his community have applied saffron dye to their beards. The Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "This is Islamic way of dyeing and I want to meet them." Ali (a.s.) went to them and conveyed the message of the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.). They came to the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.). When the latter saw them, he said, "This is an Islamic way of dyeing." Amirul Momineen (a.s.) says that when they heard this, they developed a liking for dye and applied a red dye to their beard. When the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) got this news, he said, "This is the dye of faith, I would like to meet them." Amirul Momineen (a.s.) conveyed this message to those people and they gathered near the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.). On seeing them, the Holy Prophet (s.a.w.s.) said, "This is the dye of faith." After hearing this saying, those people continued this deed till they lived."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 49

Verse: The color of dye, which Allah likes the most is dark black.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 49

Verse: Spending a dirham for dye is equal to spending a hundred dirhams in the way of Allah. There are fourteen benefits of applying dye   it stops air from ears, improves eyesight, softens the root of nose, mouth smells good, jaws become strong, removes the odor of armpits, evil thoughts lessen, angels become happy, it is a cause of glad-tidings for a believer and suffering for a disbeliever, it is the cause of beauty, fragrance and avoidance of the hardships of grave and Munkir and Nakir would shy due to dye.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 49/50

Verse: "Henna keeps away odor from man, increases one's honor and prestige, fragrances one's mouth and makes the children virtuous." He further said, "One who applies henna from head to toe after using Noorah (depilatory made of lime) his poverty would end."
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 50

Verse: Black dye is the cause of beauty for women and a cause of defeat of enemies.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 50

VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, Page 50

Verse: It is narrated from Imam Ja'far Sadiq (a.s.) that Amirul Momineen (a.s.) said, "Noorah is an amulet and it cleans and purifies the body."

VerseRef: al-Ihtijaj, v. 1, p. 572, no. 137; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 72

VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 262, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 72

VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 138, no. 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 73

Verse: When Allah, Mighty and Exalted, will bring together the first and the last of people, a caller will rise and call out so that all people will hear. He will say, 'Where are those who loved each other for Allah' sake?' and a group of people will rise, and they will be told to enter Paradise without accounting.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 126, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 73

Verse: On the Day of Resurrection a group of people will rise; they will come to the gate of Paradise and they will knock at the gate of Paradise. Then they will be asked, 'Who are you?' And they will answer, 'We are the poor.' They will then be asked, '[Have you come] before the Reckoning?!' And they will answer, 'You did not give us anything to hold us accountable for!' Allah, Mighty and Exalted will then say, 'They speak the truth. Enter Paradise!
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 264, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 73

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) said, 'When the records are spread out and the scales set up, there will be no scales set up for the people of affliction, nor record spread for them.' Then he recited this verse: "Indeed the patient will be paid in full their reward without any reckoning
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 4, p. 481, no. 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 74

Verse: Truly Allah, Mighty and Exalted, will hold all the creatures to account except those who have associated a partner to Allah, for they will not be given the chance to account on the Day of Resurrection and will be ordered straight to the Fire.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 34, no. 66; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 74

Verse: Six [groups] will enter the Fire before any account because of six [reasons].' He was asked, 'O Messenger of Allah! May Allah's blessings be upon you! Who are they?' He replied, 'The rulers because of their tyranny, the Arabs because of their prejudice, the landowners because of their arrogance, the merchants because of their treachery, the villagers because of their ignorance, and the scholars because of their jealousy.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 127; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 74

Verse: Allah will make three [groups] enter the Fire without any account  an unjust leader, a lying merchant, and an adulterous old man.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 80, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 74

Verse: I enjoin you with action indeed, then to take it to its completion, then to maintain it regularly, then to persevere in its performance and then to be pious. Verily you have been destined for a great end, so betake yourselves to your destined end.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 176; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 75

Verse: He who lags behind as a result of his deeds will not be accorded a front position because of his lineage
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 23; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 75

Verse: The ignorant is one who has allowed himself to be deceived by his desires and whims.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1285; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 422

Verse: Do not be among those who hope for the Hereafter without acting   admiring the righteous people and yet not acting like them, and despising the sinners whilst he is one of them   he fears for others worse chastisement than what he himself deserves for his sin, and for himself hopes for greater than his actions deserve   When he acts he falls short of the action, and when he is asked something, he exaggerates   so he is presumptuous in his speech though performing little action.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 150; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 75

Verse: He from whom Allah accepts a single prayer, He will not punish, nor he from whom He accepts a single good deed.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 266, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 76

Verse: If you act but a little, you will enjoy many bounties.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 183]; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 76

Verse: People transact through wealth in this world and through deeds in the Hereafter
VerseRef: al-Durrah al-Bahirah, p. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 76

Verse: Act continuously, act continuously! For verily Allah has not decreed any end to the believer' s actions except death.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 1, p. 130, no. 177; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 76

Verse: The little that you perform continuously is weightier than the great amount that you perform odiously.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 278; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 77

Verse: There is nothing more beloved to Allah than the performance of an action that is maintained regularly, even if it be little.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 82, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 77

Verse: If a man performs a certain action, he should maintain it regularly for the duration of a year, then he may move on to another act if he wishes, and that is so that the grand Night of Ordainment (laylat al-qadr) is included in his year of performing that particular act, when whatever Allah wills therein happens
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 82, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 77

Verse: The best of deeds is the most difficult of them
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 191; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 78

Verse: The best of deeds is that which is most regular, even if be something small.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 63; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 78

Verse: The best of deeds in the sight of Allah is the happiness that you bring to a fellow believer, either by driving away his hunger or by relieving him of his distress
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 191, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 78

Verse: The best of deeds is that which you force yourself to do
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 69, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 78

Verse: The best of deeds is that whose objective is Allah' s pleasure.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2958; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 78

Verse: If work is endeavor, then continuous idleness is corruptive.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 419, no. 40; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 419

Verse: Verily the servant with an ill nature will be in the lowest reach of Hell.
VerseRef: al-Mahajjat al-Baydha, v. 5, p. 93; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 173

Verse: It was said to the Prophet (SAWA) that, 'Such and such a woman fasts during the days and stands for prayer during the nights, but she is ill-natured and insults her neighbours with her tongue', the Prophet (SAWA) then said, 'There is no good in her, she is of the people of the Hellfire.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 394, no. 63; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 173

Verse: Greed, voracity, and stinginess are a result of ignorance
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1694; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 421

Verse: Ignorance is an enemy.
VerseRef: al-Durrah al-Bahirah, no. 44; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 421

Verse: The ignorant is one who disobeys Allah, even if he is beautiful to look at and of great importance.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 1, p. 160, no. 39; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 421

Verse: The characteristic of an ignorant person is that he oppresses whoever he associates with, acts unjustly towards his subordinates, flatters his superiors, and his speech is without deliberation.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 422

Verse: An ignorant person does not see his own shortcomings and is not willing to accept any advice concerning them.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1809; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 422

Verse: "One night when the Prophet (a.s) was in Ayeshah's room, she asked him: "O' Prophet of Allah! Why is it that you always put yourself to so much trouble, even though all your past and future sins are forgiven?" He replied: "O' Ayeshah! Should I not be grateful?" Ayeshah said: "Allah's Prophet (a.s) always stood up on his toes." Then the following verse was revealed: "We have not sent down the Quran to thee to be (an occasion) for thy distress."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 7 on Contentment, Hadees 148

Verse: In Al-Mahasin it is narrated that Imam Baqir (a.s) said: "We find in (Imam) Ali ibn Abitalib's (a.s) book that Allah's Prophet (a.s) used to say the following when he gave a sermon on the mosque pulpit: "I swear by Allah who has no partners that no good of this world or the Hereafter has been granted to any believer, except due to his good opinion about Allah, his good behavior, and his avoidance of gossiping and slandering. And I swear by Allah who has no partners that Allah will not punish anyone after repentance and seeking forgiveness except due to his bad opinion about Allah, insufficient hope in Allah, bad behavior, and gossiping about believers. I swear by Allah who has no partners that there are no believers who have a good opinion about Allah and receive anything less than they expect from Him. This is so since Allah is Benevolent and has authority over all that is good, and is ashamed of one of his servants having a good opinion about Him and He acting otherwise. Therefore have a good opinion about Allah and be inclined to Him."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 8 on Having a Good Opinion About God, Hadees 149

Verse: : "Allah is present in the mind of whoever has a good opinion about Him. It is Allah who said: "But this thought of yours which ye did entertain concerning your Lord, hath brought you to destruction, and (now) have ye become of those utterly lost!." [The Holy Quran: Fussilat 41:23]
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 8 on Having a Good Opinion About God, Hadees 150

Verse: Jesus the son of Mary once sent two of his companions out to work. One returned thin like a dried stick and the other one returned and was chubby. Jesus asked the first one why he was thin. He said it was due to his fear of Allah. Then Jesus asked the one who was chubby for the reason he was chubby. He said it was due to his having a good opinion about Allah.
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 8 on Having a Good Opinion About God, Hadees 151

Verse: Imam Sadiq (a.s) quoted the following from Prophet David (a.s): : "O' Allah! One who does not have a good opinion about You has no faith in You even if he has gotten to know you."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 8 on Having a Good Opinion About God, Hadees 152

Verse: In Rauzat al-Vaezeen it is narrated that the Prophet of Allah (a.s) said: "Do not die and depart from this world until you have formed a good opinion about Allah, since this is the price for Heaven."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 8 on Having a Good Opinion About God, Hadees 153

Verse: The cause of enmity is lack of consideration [for others].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6302; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 268

Verse: Everything has a seed, and the seed of enmity is mockery.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, 7316; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 268

Verse: Two men who were imprisoned were freed during the time of the Prophet Moses (a.s). One of them was large and chubby, and the other one was very thin. Moses asked the chubby man the reason for his being fat. He replied: "From having a good opinion about Allah." Then he asked the other man the reason for being so skinny. He replied: "From fearing Allah." Then Moses (a.s) raised his hands towards the sky and asked Allah to inform him which of the two were nobler. Allah revealed to him that the one who had a good opinion about Allah was nobler.
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 8 on Having a Good Opinion About God, Hadees 154

Verse: In Al-Mahasin it is narrated that Imam Sadiq (a.s) quoted the following on the authority of his noble father (a.s): "Jesus, the son of Mary said: "Blessed be one who thinks when he is quiet; is admonished when he looks; invokes the name of Allah when he talks; cries over his own sins; and the people are safe from his hands and tongue."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 9 on Thinking, Hadees 155

Verse: Al-Hassan al-Sayghal said that he asked Imam Sadiq (a.s) about the meaning of what people say when they state that it is better to think for one hour than pray for one whole night. The Imam (a.s) replied in the positive saying that the Prophet (a.s) had said: "It is better to think for one hour than to pray for one whole night." Then he asked how one should think. The Imam (a.s) replied: "He should ask the following questions when he passes a house or the ruins of an old building: Where are the residents? Where are those who constructed this building? And why do they not speak?"
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 9 on Thinking, Hadees 156

Verse: Imam Sadiq (a.s) stated that Ameer al-Momineen (a.s) said : "O' son of Adam! Indeed thinking can attract one towards good deeds, and repentance can cause one to abandon evil deeds. Whatever is not lasting - even if it seems a lot to some people - will not harm what is lasting, even if it is rare and hard to get."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 9 on Thinking, Hadees 157

Verse: All good is contained in three traits: looking, being quiet and talking. If one does not get admonished when he sees things, he is in error. Not thinking when you are quiet equals ignorance, and any talk in which there is no remembrance of Allah is in vain.
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 9 on Thinking, Hadees 158

Verse: In Al-Mahasin it is narrated that Imam Sadiq (a.s) said: "A man went to the Prophet of Allah (a.s) and said that he had come to swear allegiance to Islam. Allah's Prophet (a.s) said: "So that you kill your father?" The man withdrew his hand and changed his mind. Later he returned and said he had come to swear allegiance to Islam. Allah's Prophet (a.s) said: "So that you kill your father?" The man said: "Yes." The Prophet (a.s) said "A believer sees his faith in his actions and an unbeliever sees his disbelief in his actions. I swear by Him who has control over my life! They do not realize their own position and learn a lesson from the evil deeds of the hypocrites and the infidels which are due to the disbelief."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 10 on on Faith and Islam, Hadees 159

Verse: Man's stomach is his enemy.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4424; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 268

Verse: He who conceals [the path] of proper conduct from you in making you follow that which you desire is indeed your enemy.
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, no. 309; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 268

Verse: Imam Sadiq (a.s) quoted the following on the authority of Ameer al-Momineen (a.s) : "There are certain signs by which religious people can be recognized. These are truthfulness, trustworthiness, fulfilling one's promise, observing the relations of kin, being kind with the weak ones, and the subordinates, minimal sexual intercourse with women, doing good deeds, being good-tempered, using knowledge, and doing whatever helps man approach Allah. Blessed be such people. They shall prosper, and have a good place to return to."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 10 on on Faith and Islam, Hadees 160

Verse: Imam Sadiq (a.s) reported the following on the authority of Ameer al-Momineen (a.s) : "No one shall experience real faith unless he realizes that he shall suffer from whatever he is to suffer, and he shall be safe from whatever he should be saved from. Indeed it is Allah who brings forth loss or gain."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 10 on on Faith and Islam, Hadees 161

Verse: When Imam Ali (a.s) was questioned about faith, he said "Allah has established faith on four pillars: perseverance, certitude, justice and Jihad."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 10 on on Faith and Islam, Hadees 162

Verse: Allah will grant material goods to both His friends and His enemies. But He will only grant faith to those whom He loves.
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 10 on on Faith and Islam, Hadees 163

Verse: Imam Sadiq (a.s) reported on the authority of his grandfather that Imam Ali (a.s) said that Allah's Prophet (a.s) said: Whoever performs ablution and prays properly, pays the alms tax, overcomes his anger, controls his tongue, seeks Allah's forgiveness for his sins, and guides his family members has indeed completed the real aspects of faith and the gates of Heaven are open to him."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 10 on on Faith and Islam, Hadees 164

Verse: "One day when the Prophet of Allah (a.s) saw Harith ibn Malik ibn al-Naemane al-Ansarie, he asked him: "O' Harith! How did you spent the night until the morning?" Harith replied: "O' Prophet of Allah! I spent the night until the morning as a true believer." The Prophet (a.s) said:
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 10 on on Faith and Islam, Hadees 165

Verse: Imam Sadiq (a.s) said the following regarding Allah's statement:
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 10 on on Faith and Islam, Hadees 166

Verse: Abdul-Mumin al-Ansari narrated "Allah has granted three things to believers: Nobility in the world and his religion, prosperity in the Hereafter, and dignity in the hearts of the people of the world."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 10 on on Faith and Islam, Hadees 167

Verse: "Do you want me to tell you who a believer is? A believer is one with whom the believers trust their lives and property. Do you want me to tell you who a Muslim is? A Muslim is one from whose hands and tongue other Muslims are safe. And an emigrant is one who abstains from doing evil deeds and does not do whatever Allah has forbidden him to do."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 10 on on Faith and Islam, Hadees 168

Verse: He who witnesses a misdeed and abhors it is as one who was absent thereat, whereas he who is absent from a misdeed and yet contents himself with it is as one who witnessed it.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 456; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 265

Verse: No, rather enjoin good even if you yourself do not practice it absolutely and prohibit wrong even if you yourself do not refrain from it absolutely.'
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 213; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 265

Verse: Verily I bring myself to prohibit people from that which I myself do not refrain from, or to enjoin them that which I myself have not performed before them.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3780; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 265

Verse: Allah curses those who enjoin good but abandon its practice, and those who prohibit wrong but commit it themselves.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 129; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 265

Verse: And prohibit wrong and abstain from it yourselves, for verily you have been commanded to prohibit wrong after abstention from it.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 105; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 266

Verse: Verily the one who enjoins good and prohibits wrong should possess three qualities: he should act upon that which he enjoins and abstain from that which he prohibits; he must be just with regards to what he enjoins and just with regards to what he prohibits; and he must be gentle in what he enjoins and gentle in what he prohibits.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 109, no. 79; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 266

Verse: He who sees wrong being done should redress the situation with his own hand, and if he cannot do so then with his tongue, and if he cannot do so then with his heart [disapproving the act], and that is the weakest level of faith.
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 3, p. 223, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 266

Verse: He who abandons the prohibition of wrong with his heart, his hand and his tongue is a dead man walking amongst the living
VerseRef: al-Tahdhib, v. 6, p. 181, no. 374; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 266

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) commanded us to meet the sinners with stern faces.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 59, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 267

Verse: It is honour indeed for a believer that when he sees wrong being done, Allah, Mighty and Exalted, knows his heart to have rejected it.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 60, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 267

Verse: Gabriel has not exhorted me against anything like he has exhorted me against showing enmity towards people.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 202, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 267

Verse: After idol-worship, I have not been prohibited with anything as significantly as I have been prohibited hostility towards people.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 42; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 267

Verse: Whoever shows hostility towards others, his gallantry wanes and his kindness vanishes.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 512, no. 1119; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 267

Verse: The peak of ignorance is showing enmity towards people.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5237; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 267

Verse: Your archenemy is your lower self that resides between your two sides.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, no. 259; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 268

Verse: The enemy with the weakest stratagem is he who openly displays his enmity.
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, no. 313; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 269

Verse: Whoever falls into a sleep of neglect of his enemy is jolted awake by his crafty schemes.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8672; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 269

Verse: He who overlooks [his enemy] is himself surely not overlooked.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 62; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 269

Verse: Never underestimate an enemy even if he be weak.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10216; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 269

Verse: He who reconciles with his enemy increases the numbers on his own side.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8230; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 269

Verse: He who reconciles with the opposition achieves his aim.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8043; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 269

Verse: Luqman Al Hakeem (a.s.) said in his advice to his son, 'O my son, let your weapons against your enemy with which you bring him to the ground be crafty persuasion and a [false] display of pleasure with him, and do not pursue him by running after him in case what you harbour within may become manifest to him leading him to prepare himself for you.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 532, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 270

Verse: If everything is determined by fate and destiny, then wherefore the sorrow?!
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 16, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 885

Verse: One of the prophets complained of his grief to Allah. So he commanded him to eat grapes
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 362, no. 2262; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 886

Verse: He who finds himself sorrowful for no reason should wash his head
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 120, no. 284; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 886

Verse: Abu Basir narrated, 'I once went to visit Abu `Abdillah [al-Sadiq] (AS) along with one of our companions. I said to him, 'O son of the Prophet! Could I but sacrifice myself for you. I grieve and become sorrowful without knowing the cause of that.' So Abu `Abdillah (AS) replied, 'Truly that sorrow and joy reaches you from us, for when sorrow or joy comes to us it comes to you too, for indeed we and you are all from the Light of Allah, Mighty and Exalted.'
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 93, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 886

Verse: It is narrated in Bihar al-Anwar that the scholar [al-Sadiq] (AS) was once asked about why a man may wake up in the morning feeling sad without knowing the reason for his sorrow. He said, 'If that happens to him then he should know that his brother is in sorrow, and similarly if he wakes up happy without a specific reason for that joy. And Allah's help do we seek with regard to the rights of the brothers.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 227, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 886

Verse: Allah, Mighty and Exalted, is worshipped through nothing like continuous sorrow.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 367; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 887

Verse: Truly Allah loves every sorrowful heart
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 99, no. 30; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 887

Verse: The believer wakes up in the morning sorrowful and sleeps at night sorrowful, and nothing suits him but that
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 287, no. 18; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 887

Verse: The breath of one who is saddened on our account and is grieved for the oppression done unto us is glorification, and his grief for our cause is worship
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 226, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 887

Verse: Verily the spirits neither merge with the body nor are they independent of it. Rather they are like a thin veil surrounding the body
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 61, p. 40, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 887

Verse: The spirit is a subtle form that envelopes a dense shell [i.e. the body].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 34, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 887

Verse: Love is when hearts harbour mutual affection due to the harmony between their spirits
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2057; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 888

Verse: The body experiences six different states: health, sickness, death, life, sleep and wakefulness, and so does the spirit. Its life is its knowledge and its death ignorance; its sickness is doubt whereas its health is certainty; its sleep is its negligence and its wakefulness is its consciousness
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 61, p. 40, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 888

Verse: when asked by his companion Abu Basir whether the spirit remains with the body during sleep or leaves it, replied, 'No, O Abu Basir, verily if the spirit were to leave the body it would never again return to it. It is actually like the sun that is fixed in its place in the centre of the sky, yet its rays extend out to the earth.
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 488, no. 1360; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 889

Verse: When man sleeps, the animal spirit within him remains with his body, and that which leaves it is the rational spirit
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 61, p. 43, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 889

Verse: Beware of suspicion, for verily suspicion is the greatest lie; and do not probe one another [for information] nor spy on one another
VerseRef: Sahih Muslim, no. 2563; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 889

Verse: Do not probe for flaws in believers, for a man that probes the flaws of his brother will have Allah probe his own flaws; and when Allah probes the flaws of a man, He will expose him even if he were inside his own home.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 355, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 890

Verse: Do not ask the woman who fornicates about her partner in the offense; for just like it was easy for her to commit fornication, so it will be easy for her to accuse an innocent Muslim.
VerseRef: al-Tahdhib, v. 10, p. 48, no. 177; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 890

Verse: Do not probe into the religiosity of people lest you remain without a friend
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 253, no. 109; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 890

Verse: When the Prophet (SAWA) would send an army with a commander that he did not fully trust, he used to send someone whom he trusted to report on the commander's conduct.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 11, p. 44, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 891

Verse: Five things must be judged with the benefit of the doubt: allegiance, marriage, inheritance, animal slaughtering, and testimonies. If the person appears to be trustworthy, his testimony must be accepted without investigating his inner thoughts
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 18, p. 213, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 891

Verse: Be liberal, but do not squander; and be calculating, but do not be parsimonious
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 18, p. 150; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 891

Verse: Squandering is the epitome of destitution.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 890; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 891

Verse: Squandering is a penniless companion
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1043; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 892

Verse: A man who takes pride in squandering will be humiliated by bankruptcy
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9057; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 892

Verse: Imam al-Sadiq (AS) said about the verse: "but do not squander wastefully"   '[It refers to] one who spends for other than the obedience of Allah, who is a squanderer; and one who spends in the path of good, who is economical
VerseRef: Tafsir al-`Ayyashi, v. 2, p. 288, no. 53; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 892

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) in answer to Abu Basir's question about the verse: "but do not squander wastefully"   'When a man spends all his money and remains penniless'. Abu Basir then asked, 'Is spending in such a way for something lawful still called squandering?
VerseRef: Tafsir al-`Ayyashi, v. 2, p. 288 no. 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 892

Verse: The person with the highest station in the sight of Allah is the one who fears Him the most.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 180, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 317

Verse: Three things provide salvation fear of Allah in private, as if you see Him, for verily even though you do not see Him, He surely sees you.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 7, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 318

Verse: The one who knows Allah the most is the one who fears Allah the most.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 393, no. 64; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 318

Verse: Fear is the garment of the gnostics.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 664; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 318

Verse: O son of Adam, you will always be with the good as long as fear [of Allah] is your motto and grief your cloak.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 115, no. 176; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 318

Verse: The believer lies between two fears, fear of a sin that he has committed in the past and does not know what action Allah has taken [with regards to it], and fear for the remainder of his life in which he does not know what destructive sins he may commit, therefore he always wakes up in the morning fearful and it is only fear that reforms him.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 71, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 318

Verse: Hope in Allah with such hope that it will not embolden you to disobey Him, and fear Allah with such fear that it will not cause you to despair of His mercy.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 384, no. 39; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 319

Verse: My father (AS) used to say, 'There is no believing servant except that in his heart are two lights, a light of fear and a light of hope, if they were each to be measured neither would exceed the other.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 67, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 319

Verse: The one who fears his Lord refrains from wrongdoing.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 309, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 319

Verse: A servant is not a believer until he is both fearful and hopeful, and he is not fearful and hopeful until he acts in accordance with what he fears and what he hopes for.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 392, no. 61; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 319

Verse: The fearful one is he whose dread has not left him with a tongue with which to speak.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 244, no. 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 319

Verse: Do not fear the reproach of blame on the path of Allah.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 526, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 322

Verse: When you fear a matter, dive straight into it for verily the intensity of your wariness of it is greater than what you actually fear.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 175; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 322

Verse: If you fear the difficulty of a situation, be hard and firm in front of it and it will lower [in difficulty] for you, and wittingly deceive the problems of the age and they will become easy for you.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4108; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 322

Verse: The one who does not fear anyone will never ever fear.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8955; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 323

Verse: If you enter a place which you fear, then recite this verse, "My Lord! Admit me with a worthy entrance, and bring me out with a worthy departure, and render me a favourable authority from yourself" [Qur'an 17:80], and if you see someone whom you fear, then recite Ayat al-Kursi [The verse of the Throne in the Holy Qur'an, 2:255-257].'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 237, no. 37; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 323

Verse: Whoever does not fear Allah with regards to small matters will not fear Allah with regards to large matters.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 174, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 323

Verse: Verily the one who remembers Allah will never be struck by lightning
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 375, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 776

Verse: was once asked a question by a man, to which he duly replied, and to which the man then retorted, 'The jurists do not say this!' The Imam said, 'Woe unto you! Have you ever seen a jurist?! A real jurist is a person who is ascetic from this world, who craves for the Hereafter, and strongly holds onto the tradition of the Prophet (SAWA).'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 70, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 496

Verse: There is no man from among you who will become a jurist until they understand the intents of our speech.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, v. 2, p. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 496

Verse: Among the signs of a jurist are clemency, knowledge, and silence.
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, p. 232; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 496

Verse: One jurist is more powerful over Satan than one thousand worshippers.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 1, p. 177, no. 48; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 496

Verse: A person educated in religion is more difficult for Satan to bear than the worship of one thousand worshippers.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 1, p. 213, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 497

Verse: When a jurist believer dies a void is left in Islam that nothing can ever again fill.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 38, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 497

Verse: No believer's death makes Satan happier more than the death of a jurist.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 38, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 497

Verse: Justice is the base that supports the whole world.
VerseRef: Masalib al-Sa' ul, p. 61; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 498

Verse: Allah, Glory be to Him, made justice a support for mankind, an eliminator of wrongs and sins, and an elevator of Islam.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4789; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 498

Verse: Justice is the support of the masses and the beauty [adorning] the governors.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1954; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 498

Verse: Justice is the shield of the nations.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1873; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 498

Verse: The masses behave righteously through justice.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4215; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 498

Verse: Blessings are multiplied through justice.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4211; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 498

Verse: Among what Allah, the Exalted, revealed to Prophet Moses: 'I have not created anything as dear to Me as My believing servant, so when I try him, I do so for his own good, and I make him prosper for his own good, and I shield him for his own good. And I know best what improves My servant, so let him endure My trial and be thankful for My favors, and be content with My decree, and I will record him among the righteous
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 331, no. 14; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 662

Verse: Allah does not try anyone with anything as [severe as] respite [i.e. a false sense of security].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 383, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 663

Verse: Poverty is part of the trial, and worse than that is the sickness of the body, and worse than that is the sickness of the heart.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 146, no. 240; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 663

Verse: Whoever is plagued by one of three things wishes to die: continuous poverty, a disgraceful wife, and an overpowering enemy
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 318; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 663

Verse: Salvation comes at the peak of the ordeal
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 12, no. 70; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 663

Verse: When an ordeal is added to another, relief will result from the ordeal
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 357; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 664

Verse: During every hardship, say, 'There is no power or strength save in Allah, the High and the Great' (La Hawla wa La quwwata illa billah al- `Aliy al-`Adhim) and you will surmount it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, 77, p. 270, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 664

Verse: I saw my father in a dream, saying, 'Son, whenever you are in hardship, say abundantly, 'O Kind! O Merciful!' (Ya ra'ufu Ya rahim) Indeed, what you see in a dream is the same as what you see when you are awake.
VerseRef: Muhj al-Da`awat, p. 333; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 664

Verse: When you see people in ordeal, praise Allah without letting them hear you, lest it saddens them.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 34, no. 18; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 664

Verse: When you see a man in ordeal, say three times, without letting him hear you: 'Praise to Allah Who spared me what He tried you with, though He could have if He willed it so'. He said, 'Whoever says this will never be afflicted with that ordeal
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar,v.71,p.34, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 665

Verse: Indeed I have not seen anything like Paradise, the seeker whereof is sleeping, nor have I seen anything like the Fire, whose escapee is sleeping.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 665

Verse: Paradise is the best goal
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1024; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 665

Verse: Paradise is the abode of security.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 397; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 665

Verse: Verily there is no price for your soul except for Paradise, so do not sell it for anything else
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 13, no. 71; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 665

Verse: The price for Paradise is righteous deeds
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4698; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 666

Verse: The price for Paradise is abstention from the world
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4700; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 666

Verse: Saying 'There is no god but Allah' is the price for Paradise.
VerseRef: al-Tawhid, p. 21, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 666

Verse: The most effective way my community will enter Paradise is through God wariness and good character.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 100, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 666

Verse: Whoever meets Allah with three things will enter Paradise from any door he likes: good character, fear of Allah in public as well as in solitude, and desisting from disputation even when in the right
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 300, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 666

Verse: Would you all love to enter Paradise?' They replied, 'Yes, O Prophet of Allah.' He said, 'Shorten your expectations, fix your eyes on death, and feel ashamed in front of Allah to the extent one ought to.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 272; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 667

Verse: Whoever meets his end in jih?d for the sake of Allah, even for a moment equal to the gasping of a camel, will enter Paradise.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 2, p. 122, no. 1604; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 667

Verse: There are three things which if a person performs even one, Allah will make Paradise incumbent upon him: to give charity when one is needy oneself, cheerfulness with the whole world, and being just in spite of one's self
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 103, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 667

Verse: Through trials one attains Paradise.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4204; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 667

Verse: Paradise is surrounded by trials and patience. So whoever endures trials in the world will enter Paradise. Hell is surrounded by pleasures and desires. Thus, whoever allows himself its pleasures and desires [of the world] will enter the Fire.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 89, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 668

Verse: Whoever asks Allah for Paradise but does not endure tribulations has in fact ridiculed himself.
VerseRef: al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 356, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 668

Verse: Whoever safeguards, for my sake, what is between his beard [i.e. his tongue] and what is between his legs [i.e. his private parts], I will safeguard Paradise for him
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 411, no. 99; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 668

Verse: Verily the one whom Allah is most pleased with from among you is the one who is the most generous towards his dependents.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 136, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 602

Verse: When you are invited to weddings, take your time [in attending] for they incite remembrance of this world's pleasures, and when you are invited to funerals, hasten to attend for they incite remembrance of the Hereafter
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 279, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 602

Verse: Above every act of piety is yet a greater act of piety until a man is killed in the way of Allah, and when he is killed in the way of Allah, there is no act of piety greater
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 348, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 603

Verse: The most dignified way to die is to be martyred
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 100, p. 8, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 604

Verse: I wish that I may fight in the way of Allah and be killed in the way of Allah, then fight again and be killed again many times over
VerseRef: Sahih Muslim, no. 1876; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 604

Verse: Nobody who dies and who has a good position with Allah that pleases him ever wishes to return back to this world, not even to be given the world and all that is in it, except the martyr, for he wishes to return to it in order that he may be martyred again because of the virtue that he has seen in martyrdom.
VerseRef: Sahih Muslim, no. 1877; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 604

Verse: Verily if you are not killed then you are going to die anyway, and I swear by the One Who holds Ali's soul in His Hand, a thousand strikes of the sword on one's head is easier to bear than to die in one's bed
VerseRef: Kitab al-Irshad, v. 1, p. 238; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 604

Verse: Whoever sincerely asks Allah to grant him martyrdom, Allah makes him attain the station of the martyrs, even if he dies in his own bed
VerseRef: Sahih Muslim, no. 1909; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 605

Verse: Whoever dies loving the household of Muhammad dies a martyr.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 68, p. 137, no. 76; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 605

Verse: Many a speech is answered by silence.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5303; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 110

Verse: Whoever dies accepting our guardianship during the occultation of the one who will rise up [the awaited twelfth Imam, al-Mahdi], Allah will grant him the reward of a thousand such martyrs as died in the battles of Badr and Uhud
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 173, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 605

Verse: Merits come through good perfection [of character] and noble actions, and not through excess money and eminent feats.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1925; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 606

Verse: The merit of chiefs lies in the goodness of their worship.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6559; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 606

Verse: So the pious among them are the people of merits; their speech is truth and their dress [attitude] is moderate.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 193; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 606

Verse: He who lifts his head [i.e. holds himself] from misjudging has acquired the sum of all the merits.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5139; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 606

Verse: He who is good to one who does bad to him has attained all merits.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8905; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 607

Verse: Be forgiving with your power, generous in spite of your own hardship and effective in spite of your own neediness, and your virtue will be perfected.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7179; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 607

Verse: When the Day of Judgment comes Allah, Blessed and most High, will gather the first and the last of creation in one place. A caller will cry out, 'Where are the people of merit?' The Imam then said, 'Then a handful of people will rise, and the angels will receive them asking them, 'What were your merits?' They will say, 'We used to visit those who cut us off, give to those who deprived us, and forgive those who oppressed us.' It will then be said to them, 'You have spoken the truth. Enter Paradise.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 107, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 607

Verse: There are four types of merits: the first is wisdom, and its basis is thinking. The second is chastity, and its basis is desire. The third is power, and its basis is anger. The fourth is justice, and its basis is moderation in the faculties of the self.
VerseRef: Kashf al-Ghamma, v. 3, p. 138; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 607

Verse: Fairness is the best of merits.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 805; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 607

Verse: Safeguarding the tongue and spreading goodness [to others] are among the best merits of the human
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4899; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 607

Verse: There is not merit greater than goodness [to others].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10625; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 608

Verse: The fountainhead of merits is the overpowering of anger, and the eradication of desire
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5237; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 608

Verse: The peak of merits is knowledge
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6379; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 608

Verse: Those among you who have the best status with Allah, most High, are those who prolong their hunger and contemplation. Those of you who are most hated by Allah, most High, are those who sleep, eat and drink excessively.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 100; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 608

Verse: He who answers regarding all that is asked is mad.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 238, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 110

Verse: O people! The most virtuous of people is he who is humble from loftiness, abstains from [accumulating] wealth, is fair in spite of his strength and forgiving in spite of his power. Verily, the most virtuous of people is a servant who takes what suffices him from this world, takes self-restraint as his companion therein, prepares his provisions to leave [this world], and is ready for the journey [to the Hereafter].
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, p. 337, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 608

Verse: The most virtuous of Allah's servants according to Allah is a just leader, who is guided and guides [others], and who has established the known tradition, and abolished the unknown innovations
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 164; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 609

Verse: The most virtuous of people according to Allah is he to whom action in accordance with what is right is most beloved - even if it damages and worries him   rather than what is false, even if it gives him benefit and increases him.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 609

Verse: When the Prophet (SAWA) saw a she-camel, whose knees were tied up, carrying her load, he said, 'Where is her owner? Tell him that he should prepare for the lawsuit tomorrow [the Day of Resurrection].'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 7, p. 276, no. 50; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 107

Verse: Verily Allah loves gentleness and He aids in implementing it, so when you ride a lean animal, dismount it at the right place for if the land is barren and arid then get away from it and if the land is lush and fertile then dismount the animal [and allow it to rest].
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 120, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 108

Verse: The animal has six rights over its owner: once the owner has dismounted the animal he should allow it to graze, he should give it access to water if they pass by it, he should not hit the animal except when it truly deserves it, he should not burden it with a load that it cannot bear, he should not overtask it with a journey that it cannot endure and he should not sit on it for lengthy periods of time.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 8, p. 258, no. 9393; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 108

Verse: Do not hit animals on their faces for verily they praise and glorify Allah.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 6, p. 538, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 108

Verse: Verily a woman was chastised for the fact that she tied up a cat and left it till it died of thirst.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 1, p. 280, no. 864; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 109

Verse: Where there are several answers, the correct one will remain hidden.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 243; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 110

Verse: Sometimes even the eloquent fails to come up with an answer.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5378; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 110

Verse: He who rushes to give answers will not perceive the truth.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8640; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 110

Verse: One of the proofs of virtue is giving correct answers.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9417; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 110

Verse: Leave sharpness and reflect instead on the argument, and avoid idle talk in order to be safe from error
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5136; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 110

Verse: If you remain clement with the ignorant, you give him indeed an adequate answer.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4104; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 110

Verse: Allah despises the adulterous old man, the wealthy oppressor, the arrogant pauper, and the persistent beggar; He nullifies the reward of the bragging doner, and he hates the blatantly insolent liar.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 42; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 111

Verse: Allah despises anyone who is ill-mannered, swaggering [in his gait], frequenting the markets, a corpse by night, [sleeping] like a donkey during the day, knowledgeable about this world, but ignorant about the Hereafter
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 28, no. 24; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 111

Verse: Allah despises a man who does not fight intruders in his home.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 28, no. 43679; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 111

Verse: Allah, the Exalted, despises the insolent man who is audacious [in committing] acts of disobedience.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3437; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 111

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) used to say, 'Allah despises the one who frowns at the faces of his brethren.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 8, p. 321, no. 9552; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 112

Verse: Allah despises the vile person who displays his vices publicly.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 383, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 112

Verse: The most despised, by Allah, from among you are those who roam about gossiping and separating brothers, and seeking out flaws in innocent people.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 383, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 113

Verse: The person most despised by Allah from among all His creatures is the backbiter.'
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3128; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 113

Verse: The person most despised by Allah, the Exalted, from among His creatures is the one whose greatest concerns are [sating the appetite of] his stomach and his private parts
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3294; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 113

Verse: The person most despised by Allah, the Exalted, is the ignorant one.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3359; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 113

Verse: The person most despised by Allah, the Exalted, is the overbearing scholar
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3164; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 114

Verse: Moses (AS) said, 'O Lord! Who do You despise the most from among Your servants?' He replied, 'The one who [sleeps like] a corpse by night and is idle during the day.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 180, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 114

Verse: The person most despised from among Allah's creatures is a man whose [sharp] tongue people are wary of.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 323, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 114

Verse: Nothing is more despised by Allah than a full stomach
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 36, no. 89; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 115

Verse: Allah can fulfill people's needs through means in the hands of other people. Whoever gets what he needs should be content, patient and accept it from Allah.
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 7 on Contentment, Hadees 142

Verse: With the profusion of the intellect, clemency flourishes.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4274; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 188

Verse: People gather together either out of consent or displeasure. If they are pleased with an affair, they will commit themselves to it. But if they are displeased with an affair, they will abandon it.
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 7 on Contentment, Hadees 143

Verse: Imam Reza (a.s) quoted on the authority of his noble grandfather (a.s):  "A group of people went to visit Allah's Prophet (a.s) in one of the battles. The Prophet (a.s) asked them from which tribe they were. They told him that they were of the believers. He asked them about the degree of their faith. They replied: "We are patient during times of hardship, we are grateful during times of poverty, and we are content with what Allah has destined for us." The Prophet (a.s) said: "Those people are so wise and knowledgeable that they are nearly in the position of Prophets." Then he faced them and said: "Then if you are what you claim to be, do not build what you will not live in; do not collect what you will not eat; and fear Allah to whom is your return."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 7 on Contentment, Hadees 144

Verse: Perseverance and contentment with divine destiny are the highest forms of Allah's worship. Allah will only destine what is beneficial for those who are patient and content with what Allah destines for them-whether they like it or not.
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 7 on Contentment, Hadees 145

Verse: One of the companions of Imam Sadiq (a.s) went to see him. The Imam (a.s) was seriously ill and near death. He saw that the Imam (a.s) was very weak, and he cried. Imam Sadiq (a.s) asked why he cried. He said: "Should I not cry seeing you this way?"  "Do not cry. Believers are always receiving what is good for them. Be it they lose a part of their body, or they become the owner of whatever lies between the East and the West, it is good for them."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 7 on Contentment, Hadees 146

Verse: : "Being grateful for Allah's blessings is not committing divinely forbidden acts."
VerseRef: Mishkat ul-Anwar, Section 1 on Faith, Islam & Related Issues, Chapter 7 on Contentment, Hadees 147

Verse: Beware of antagonistic dispute for verily it corrupts the heart and engenders hypocrisy.
VerseRef: Hilyat al-Awliya, v. 3, p. 184, no. 235; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 267

Verse: Self-admiration is the opposite of proper conduct, and is the bane of the hearts.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 74; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 831

Verse: Self-admiration corrupts reason
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 726; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 832

Verse: Self-restraint protects the soul from all sides and keeps it away from base things
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1989; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 834

Verse: The zakat of beauty is chastity.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5449; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 834

Verse: If you are not of the clement ones then feign clemency for verily few people who imitate a group fail to become one of them.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 207; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 188

Verse: The clement one is he who tolerates his brother.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1111; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 188

Verse: A man cannot be a worshipper until he is clement.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 111, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 188

Verse: Incumbent upon you is clemency for verily it is the fruit of knowledge.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6084; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 188

Verse: Clemency and forbearance are two twins that produce great resolution.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 460; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 189

Verse: One who is clement has the upper hand.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 208, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 190

Verse: One who is clement with his enemy is victorious.
VerseRef: Kanz al-Fawa' id li al-Karajiki, v. 1, p. 319; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 190

Verse: Verily the first recompense from the qualities of the clement person is that the people will assist him against the ignorant one.
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 319, no. 897; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 190

Verse: Clemency in the midst of severe anger will protect one from the anger of the Almighty.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1776; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 190

Verse: Clemency suffices as a helper.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 112, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 190

Verse: Imam Hasan ibn 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when asked about clemency, said, '[It is] suppressing one's anger and controlling oneself.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 102, no. 7402; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 190

Verse: The clement person is unknown until he is angered.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 178, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 191

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when asked about the most clement person, said, 'The one who does not become enraged.'
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 322, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 191

Verse: The man who finds his clemency in the midst of his anger amazes me.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 112, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 191

Verse: He who has confidence in the fact that whatever sustenance Allah has apportioned for him will definitely reach him has secured comfort for his heart.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8763; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 191

Verse: A compatible wife is one of the two main comforts.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1633; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 191

Verse: He who restricts himself to what is just sufficient for maintenance has secured comfort and leads a carefree life.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 371; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 191

Verse: The greatest comfort lies in practicing abstemiousness in this world.
