VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1316; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 192

Verse: Tranquility and comfort lie in satisfaction and certainty, whereas worry and sorrow lie in doubt and dissatisfaction.
VerseRef: Mishkat al-Anwar, no. 34; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 192

Verse: Absolute tranquility lies in despairing of [any favours from] people.
VerseRef: Mishkat al-Anwar, no. 184; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 192

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) addressing his companions, 'Do not wish for the impossible.' They retorted, 'Who ever wishes for the impossible?' to which he replied, 'You do. Do you not wish for comfort in this world?' They replied, 'Yes', so he (AS) said, 'Comfort is impossible for the believer to secure in this world.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 81, p. 195, no. 52; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 192

Verse: Practice the various trades, for there is in them independence for you from what is in the hands of others, and indeed Allah loves the one gainfully engaged in a profession.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 12, p. 4, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 193

Verse: Trading enhances the intellect
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 148, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 193

Verse: Abandoning trading diminishes the intellect.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 148, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 193

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.), when the clothes merchant, Mu`adh ben Kathir told him, 'I intend to leave the market while I have some money in hand', said, 'Then regard for you will fall and you will not be sought for help with anything
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 149, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 193

Verse: Whoever sells or buys must avoid five habits, or he should not sell or buy at all: usury, [false] oaths, hiding the defects [of merchandise], praising what he sells, and showing disapproval for what he intends to buy.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 103, p. 95, no. 18; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 193

Verse: A good action is easier [to do] than a bad one.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam,. no. 1199; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 351

Verse: All of goodness lies in the awe of Allah.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 122; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 352

Verse: Three things sum up all of goodness: bestowing of favours, maintaining covenants and pacts, and strengthening blood-kinship.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4675; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 352

Verse: All of goodness is contained in those actions which remain, and in contempt for all that is transient.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam,. no. 4735; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 352

Verse: All of goodness is in friendship for the sake of Allah, enmity for the sake of Allah, love for the sake of Allah and hate for the sake of Allah.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam,. no. 4781; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 352

Verse: I saw goodness in its entirety was summed up in cutting off one's greed for other people's possessions.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 171, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 352

Verse: Goodness in its entirety is man's guarding over himself.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 278; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 352

Verse: Verily Allah loves those good actions which are hastened towards.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 142, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 356

Verse: There are four things which when given to someone, they have indeed been given the good of this world and the Hereafter: a persevering body, a remembering tongue, a thankful heart and a righteous wife.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 2, p. 414, no. 2338; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 353

Verse: The good of this world and the Hereafter has been brought together in the concealing of secrets and the befriending of good people.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 74, p. 178, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 353

Verse: There are three things which if one possesses, they have been endowed with the good of this world and the Hereafter. They are: contentment with [Allah's] decree, patience in the face of tribulation, and thankfulness in times of ease.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4670; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 353

Verse: The best matters are those of the middle way.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 292, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 357

Verse: Allah   glory be to Him - does not give His servant any good of this world or the Hereafter except as a result of his good nature and good intention.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam,. no. 9670; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 353

Verse: There are four things which when given to someone, they have indeed been given the good of this world and the Hereafter: truthful speech, fulfilment of trust, restraint in [filling] one's stomach, and a good nature.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam,. no. 2142; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 353

Verse: Goodness does not lie in the increase of your wealth and of your progeny, rather goodness lies in the increase of your knowledge, and the heightening of your clemency, and in your vying with other people in the worship of Allah. If you do good then you should praise Allah, but if you commit evil then seek forgiveness from Allah.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 94; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 354

Verse: Absolute goodness that is untainted with evil is being thankful for bounties and having patience in calamity.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 234; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 354

Verse: When Allah wants good for a servant, He makes him proficient in the knowledge of religion, induces him to abstain from the world and gives him insight into his own faults.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 80, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 354

Verse: When Allah wants good for a servant, He inspires him with contentment and gives him a righteous spouse.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4115; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 355

Verse: Verily when Allah wants good for a servant, He marks his heart with a white spot so that his heart is occupied with seeking the truth, then He is faster at fulfilling your needs than a bird flying to its nest.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 292, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 355

Verse: Verily when Allah   Blessed and most High   wants a community to remain and thrive, He endows them with aspiration and chastity.
VerseRef: al-Durr al-Manthur, v. 3, p. 270; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 355

Verse: When Allah wants good for a household, He makes them proficient in the knowledge of religion, He causes the younger ones from among them to revere the elders, He bestows them with moderation in their livelihood and with economy in their spending, He gives them insight into their faults, thus causing them to repent, and when He wants other than that [i.e. good for them] then He leaves them unattended.
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 356

Verse: He for whom a door of goodness is opened must seize the opportunity for verily he does not know when it will close.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 165, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 356

Verse: Rush to undertake good actions before you are preoccupied with other things.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 620, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 356

Verse: My father used to say, 'When you intend to do a good thing, then hasten to undertake it for you do not know what will happen.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 142, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 356

Verse: The best of matters are the religious obligations and the worst of them are the innovations.
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, p. 342; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 356

Verse: The best of matters are those with the best outcomes.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 395, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 357

Verse: The best of matters are those that are easy to start, pleasant to finish and whose outcome is praiseworthy.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5032; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 357

Verse: Excellent chastity, and satisfaction with the bare necessities are among the pillars of faith.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4838; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 291

Verse: The strongest of bonds is the stance of Godwariness
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 33; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 292

Verse: A part of faith is that which is firm and steadfast in the hearts, and another part is that which remains temporarily in the hearts and the breasts up until a certain time.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 189; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 292

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) when asked what consolidates a servant's faith, replied, 'The thing that consolidates it in him is piety, and that which takes him out of it [i.e. faith] is greed.'
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 9, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 292

Verse: Faith is only consolidated in him through action, and action is a part of it.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 38, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 292

Verse: A servant will never savour the taste of faith until he abandons lying, both in jest and earnestness.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 249, no. 14; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 293

Verse: A servant will never savour the taste of faith until he knows that that which afflicts him would never have missed him, and that that which has missed him would never have touched him, and that the only One to induce harm and benefit is Allah, Mighty and Exalted.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 58, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 293

Verse: Man will never taste the reality of faith until he possesses three qualities: understanding of religion, perseverance in calamities, and a good assessment of his income.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 85, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 293

Verse: He whose greatest concern is fulfilling his own desires has the sweetness of faith wrested from his heart.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 6, p. 116; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 294

Verse: It is prohibited for your hearts to experience the sweetness of faith until they abstain from this world [i.e. its pleasures].
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 128, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 294

Verse: The most basic level of infidelity is for a man to hear a fellow brother say something and memorize it for future use against him in order to shame him with it. Those are worthless people indeed.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 193, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 294

Verse: The servant can come out of faith through five means, all resembling each other: infidelity, polytheism [i.e. associating anything with Allah], straying from the truth, immorality, and embarking on committing grave sins.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 330; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 294

Verse: Two traits can never be found at the same time in a believer: miserliness and pessimism about one's sustenance.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 172, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 295

Verse: Two traits can never be found at the same time in a believer: avarice and ill-naturedness.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 173, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 295

Verse: The believer can be predisposed to any trait, but he cannot be predisposed to lying or treachery.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 55; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 295

Verse: Six things cannot be found in a believer: [a feeling of] hardship, anxiety, jealousy, disputatiousness, dishonesty, and aggression.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, p. 377; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 295

Verse: Verily Allah, exalted be His praise, says: 'By My Might and Exaltedness, I have not created any creature more beloved to Me than My believing servant.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 158, no. 75; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 296

Verse: The believer is more sanctified than the Ka`ba.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 27, no. 90; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 296

Verse: The similitude of the believers in their mutual love, affection and compassion for one another is as one body   if a single limb ails then the rest of the body suffers in insomnia and fever.
VerseRef: Musnad Ibn Hanbal, v. 6, p. 379, no. 18408; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 296

Verse: Holy Prophet Muhammad al Mustaf? (s.a.w.w.) said, describing the believer, '[He is] subtle in his movements, sweet to look at  he seeks out the loftiest of matters, and has the most outstanding moral ethics  he is not prejudiced against he whom he does not like, nor biased in favour of one he loves  he is hardly a burden, and instead is very helpful  he perfects his actions as if he is being watched, lowers his gaze, is liberal in his giving, and never turns away a beggar  he considers his words carefully and guards his tongue  he neither accepts falsehood from a friend, nor rejects the truth from an enemy  he only learns in order that he might know, and he only seeks to know in order that he may act  When he travels with worldly people, he is the smartest of them, and when he travels with the people of the Hereafter, he is the most pious from among them.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 67, p. 310, no. 45; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 298

Verse: The believer is such that his joy is evident on his face whereas his sorrow is in his heart. His breast is at its widest [i.e. biggest heart] but his ego is at its lowest. He despises high rank and shuns reputation. His grief is long-lasting and his ambition is lofty. His silence is much and his time occupied. He is grateful, extremely patient, and immersed in deep thought. He is thrifty with his needs. He is good-natured and mild-tempered. His soul is firmer than steel whilst he [i.e. his ego] remains lower than a slave.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 69, p. 410, no. 127; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 299

Verse: The believer is grateful in times of prosperity, patient during tribulation, and fearful in times of ease.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1743; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 299

Verse: The believer is gullible and kind, secure from his own lower self, yet wary and distressed [on account of it].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1901; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 299

Verse: The believer is he who has purified his heart of all that is base.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1956; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 299

Verse: The believer is he who protects his religion by putting his world at stake, whereas the impudent one is he who protects his worldly affairs by putting his religion at stake.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2160; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 299

Verse: The believer is silent in order that he remains safe, and speaks [only] in order to benefit.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 231, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 299

Verse: The believer is a great helper, and a very light burden. He is good at economising for his livelihood, and is never stung twice [i.e. never makes the same mistake again].
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 241, no. 38; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 300

Verse: Obedience to Allah cannot be attained except by one who possesses earnestness and exerts himself to the utmost.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6009; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 493

Verse: Know that between Allah and His creation there is no proximal angel, nor prophet, nor anything else [to intervene], except for their obedience to Him. So strive to obey Allah!
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8 p. 7, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 494

Verse: The most diligent of people is he who abandons sins.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 28, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 494

Verse: The best jihad is performed by one who awakes in the morning with no intention to wrong anyone.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 456, no. 1053; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 494

Verse: When someone addressed Imam al-Baqir (AS), saying, 'I am weak in my worship, praying and fasting but a little, though I strive to eat only that which is permissible, and be sexually intimate with only those whom it is permissible', the Imam replied, 'What jihad is there better than restraint of the stomach and the private parts?!
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 455, no. 1052; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 494

Verse: The best of worship is the study of religion.
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 1, p. 93, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 495

Verse: Learn the Quran for it is the best of speeches, and study it for it is the spring of the hearts.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 110; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 495

Verse: The superiority of a learned person over a worshipper is as the superiority of the sun over the planets, and whoever does not educate themselves in their religion, Allah will not accept a single deed from them.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 321, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 495

Verse: A person will not be totally educated until he sees people like camels, so he should not be amused by their presence and it should not change him, just as the presence of a [real] camel does not change him. Then he must return to his self and become the greatest humiliator of his self.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 304, p. 51; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 495

Verse: Shall I inform you of a true learned person? He who does not allow people to commit acts of disobedience to Allah, does not let them lose hope in the mercy of Allah, does not assure them against the devices of Allah, and does not leave the Quran in his desire for something other than it.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, p. 204; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 496

Verse: Justice is the regulatory system of authority.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 774; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 498

Verse: Nothing can cause nations to flourish like justice.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9534; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 498

Verse: was once asked which was better, justice or generosity, to which he replied, 'Justice puts things in their rightful place, whereas generosity takes them away from their course. Justice is a general predominant state, whereas generosity is a transient characteristic. Justice is therefore the nobler and better of the two.'
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 437; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 499

Verse: Allah has made justice incumbent as a source of tranquility for the hearts.
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 247, no. ; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 499

Verse: There is a rank that Allah reserves for the servant which he can only attain through one of two things: either the loss of his wealth or through affliction in his body
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 257, no. 23; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 662

Verse: Asceticism is the key to the door of the Hereafter and immunity from the Fire, and it is to abandon all those things that preoccupy you from Allah, neither experiencing regret upon their loss, nor self-admiration for having abandoned them, nor awaiting deliverance from them, nor seeking praise on account of them, and nor anything else in exchange for them. Rather you see their loss as a source of comfort and their presence as a source of misfortune, such that you consistently run away from misfortune and seek refuge in comfort.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 315, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 119

Verse: The one who practices asceticism from worldly pleasures is such that he neither allows the prohibited things to overcome his perseverance [in the way of Allah], nor the permissible things to distract him from gratefulness to Allah.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 37, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 120

Verse: He who attains inner knowledge of Allah has achieved perfection in his knowledge indeed.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7999; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 436

Verse: The inner knowledge of Allah, Glory be to Him, is the highest of knowable truths.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9864; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 436

Verse: The fruit of knowledge is attaining inner knowledge of Allah.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4586; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 436

Verse: He whose heart finds peace in knowing Allah, finds peace in being needless of Allah's creatures.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8896; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 437

Verse: If people knew the virtue of knowing Allah, Mighty and Exalted, they would never extend their gaze to the splendour and bounties of the life of this world that Allah has granted to the enemies. They would then regard such people's worldly goods to be more insignificant that the dust under their feet, and they would take great pleasure at attaining knowledge of Allah, Mighty and Exalted, and would savour it as if they were tasting the experience of being in the gardens of Paradise with the friends of Allah. Verily the inner knowledge of Allah is an intimate companion in every type of desolation, a friend in every type of loneliness, a light in every darkness, a source of strength from all weakness, and a cure for all ailments.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 247, no. 347; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 437

Verse: He who attains inner knowledge of Allah and aggrandizes Him forbids his mouth from speaking [vain] and his stomach from eating, and satisfies himself through fasting and praying.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 444, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 437

Verse: He who is most knowledgeable of Allah is most fearful of Allah.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 393, no. 64; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 438

Verse: The least knowledge of Allah leads one to abstain from the vanities of this world.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10984; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 438

Verse: Verily it does not befit one who has attained inner knowledge of the grandeur of Allah to behave proudly, for verily the elevation of those who acknowledge His grandeur comes from their abasing themselves in front of Him.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 147; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 438

Verse: The peak of inner knowledge of Allah is fear [of Him].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6359; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 438

Verse: The person who best knows Allah asks of Him the most.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3260; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 438

Verse: The creature of Allah most eligible for submission to the decree of Allah, Mighty and Exalted, is he who knows Allah, Mighty and Exalted.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 62, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 438

Verse: He who attains inner knowledge of Allah fears Allah, and he who fears Allah restrains himself from this world.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 185; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 438

Verse: Verily the person who best knows Allah is the most content with the decree of Allah, Mighty and Exalted.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 184; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 439

Verse: The gnostic's face is cheerful and smily, whereas his heart is apprehensive and sorrowful.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1985; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 439

Verse: Longing [for Allah] is the sincerest friend of the gnostics.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 855; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 439

Verse: Fear is the cloak of the gnostics.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 664; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 439

Verse: Crying much due to fear of Allah for any possible distance between oneself and Allah is the regular worshipful state of the gnostics.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1791; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 439

Verse: Trust in Allah and you will attain inner knowledge [of Him].
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 376; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 439

Verse: Imam Mosa ibn Ja'far al-Kazim (a.s.) when he was asked about the lowest degree of inner knowledge, replied, 'It is to affirm that there is no god but He, and that He has no likeness or match, and that He is eternal, positively proven to exist, present and not absent, and that there is nothing like Him.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 86, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 440

Verse: Get to know Allah through Allah, and the Prophet through the message he brought, and those vested with authority through their command to do good, their justice and righteousness.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 85, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 440

Verse: The best of deeds is adherence to the truth
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3322; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 78

Verse: when asked about the best of deeds, replied, 'Performing the prayer at its prescribed time, being kind to one' s parents and combat in the way of Allah (jihad), Mighty and Exalted.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 158, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 78

Verse: There are three qualities which if a person does not possess, his action remains incomplete piety which safeguards him from acts of disobedience to Allah, a good nature by means of which he maintains amicable relations with people, and clemency by means of which he retorts the rashness of the ignorant.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 116, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 78

Verse: He who does not guard his tongue has not performed any good deeds.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 85; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 79

Verse: A good deed accompanied by doubt and denial is to no avail
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 400, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 79

Verse: Allah does not accept a good deed from a believer as long as he harbours ill will against a fellow believing brother
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 361, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 79

Verse: Be cautious of every deed which the doer is pleased to perform himself but hates Muslims at large to perform it.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 18, p. 41; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 80

Verse: Be cautious of every deed which is performed in secret but is embarrassing to perform in public.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 69; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 80

Verse: Beware of any deed whose performance would be denied by its doer if mentioned to him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 369, no. 19]; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 80

Verse: When Ibrahim, the son of the Prophet (SAWA) passed away, the Prophet (SAWA) saw a gap in his grave, which he filled with his hand, and then said, 'When any of you performs a good deed, he should perfect it.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 2, p. 883, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 81

Verse: People' s deeds are exposed [to me] every Monday and Thursday. The deeds of one who seeks forgiveness are forgiven to him, and those of the repentant are pardoned, whilst the deeds of those who harbour rancour are returned to them because of their rancour until they repent for them
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 3, p. 458, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 81

Verse: Verily your deeds are exposed to me every day, and whatever good I see I ask Allah to increase them for you, and whatever bad I see, I seek forgiveness from Allah for you.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 1, p. 191, no. 582; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 81

Verse: Verily the deeds of this community are exposed to Allah, most High, every single morning.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 44, no. 156; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 82

Verse: was asked about Allah' s verse "And say, 'Go on working, for Allah will see your conduct, and His Apostle and the faithful [as well]", replied, 'It is us that He means [by the faithful].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 23, p. 337, no. 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 82

Verse: Aabdullah b. Aban said to him, 'Verily a group of your adherents have asked me to request you to supplicate Allah on their behalf' , replied, 'By Allah, verily I am the one who presents their deeds to Allah every day.'
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 11, p. 392, no. 25; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 82

Verse: The angel on man's right [shoulder] records his good deeds, whilst the angel on the left records his evil deeds. The two angels of the day record the servant' s deeds by day, and the two angels of the night record the servant' s deeds by night.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 5, p. 327, no. 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 82

Verse: Verily Allah likes it for a believing servant of His, when he goes to visit a fellow brother, to get ready and adorn himself.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 79, p. 307, no. 23; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 83

Verse: You should adorn yourself for your fellow Muslim brother when you go to visit him just as you adorn yourself for a stranger for whom you want to make a good first impression.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 298, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 83

Verse: The adornment of your inner selves is more beautiful than the adornment of the outer.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5503; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 83

Verse: The adornment of faith is purity of one's innermost thoughts coupled with good actions manifested outwardly.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5504; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 83

Verse: The best thing a man can adorn himself with is tranquility coupled with faith.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 337, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 84

Verse: The best attire is that which enables you to blend in with people, which makes you look presentable in front of them, and which does not give tongues an excuse to wag about you.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3470; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 84

Verse: No one can adorn himself with a better adornment than the obedience of Allah.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9489; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 84

Verse: Afflictions are the keys to reward
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 85

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) was once asked what the worst affliction was, to which he replied, 'To be afflicted with a blow to one's faith.'
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 85

Verse: The greatest affliction and source of wretchedness is infatuation with this world.
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 85

Verse: The greatest affliction is ignorance
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 85

Verse: Declining your subjects' daily bread suffices to make of you a sinner.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 444; Page No. 66

Verse: Delay in the payment of debt is a form of injustice.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 445; Page No. 66

Verse: Delay in three things is not allowed: setting prayers in due time, carrying a dead body (for burial) as soon as possible, and marrying a widow to someone equal in status with her.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 446, Page No. 66

Verse: Deprived from my intercession will be the one who does not accept someone's sincere or insincere apology.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 447; Page No. 67

Verse: Descent is (like unto) wealth.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 448; Page No. 67

Verse: Dinars and Dirhams are seals of God on the earth, and the requests of whoever delivers his Master's seals to Him will be granted.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 449; Page No. 67

Verse: Diseases are God's whips on the earth for the correction of people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 450; Page No. 67

Verse: Divine anger is so severe for the one who regards himself the lord of lords, (for) there is no lord but the Lord (God).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 451; Page No. 67

Verse: Divine wrath is so severe for the one who oppresses those who have no helper save God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 452; Page No. 67

Verse: Divorce is the most despised thing God has declared lawful.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 453; Page No. 67

Verse: Divorce is the most hateful (of all) lawful things to God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 454; Page No. 67

Verse: There is no loneliness more miserable than self-admiration.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 113; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 831

Verse: Do brush your teeth, for a very good practice it is! It strengthens (your) gum, wipes out stink from (your) mouth, refreshes (your) stomach, elevates (your) status in Paradise, and makes God pleased and Satan furious.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 455; Page No. 67

Verse: Do brush your teeth, for it's the cause of mouth purification and divine satisfaction.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 456; Page No. 68

Verse: Do fear God, for it's the origin of all the good.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 457, Page No. 68

Verse: Do fear God, the Greatest and the most Powerful, and remember Him in all cases. When you commit an evil deed, do repent instantly -- a covert repentance for a covert sin, and an overt repentance for an overt sin.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 458, Page No. 68

Verse: Do good immediately after doing wrong.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 459; Page No. 68

Verse: Do good to those who deserve it and those who do not, for if your goodness the former receive, it would be quite appropriate; otherwise, you yourself will be the receiver of it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 460; Page No. 68

Verse: Do not allow your silly ones rule over you.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 461; Page No. 68

Verse: Do not ask people for anything.Should your scourge fall down, bend and take it up and do not ask others to do so.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 462; Page No. 68

Verse: Do not backbite Muslims and do not try to discover their faults.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 463; Page No. 68

Verse: Do not be a company but to believers, and do not share your meal save with the pious.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 464; Page No. 68

Verse: Do not be a company to the one who does not regard you of equal status with him.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 465; Page No. 69

Verse: Do not be amazed at anybody's being a Muslim; rather (try to) know the essence of his/her thought.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 466; Page No. 69

Verse: Do not be amazed at anybody's state of affairs; rather, (wait to) see its end.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 467; Page No. 69

Verse: Do not be contentious to your brothers (in faith), do not make fun of them, and do not break your promises (in respect to them).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 468; Page No. 69

Verse: Do not be easy-going to yourself, but hard on people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 469; Page No. 69

Verse: Do not be in gross grief, for your due sustenance and whatever is destined for you will surely come to pass.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 470; Page No. 69

Verse: Seeking forgiveness alongside persistent sinning is renewing one's sins.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 223; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 830

Verse: The one who seeks forgiveness for a sin and then repeats it is as one who mocks his Lord
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 504, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 830

Verse: He who seeks forgiveness with his tongue but does not feel remorse in his heart has fooled himself
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 356, no. 11]; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 830

Verse: Self-admiration shows up your faults
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 954; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 831

Verse: Self-admiration is foolishness
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 62; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 831

Verse: An evil deed [of yours] that upsets you is better in the sight of Allah than a good deed which you feel proud about
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 46; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 831

Verse: Beware of self-satisfaction lest it increases the cause for [Allah's] wrath against you
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2642; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 831

Verse: The consequence of self-admiration is hatred [of other people towards you].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4606; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 831

Verse: Self-admiration prevents progress
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, no. 167; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 832

Verse: Verily Allah, Blessed and most High, says, 'Verily from among My servants is he who asks Me to enable him to perform an act of obedience to Me in order that he may procure My love, but I however, withhold that from him in order that he does not come to feel proud of that action of his.
VerseRef: al-Zuhd li al-Husayn b. Sa`aid, p. 68, no. 179; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 832

Verse: He who is overtaken by self-admiration perishes
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 313, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 832

Verse: He regards the little good that others do as being much and regards the abundance of good that he himself does as being little
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 1, p. 132, no. 184; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 832

Verse: Undervalue the abundant acts of obedience that you perform for Allah, in contempt of your lower self and in order to expose yourself to Allah's pardon
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 285; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 832

Verse: Iblis [Satan]   may Allah's curse be on him   says to his troops, 'If I can gain mastery over three things in man, I will no longer care how much good he does for it will not be accepted from him: if he overrates his good deeds, forgets his sins, and is overcome by self-admiration
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 112, no. 86; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 833

Verse: What is the matter with man that he is so given to self-admiration when his origin was but a putrid droplet, and his end is as a filthy corpse, and between these states he is but a vessel for excrement?!
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9666; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 833

Verse: Block the path of self-admiration through self-knowledge
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 285] ; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 833

Verse: If crossing the Sirat [Bridge extended over Hell] is a reality, then wherefore the need for self-admiration?!
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 16, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 833

Verse: Verily Allah, Mighty and Exalted, loves the reserved and shy person, and despises the bawdy and importunate beggar
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 39, no. 43; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 834

Verse: The fighter who is martyred in the way of Allah has no greater reward than the one who is able to sate himself but remains chaste. The chaste person may well become one of the angels
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 474; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 834

Verse: Self-restraint is the root of all good
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1168; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 834

Verse: Self-restraint is the best part of spiritual chivalry (futuwwa).
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 529; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 834

Verse: Verily Allah has made jihad obligatory and has magnified it and made it a [source of] triumph and a helper. By Allah, neither one's worldly affairs nor one's religion are set aright except through it.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 11, p. 9, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 559

Verse: Certainly jihad is the noblest of deeds after [acceptance of] Islam, and it is the pillar of religion. The reward for it is great, while at the same time, consistently maintaining one's honour and strength. There are rewards and good tidings of Paradise after martyrdom.
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 1, p. 408, no. 429; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 559

Verse: Jihad is the greatest deed after fulfilling the obligatory ones.
VerseRef: Mishkat al-Anwar, no. 154; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 559

Verse: Swords are the keys to Paradise.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 11, p. 13, no. 12293; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 559

Verse: The doors of the heavens are opened for those who wage jihad.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1347; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 560

Verse: Whoever equips a warrior, even with a needle and thread, Allah forgives his past and future sins.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 11, p. 24, no. 12333; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 560

Verse: Whoever carries a message on behalf of a fighter during war is like one who frees a slave, and he partakes in the reward of the one who actually fought.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 11. p. 14, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 560

Verse: Fight in the way of Allah with your hands; and if you are not able to do so then fight with your tongues; and if you are still not able to then fight with your hearts.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 100, p. 49, no. 23; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 561

Verse: By Allah! By Allah! Wage jihad with your wealth, your selves and your tongues for the sake of Allah.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 47; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 561

Verse: Allah covers with disgrace the one who abandons jihad, and subjects him to poverty, and deprivation in his religion. Verily Allah, blessed and most High, has honoured my community by the solid hooves of its cavalry, and the tips of its lances.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 462, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 561

Verse: Jihad has four branches: enjoining the good, forbidding the wrong, fortitude in the battlefield, and detesting the wicked.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 232, no. 74; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 561

Verse: The eyes of two categories of people will never touch the fire: the one who cried out of fear of Allah, and the one who spent the night awake standing guard for the sake of Allah.
VerseRef: Sunan al-Tirmidhi, no. 1639; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 562

Verse: Know that man gets satiated and wearied with everything except life, because he does not find any comfort in death.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 133; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 563

Verse: The worth of a man with regards to his perception of things is his knowledge of [the workings of] time
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 80, no. 66; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 940

Verse: The man who best understands time is he who is not taken aback by its proceedings.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3252; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 940

Verse: He who knows [the workings of] his time is never overwhelmed by its obscurities
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 356; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 940

Verse: He who places his trust in time has gone mad
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 54, no. 204; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 940

Verse: Whoever trusts time is betrayed by it, and whoever holds it in high esteem is abased by it
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8028; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 940

Verse: Whoever trusts time is betrayed by it, whoever attaches great importance to it is abased by it, whoever is angry with time, it spites him even more, and whoever takes refuge with time is forsaken by it. Not everyone who throws hits the target. When the sultan changes so does the time
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 213, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 940

Verse: Time betrays the one who believes he possesses time, and it does not seek to please the one who blames it
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2093; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 941

Verse: Whoever preoccupies himself with time is occupied by it in turn.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7890; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 941

Verse: He who blames time will find no end to his frustration.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 53, no. 204; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 941

Verse: Whoever resists time is spited by it even more, and whoever surrenders to it is not safe either
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9054; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 941

Verse: Whoever contends with time is thwarted, and whoever is resentful towards it ends up getting angry himself.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 85; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 941

Verse: Al-Rayyan b. al-Salt narrated that Imam al-Rida (AS) recited some verses he had composed for `Aabd al-Muttalib:
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 177, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 942

Verse: Whoever transmits to my people one tradition by which a practice is established or a heresy is blocked, will enter Paradise
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 152, no. 43; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 942

Verse: Truly our tradition enlivens the hearts
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 144, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 942

Verse: Indeed one true tradition that you receive from a truthful person is better for you than the whole world and all that it contains.
VerseRef: Amali al-Mufid, p. 42, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 942

Verse: Know the people's positions with respect to us through the amount of their narration of our traditions
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 150, no. 24; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 943

Verse: O Allah! Have mercy on my ambassadors' thrice. He was asked, 'O Messenger of Allah! Who are your ambassadors?' He said, 'Those who learn my traditions and practices, and then teach them to my community.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 152, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 943

Verse: The narrator of traditions who understands religion is better than a thousand worshippers who have neither understanding of religion nor knowledge of traditions
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 150, no. 24; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 943

Verse: Whoever memorizes forty traditions from which my community benefits in their religious affairs, Allah will raise him on the Day of Resurrection as a learned jurist and a scholar.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 156, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 943

Verse: Your aim must be to understand [the traditions] rather than just narrating [them].
VerseRef: Kanz al-Fawa' id li al-Karajiki, v. 2, p. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 944

Verse: The ambition of the foolish is to report [traditions] whereas the ambition of the scholars is to understand the traditions
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 160, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 944

Verse: One tradition that you understand is better than a thousand traditions that you merely narrate
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 2, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 944

Verse: Whoever deliberately ascribes lies to me, let him take his seat in the Fire
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 227, no. 398; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 944

Verse: Whoever rejects a tradition that is transmitted to him on my authority will have me to contend with on the Day of Resurrection. So when you hear a tradition from me that you do not know, say: "Allah knows better."
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 212, no. 114; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 945

Verse: The traditions that do not correspond with the Qur'an are false
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 69, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 945

Verse: Whenever a tradition from the household of Muhammad - peace be upon them all   is transmitted to you, towards which your hearts lean and it seems familiar to you, accept it. And whatever your hearts resent and you reject, then refer it back to Allah and the Prophet and the scholar from the household of Muhammad (SAWA).
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 189, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 945

Verse: Whenever a tradition is transmitted to you from me that agrees with the truth, then I have truly said it, and whatever tradition is transmitted to you from me which does not agree with the truth, then I have not said it, for I speak nothing but the truth.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 390, no. 30; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 946

Verse: No sooner do two differing claims arise than one of them is erroneous
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 183; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 244

Verse: People, in their effort to avoid disgrace, rush headlong into it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2172; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 247

Verse: He who discloses his shortcomings to others resigns himself to disgrace.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 201; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 247

Verse: was asked by `Abd al-Mu'min al-Ansari, 'Verily some people narrated from the Prophet (SAWA) that he said, "The separation of my community is a mercy" and they were truthful, so I ask that if their separation is a mercy then is their congregation a chastisement?', to which the Imam replied, 'It is not as you understand it nor as they understood it, actually he meant the saying of Allah, "But why should not there go forth a group from each of their sections " so He commanded them to go forth to the Prophet (SAWA) and to frequent him and learn from him then to return to their people and teach them, so what is meant is [physical] separation from their cities, not separation or difference with regards to the religion of Allah, for verily the religion of Allah is one.'
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 157, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 244

Verse: The Prophet (SAWA) was asked about the congregation of his [religious] community, and he said, 'The congregation of my community are those who are the people of truth even if they are few in number.'
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 154, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 245

Verse: Verily you are brothers in the religion of Allah, nothing has separated you except ill natures and bad consciences, consequently you do not bear the burdens of each other, nor do you advise each other, nor spend on each other, nor love each other.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 113; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 245

Verse: If the ignorant ones had kept silent, men would not have differed.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 81, no. 75; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 245

Verse: Make do with little rather than disgracing yourself [by begging].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 362; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 245

Verse: Death is preferable over a life of disgrace. Frugal living is preferable over begging from others.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 396; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 246

Verse: A lifetime of honour can never compensate for an hour of disgrace.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5580; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 246

Verse: O Allah! Let my soul be the first of those precious objects that you will wrest from me, and the first thing to be reclaimed out of all Your bounties held in trust with me.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 215; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 246

Verse: Death with dignity is better than living with disgrace', and articulated the following couplet on the day he was martyred:
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 44, p. 192, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 246

Verse: Whoever succumbs to degrading himself is not considered from among us, the ahl al-bayt.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 58; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 246

Verse: Verily Allah, Blessed and most High, has placed everything at the disposal of the believer except that which brings disgrace upon him
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 63, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 246

Verse: A believer must never disgrace himself.' When asked by someone how this disgrace comes about, he replied, 'By going out of his way to obtain that which is beyond his control, he ends up disgracing himself.
VerseRef: Mishkat al-Anwar, no. 245; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 247

Verse: The most disgraceful of people is he who humiliates others.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 44, p. 142, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 247

Verse: There is no disgrace worse than that of greed.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 286; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 247

Verse: He who loves life is bound to face disgrace.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 110, no. 120; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 248

Verse: Three things bring about malice: hypocrisy, oppression, and self-admiration
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 316; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 116

Verse: Someone once came to one of the Imams (AS) complaining about a man who was wronging him. The Imam (AS) replied, 'Be patient with him.' The man retorted, 'But people are taking me for a disgraced fool.' The Imam replied, 'The disgraced one is actually the one who wrongs others.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 46, p. 205, no. 78; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 248

Verse: No sooner do a people go astray than they exaggerate in dispute.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 138, no. 52; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 248

Verse: Avoid dispute, for it brings about doubt.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 615, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 248

Verse: We are the ones who debate about the religion of Allah.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 125, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 248

Verse: The subject of disputing about religion was mentioned in the presence of al-Sadiq (AS), and that the Prophet (SAWA) and the infallible Imams (AS) prohibited it. So al-Sadiq (AS) said, 'He never prohibited it absolutely, but only prohibited dispute in ways that are not the best.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 125, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 249

Verse: It is no small wonder if man is given salvation [on the Day of Resurrection], rather what is a wonder is how he manages to end up in eternal damnation in spite of Allah's all-encompassing mercy.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 153, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 250

Verse: Elicit Allah's mercy through the performance of the acts of obedience that He has commanded you.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 120; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 250

Verse: Allah's remembrance elicits the descent of His mercy.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4209; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 250

Verse: Spreading mercy [to others] elicits the descent of Allah's mercy.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4343; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 250

Verse: Holy Prophet Muhammad al Mustaf? (s.a.w.w.) said to the archangel Gabriel, 'Which place is most despised by Allah?' He said, 'The marketplaces, and the most despised from among those who frequent them is he who is the first to enter and the last to leave.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 84, p. 4, no. 76; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 115

Verse: Allah despises excessive sleep and excessive idleness.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 180, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 115

Verse: Three things deserve the antipathy of Allah, the Exalted: [excessive] sleeping without night-vigil, laughing without a cause, and eating on a full stomach.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 89, no. 25; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 115

Verse: A man from [the tribe of] Khath`am came to the Prophet (SAWA), asking, 'Which deeds are the most despised by Allah, the Exalted?' The Prophet replied, 'Associating anyone with Allah.' The man asked, 'Then what?' He said, 'Cutting off one's kin.' The man asked, 'Then what?' He said, 'Enjoining evil and forbidding what is good
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 290, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 115

Verse: Allah, the Exalted, despises gossip, wasting money, and persistent begging.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 335, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 116

Verse: You have been sneaked upon by the plague of previous nations: jealousy and malice
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 367, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 116

Verse: Allah detests two sounds: [the sound of] wailing at a catastrophe, and [the sound of] a flute in the time of prosperity.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 40; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 116

Verse: Beware of anxiety, for it cuts off hope, weakens action, and brings sorrow. And know that the way out [of trouble] lies in two things: resourcefulness where a stratagem exists, and perseverance wherever stratagems fail.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 144, no. 29; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 117

Verse: Overcome anxiety with patience, for anxiety erases [Allah's] reward and augments the catastrophe.'
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2527; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 117

Verse: upon hearing the weeping of women for the dead killed in the battle of Siffin, said, 'Do your women prevail over you from what I can hear?! Can you not prohibit them from making this din?!
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 322; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 117

Verse: The worst expression of grief is screaming and wailing with loud cries, beating one's face and chest, tearing out one's hair; and a man who takes up wailing is a man who has abandoned patience.
VerseRef: Musakkin al-Fu'ad, p. 99; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 117

Verse: The catastrophe is but a single one for the patient man, and two for the anxious one.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 414; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 117

Verse: People cannot worship Allah with anything better than asceticism from worldly pleasures.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 322; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 117

Verse: Asceticism is the distinguishing characteristic of Godwary people and the natural disposition of those who turn to Allah.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1713; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 118

Verse: Verily among the qualities that greatly develop one's faith is abstention from worldly pleasures
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 128, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 118

Verse: In one of His conversations with Prophet Moses (AS), Allah told him the following, ' those who seek to adorn themselves [for Me] have no better apparel than abstention from the worldly pleasures that they find indispensable.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 13, p. 349, no. 37; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 118

Verse: All goodness has been placed in one house, and its key is asceticism and restraint from worldly pleasures.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 49, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 118

Verse: Asceticism from worldly pleasures means to cut short one's hopes of this world, to be grateful for every single bounty, to have piety and to keep away from all that which Allah has prohibited.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 58; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 118

Verse: Asceticism is not to prohibit oneself that which is allowed. Rather it is to find that which is with Allah more secure than that which is in one's own possession
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 172, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 118

Verse: Asceticism is summed up between two phrases in the Qur'an, where Allah, most High, says, "So that you may not grieve for what has escaped you, nor be exultant at what He has given you." Therefore, one who neither grieves about past losses nor is overjoyed about the possessions he is granted has perfected his asceticism from both sides.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 70, p. 317, no. 23; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 119

Verse: Those who restrain themselves from worldly pleasures are such that their hearts are weeping though outwardly they may laugh, they experience great sorrow though they display joy, and they are filled with self-contempt though they rejoice at all that they have been bestowed.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 113; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 120

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) when asked to define the ascetic, said, 'The ascetic is the one who renounces the permissible things in this world for fear of having to account for them, and renounces the forbidden things of this world for fear of punishment for them.'
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 52, no. 199; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 120

Verse: Imam Ali ibn Mosa al-Rez? (a.s.) when asked about the qualities of the ascetic, replied, 'He manages to still his hunger without pursuit of food, he is well-prepared for his death, and weary of his life in this world.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 349, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 120

Verse: The person best able to practice abstemiousness is he who understands the inferiority of this worldly life
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3209; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 120

Verse: He who attains inner knowledge of his self attains inner knowledge of his Lord
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7946; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 435

Verse: It befits one who knows the dignity of his own self to deem it too great for the vileness of this world.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1093; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 435

Verse: It befits one who knows the dignity of his own self to adhere to temperance and self-restraint.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10927; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 435

Verse: It befits one who knows the dignity of his own self to never allow a sorrowful and self-cautious state to leave him.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10937; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 435

Verse: Make us from among those who have attained inner knowledge of their selves and are convinced of their true abode, such that they spend their whole lives in Your obedience.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 94, p. 128, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 435

Verse: Imam Muhammad ibn 'Ali al-Baqir (a.s.) said in his advice to Jabir al-Ju`afi, 'There is no inner knowledge like your inner knowledge of your own self.'
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 286; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 435

Verse: A Muslim does not seek to treat himself [with medicine] until the ailment overcomes his health
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 620, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 771

Verse: There is no medicine except that it exacerbates another ailment, and there is nothing more beneficial to the body than self-restraint from all except that which the body needs
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 8, p. 273, no. 409; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 771

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when asked, 'Which is the worst humility?', said, 'Coveting the world.'
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 322, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 228

Verse: The covetous is a captive of a lowliness whose captivity is never-ending.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1370; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 228

Verse: Sustenance is allotted, and the covetous is denied.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 96; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 229

Verse: The covetous one is poor even if he owns the whole world.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1753; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 229

Verse: The one who covets is wretched and miserable.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7723; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 229

Verse: The covetous one is never satiated.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 365; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 229

Verse: Covetousness does not increase sustenance, but rather it degrades its worth.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1877; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 229

Verse: Self-restraint does not prevent [the descent of] sustenance, nor does covetousness attract any surplus [sustenance]; for indeed sustenance is allotted, and death is certain, and covetousness is only asking for sin.
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, no. 428; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 229

Verse: The similitude of the one who covets this world is as the caterpillar: the more silk it spins around itself, the harder it makes its exit for itself, until it dies of grief.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 316, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 229

Verse: The Commander of the Faithful, blessings of Allah be upon him, used to say, 'O son of Adam! If only you sought from the world enough to satisfy your needs, indeed the very least from it would be enough to satisfy your needs. But if instead you desire more than your needs, then truly everything that it contains will not suffice you.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 138, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 230

Verse: Know O Ali, that cowardice, miserliness, and covetousness are all a single disposition, brought together through entertaining a low opinion [of Allah].
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 559, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 230

Verse: In Paradise, only names of the things belonging to this world exist.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1045; Page No. 147

Verse: In Paradise, the whip of one of you will be preferred to whatever is there between the earth and sky.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1046; Page No. 147

Verse: In the Day of Judgment, all affluent people will wish to have only possessed their daily bread in worldly life.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1047; Page No. 147

Verse: In the Day of Judgment, God will bestow the reward of seventy-two truthful men on a child who spends his pre-
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1048; Page No. 147&148

Verse: In the Day of Judgment, God will forgive a leader who forgives (people) in anger.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1049; Page No. 148

Verse: In the Day of Judgment, God will not attend the one who collects his/her dress(from people) out of vanity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1050; Page No. 148

Verse: In the Day of Judgment, God will not cast a look at the one who has committed adultery with his neighbor's wife, will not make him purified, and will order him to enter Hell with Hell-dwellers.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1051; Page No. 148

Verse: In the Day of Judgment, God will surely avoid saving the one who has frightened a believer.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1052; Page No. 148

Verse: In the Day of judgment, judges would experience an hour when they would wish for not having had judged between two persons even on a date.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1053; Page No. 148

Verse: In the Day of Judgment, people are first called to account concerning blood(shed).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1054; Page No. 148&149

Verse: In the Day of Judgment, the Exalted God addresses man, saying: "O son of Adam! I got sick, but to Me you did not pay a visit!" Man asks, "How could I visit You, Lord of the worlds?" God says: "Do you not remember that such and such a servant of me was sick, but you didn't visit him? Had you visited him, you would have met Me with him." Then, God continues, "O son of Adam! I requested you to give me food, but you didn't do what you could!" Man asks, "How could I offer food to You, Lord of the worlds?" God says: "Don't you remember that such and such a servant of Me asked you for food, but to him you were rude? Had you offered him food, with Me you would have found it." Then, God continues, "O son of Adam! I demanded you to give me water, but you hesitated to offer!" Man asks, "How could I give water to You, Lord of the worlds?" God says: "Don't you remember that such and such a servant of Me asked you for water, but you refused to offer? Had you offered him water, with Me you would have found it."
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1055; Page No. 149

Verse: In the Resurrection, a caller will call out, saying, "whoever has done something for anyone other than God, should ask him for reward".
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1056; Page No. 149

Verse: In the sight of God, seeking knowledge is superior to prayer, fasting, pilgrimage to Mecca, and jihad (struggling in the way of God, the Greatest and the most Powerful).
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1057; Page No. 149

Verse: In usury, both parties are equally sinful.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1058; Page No. 149

Verse: In whatever state one dies, in the same way will God resurrect him/her.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1059; Page No. 149

Verse: Increase in knowledge with lack of increase in reluctance to the world results in one's further remoteness from God.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1060; Page No. 150

Verse: Inform the rulers of the needs of those who cannot do so, for whoever performs such an action will be granted steadfast feet by God to pass over the Bridge in the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1061, Page No. 150

Verse: Insulting a Muslim is wickedness, fighting him is blasphemy, and his wealth is as worthy as his blood.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1062; Page No. 150

Verse: Is there anybody to walk on water without getting wet? That's why a man of the world will not be safe from sins.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1063; Page No. 150

Verse: Islam (submission to God) is an overt (phenomenon), but faith is (hidden) in heart.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1064; Page No. 150

Verse: Islam is based on the following five (pillars): bearing witness that there is no god but Allah and Muhammad (P.B.U.H.) is His Messenger, setting up prayer, paying the poor due, making pilgrimage to Mecca and keeping fast in the month of Ramadan.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1065; Page No. 150

Verse: Islam is clean (pure).Be clean, therefore, for nobody will be allowed to Paradise save the clean people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1066; Page No. 151

Verse: The one who condemns a fellow brother for a sin that he has already repented for will not die before committing it himself.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 113; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 207

Verse: The one who exposes someone' s monstrous deed is as the one who initiated it, and the one who condemns a believer for something will not die before becoming guilty of it himself.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 356, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 207

Verse: If one of your servants commits adultery, lash her with the prescribed punishment but do not shame her.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 57; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 207

Verse: If your Muslim brother condemns you for whatever he knows about you, then do not condemn him back for whatever you know about him. You will have a reward whereas he will carry a sin.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 155; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 208

Verse: Anybody who discredits a believer' s self-esteem will die an evil death, and he becomes deserving of never again returning to a good end.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 361, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 208

Verse: He who reviles a believer will be reviled by Allah in both this world and the Hereafter.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 356, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 208

Verse: Do not express malicious gloating at your brother [for a sin or misfortune] for Allah will have mercy on him as a result and make it befall you instead.' He also said, 'He who gloats over an affliction that has befallen his brother will not leave this world until he has been tried similarly.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 359, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 208

Verse: Whoever condoles with a grief-stricken person receives the same reward as him [The reward of the grief-stricken is for their endurance of their pain (ed.)].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 94, no. 46; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 209

Verse: Whoever condoles with a mother bereaved of her child will be shaded by Allah by the shade of His Throne on the Day when no other shade will avail.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 227, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 209

Verse: The minimum condolence required of you is that the bereaved one sees you present.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 1, p. 174, no. 505; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 209

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) narrated that when the Prophet (SAWA) gave condolences, he would say, 'May Allah recompense you and have mercy on you' , and that when he gave congratulations, he would say, 'May Allah bless you and send blessings on you.'
VerseRef: Musakkin al-Fu'ad, p. 108; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 209

Verse: The intellect is the authoritative proof of the believer.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 25, no. 24; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 466

Verse: Imam Ali ibn Mosa al-Rez? (a.s.) when giving condolences to al-Hasan b. Sahl, 'Congratulating someone for the reward that is in store for them is more appropriate than condoling them for a transient affliction.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 353, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 209

Verse: Holy Prophet Muhammad al Mustaf? (s.a.w.w.) when asked, 'Who are the congregation of your community?', replied, 'Those who are with the truth, even if they are but ten people.'
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 154, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 211

Verse: A man's conjecture is proportionate to the extent of his reason.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6038; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 211

Verse: An intellectual man's conjecture is sounder than an ignorant man's certainty.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6040; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 211

Verse: Be wary of the opinions given by believers, for verily Allah has made the truth flow from their tongues.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 309; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 212

Verse: Make an excuse for your fellow brother, and even if you do not have an excuse [for his behaviour], then seek out an excuse for him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 197, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 212

Verse: See the best in any situation involving a fellow brother, until you experience something from him which proves you wrong, and do not assume the worst about something that your brother may say if you can find the possibility for good therein.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 250, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 212

Verse: Entertaining good opinions is a comfort to the heart and [indicates] soundness of faith.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4816; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 212

Verse: Entertaining good opinions reduces anxiety, and saves one from being taken over by sin.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4823; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 212

Verse: The one who thinks the best of people gains their love.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8842; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 212

Verse: The best of piety is to think the best of people.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3027; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 213

Verse: Beware of suspicion for verily suspicion is the worst of all lies.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 195, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 213

Verse: He who has no valorous qualities has no religion
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 389; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 766

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) wrote in his letter to al-Ashtar when he appointed him governor of Egypt, 'Verily miserliness, cowardice and greed are all evil impulses brought together by entertaining a low opinion of Allah.'
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 53; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 213

Verse: There is no room for faith with suspicion.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10534; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 213

Verse: Suspicion corrupts matters and gives rise to evils.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5575; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 213

Verse: The evil person cannot think well of anybody because he can only see people as he himself is predisposed.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1903; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 214

Verse: Verily the best of religion is love for the sake of Allah and hate for the sake of Allah
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3540; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 764

Verse: Religion immunizes
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 764

Verse: Religion is the strongest support
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 489; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 764

Verse: The Commander of the Faithful (AS) would frequently say in his sermons, 'O people! Preserve your religion, for the bad deed of a religious person is better than the good deed of a religion-less person, because the bad deed of a religious person can be forgiven but the good deed of a religion-less person is not even accepted
VerseRef: Nahj al-Sa`ada, v. 3, no. 368; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 765

Verse: The bane of religion is suspiciousness
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3924; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 765

Verse: The corruption of religion lies in [the vanities of] this world.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6554; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 765

Verse: The bane of religion is in jealousy, self-conceit and pride.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 307, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 765

Verse: If you are faced with a tribulation, shield your life with your wealth. If you are faced with a calamity, then shield your religion with your life, and know that the ruined man is he who destroys his religion himself and that the corrupted one is he who spoils his religion himself
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 216, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 765

Verse: All praise be to Allah who did not allow my religion to be afflicted
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 268, no. 183; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 765

Verse: One who subjects himself to the obedience of someone who disobeys Allah has no religion, and the one who subjects himself to attributing a lie or falsity to Allah has no religion, and the one who subjects himself to denying any of Allah's signs has no religion
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 373, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 766

Verse: He who subjects himself to following an oppressive leader unendorsed by Allah has no religi0n
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 135, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 766

Verse: The one who has no covenant has no religion
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 84, p. 252, no. 48; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 766

Verse: Anyone whose love and hate is not based on religion, has no religion.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 127, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 766

Verse: He who has no piety has no religion
VerseRef: Kamal al-Din, p. 371, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 766

Verse: Abu Basir asked Imam al-Sadiq (AS), 'May I be your ransom! Please inform me about the religion that Allah has obligated upon his servants, [the religion] that they cannot afford to be ignorant of and the only religion that will be accepted from them. What is it?' The Imam (AS) replied, 'Bearing witness that there is no god except Allah and that Muhammad (SAWA) is the messenger of Allah, establishing the prayer, paying the alms-tax, pilgrimage to the House for those who are able to do so, fasting the month of Ramadhan.' Then the Imam momentarily paused and then repeated twice, 'and divine guardianship [of the divinely appointed Imams] (al-walaya).
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 22, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 767

Verse: The one who understands his religion from the Book of Allah, mountains will move before he does [in his faith], and the one who enters a matter with ignorance [i.e. accepts religion ignorantly] will leave it in ignorance
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 23, p. 103, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 768

Verse: The one who enters this religion through men will exit it through men just as they caused him to enter it. And whoever enters this religion through the Book and the prophetic practice, mountains will move before he does [in his faith].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 2, p. 105, no. 67; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 768

Verse: Protect your religion by means of your worldly affairs and you will profit in both, but do not use your religion to protect your worldly affairs as you will lose them both
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5861; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 768

Verse: No sooner do people omit any aspect of their religion for the sake of improving their worldly affairs than Allah will open for them something that will be more detrimental to them [than the improvement of their worldly affairs].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 10831; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 768

Verse: You will be afflicted with an obscure matter that will leave you with no sign to indicate to the solution, nor a leader to guide the way. None shall be saved from it except the one who recites the 'Supplication of the Drowning Person'. [The narrator says] I asked the Imam, 'What is the Supplication of the Drowning Person?' The Imam replied, 'O Allah, O the Beneficent, O the Merciful, O He who causes the hearts to fluctuate, affirm my heart upon Your religion
VerseRef: Kamal al-Din, p. 352, no. 49; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 769

Verse: Verily the preservers of Allah's religion are the same people who established the religion and helped it, they guarded it from all sides, they preserved it for the servants of Allah and carefully watched over it
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3912; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 769

Verse: A prophet from among the prophets fell sick and said, 'I will not treat myself [with medicine] until the One who made me sick heals me'. Then Allah revealed to him saying, 'I will not heal you until you treat yourself [with medicine] for verily the healing is from Me
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 62, p. 66, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 770

Verse: For every ailment, there is a cure
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7275; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 770

Verse: Avoid medicine as long as your body can bear the ailment, but if it cannot bear the ailment, then resort to medicine.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 81, p. 211, no. 30; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 771

Verse: Everything has a lock, and the lock of faith is moderation
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 118, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 556

Verse: Moderation is worth half of one's livelihood.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 120, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 556

Verse: Verily this religion is firm so penetrate into it gently, and do not arouse aversion for Allah's worship in His servants that they may become like shattered riders who have neither gotten further in their travel nor have any drive left to continue.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, p. 86, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 556

Verse: There is no wealth more profiting than the intellect.
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, no. 244; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 466
