Verse: Cajole your soul tactfully to worship, and be gentle with it and do not force it. Make allowances for both its weariness and its activity, except for the daily obligations that are incumbent upon it, for it must fulfil them and undertake them at their prescribed times.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 69; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 556

Verse: Verily in leniency is to be found abundance and benediction, so whoever is divested of leniency is deprived of good.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 119, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 557

Verse: Leniency eases hardships and facilitates difficult situations.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1778; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 557

Verse: For him who is rendered helpless in making a decision and who is at a loss of what to do, moderation is the key.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 128, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 557

Verse: The last piece of advice that al-Khiar* gave to Prophet Moses (AS) was: 'When a person is lenient towards someone in this world, Allah will be lenient with him on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 386, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 557

Verse: One who is lenient and moderate in his affairs will obtain whatever he wants from people.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 120, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 557

Verse: If you wish to be honoured [by people] be lenient [towards them], and if you wish to be humiliated then be rough
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 269, no. 109; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 558

Verse: Whoever dies, having neither waged a campaign nor having intended to do so, dies on a branch of hypocrisy [in his heart].
VerseRef: Sahih Muslim, v. 3, p. 1517, no. 1910; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 558

Verse: It is better for a Muslim to bear patiently certain instances of jihad even for a single day than to worship for forty years.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 11, p. 21, no. 12324; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 558

Verse: Indeed jihad is one of the gates of Paradise that Allah will open for his exceptional friends. It is the garment of piety, Allah's fortified defense and a solid shield.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 27; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 558

Verse: Jihad is the pillar of religion and the path of the felicitous.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1346; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 559

Verse: In the Hadith Of Meeraj (The Prophet's Ascension to the heavens), the Prophet (SAWA) said, 'O Allah! What is the outcome of hunger?' He said, 'Wisdom, protection of the heart, drawing closer to Me, lasting sorrow, less burden on the people, telling the truth, and lack of concern whether one lives in wealth or poverty.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 22, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 330

Verse: How good a helper hunger is at taming the self and breaking its habit.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 16, p. 214, no. 19634; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 330

Verse: Lack of sleep sweetens sleeping and hunger increases the tastiness of food.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 369, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 330

Verse: How can one renounce the pleasures of this world when he has not yet fathomed the worth of the Hereafter?!
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6987; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 120

Verse: Remember death frequently, for no sooner does man increase his remembrance of death than he begins to renounce this world's life.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 64, no. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 120

Verse: Imam Mosa ibn Ja'far al-Kazim (a.s.) once said while standing at a graveside, 'Indeed something that ends with this [i.e. death] is worthy of its beginning being spent in abstemiousness. And indeed something that begins with this is worthy of its end being feared with apprehension
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 320, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 120

Verse: If the inhabitants of this world used their intellect, the world would self-destruct [for it would cease to be of any importance].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 377, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 121

Verse: He who renounces this worldly life, neither concerning himself with its baseness nor vying for its glory, Allah rewards him with a gift that is unobtainable through any of His creatures, grants him knowledge without the need for learning, secures wisdom in his heart and makes it flow upon his tongue.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 63, no. 155; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 121

Verse: Abstain from the vain pleasures of this world and divine mercy will descend upon you.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2275; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 121

Verse: Abstaining from the vain pleasures of this world is the greatest source of comfort.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1316; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 121

Verse: He who renounces the world's vain pleasures finds its afflictions trivial and is not bothered by them as a result.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 281; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 121

Verse: It is forbidden for your hearts that they should taste the sweetness of faith until and unless they abstain from the pleasures of this world.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 63, no. 155; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 122

Verse: The most abstemious of people is he who renounces the prohibited things.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 27, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 122

Verse: Do not be of those who try to secure the Hereafter by means of the worldly life they disparage this world using ascetic terms, yet act like those who covet it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 68, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 122

Verse: The best level of asceticism is to conceal one's asceticism.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 122

Verse: When an abstemious person flees from people, seek after him, and when he seeks after people, flee from him.'
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, nos. 3078-3079; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 122

Verse: Allah says, 'O son of Adam, be satisfied with what I have given you and you will be among the most abstemious of people.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 139, no. 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 122

Verse: Verily he who is most persevering in the face of adversity is the most abstemious from among you.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, p. 308, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 122

Verse: Adhere to sureties [that you are liable for] in all firmness.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 155; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 123

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) said, in his epistle to M lik al-Ashtar: 'And if you make a covenant between yourself and your enemy or give him a surety [against life or property], then stand by your pact with loyalty and observe your liability with trustworthiness. Make yourself the shield for your word, for there is nothing from Allah's mandates that all people agree upon, despite their diverse opinions on everything else, as much as they do with regards to respecting the fulfilment of covenants.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 53; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 123

Verse: The Muslims are brothers, their blood is co-equal, those under them strive to secure their protection, and they are like one hand against their enemy.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 100, p. 46, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 124

Verse: On the night that I was taken on my Night-Journey [to the heavens], I passed by a group of people scratching their own faces with their nails, so I asked, 'O Gabriel, who are these people?' so he replied, 'These are people who backbit about other people and disparaged their reputations.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 115; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 124

Verse: Backbiting is worse than adultery', at which he was asked, 'How so?' He replied, 'A man commits adultery, then repents, and Allah pardons him for it, whereas the backbiter is not forgiven until his victim forgives him.
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 3, p. 511, no. 24] ; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 125

Verse: Backbiting is the attempt of one who is incapable [of doing better himself].
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 461; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 125

Verse: Imam Husayn ibn 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) said to a man who was backbiting about a man in his presence, 'Stop backbiting, for verily it is the food of the dogs of Hell.'
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 245; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 125

Verse: Do not backbite lest you become a victim of backbiting, and do not dig a hole for your brother lest you fall in it yourself, for you will be paid back whatever you put in.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 249, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 125

Verse: Fearing God is above all wisdom, and abstinence is the leader of all deeds.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 607, Page No. 88

Verse: Feed the pious your food and to the believers, do good.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 608; Page No. 88

Verse: Feeding a hungry Muslim is a cause of being blessed.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 609; Page No. 88

Verse: Feeding your wife, your children, your servants and yourself is considered charity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 610; Page No. 88

Verse: A man once came and told Ali b. al-Husayn (AS) [i.e. Imam Zayn al-Abidin], 'Verily x has said that you are astray and that you are an innovator!' So Ali b. al-Husayn (AS) said to him, 'Neither have you observed the right of the man you sat with by transmitting to us what he spoke about, nor have you observed my right by informing me of something about my brother which I would not have known!   Beware of backbiting for verily it is the food of the dogs of Hell, and know that whoever frequently talks about people's faults, the frequency of his backbiting is a witness [to the fact] that he only finds faults in others according to the extent present in himself.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 246, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 125

Verse: Backbiting eats away at a man's faith faster than a gangrenous sore can eat away to the inside.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 357, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 126

Verse: Whoever backbites a fellow Muslim man or woman, Allah neither accepts his prayer nor his fasting for forty days and nights, until and unless the victim of his backbiting forgives him.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 258, no. 53; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 126

Verse: On the Day of Resurrection, a man will be brought forth to stand before Allah, and his book of deeds will be presented to him, and he will not see any of his good deeds therein, upon which he will exclaim, 'My God, this is not my book! For verily I do not see any of my acts of obedience therein?!' So he will be told, 'Verily your Lord neither loses nor forgets [deeds], but your deeds have gone because of your backbiting people.' Then another man will be brought forth, and will be presented his book of deeds, and he will see many acts of obedience recorded therein, and will exclaim, 'My God, this is not my book! For verily I did not perform all these acts of obedience!' and he will be told, 'It is because so and so backbit you, so his deeds have been transferred to you.
VerseRef: Jami`a al-Akhbar, p. 412, no. 1144; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 126

Verse: Shall I inform you who the absolutely most generous one is Allah is the Absolutely Most Generous One, and I am the most generous of Adam' s offspring, and the most generous from amongst you all after me is the man who has been taught knowledge and subsequently spreads his knowledge to others. He will be raised on the Day of Resurrection as a community in himself, and after him is the man who is generous in giving up his life for Allah, Mighty and Exalted, and is killed for Him.
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 1, p. 119, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 511

Verse: For the teacher of good, all the animals on the land and the fish in the sea seek forgiveness on his behalf, as do all creatures great and small in Allah' s earth and sky.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 159, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 511

Verse: He who seeks knowledge for Allah, no sooner does he learn even a chapter of it than it increases him in humility within himself, in humbleness in front of people, it increases his fear of Allah and his striving in religion, and that is the one who benefits from the knowledge that he gains. And he who seeks knowledge for this world and for status amongst people and for a favoured position with the ruler, no sooner does he learn even a chapter of it than it only increases his arrogance within himself, his presumptuousness with people, his self-delusion about Allah and his estrangement from religion. That is the one who does not benefit from his knowledge, and must subsequently refrain from it and stop furnishing proof for the case against himself in order not to feel regret and shame on the Day of Resurrection.
VerseRef: Rawdhat al-Wa`aizin, p. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 512

Verse: He who desires knowledge in order that he may beguile people will never even smell the fragrance of Paradise.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 364, no. 2661; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 512

Verse: Take of knowledge whatever seems good to you, but beware of seeking knowledge for four reasons in order that you may contend with the scholars, or in order to wrangle with foolish people, or that you may show off with it in gatherings, or in order that people may look up to you to lead them.
VerseRef: Kitab al-Irshad, v. 1, p. 230; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 512

Verse: He who gains knowledge for the sake of Allah, acts upon it for the sake of Allah and teaches it for the sake of Allah is called great in the kingdom of the heavens, and it is exclaimed about him 'Indeed he gains knowledge for Allah, acts for Allah and teaches for Allah!
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 167, no. 280; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 513

Verse: Take the truth even if it be from wrongdoers, but do not take falsehood even if it be from the righteous   be critics of speech.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 359, no. 769; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 513

Verse: Knowledge is a part of religion [just as] prayer is a part of religion, so be careful who you take this knowledge from.
VerseRef: Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 513

Verse: Take wisdom from whoever brings it to you, and look at that which is being said and do not look at who is saying it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5048; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 513

Verse: Knowledge can only be gained from a divine scholar, and recognition of that scholar is through the intellect.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 11, p. 258, no. 12926; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 513

Verse: Be gentle towards those whom you teach as well to those whom you learn from.
VerseRef: Munyat al-Murid, p. 193; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 514

Verse: The right of your subjects through the knowledge you possess is to know that Allah has made you a custodian over them on account of the knowledge He has bestowed on you and the storehouses [of wisdom] which He has opened up for you. If you teach people well, and do not mistreat them, nor treat them harshly, then Allah will increase His grace upon you. But if you withhold your knowledge from people or treat them harshly when they seek knowledge from you, then it will be Allah' s right to deprive you of knowledge and its magnificence, and to make you fall from your place in the people' s hearts
VerseRef: Aaw`ali al-La'ali, v. 4, p. 74, no. 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 514

Verse: Do not turn your cheek disdainfully from the people" 302, said, 'That people should be equal in your eyes when it comes to [sharing] knowledge.
VerseRef: Munyat al-Murid, p. 185; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 514

Verse: Fighting with Muslims originates from blasphemy, abusing them is a sinful act, and a Muslim is not allowed to be sulk with his Muslim brother more than three days.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 615; Page No. 89

Verse: Find pretense to pardon the faults of the fair, generous people.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 616; Page No. 89

Verse: Find the proximity of God by being hostile to (His) enemies, visiting them grimfaced, seeking God's pleasure in making them displeased and getting close to God by keeping distance with them.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 617, Page No. 89

Verse: The right of the one who trains you in knowledge is to magnify him, to frequent his sessions, to listen to him attentively, and to attend to him with devotion. You should not raise your voice to him, nor answer a question that someone has asked him about something, so that he may be the one to answer. You should not address anyone else in his session, nor backbite anyone in his presence. You must defend him if anyone ever speaks ill of him in your presence, conceal his faults and publicise his virtues. You should not sit in the company of his enemy, nor be hostile towards his friend. If you fulfil this right, Allah' s angels bear witness that you frequented him and learned from his knowledge for the sake of Allah, exalted be His Name, and not for the sake of people.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 567, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 516

Verse: When you see a scholar, be a servant to him.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4044; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 516

Verse: He who shows reverence to a scholar has revered his Lord.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8704; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 516

Verse: Man' s intellect is incomplete until ten qualities come together in him   that he must never tire of seeking knowledge his whole life.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 112; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 517

Verse: The student must discipline himself in his quest for knowledge, and not become bored of learning, nor overestimate what he already knows.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6197; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 517

Verse: Only he who lengthens his study attains knowledge
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 758; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 517

Verse: He who gives a great deal of thought to what he learns masters his knowledge, and comes to understand that which he could not understand before.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8917; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 517

Verse: Whoever says 'I am a knowledgeable man' is indeed ignorant.
VerseRef: Munyat al-Murid, no. 137; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 518

Verse: The scholars are the governors over people.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 507; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 518

Verse: The scholar is the one who is never satiated with knowledge, and never becomes full of it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1740; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 518

Verse: The scholar is the one who never gets bored of gaining knowledge.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1303; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 518

Verse: The scholars from among our shi`aa are stationed at the opening next to where Satan and his demons are, preventing them from coming out to the weak shi`aa and from letting Satan and his followers gain mastery over them.
VerseRef: al-Ihtijaj, v. 1, p. 13, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 518

Verse: The fruit of knowledge is action in accordance with it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4624; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 518

Verse: The fruit of knowledge is worship.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4600; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 519

Verse: Fear the oppressor's curse, for it ascends as a flame high to the sky.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 606, Page No. 88

Verse: Five things are among worldly disasters: a friend's death, waste of wealth, enemies' reproach, abandonment of learning, and a bad wife.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 618; Page No. 89

Verse: Five things break (man's) back: mistreating one's parents, being disloyal to one's husband against his confidence, disobeying God on the part of the one whom people obey as a leader, breaking one's promises, and speaking ill of people's consanguinity.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 619; Page No. 89

Verse: Five things break one's fasts and invalidate one's ablution: telling lie, backbiting, tale-bearing, casting a passionate look (at someone) and swearing falsely.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 620, Page No. 89&90

Verse: Five things give rise to five other things: those who break their promise will be subjected to the rule of their enemies. Those who judge contrary to God's Law, will suffer poverty. Those who commit obscene acts, will face recurrent unexpected deaths. Those who make use of short weights in selling, will be afflicted with famine. Those who do not give poor-rate, will suffer years of drought.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 621; Page No. 90

Verse: Flattery is not an attribute of a (true) believer.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 622; Page No. 90

Verse: Follow moderateness in life, for everything gets beautified with it and debased without it.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 623; Page No. 90

Verse: For (the realization of) three things I (earnestly) swear: the Exalted God will not consider those who have a share in Islam of equal status with those who don't - the shares in Islam being prayer, fasting and alms, He will not leave a servant on his own in the Hereafter after having offered him His friendship here, and He will offer him the otherworldly company of those whom he loves in this world. The fourth thing for which I can swear, and hope not to be sinful an oath is that when God keeps hidden a servant's doings here, He will (certainly) do so in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 624; Page No. 90&91

Verse: For every disease, God has devised a certain remedy.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 625; Page No. 91

Verse: For every heart there is a piece of cloud as that of the Moon, covering it to darkness when it begins to shine and letting it shine one more time.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 626, Page No. 91

Verse: For every sin there is (a form of) penitence, save for bad-temperedness.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 627; Page No. 91

Verse: For every sin there is a way of repenting before God, save ill- temperedness, for verily an ill-tempered person does not repent of any sin without a later return to something worse.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 628; Page No. 91

Verse: For everything some alms are due, and for one's house, the drawing room.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 629; Page No. 91

Verse: For everything some alms are due, and for the body, fasting.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 630, Page No. 91

Verse: For everything there is a (form of) harm leading to its ruin, and the harm to this religion are corrupt rulers.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 631, Page No. 91

Verse: For everything there is a beauty, and for the Quran, a nice recitation.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 632, Page No. 91

Verse: Verily promises are chains on people' s necks until the Day of Resurrection. So whoever fulfils them is delivered by Allah, and whoever breaks them is forsaken by Allah, and whoever takes them lightly will have to contend with the One Who has placed special emphasis on them and Who has enjoined upon His creation to fulfil them.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3650; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 226

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) in a letter he wrote to al-Ashtar when he appointed him governor of Egypt, said, 'Among all things made incumbent by Allah, there is nothing on which people are more strongly united, in spite of the difference of their opinions and the diversity of their views, than the respect for fulfilling promises.'
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 53; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 226

Verse: Verily fulfilment of a promise is part of faith.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3379; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 226

Verse: He who does not observe his promises and his guarantee does not have conviction in Allah.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9577; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 227

Verse: There are three things wherein Allah, Mighty and Exalted, has not granted anyone a concession   the fulfilment of one' s promise, be it to the good person or the bad.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 162, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 227

Verse: Imam Muhammad ibn 'Ali al-Baqir (a.s.) said with regards to Allah' s verse "Do not be like her who would undo her yarn, breaking it up after [spinning it to] strength, by making your oaths a means of [mutual] deceit among yourselves  "[ Qur' an 1692], said, 'The one who undid her yarn was a woman from the tribe of Bani Taym b. Murrah, called Rabita (Rayta), daughter of Ka`ab b. Sa`ad b. Taym b. Ka`ab b. Lu`aayya b. Ghalib. She was a stupid woman who would spin hair, and after she had spun it, she would undo it then start to spin it all over again. So Allah said, "Do not be like her who would undo her yarn  " Verily Allah, Blessed and most High, has commanded the fulfilment of the oath and has prohibited its breaking, and has made this a parable for them.'
VerseRef: Tafsir al-Qummi, v. 1, p. 389; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 227

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) when asked about the verse "O you who have faith! Keep your agreements", replied, '[It refers to] promises.'
VerseRef: Tafsir al-Qummi, v. 1, p. 289, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 227

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when asked about covetousness, said, 'It is the desire for something little through the loss of a lot.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 167, no. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 228

Verse: Covetousness is a terminal [source of] distress.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 982; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 228

Verse: Covetousness stains one's gallantry.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1107; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 228

Verse: Covetousness is the mount of pains.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 280; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 228

Verse: In order to keep women at home, spare them (variegated) dresses.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah, Tradition No. 1044, Page No. 147

Verse: Covetousness and meanness are founded on doubt and lack of trust in Allah.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6195; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 230

Verse: Ignore the sins of the generous, the shortcomings of the learned and the awe of the just kings; for whenever they slip, the Exalted God gives them a hand.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1040; Page No. 146&147

Verse: Ill-speaking guys will not be allowed to Paradise.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1041; Page No. 147

Verse: Improvement of living shows man's deep knowledge, and seeking what improves you is not mammonism.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1042; Page No. 147

Verse: In Day of Judgment, God will not make one immune from fear, if s(he) has terrified a believer, and will make one suffer humility, if s(he) has backbited a believer.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 1043; Page No. 147

Verse: The Imam needs a wise heart, an expressive tongue and a staunch soul [i.e. authority] in establishing the truth.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 11010; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 538

Verse: One who appoints himself as a leader of the people must first begin by educating himself before educating others; he must discipline through his own behaviour, before disciplining with his tongue.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 110; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 538

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said to a man who was experiencing intense grief at the loss of his son, 'You are grieving at the minor affliction and are heedless of the major affliction! If only you prepared yourself for the place that your son has passed away to, your grief would not be so intense, for your affliction at having neglected preparation for it [i.e. the Hereafter] is much greater than the loss of your son.'
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 5, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 85

Verse: Indeed we belong to Allah, and to Him do we indeed return' during an affliction, his entrance into Paradise is made obligatory.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 235, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 86

Verse: Wailing is an act from the pre-Islamic age of ignorance.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 103, no. 50; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 86

Verse: Among the hidden treasures of goodness are: concealing one's afflictions, one's illnesses and one's charity [from others].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 103, no. 50; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 86

Verse: All praise is due to Allah, Who did not afflict me in my faith, and all praise is due to Allah Who, if He had willed for my affliction to be greater than it is could have made it so, and all praise is due to Allah for the command that He willed to be and it is.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 268, no. 183; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 86

Verse: Verily when someone dies, Allah sends an angel to the most grieved member of his family, who strokes his heart and makes him forget the agony of grief, and if it were not for this, the world would never again thrive.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 227, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 87

Verse: Whoever gloats over an affliction that has befallen his fellow brother does not leave this world until he is tried similarly
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 359, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 87

Verse: The evil deed to be punished the quickest is agression.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 327, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 87

Verse: Whoever draws the sword of agression will be killed by it [himself].
VerseRef: Nahj al-Sa`ada, v. 1, p. 52; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 87

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) with regards to the verse: "But should someone be compelled, without being aggressive or rebellious "57, said, 'The agressor is whoever rises to fight against the Imam.'
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 213, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 88

Verse: There are two kinds of fighting: one is the fighting against polytheists; they must not be left until they accept Islam or pay the tax with humility. The second is the fighting against the people of innovation [from among Muslims]; and they should not be left until they comply with the command of Allah or else they be killed.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 11, p. 18, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 89

Verse: [Rebellious] Agressors [from among Muslims] are to be fought and killed in the same way that one kills polytheists; and Muslims can rally all the support they can against them, and when possible, they can be taken prisoners just as polytheists are taken captive
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 11, p. 65, no. 12437; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 89

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) said about one who declares enmity towards the Imam of the Muslims: 'If it were not for the fact that we were afraid for your sake   that one of you may be killed for killing one of them, and one of you is worth a thousand of their men   we would order you to kill them; but this is left to [the discretion of] the Imam.'
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 11, p. 60, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 89

Verse: Verily  courage has a limit, which when overstepped becomes foolhardiness.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 377, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 225

Verse: Every single Muslim that plants or cultivates anything of which humans, animals or birds may eat from is counted as charity towards them on his behalf.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 13, p. 460, no. 15892; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 90

Verse: Imam Mu?ammad ibn 'Ali al-Baqir (a.s.) narrated that his father used to say, 'The best of occupations is tilling the land, the produce of which is eaten by both the good-doer and the wrongdoer. That which the good-doer eats will seek forgiveness on his [i.e. the grower's] behalf, and that which the wrongdoer eats will curse him [i.e. the wrongdoer]. The birds and animals eat thereof too.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 260, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 90

Verse: He who, in spite of having water and soil at his disposal, is still poor, is dissociated by Allah.
VerseRef: Qurb al-Isnad, p. 115, no. 404; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 90

Verse: Do good and do not underestimate it at all, for verily a little good is actually a lot and a small amount of it is much.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 422; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 357

Verse: Do not belittle anything that is good, for verily you will see it tomorrow and it will make you happy.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 182, no. 37; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 357

Verse: Verily good and evil can only be known through people, so if you want to know good then do good and you will know its people, and if you want to know evil then commit evil and you will know its people.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 41, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 357

Verse: The most intelligent of people is he who looks further into the consequences
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3367; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 752

Verse: Victory comes through firm resolution and determination
VerseRef: Aaw`ali al-La'ali, v. 1, p. 292, no. 164; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 752

Verse: It is narrated in the tradition recounting the Prophet's Ascension to the Heavens (al-mi`araj) that Allah addresses the Prophet (SAWA) saying, 'O Ahmad, Verily the good people and the people worthy of a good Hereafter have gentle countenances and much modesty, they possess little foolishness, they are of much benefit and they are seldom deceptive. People are at ease when with them whereas their souls are exhausted on account of them. Their words are balanced, they take account of their souls and exhaust them [through making them perform good]. Their eyes sleep but their hearts do not, their eyes weep and their hearts are remembering. When people are recorded as being neglectful, they are recorded amongst the remembering ones  Nothing preoccupies them from Allah for a split second. They do not desire much food, neither wish to speak much nor have many clothes. According to them, people are dead and Allah is the Living One, the All-Sustainer.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 24, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 358

Verse: There is nothing better than goodness except its own reward.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 7487; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 358

Verse: Better than truthfulness is the one who practices it, and better than good is its doer.
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 223, no. 385; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 358

Verse: Better than good is its doer, more beautiful than beautiful words is the one who says them and weightier than knowledge is the one who carries it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 370, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 359

Verse: He who guides towards good has the same reward as the one who does it.
VerseRef: Sahih Muslim, no. 1893; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 359

Verse: Woe unto him whose ones exceed his tens' - by this he meant that the bad deed is counted one, but the good deeds are counted as ten.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 281; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 360

Verse: When the believer excels in his good deed, Allah will enhance each one of his good deeds to equal seven hundred, for Allah, Blessed and most High, says: "Allah enhances severalfold whomever He wishes.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 247, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 360

Verse: The hearts have been predisposed to love those who do good to them, and to dislike those who do bad to them.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 37; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 360

Verse: Good-doing is incumbent upon you, for it is the best cultivation and the most profitable commodity.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6112; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 360

Verse: What a good provision for the Resurrection good-doing towards people is.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9912; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 360

Verse: Good-doing is the tithe (Zakat) of victory.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5450; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 361

Verse: He whose good-doing is much his brethren will love him.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8473; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 361

Verse: Hearts are won over through good-doing.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4339; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 361

Verse: Do good unto the one who has wronged you.
VerseRef: Kanz al-Fawa' id li al-Karajiki, v. 2, p. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 361

Verse: Indeed your good-doing to the enemies and the jealous ones who scheme against you is more irritating to them than your taking an offensive stance against them, and it is also a motivation for their reform.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3637; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 361

Verse: It is narrated in Nur al-Thaqalayn with regard to Allah's verse: "Certainly whoever submits his will to Allah and is a good-doer "[ Qur'an 2:112]: It is reported that the Prophet (SAWA) was asked about good-doing, to which he replied, 'It is to worship Allah as if you see Him; for verily even if you do not see Him, indeed He sees you.'
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 1, p. 553, no. 579; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 362

Verse: Truly if you do good, then it is your own soul that you honour and do good to, but if you do wrong, it is your own soul that you degrade and wrong.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3808; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 362

Verse: Good manners are the perfection of man.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 998; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 362

Verse: O Believer! This knowledge and good manners are the value of your soul so strive to learn them, for however much your knowledge and good manners increase, so will your value and worth accordingly.
VerseRef: Mishkat al-Anwar, p. 135; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 363

Verse: Good manners are the best disposition.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 967; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 363

Verse: The best inheritance parents bequeath their progeny are good manners.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 5036; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 363

Verse: People need good manners more than gold and silver.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3590; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 363

Verse: Good manners are the best lineage and the noblest means.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4853; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 363

Verse: Acquire good manners, for they are the best personal merit.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6096; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 363

Verse: Imam al-Kazim (AS), in his advice to Hisham b. al-Hakam, said: "O Hisham, nothing has been bestowed upon the servants better than the intellect. The sleep of a man of intellect is better than the night vigil of an ignorant man. Every singleignorant man. Every single prophet that Allah has sent down has been a man of intellect, whose intellect supercedes the labour of all diligent workers. The servant is not considered as having fulfilled an obligatory act from among the acts made incumbent by Allah until he understands it."
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 397; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 467

Verse: The friend of every man is his intellect and his enemy is his ignorance.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 11, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 467

Verse: Verily the stupid person suffers as a result of his stupidity worse than the licentiousness of an immoral person. The servants will rise up in rank in the Hereafter and will receive great rewards from their Lord in proportion to their intellects.
VerseRef: Majma`a al-Bayan, v. 1, p. 487; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 467

Verse: Verily all good is grasped through the intellect, and the man devoid of intellect has no religion.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 54; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 467

Verse: Both the abodes [of the world and the Hereafter] are grasped by the intellect, and whoever is deprived of the intellect is deprived of them both.
VerseRef: Kashf al-Ghamma, v. 3, p. 197; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 468

Verse: One should revere his neighbour as he reveres his mother
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 1, p. 274, no. 834; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 634

Verse: When Allah created the intellect He said to it, 'Come forward' so it came forward, then commanded it, 'Go back' and it went back. Then He said to it, 'By my Honour and Exaltedness, I have not created anything better than you. It is you that I command, and you that I prohibit from things, and you that I punish and you that I reward
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 26, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 468

Verse: Among what was revealed to Moses (AS) was, 'I take My servants to account according to the level of intellect that I have given them.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 1, p. 308, no. 608; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 468

Verse: I found written in the Book [i.e. the Book ascribed to Imam Ali (AS)] that the worth and value of every man is his knowledge. Verily Allah, Blessed and most High, will take people to account according to the intellects that He has given them in this world' s life.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 1, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 468

Verse: He who wants wealth without the need for riches, and comfort of the heart free from jealousy, and security in his faith should implore Allah, Mighty and Exalted, in his plea for Him to perfect his intellect.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 18, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 468

Verse: Verily Allah has two authoritative proofs over people a manifest proof and an inward proof. The manifest proof is represented by the prophets and messengers and Imams (AS), and the inward proof is represented by the intellects.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 16, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 469

Verse: Imam al-Kazim (AS) in his advice to Hisham b. al-Hakam, said, "Allah has only sent His prophets and messengers to His servants in order that they may come to an understanding of Allah, so the ones who best heed their call are those who have the best inner knowledge, and the ones who know Allah' s command the best are those that have the best intellects, and those that have the most perfect intellects will be the ones with the highest status in this world and in the Hereafter".
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 16, no. 12; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 469

Verse: Verily the intellect is a lasso used to restrain ignorance, and the carnal soul is like the vilest of beasts which if left unrestrained will go wild.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 15; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 469

Verse: The intellect is a light that Allah has created for mankind and which He has ordained to illuminate the heart, in order that with it, he may know the difference between the visually manifest things and the unseen things.
VerseRef: Aaw`ali al-La'ali, v. 1, p. 248, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 469

Verse: [To be a man of] intellect is that you say only that which you know and act upon what you say.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2141; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 470

Verse: [To be a man of] intellect is to preserve your experiences, and the best of all that you have experienced is that which has taught you a lesson.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Letter 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 470

Verse: There are two divisions of intellect the natural intellect and the intellect of experience, and both of them produce benefit
VerseRef: Masalib al-Sa' ul, p. 49; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 470

Verse: Imam Hasan ibn 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when asked about the intellect, said, 'To suppress one' s annoyance until the opportunity arises.'
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 240, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 470

Verse: Imam Hasan ibn 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when his father asked him regarding the intellect, said, 'It is for the heart to safeguard what you have deposited therein.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 401, no. 62; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 470

Verse: The attribute of a man of intellect is that he is clement towards one who behaves rashly with him, overlooks the fault of one who wrongs him, is humble even towards one who is lower than him in rank, tries to get ahead of those above him in his quest for good. Whenever he wishes to speak, he contemplates if what he wants to say is good, he says it and benefits as a result, and if it is bad, then he keeps quiet and remains safe as a result. When a temptation arises before him, he holds fast to Allah and guards his hand and his tongue if he sees virtue in it, he seizes it, neither losing his modesty thereat nor displaying any greed. These are ten qualities by which a man of intellect may be known.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 28; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 471

Verse: The most intelligent of people is he who is best at dealing with people.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 28, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 471

Verse: The chest of a man of intellect is the strongbox of his secret.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 471

Verse: was asked to describe a man of intellect, to which he replied, 'He is the one who puts things in their place.' The he was asked, 'So describe to us the ignorant man', to which he replied, 'I have already done so.
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 245; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 471

Verse: The man of intellect is never stung twice from the same hive.
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, p. 245; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 471

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) was asked what the intellect was, to which he replied, 'It is that with which The Beneficent God is worshipped and with which Paradise is attained.' So the man asked, 'So what about that which even Muawiya possessed' He replied, 'That is a vicious thing, that is devilry, and resembles intellect, though it is not intellect.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 11, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 471

Verse: The man of intellect must be well aware of the times he lives in, attentive of his affairs and guarding of his tongue.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 116, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 471

Verse: The nourishment of the body is food whilst the nourishment of the soul is feeding others.'
VerseRef: Mishkat al-Anwar, no. 325; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 323

Verse: That which you yourself eat gets consumed whereas that which you feed others diffuses [i.e. the benediction in that sustenance].
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9634; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 323

Verse: Verily Allah loves the feeding of food to others, and the spilling of blood [for His sake].
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 143, no. 1370; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 324

Verse: One of the things which gives one obligatory entrance into Paradise and forgiveness is feeding a starving person', then he went on to recite the verse of Allah in the Qur'an: "or feeding [the needy] on a day of starvation."
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 145, no. 1381; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 324

Verse: Verily the Commander of the Faithful resembled the Prophet (SAWA) the most in the way that he ate. He used to eat bread, vinegar and (olive) oil, and feed others bread and meat.
VerseRef: al-Mahasin, v. 2, p. 279, no. 1901; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 324

Verse: Verily it is only a festival for he whose fasts Allah has accepted and whose prayers He has acknowledged, and every day in which we do not disobey Allah is a day of celebration.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 20, p. 73; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 324

Verse: Suwayd b. Ghafla narrated, 'I went to visit him [i.e. Imam Ali (AS)] on one of the festivals, and he had a small table in front of him on which was wheat bread, and a plate of khatifa[khatifa a food made of flour and milk (ed.)] and milbana[milbana a food made of bran, milk and honey (ed.)], so I asked, 'O Commander of the Faithful, it is a day of celebration and you are eating khatifa! to which he replied, 'It is only a day of celebration for whoever has been forgiven.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 40, p. 326, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 325

Verse: Amir al-Mu'minin Imam 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when he was brought a gift for Nayruz, exclaimed, 'What is this' to which they replied, 'O Commander of the Faithful, today is Nayruz.' He replied, 'Make everyday Nayruz for us [i.e. through your good actions].'
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 3, p. 300, no. 4073; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 325

Verse: Our Nayruz is everyday.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 3, p. 300, no. 4074; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 325

Verse: Astuteness and gluttony cannot coexist.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 12, p. 94, no. 13615; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 329

Verse: When the stomach is filled with [even] permissible food, the heart becomes blind to goodness.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4139; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 329

Verse: Overeating spoils piety.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 659; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 329

Verse: Overeating is the greatest aid to acts of disobedience.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 9922; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 329

Verse: Applaud a man who abstains from food, sleeps hungry, and has patience. These are the ones who will be satiated on the Day of Judgment.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 462, no. 17; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 329

Verse: said to Mu`aalli b. Khunays when he came to visit him for Nayruz, 'Do you know what this day is' to which he replied, 'May I be your ransom, this is a day to which the Persians attach great importance and in which they give each other gifts.' So Imam al-Sadiq (AS) said, 'By the Ancient House in Makkah! That is only because of a much older reason which I will explain to you so that you may understand   O Mu`aalli, verily the day of Nayruz is the day when Allah took the servants' covenants from them that they would worship Him and that they would not associate anything with Him, and that they would believe in His prophets and His divine proofs, and that they would believe in the Imams (AS). This is also the day when the sun rose for the first time   Every day of Nayruz is a day when we await joy for verily it is one of our special days and one of the days of our shi`aa. The Persians have kept its significance whereas you have lost it   This is the first day of the Persians' new year, and they have managed to stay alive since having been only thirty thousand in number. The pouring of water on the day of Nayruz has become a practice '
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 59, p. 92, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 326

Verse: On the day of Nayruz, take a bath and wear your cleanest clothes, and perfume yourself with the best of fragrances, and fast on that day.
VerseRef: Wasael al-Shi`aah, v. 7, p. 346, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 326

Verse: It is narrated in Bihar al-Anwar 'It has been related that Mansur [Dawaniqi][ One of the Abbasid Caliphs (ed.)] ordered Imam Musa al-Kazim (AS) to sit with him to receive gifts and greetings for the day of Nayruz, so that he may take the gifts presented to him, so Imam replied, 'Verily I have examined the traditions from my grandfather the Prophet (SAWA) and have not found a single tradition about this festival. Rather it is a practice of the Persians which Islam eradicated, and God forbid that we should revive what Islam has eradicated.' So Mansur said, 'We only celebrate it as a matter of policy for our army[It is possible that his army consisted of Persians whose favour and allegiance he wished to secure by his observance of their festival (ed.)], so I request you by Allah the Great to sit down' , so he sat down  '
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 59, p. 100, no. 2 and v. 48, p. 108, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 326

Verse: A man whose [consumption of] food is little has a healthy stomach and a pure heart, and a man whose food is plenty has a sickly stomach and a hard heart
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 46; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 327

Verse: Eating little is a sign of self-restraint, and eating a lot is a sign of wastefulness.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 16, p. 213, no. 19634; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 327

Verse: Man cannot fill a container worse than his stomach.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 100; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 328

Verse: A man who fills his stomach will not enter the dominion of the heavens and the earth.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 100; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 328

Verse: Be warned against excessive food, for it poisons the heart with hardness, slows the limbs in performing acts of obedience, and blocks the souls from hearing counsel.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 182, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 328

Verse: A man who eats excessively, his health declines and his burden becomes heavier than he can endure.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8903; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 328

Verse: Hunger and disease cannot coexist.
VerseRef: Mustadrak al-Wasa`il, v. 16, p. 222, no. 19652; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 328

Verse: One of the noblest deeds of a kind person is feigning ignorance of that which he knows already
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 222; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 634

Verse: The proper way to maintain a state of coexistence and mutual intimacy with people is according to a set measure, two thirds of which are to know each other very well and a third of which is to feign ignorance of each other's faults
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 359; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 634

Verse: A believer's dignity lies in his standing for the night prayer, and his honour lies in abstaining from [tarnishing] other people's good reputations.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 488, no. 9; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 637

Verse: Do not leave the night prayer, for verily the one who is truly duped is the one who has lost out on the night prayer.
VerseRef: Ma`ani al-Akhbar, p. 342, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 637

Verse: Every single good deed that the servant carries out has a reward mentioned for it in the Qur'an except for the night prayer, for verily Allah has not expressed its reward because of the great significance it holds with Him. Thus, He says, "Their sides vacate their beds to supplicate their Lord in fear and hope  No one knows what has been kept hidden for them of comfort as a reward for what they used to do"[ Qur'an 32:16].
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 8, p. 126, no. 27; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 637

Verse: The night prayer brightens one's face, the night prayer fragrances one's breath, and the night prayer attracts sustenance
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 363, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 637

Verse: I have been deprived of [the opportunity to] pray in the night', to which Imam replied, 'You are one whose sins have imprisoned you
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 450, no. 34; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 638

Verse: Verily a man tells a lie and he is deprived of the nigh prayer as a result
VerseRef: Ellal al-Shara'ie, p. 362, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 638

Verse: Do not take oath by Allah whether you are truthful or lying, for verily He says "Do not make Allah an obstacle, through your oaths."[
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 7, p. 434, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 639

Verse: It is narrated in Thawab al-A`amal that Allah says, 'I do not allow one who takes false oaths to obtain My mercy.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 261, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 639

Verse: Beware of taking immoral oaths for verily they leave the houses empty of their tenants
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 270, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 639

Verse: Whoever takes an oath knowing that he is lying, has surely waged war with Allah.
VerseRef: Sawab al-A`amal, p. 269, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 639

Verse: He who adopts prudence is cautious, and he who lacks prudence is reckless.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, nos. 7913, 7914; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 751

Verse: Prudence is the lamp-niche of suspicion
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 356; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 751

Verse: He who involves himself in matters without considering the consequences exposes himself to troubles.
VerseRef: Tuhaf al-`Uqoul, no. 90; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 752

Verse: Planning before action will preserve you from regret.
VerseRef: Uyoun Akhbar al-Reza (AS), v. 2, p. 54, no. 204; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 752

Verse: Imam Mosa ibn Ja'far al-Kazim (a.s.) was once asked about gypsum that is burnt along with dried excrement and bone ash, and then used to plaster a mosque, and whether prostration on such plaster is allowed. He replied, 'Verily water and fire [from the kilning process] have purified it
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 330, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 756

Verse: Allah has obligated faith in order to purify one from polytheism
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, Saying 252; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 756

Verse: Verily being wary of one's duty to Allah is the remedy for the disease of your hearts   and the purifier of the pollution in your souls
VerseRef: Nahj al-Balagha, no. 198; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 757

Verse: Since you have no choice but to purify your bodies, then make a point of purifying yourselves of your faults and your sins
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3743; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 757

Verse: Acquaint yourself with Allah in times of ease and Allah will acknowledge you in times of difficulty.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 87, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 904

Verse: A believer must supplicate Allah in times of ease the same way that he supplicates Allah in times of difficulty
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 488, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 904

Verse: Allah revealed to Prophet Moses (AS), 'O Moses, ask Me for every single thing that you need, even the grass for your sheep to graze and the salt for your food.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 93, p. 303, no. 39; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 904

Verse: Ask Allah for whatever occurs to you from your needs even for the laces of your shoes, for verily if He does not facilitate for it, it will not be facilitated.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 93, p. 295, no. 23; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 904

Verse: Do not deem the smallest of your needs as insignificant, for verily the most beloved of the believers with Allah is the one who asks [Him] the most
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 97, no. 2275; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 905

Verse: He who knocks on Allah's door, it is opened for him
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 8292; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 905

Verse: Allah has never opened the door of request for anyone only to hold back the door of response
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 113, no. 7; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 905

Verse: We supplicate but are not answered?' the Imam said, 'Because you call upon One whom you do not know
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 93, p. 368, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 905

Verse: Regarding the saying of Allah, "so let them respond to Me, and let them have faith in Me" Imam al-Sadiq (AS) said, 'It means that: "they should know that I [Allah] am capable of giving them what they ask Me for".
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 93, p. 323, no. 37; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 906

Verse: Imam Ali (AS) when he was asked regarding Allah's verse: "Call Me and I will hear you[r supplications]"   'So why does it happen that we supplicate and are not answered?' - replied, 'Because your hearts have been treacherous in eight areas, the first of them being that you know Allah but you do not fulfil your right towards Him as is obligatory upon you, so your inner knowledge of Him has not benefited you at all  so then which supplication will be answered for you with this [state of affairs] after you have blocked its doors and paths?!
VerseRef: A`alam al-Din, no. 269; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 906

Verse: Verily a servant raises his hands to Allah [in supplication] while his food is unlawful! So how can his supplications be answered while he is in this state?!
VerseRef: Irshad al-Qulub, no. 149; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 906

Verse: Make your earnings lawful and your supplication will be answered, for verily when a man raises an unlawful morsel of food to his mouth, his supplication is not answered for forty days.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 20, no. 2045; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 907

Verse: If any of you wants his supplication to be answered then he should make a lawful earning and stop wronging people, for verily the supplication of a servant who has unlawful food in his stomach or has wronged anyone from Allah's creation will not be raised to Allah
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 93, p. 321, no. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 907

Verse: Know that Allah does not answer supplication from a heedless and distracted heart
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 93, p. 321, no. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 907

Verse: Seize the opportunity to supplicate during tenderness [of your heart] for verily it is a mercy
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 30, no. 60; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 907

Verse: Verily Allah does not answer the supplication that comes from a hard heart
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 473, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 907

Verse: When any of you feels softness and compassion, then he should supplicate, for no sooner does the heart soften than it becomes pure and sincere
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 477, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 907

Verse: Verily a servant asks Allah his need and it is Allah's way that He either grants it very soon or after some time. The servant sins and Allah   Blessed and most High   says to the angels, 'Do not grant him, and deprive him of it for verily he has exposed himself to My displeasure and has made himself deserving of My deprivation
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 329, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 908

Verse: Allah revealed to Prophet Jesus (AS) saying, 'Tell the community of Israelites that  verily I do not answer the supplication of anyone from among you against whom one of My creation holds a claim of wrong or oppression.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 337, no. 40; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 908

Verse: Verily Allah says, 'By My Might and Exaltedness, I do not answer the supplication of one who has been wronged when he calls Me regarding the wrong that has been done unto him, while someone else holds a similar claim of wrong against him
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, 75, p. 312, no. 20; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 908

Verse: Verily the Kindness of Allah, glory be to Him, does not contradict His Wisdom, therefore not all supplications are answered
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3478; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 909

Verse: The supplication that is preceded by "In the Name of Allah, the all-Beneficent, the all-Merciful" will not be rejected
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 52, no. 131; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 909

Verse: Verily every supplication that is not preceded by praise [of Allah] is incomplete
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 93, p. 317, no. 21; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 909

Verse: A supplication remains veiled until the supplicant sends blessings on Muhammad and the family of Muhammad
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 491, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 909

Verse: If anyone has a need from Allah, then he should begin by sending blessings upon Muhammad and his family, then ask his need. Thereafter he should seal it by sending blessings upon Muhammad and the family of Muhammad, for verily Allah is too kind than to just accept the two blessings [at the beginning and at the end] and leave the middle, because the request for blessings on Muhammad and his family is never veiled from Him.
VerseRef: Makarim al- Akhlaq, v. 2, p. 19, no. 2040; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 910

Verse: If you have a need from Allah, then say, "O Allah, verily I ask you for the sake of Muhammad and Ali, for verily they have a special station with You
VerseRef: al-Da`awat, p. 51, no. 127; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 910

Verse: [In supplication] praise Allah, then acknowledge your sins, then ask your request.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 93, p. 318, no. 23; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 910

Verse: Laughing without cause stems from ignorance.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 76, p. 59, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 531

Verse: It is incumbent upon you to be bound to the lawful, and excel in goodness to your family, and be in remembrance of Allah at all times.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 6131; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 531

Verse: Sword-combat is easier than seeking the lawful.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 5, p. 161, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 531

Verse: Imama is the [structural] system of the [Muslim] community.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1095; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 532

Verse: Islam is based on five: prayer, alms, fasting, the obligatory pilgrimage (Hajj), and the divine guardianship [of the Imams from the household of the Prophet]. And no other issue has been called for as much as divine guardianship.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 3, p. 18, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 532

Verse: Allah will not accept the good deeds performed by the servants if they accept the custodianship of a tyrant leader who has not been appointed by Allah, most High.
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 4, p. 104, no. 130; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 532

Verse: Imama is the light, and that is the purport of His saying [in the Qur'an]: "So have faith in Allah and His Apostle and the light which We have sent down". He (AS) said, 'The light is the Imam.'
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 5, p. 341, no. 16; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 532

Verse: And it was revealed in the Prophet's farewell pilgrimage, during the end of his life: "Today I have perfected your religion for you " and the issue of Imama is the completion of the religion.
VerseRef: Nur al-Thaqalayn, v. 1, p. 589, no. 33; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 533

Verse: Verily Imama is the growing basis of Islam, as well as its lofty branches.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 200, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 533

Verse: Verily Imama is the reins of religion, the ruling system of the Muslims, the prosperity for the world and an honour for the believers.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 200, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 533

Verse: Verily Allah, Blessed and most High, took Abraham [Prophet Abraham (AS) is known in the Arabic tradition as Abraham (ed.)] as a slave before He took him as a prophet, and verily Allah took him as a prophet before He took him as an apostle, And verily Allah took him as an apostle before He took him as a friend. And verily Allah took him as a friend before He made him an Imam. And when all these ranks came together in him, He said, "I am making you the Imam of mankind.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 175, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 533

Verse: Certainly Allah has not left the earth without a knowledgeable authority, for if it were not such, the truth would never be distinguished from falsehood.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 178, no. 5; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 534

Verse: The earth   ever since its existence   has never been without a knowledgeable authority, who revives all that people destroy of the truth.' Then he recited this verse: "They desire to put out the light of Allah with their mouths, but Allah shall perfect His light, though the faithless be averse
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 23, p. 37, no. 65; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 534

Verse: Verily Allah's proof [authority] over His creation will not be established except by an Imam in order that He [Allah] be known.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 177, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 534

Verse: O Allah, indeed the earth will not be devoid of one who upholds the proofs for the sake of Allah - either a manifest and well-known authority, or one who fears [for his life] and is hence, undistinguishable - so that His proofs and arguments may never be invalid.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 23, p. 46, no. 91; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 535

Verse: The earth will never remain without an Imam, be he apparent or hidden.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 23, p. 23, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 535

Verse: If the earth were to remain without an Imam, it would perish.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 179, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 535

Verse: Certainly the earth cannot exist without an authority [of Allah's] therein. In fact, mankind can only prosper through him, and the earth can only prosper through that.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 23, p. 51, no. 101; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 535

Verse: When the Day of Judgment comes  an address will come from Allah, the Exalted, saying, 'Lo! whosoever accepts the leadership of an Imam in the worldly abode should follow him wherever he takes him, hence 'those who were followed will disown the followers...
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 8, p. 10, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 536

Verse: Whoever dies without knowing his Imam has died a pagan [pre-Islamic] death.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 23, p. 76, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 536

Verse: Imam Husayn ibn 'Ali ibn Abi Talib (a.s.) when asked how to attain knowledge of Allah, replied, 'It is for the people of every time to know their Imam, obedience to whom is mandatory.'
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 23, p. 83, no. 22; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 536

Verse: Imam Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Sadiq (a.s.) regarding Allah's verse: "and he who is given wisdom ", said, '[It is] obedience to Allah and knowing one's Imam.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 185, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 537

Verse: The Imam is a guide between Allah and His creation, therefore whoever acknowledges him is a believer, and whoever rejects him is a disbeliever.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 23, p. 88, no. 32; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 537

Verse: He who neither knows us nor rejects us is astray, until he returns to the guidance that Allah has made incumbent upon him - that is the obligatory obedience to us. And if he dies in this deviation of his, Allah will do with him as He pleases.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 1, p. 187, no. 11; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 537

Verse: None can bear this responsibility [Imama] except those who are patient, and have insight and knowledge of the circumstances of this issue.
VerseRef: Sharhe Nahj al-Balagha by Abi al-Hadid, v. 7, p. 36; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 537

Verse: Aa'isha narrated, 'When Ibrahim [the Prophet's son] passed away, the Prophet (SAWA) cried such that tears rolled onto his beard, so people said to him, 'O Prophet of Allah, you dissuade people from crying and here you are now crying?!' to which he replied, 'This is not crying, it is compassion, for he who does not have compassion [for others] will not be treated with compassion [by Allah].'
VerseRef: Amali al-Tusi, p. 388, no. 227; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 86

Verse: Abu Hurayra narrated, 'A man from the family of the Prophet (SAWA) had passed away and the women were gathered around crying for him when `Aumar stood up and prohibited them from doing so, and told them to go away from there. The Prophet (SAWA) then said, 'Leave them O `Aumar, for verily the eye feels teary [at the moment], the heart is afflicted and the pain of the incident is still fresh.'
VerseRef: al-Nasai, p. 4, no. 19; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 86

Verse: Two voices are cursed and despised by Allah: howling when struck by an affliction, and singing when blessed with a bounty.
VerseRef: Da`aim al-Islam, v. 1, p. 227; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 86

Verse: Afflictions are easy for one who is abstemious in this world.
VerseRef: Kanz al-Fawa' id li al-Karajiki, v. 2, p. 163; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 87

Verse: He who finds an affliction too great to bear should think about [the greatness of his affliction resulting from] my passing away from this world, and his own affliction will become easier to bear.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 82, p. 84, no. 26; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 86

Verse: Increase your remembrance of death, the day that you will rise from your graves, and your standing before Allah, Mighty and Exalted, and your afflictions will become easier to bear.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 616, no. 10; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 86

Verse: Fever makes one's sin fall just as trees let their leaves fall.
VerseRef: Nahj al Fasahah; Tradition No. 614; Page No. 88&89

Verse: Verily Allah, Mighty and Exalted, created locks for all evils, and he made the keys to those locks to be alcohol; and lying is worse than alcohol.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 72, p. 236, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 271

Verse: Anger is the key to all evils.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 263, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 271

Verse: Verily Satan addresses his devils saying, 'Avail yourselves to meat, intoxicants and women, for verily I do not see the merging together of more evils except through these.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar,v. 62, p. 293; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 272

Verse: Force yourselves to do good, and exert yourselves therein, for verily evil is something man naturally tends towards.
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 2, p. 120; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 272

Verse: Compel yourself to good virtues, for verily vices are something you have a natural tendency for.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2477; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 272

Verse: Expectation is a mercy for my community; without expectation no mother would nurse her child, nor would anyone plant a tree.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 173, no. 8; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 272

Verse: Expectation is an amiable companion.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1042; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 273

Verse: While Isa son of Maryam (AS) was sitting, he saw a man working the land with a shovel. Isa (AS) said, 'O Allah, take his expectation away from him!' The man put his shovel down and rested on the ground for an hour. Then Isa (AS) said, 'O Allah, give him back his expectation!' The man stood up and returned to work.'
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 272; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 273

Verse: A man who expects to be alive tomorrow is a man who expects to be alive forever.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 167, no. 31; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 273

Verse: There is no end to expectation.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1010; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 273

Verse: Expectations never cease.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 639; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 273

Verse: Guard yourselves against false expectation, for many a person who begins the day does not live to see its end, and many a one is envied at the beginning of the night while his mourners have assembled by the end of it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 2572; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 274

Verse: Expectation is like the mirage - it deceives those who view it and leaves behind those who place their hope on it.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1896; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 274

Verse: Wishes blind the eyes of insight.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1375; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 274

Verse: Expectation is the sultan of the Satans over the hearts of the oblivious.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1828; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 274

Verse: The fruit of expectation is the spoilage of deeds.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 4641; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 274

Verse: Expectation causes the heart to forget, breaks promises, increases oblivion, and brings about grief.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 78, p. 35, no. 117; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 275

Verse: Expectation drives reason away, breaks promises, encourages oblivion, and brings about grief. So distrust expectation, for it is deceitful and its addict is a sinner.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 293, no. 2; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 275

Verse: How many a favor Allah grants His servant without his having expected them, and how many a hopeful one entertains high hopes when [Allah's] choice favours others.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 71, p. 152, no. 55; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 275

Verse: It has been narrated that the Prophet (SAWA) took three sticks and set one of them in front of him, another one next to it, and the third far away from the two. He then asked, 'Do you know what this is?' to which they replied, 'Allah and His Messenger know better.' He said, 'This one is man, and this is death [next to it], while that one is expectation, which man entertains [about his long life], but death falls upon him prior to his expectation.'
VerseRef: Tanbih al-Khawatir, v. 1, p. 272; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 275

Verse: If man were to see his death [approaching] and the speed at which it draws near to him, he would despise expectation.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 73, p. 95, no. 79; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 276

Verse: O Abu Dharr, beware of backbiting, for verily backbiting is worse than adultery ' [Abu Dharr narrates], I asked, 'O Prophet of Allah, and what is backbiting?' to which he replied, 'Your mentioning something about your fellow brother that he would not like.' I asked, 'O Prophet of Allah, and what if the thing mentioned about him was actually true about him?' so he replied, 'Know that if you say something about him that is true then you have indeed backbit about him, and if you what you have said is not true, then you have indeed slandered him
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 77, p. 89, no. 3; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 126

Verse: It is bad enough to talk about your brother regarding what is true [let alone what is false]!
VerseRef: al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib, v. 3, p. 506, no. 13; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 127

Verse: He who talks about someone behind his back, mentioning what is true about him, and what people already know, then he has not backbit about him, whereas he who talks about someone behind his back about something that is true but that people do not know about, then he has backbit about him.
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 358, no. 6; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 127

Verse: Four types of people are such that talking about them behind their backs is not considered backbiting: the immoral person who makes a public display of his immorality; the dishonest leader who, even if you were to be good to would not appreciate you and if you were to be bad to would not forgive you; those who joke about their [and others'] mothers; and one who is a dissenter, who defames my community, and draws his sword against it.
VerseRef: Bihar al-Anwar, v. 75, p. 261, no. 64; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 127

Verse: The one who listens to backbiting is as [bad as] the backbiter.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 1171; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 128

Verse: O my son, steer your hearing clear of such a person, for verily he took the most repulsive thing from his mind and poured it into yours!
VerseRef: al-Ikhtisas, p. 225; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 128

Verse: The right of the ears is to keep them pure from listening to backbiting, and from that which is unlawful to listen to.
VerseRef: al-Khisal, p. 566, no. 1; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 128

Verse: Whoever does a good service to his fellow brother by deterring people from talking behind his back in a gathering where he hears them backbiting him, Allah will repel from him a thousand types of evil in this world as well as in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: Amali al-Saduq, p. 350; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 128

Verse: He in whose presence a fellow Muslim brother is talked about behind his back, and who does not defend him despite having the ability to do so, Allah disgraces him in this world as well as in the Hereafter.
VerseRef: al-Faqih, v. 4, p. 372; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 129

Verse: Holy Prophet Muhammad al Mustaf? (s.a.w.w.) was asked about the penance for backbiting, to which he replied, 'You must seek Allah's forgiveness on behalf of the one you have talked about every time you remember him.'
VerseRef: al-Kafi, v. 2, p. 357, no. 4; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 129

Verse: Cowardliness is an affliction
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 89; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 130

Verse: Desire is the bane of the hearts.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 314; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 130

Verse: The bane of faith is idolatry
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3915; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 130

Verse: The bane of certainty is doubt.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3916; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 130

Verse: The bane of bounty is ingratitude.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3918; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 131

Verse: The bane of good lineage is pride.
VerseRef: Ghurar al-Hikam, no. 3919; Mizan ul Hikmah, page No. 131

Verse: The bane of cleverness is deception
